DOC.HEAD: Cardinal's Excommunication Threat Unlikely
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 4th graf, ``If such..' to define excommunication, picks up 5th graf pvs, `U.S. Rep...; ADDS 3 grafs with O'Connor spokesman defending his position; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Cardinal John O'Connor on Thursday warned that Roman Catholic officials who support abortion rights could face excommunication, but church experts and politicians dismissed the threat. The cardinal delivered his strongest and clearest statement yet on the subject of excommunicating pro-choice Catholic politicians in a 12-page piece in Catholic New York, the weekly archdiocesan newspaper. ``Where Catholics are perceived not only as treating Church teaching on abortion with contempt, but helping to multiply abortions by advocating legislation supporting abortion, or by making public funds available for abortion, bishops may decide that ... such Catholics must be warned that they are at risk of excommunication,'' wrote O'Connor, who is the chairman of the bishops' Committee for Pro-Life Activities. ``If such actions persist, bishops may consider excommunication the only option,' he added. O'Connor did not mention any politicians by name, and said any bishop would ``engage in considerable prayer and discussion'' before taking such action. Excommunication blocks a Catholic from receiving most sacraments within the church. U.S. Rep. Charles Rangel, who was barred from speaking at a high school graduation at St. Patrick's Cathedral last week because of his pro-choice stance, said he did not want to believe O'Connor had issued ``such a mean-spirited statement.'' ``The cardinal obviously has a closer working relationship with God than I do, so therefore I would not risk challenging his authority,'' Rangel, D-N.Y., said in Washington. ``On the other hand, I feel very comfortable that comes Judgment Day, we will be on equal footing.'' Gov. Mario Cuomo, speaking at City Hall, reaffirmed his position of personal opposition to abortion but public support of a woman's right to decide. The governor then acknowledged the talk of excommunication bothered him. ``I don't like to hear it. How could you? This is something fundamental to our family,'' said Cuomo. Experts in church policy disagreed with O'Connor, saying support of a pro-choice stance was not grounds to expel politicians from the church. ``He's wrong,'' said the Rev. Richard McBrien, chairman of the theology department at the University of Notre Dame in South Bend, Ind. ``On the question of abortion, the only person clearly subjected to excommunication would be the person who procures the abortion.'' That would mean the woman and perhaps her doctor, but not politicians, he said. ``Mario Cuomo is not performing abortions. Mario Cuomo is not running an abortion clinic on the side,'' said McBrien. ``He (O'Connor) doesn't really have a canonical leg to stand on.'' The Rev. Robert Drinan, a former Massachusetts congressman, agreed that O'Connor's statements were misguided. ``That goes against what the bishops have been saying,'' said Drinan, a Georgetown University Law Center professor. ``I think that won't be taken that seriously. Catholics and everyone else would resent it.'' But the Rev. Joseph Penna, speaking for the Archdiocese of New York, said Thursday evening that a person could be excommunicated even if they do not directly take part in an abortion. ``It goes beyond who procures an abortion,'' said Penna, of St. Joseph's Seminary in Yonkers. If church officials determined that an individual served as an accomplice to an abortion by ``giving scandal to other people,'' that person could be excommunicated, he said. ``And by giving scandal, I mean a person would look at someone else and say, `If that person can do it, so can I,''' said Penna, speaking of the leadership roles that politicians play in society.

DOC.HEAD: Two American Climbers Found Dead on Mount McKinley
DOC.TEXT: The bodies of two climbers missing on Mount McKinley were found by rescue helicopters hovering near the 16,000-foot level of North America's tallest peak, a National Park Service spokesman said. The bodies of Michael Koshuta, 33, of Centreville, Va., and Stuart Jones, 29, of Washington state were spotted Tuesday afternoon, said spokesman John Quinley. No hometown was immediately available for Jones. The men were declared missing Tuesday, one day after a troubled Japanese climbing party that suffered the season's first fatality was airlifted off the mountain. There was no effort to remove the bodies from the 15,800-level because of the slope of the mountain and the threat of avalanche. Officials will decide later when it will be safe to return, Quinley said. The men were roped together and appeared to have died after a fall, the spokesman said. They were last sighted June 1 at the 16,100-foot level. Mount McKinley is 20,320 feet tall. Koshuta and Jones were experienced mountaineers who had climbed elsewhere in the Denali Range, Quinley said. There were no immediate clues as to what caused the accident or when it happened. The two climbers were scheduled to complete their descent four days ago. Three food caches they left along their planned route down the mountain hadn't been touched, Quinley said. Denali National Park rangers began looking for them Monday as rangers and two Army Chinook helicopters rescued three frostbitten, ill Japanese climbers and lowered the body of a fourth Japanese to 14,000 feet. The helicopters began looking for the missing Americans on Tuesday. The body of Hairoaki Ito, who died Sunday of altitude sickness, was expected to remain at 14,000 feet until friends could arrange for its removal or until an Army helicopter is called to the area on other business, Quinley said.

DOC.HEAD: Abbott Says Victim's Widow Has Suffered No Financial Damage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf, `Daniel Leonard ...,' with 6 grafs to ADD Abbott reducing Mrs. Adan to tears on Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Jack Henry Abbott, fighting to keep the rewards of the writing career he developed in prison with Norman Mailer's help, said Thursday that when he killed a young actor in 1981, he caused no financial loss to the widow. Acting as his own attorney in defense against a $17 million wrongful death lawsuit, Abbott said his victim, Richard Adan, had no more than $500 when he was killed and was being supported largely by his wife, Ricci, now 32. He also has insisted that he killed Adan swiftly with a knife stab to the heart, and therefore Mrs. Adan deserves no payment for Adan's pain and suffering. Following the judge's final instructions, the jury deliberated briefly, then was excused until Friday. Abbott, 46, gained fame from writing ``In the Belly of the Beast,'' a best-seller composed of letters he sent from prison to Mailer from 1978 through 1981. Mailer supported Abbott's parole that year. Abbott had been out of prison six weeks when he slew Adan outside the Bini-Bon restaurant on Manhattan's Lower East Side on July 18, 1981. Abbott spent more than three hours in closing arguments Thursday trying to convince the jury of six that Adan, 22, was one of thousands of young actors of modest talent who had a ``one-in-a-million'' chance of success before he died. Abbott sneered at a Pace University economist's projections that Adan might have netted $17 million in his lifetime. Abbott said the projections assumed that Adan ``would have been a movie star of the caliber of Paul Newman.'' Mrs. Adan's lawyers have proceeded on a theory of Adan's ``future value,'' Abbott said, ``because they have nothing more to go on.'' As Abbott belittled Adan he stood at a lectern, dangling his left hand, which has the letters J-A-C-K tattooed on the four fingers. Mrs. Adan reacted to Abbott's argument by laying her head on the knee of Henry Howard, her stepfather. On Wednesday, Abbott reduced Mrs. Adan to tears, then said her weeping would prejudice the jury against him. ``Mrs. Adan, I noticed you have a lot of tissues,'' he said as he cross-examined Mrs. Adan. ``Did you anticipate weeping on the stand? Do you have any children?'' ``No!'' she said. ``Just you?'' Abbott said. ``Yes,'' she said as she started to weep more loudly. Abbott then demanded a mistrial because of ``prejudice and bias.'' The judge denied the motion. Daniel Leonard, one of Mrs. Adan's lawyers, told the jury in a 12-minute summation Thursday that the future was all the couple had. Observing the defendant's constant references to himself, Leonard told the jury that the case was not about Abbott. ``It's about the promise of a great life, about two young people's future together,'' the lawyer said. Abbott, who said he has been out of prison a total of 11 months since he was 12, is serving 15 years to life for a first-degree manslaughter conviction in Adan's death. Mrs. Adan sued him for $10 million for wrongful death and pain and suffering. Her lawyers upped the lawsuit to $17 million after testimony by the economist, Edmund Mandell. While Abbott maintains Adan endured no pain because the knife thrust killed him almost instantly, Leonard said there was proof that ``Richard suffered greatly for 10 or 15 minutes before he died.'' Mailer, very visible during Abbott's criminal trial, has been absent from this one. He has not been reached for comment. Mrs. Adan's lawyers estimate that Abbott has a little more than $100,000 in escrow held by the Manhattan sheriff in case of a civil judgement in Mrs. Adan's favor. Abbott also has $15,000, earned from his writings, that is being held by the state Crime Victims Board. Abbott asked each witness, ``Did you read my book?'' At one point he even asked Judge Carol Arber. She replied that she had looked at parts of it. He attacked Mrs. Adan and her family, saying they wanted to punish him by insuring that no publisher will deal with him because of the legal lien on his finances. ``These proceedings have been brought by Mrs. Adan to stop me from publishing again,'' Abbott said.

DOC.HEAD: Trying To Grab the IRA: Extradition Disputes Worsen
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Dermot Finucane, Northern Ireland jailbreaker and IRA gunman wanted by Britain, is enjoying a fine Dublin summer, savoring freedom and drawing welfare checks. ``It's a great victory,'' said Finucane, 29, who has spent most of his adult life in jail or on the run. ``For someone suddenly to say you're free ... it's also frightening and bewildering and wonderful at the same time.'' To the British government, his freedom is infuriating and the reasons are disturbing. In March, the Irish Supreme Court refused to extradite Finucane to British-ruled Northern Ireland. It said his offense of possessing weapons was politically inspired, since the Irish Republican Army is fighting to unite Ireland. The five judges added that Finucane probably would be beaten by prison guards if returned to the jail from which he escaped in 1983. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain called the ruling ``deeply offensive'' and said it encouraged ``terrorists to the view that they will probably find a safe haven in the Republic of Ireland.'' Disputes over extradition have long clouded relations between the two countries, but things reached a new low after Finucane and an IRA comrade, James Clark, walked free March 13 into the arms of jubilant supporters. Both were convicted in Northern Ireland and sentenced to 18-year prison terms. Prime Minister Charles Haughey's Fianna Fail party, political heirs of the Irish nationalist heroes who wrested independence from Britain in the 1920s, is instinctively opposed to handing Irish people over to the British. The IRA is dedicated to overthrowing the institutions governing the Irish Republic, as well as British rule in Northern Ireland. Ireland, like Britain, outlaws the organization and keeps its supporters off radio and television. Extradition remains a problem, however, because of the deeply rooted belief that an Irish nationalist will not get fair treatment from the British. In the past year, British appeal judges have quashed the convictions of four Irish people jailed for IRA bombings in Britain in 1974 and three who were accused of plotting to assassinate a British government minister. Six Irishmen serving life sentences for a 1974 bombing in Birmingham that killed 21 people have won widespread support for their campaign to prove they were unjustly convicted. It all ``reinforces widespread unease about the conduct of court cases in Britain in which Irish people are charged with terrorist offenses,'' said columnist Mary Holland of the Irish Times, which opposes the IRA. Among those who got away is a Roman Catholic priest, Patrick Ryan. The Irish attorney general refused his extradition on terrorism charges in 1988, declaring British politicians and newspapers had damned Ryan in such intemperate language that a fair trial was impossible. Britain and other Irish political parties are putting pressure on Haughey to amend the extradition laws. Critics want it spelled out that such crimes as murder or possessing weapons cannot be deemed political. ``The idea that such barbarism should somehow be construed as a form of political action is nauseating and immoral and cannot continue,'' said Desmond O'Malley, leader of the Progressive Democrats, the Fianna Fail's junior coalition partner. Recent bombings in London have increased the pressure on Haughey. The British say the attacks herald a summer onslaught in mainland Britain as part of the IRA campaign to unite Protestant-dominated Northern Ireland with the overwhelmingly Catholic republic. Haughey says a 1987 act curtailing the plea of political motivation will ``do away with the present difficulties.'' He tells critics to wait and see how the courts apply the 1987 statute, which incorporates the European Convention on the Suppression of Terrorism. ``Our extradition laws are amongst the best in the world,'' he told Fianna Fail's annual convention soon after Finucane was released. Also, however, delegates endorsed a resolution opposing any extraditions ``to Northern Ireland and Britain in present circumstances.'' It said suspects should be tried instead under the republic's anti-terrorist laws. Although Finucane's case predates the 1987 act, some critics say his release has undermined it and is good news for five Northern Ireland fugitives fighting extradition under the stricter law. Cases still take a year or more to grind through appeals, and scope remains in the 1987 act for fighting extradition on political grounds2, Britain has made 112 applications for extradition of security offenders, Northern Ireland officials say, with seven granted, 41 refused, and five still being fought. The rest lapsed. To Northern Ireland's unionists, the Protestant. Since 197 majority, Ireland looks like a haven for their terrorist foes. The British feel let down, because improved extradition procedures were supposed to be the reward for giving Ireland a say in the running of Northern Ireland under the 1985 Anglo-Irish Agreement. Ireland's Progressive Democrats began a campaign May 14 to toughen the extradition law, and found the opposition Fine Gael and Labor parties generally supportive. ``It is a huge scandal that that man (Finu on suspected safe houses in 1987. His brother Patrick, a lawyer who defended IRA suspects, was shot to death and Protestant militants claimed responsibility. Another brother, Gerard, is in an Irish jail for IRA activity and John Finucane was killed in an auto accident en route to an IRA operation.

DOC.HEAD: Explosions Rock Gasoline Storage Plant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with details of fire and injuries; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Explosions ripped through a gasoline storage plant in southwest Indiana on Wednesday, seriously injuring three men. The largest of seven cylindrical tanks at the Greene County Farm Bureau Co-op exploded about 2:30 p.m. and was still burning Wednesday night, state police Cpl. Omar Davis said in Bloomington. Davis said officials of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency were determining whether to smother the blaze with foam or let it burn itself out. Although fears that the fire would spread to the other tanks subsided, residents up to two miles away were evacuated. ``Two businesses are very close and there are a few scattered homes nearby, but it's mostly rural,'' said sheriff's dispatcher Sheri Campbell. The size of the tank and the amount of gasoline it held had not been determined, Davis said, noting conflicting reports that it contained 8,000 gallons or 42,000 gallons. Davis said the accident occurred as workers emptied a gasoline truck into the tank using a pump. ``The pump apparently sparked and ignited the truck and from there, somehow or other, the tank caught fire,'' he said. The three injured were taken to hospitals to be treated for burns. Leo Goodwin, listed in critical condition, was taken to Riley Hospital in Indianapolis; Dick Smiley, also listed as critical, was taken to Wishard Hospital in Indianapolis; and Richard Knight, who was in serious condition, was taken to Deaconess Hospital in Evansville, Davis said. Their ages and hometowns were unavailable. Dark smoke was seen as far away as six or seven miles from the plant, which is outside Switz City, 75 miles southwest of Indianapolis.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Identify Site of Second ``Katyn Massacre''
DOC.TEXT: The KGB has identified a park outside the Ukrainian city of Kharkov as the likely burial site of 3,900 Polish officers massacred by the Soviet secret police in 1940, the Polish PAP news agency reported. The victims represent part of the approximately 15,000 Polish officers from three internment camps who were systematically killed in what has become known as the Katyn Massacre. More than 4,300 bodies of the executed Polish officers were discovered at Katyn near Smolensk in 1943, but the exact fate of the other missing officers has remained a mystery. The 15,000 officers were seized by the Soviet Union in the early days of World War II. Soviet officials acknowledged in April that the officers were killed by the NKVD, Stalin's secret police and the KGB's predecessor. For decades, Soviet governments had maintained that the officers died at the hands of invading German armies. PAP quoted the chief of the KGB office in Kharkov, a city of 1.2 million 500 miles south of Moscow, as saying the Polish soldiers were buried in a wooded park around the city. The KGB chief was not identified. The report was published Wednesday in the Polish government newspaper Rzeczpospolita. PAP said the burial site also contained some Soviet victims of the NKVD. The officers whose remains were found at Katyn had been interned at a camp in Kozielsk, in western Russia. Still unknown is the final resting place of the more than 6,000 Polish officers interned at the third Soviet camp at Ostashkov, a town 200 miles northwest of Moscow.

DOC.HEAD: Frankfurt Tops List of Prosperous European Cities
DOC.TEXT: The financial center of Frankfurt is Western Europe's most prosperous city _ followed by Brussels, Venice, Munich, and Amsterdam, a university report says. The Belgian, Italian, Dutch and West Germany cities led 117 urban areas ranked by University of Reading economics professor Paul Cheshire. Only European Community cities with a minimum population of 300,000 were considered and Portugal and Greece were not included because they could not provide adequate figures, said Cheshire. To determine the cities' rankings, Cheshire said he looked at their per capita gross domestic product, unemployment, migration and other factors. The three poorest cities in the survey were all in Spain: Malaga, Cordoba and Seville. The results, based on figures up to 1988, are to be published in the July issue of Urban Studies, an international journal published in Britain. Cheshire made a copy of his article available to The Associated Press on Wednesday. The cities that fared best are large, have big service sectors, and are centrally located in Europe, Cheshire said: ``European economic integration is of much greater benefit to the more central regions of Europe than it is to the more peripheral ones.'' The rest of the list also was dominated by West German cities. Here are the remaining 25 most prosperous urban areas: 6. Strasbourg, France 7. Bonn, West Germany 8. Nice, France 9. Stuttgart, West Germany 10. Florence, Italy 11. Palma, Spain 12. Hanover, West Germany 13. Duesseldorf, West Germany 14. Bologna, Italy 15. Nuremberg, West Germany 16. Antwerp, Belgium 17. Milan, Italy 18. Karlsruhe, West Germany 19. Brighton, England 20. Dijon, France 21. Cologne, West Germany 22. Lyon, France 23. Paris 24. Wiesbaden, West Germany 25. Hamburg, West Germany Among other major European cities, Berlin ranked 34th; London, 35th; Rome, 50th; and Madrid, 54th.

DOC.HEAD: Police Use Tear Gas to Break Up Teachers' Protest
DOC.TEXT: Police hurled tear gas canisters to disperse protesting student teachers outside the Education Ministry in a rare confrontation on this French Caribbean island. One protester was struck by a tear-gas canister and injured in the clash, police said Wednesday. They said an academic inspector from France was attacked while leaving the ministry. Another protester, who had been staging a hunger strike at the government building for more than a week, was hospitalized because of weakness. About 60 people had been taking part to protest the French government's refusal to allow student teachers to complete their training on the island rather than in France. Residents said it was the first violent clash between police and protesters on the island in at least 20 years. Martinique, with a population of 333,000, is a French overseas department, a status roughly equivalent to that of a U.S. state. The island is part of the Windward chain 425 miles south of Puerto Rico.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Sue White House Aide Over Convention Protest
DOC.TEXT: Massachusetts' Democrats have filed a lawsuit accusing a White House aide and the Springfield police union of conspiring to disrupt the party's convention. The union picketed the convention hall in Springfield on June 2, preventing delegates from entering for several hours. Among those named in the lawsuit filed in state court Wednesday were Ronald Kaufman, deputy assistant to President Bush for personnel, and union president Robert Jacobson. The lawsuit alleges that Kaufman and the union conspired to violate Democratic delegates' right to assemble and that pickets struck, shoved and spit on people who tried to enter the convention hall. Kaufman was in Springfield at the time of the convention, spoke with Jacobson the night before the protest and also met with members of the union in Washington before the convention. But he and Jacobson have repeatedly denied they conspired to interfere with the convention. Jacobson said the protest was part of a dispute with the city. ``I'm glad they're filing because I've got a secret weapon: truth,'' Kaufman said Wednesday. The lawsuit seeks an unspecified amount in damages.

DOC.HEAD: Fast-Killing Monkey Virus Could Shed Light on AIDS
DOC.TEXT: Slight genetic mutations allowed a monkey AIDS virus to kill within days rather than months, a finding that could improve scientists' understanding of human AIDS, researchers reported today. The result raises the possibility that a human AIDS strain may exist that kills within days or weeks of infection, rather than years, said study co-author Patricia Fultz. A federal AIDS expert said he strongly doubts such a human strain exists. But he and Fultz said the monkey virus may still help scientists study AIDS. The new work is presented in the British journal Nature by Fultz, of the Yerkes Regional Primate Research Center at Emory University in Atlanta, with scientists there, at Harvard University and the Stanford University School of Medicine. They studied a recently isolated strain of a simian immunodeficiency virus. Scientists study these monkey viruses, called SIVs, to gain clues about AIDS. In monkeys called pig-tailed macaques, the fast-acting SIV produced bloody diarrhea and death in as little as six days after it infected the animal, researchers reported. In contrast, the virus from which this strain evolved allows eight months or more of survival after infection, Fultz said Wednesday. The genetic makeup of the fast-acting virus strongly resembles that of other SIVs and gained its wallop by acquiring only subtle mutations, so the possibility that a fast-acting human AIDS virus exists must be considered, the researchers said. But Malcolm Martin of the Laboratory of Molecular Biology at the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases in Bethesda, Md., said it is highly unlikely such a virus exists. No such virus has been observed in the hundreds of thousands of people infected with the AIDS virus, and if a fast-acting human version were going to appear, it would have shown up by now, he said. Further study of the fast-acting SIV strain may identify the genes that make it act so quickly, which in turn may give clues for fighting the human AIDS virus, Fultz said. Martin said that since the virus causes severe disease more quickly than other SIVs, it may also provide a way to test AIDS therapies more quickly.

DOC.HEAD: Facts on Burning Supertanker
With PM-Tanker Blast, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are key facts about the Mega Borg, the supertanker burning in the Gulf of Mexico: LENGTH: 885 feet, 10 inches. AGE: 15 years. REGISTRY: Norwegian. OPERATOR: Mosvolds Shipping of Farsund, Norway. OWNERS: Mosvolds owns less than 50 percent; other owners are private investors through the K-S Mega Borg investment group of Farsund. The ship's U.S. agent is Biehl and Co. of Galveston, Texas. OFFICERS AND CREW: Officers and crew from India and the Philippines. Captain is C.M. Mahidhara. HULL TYPE: Single hull. ORIGIN AND DESTINATION: Came from Palanca, Angola; its next port of call, after Galveston, was to be Aruba. CARGO AT TIME OF ACCIDENT: 38 million gallons of light crude oil. OIL'S OWNER: Elf Trading Inc. of Houston, a subsidiary of the French oil company Elf Aquitine Group. THE ACCIDENT: Began late Friday while some of ship's cargo was being loaded onto another tanker in the Gulf of Mexico 57 miles southeast of Galveston. Explosion in engine room and fire killed two crewmen, left two missing and injured 17, none seriously; 20 others were rescued. Smaller explosions hit Saturday; five powerful blasts within 20 minutes Sunday sent blazing crude into the water, and the ship tipped toward its stern. Firefighters on Tuesday declared the blaze under control, but the vessel continued to leak oil.

DOC.HEAD: Tommy Martin: A Man You Can Look Up To
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Tommy Martin is a single woman's dream. He's a mature, easygoing bachelor, he's a good cook and he even does windows. Boy, does he do windows! Every day this week, Martin scales the sheer face of the 30-story Gannett Co. Inc. headquarters building, one of the tallest in metropolitan Washington, D.C., to scrub its 5,000 windows from the outside. The annual spring cleaning takes Martin, 53, and his buddy, Lucien Coleman, 62, about three weeks. They finished Gannett's twin USA Today building last week, and both gleaming towers will be washed again this summer and fall. From his perch on a gently swaying platform only three feet wide, Martin has a breathtaking view of Washington's monuments and tree-shaded malls across the Potomac River. The 380-foot plunge from Gannett's rooftop to the busy streets below is an acrophobic's nightmare, but a downward glance doesn't bother Martin. ``It's a good job,'' he says. ``A lot of people look up to you.'' Martin's been a professional window washer for 30 years and he's never suffered high anxiety from the time he climbed trees as a kid. No sweaty palms, no churning stomach, no dizzy spells. He doesn't take tranquilizers, and sleeps like a baby at night. He did utter a prayer once when his platform tipped over and he took a four-story free fall until he was caught by the heavy safety rope attached to his belt. He escaped with only rope burns on his hand. Martin is such a relaxed fellow that when one of his platform's electrically powered hoist cables stalled, leaving him swinging 100 feet in the air for half an hour, he simply laid down until an engineer fixed the problem. ``It wasn't going anywhere, so I took a little nap,'' he said. Martin likes the fresh air and sunshine, the pay is good ($140 a day) and the solitude of working at great heights gives him plenty of time to think, he says. For entertainment, he waves at startled office workers as he suddenly drops into view, a sort of high-rise peeping Tommy. The other day, an airliner roared so close to the Gannett building on its approach to nearby National Airport that ``I could see the passengers inside,'' he said. Martin says he can ride up or down the building in 20 minutes, swabbing windows and aluminum paneling with a sudsy solution of household detergent and ammonia and scraping them dry with a squeegee. A lifelong bachelor, Martin cooks his own dinner when he returns home for the evening. His favorite is meatloaf and collard greens. But he offers a warning to any females who might be hunting for a husband: ``I don't do windows around the house.''

DOC.HEAD: Marion Barry Abandons Re-Election Plans
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to include Barry denial of linkage between political decision and trial.
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry, struggling against drug possession and perjury charges, said Wednesday he would not seek re-election to a fourth term. ``Now is a time for healing,'' the embattled mayor said. Barry hastily summoned his cabinet to reveal his decision shortly before he told his constituents via a televised announcement. His move sparked speculation of an effort to rekindle plea bargain talks that broke down over a week ago. However, Barry denied that his political decision had anything to do with his trial. Barry has pleaded innocent to 10 misdemeanor cocaine possession charges, one misdemeanor cocaine conspiracy charge, and three felony counts of lying to a grand jury about his alleged drug use. As jury selection crawled along, U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson said he hoped to seat a jury on Monday. ``Now is a time for healing, healing for me personally and for you politically,'' Barry said. Barry said public opinion polls indicated he could win another term, but he added, ``What good does it do to win the battle if in the process I lose my soul?'' Barry's pre-taped address was broadcast on Howard University radio and television. Barry ``is seeking to portray himself as a victim, someone who's given up something very important in the wake of these charges,'' said one source who has spoken to Barry several times in the past week. ``The thinking is, the jury may go easy on him if they feel he's voluntarily dropped something so dear.'' Barry decided over the weekend not to seek re-election, but postponed making the announcement because of publicity surrounding the efforts of Jesse Jackson and others to act as mediators in Barry's case, sources said. Barry's decision was expected to boost the mayoral candidacies of D.C. Council member John Ray and Walter Fauntroy, the District of Columbia's non-voting delegate to Congress. Barry's successor will take office Jan. 1. Barry said his decision ``will go a long way toward lifting the shadows'' over other candidates' campaigns. He noted that some have called on him to resign immediately, but said that would be ``disruptive'' for the city. Barry supporters have organized a rally for Thursday outside the courthouse where the mayor's case is being tried. Anita Bonds, Barry's campaign manager, has circulated a letter to city workers urging them to attend. Meanwhile, six potential jurors questioned Wednesday said they would not be affected by either an announcement that Barry would forgo seeking a fourth term or a declaration that he would run. Prosecutors had raised the issue with the prospective jurors. Interviews of the prospective jurors will end at noon Friday, the jury will be seated Monday and opening statements will be Tuesday morning, said Jackson. Seventy-seven people have been sent into a pool of potential jurors since the process began June 4. Barry aides had floated the idea of a plea bargain last week in which the mayor would agree to plead guilty to misdemeanor charges. But sources close to U.S. Attorney Jay Stephens' office said the prosecutor would not accept a deal that did not include a felony conviction. Stephens has said any decision Barry made on re-election would be irrelevant to the criminal case. But for the first time on Wednesday, lawyers raised questions with the prospective jurors about Barry's political plans. Assistant U.S. Attorney Judith Retchin asked one woman if her work on the criminal case would be affected if she learned Barry were not going to seek re-election. No, replied the prospective juror, who had worked a number of years ago in a city summer youth employment program. Nor would she be affected if Barry announced he would run, said the woman, who reiterated her answers when questioned similarly by R. Kenneth Mundy, the mayor's lawyer. A second prospective juror said he wouldn't be affected by a Barry announcement on his political future. ``If it's not part of the trial, I would not consider it,'' said the man. One man said that he would regard a decision by Barry not to run for re-election as an admission of guilt. He said he thinks Barry should resign because the publicity surrounding the investigation and prosecution of the mayor ``has hurt the city.'' That man was one of seven excluded from the jury pool.

DOC.HEAD: Logging Reductions Planned for Mount Baker-Snoqualmie National Forest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 16th graf, `Old growth ...,' to CORRECT that definition is at least 21 inches in diameter measured 4{ feet from the ground, sted 21 inches and 4{ feet tall.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Spotted Owl
DOC.TEXT: A plan to reduce logging by 46 percent in Washington's largest national forest was announced Wednesday, and more drastic reductions may be ordered to protect the northern spotted owl, officials said. Mount Baker-Snoqualmie National Forest supervisor Doug MacWilliams briefed a few dozen interest-group representatives on the 10-to-15-year plan for land and resource management. He said it represents a major shift in favor of recreation and a ``very severe'' blow to the timber industry. The proposed timber harvest reductions would cost about 1,800 jobs, MacWilliams said. ``Every one of us in this room will feel it in some way or another,'' he said. ``When you go to buy a 2-by-4, you're going to be paying through the nose for it,'' he said. The plan, replacing one dating from 1963, takes effect 90 days after publication Friday in the Federal Register and will remain in effect pending the outcome of appeals, MacWilliams said. Representatives of industry, landowner and environmental groups all say they will appeal various aspects of the plan. It is the product of 10 years of research and debate, but is subject to amendment by the Forest Service. Mount Baker-Snoqualmie, covering 1.7 million acres from the Canadian border to the area around Mount Rainier National Park, is the second largest timber-producing national forest in Washington. At the same time, it probably has the heaviest recreation demands of any national forest in the state, said forest spokesman Warren Olney. The plan would set the average annual timber harvest at 108 million board feet _ 46 percent less than the average for the past decade and 36 percent less than proposed in a draft plan two years ago. The forest would produce $526 million in income a year, MacWilliams said. The harvest would drop to 45 million board feet, however, if a scientific report on protection of the owl is accepted by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, he said. Fish and Wildlife officials are scheduled to decide by June 23 whether to list the owl as threatened, a decision that would trigger further logging restrictions. However, MacWilliams said, the harvest would rise by a total of roughly 40 percent over the two decades following the planning period and then level off at a sustained-yield level. About 95 percent of the roadless acreage would remain intact and 97 percent of the 643,000 acres of old growth would remain in the year 2000. Old growth was defined in the plan as trees at least 21 inches in diameter measured 4{ feet from the ground. Using the Wilderness Society's definition of at least 32 inches, however, there is only about half as much virgin forest left, said Jean Durning, regional director of the environmental group. Other features of the plan include a recommendation that 30 rivers stretching along 462 miles be designated as wild and scenic, a protection now accorded in Washington only to the Skagit River system. The draft plan had proposed wild-and-scenic designation for five rivers. The plan also calls for construction of 220 miles of trails, rebuilding of 493 miles and maintenance of 891. The draft plan had called for 80 new miles, 240 for rebuilding and 1,144 for maintenance.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Zsa Zsa Gabor has opted to serve a three-day jail sentence for slapping a motorcycle policeman rather than pursue an appeal. ``She's just tired of it, and 72 hours isn't going to kill her,'' spokesman Phil Paladino said Wednesday. The 72-year-old Miss Gabor probably will go to jail within a month, he said. ``As Zsa Zsa would say, you can't beat City Hall,'' Paladino said. ``In her heart, she's innocent.'' Miss Gabor was convicted of smacking Beverly Hills Officer Paul Kramer during a traffic stop a year ago. She also was sentenced to community service at a homeless shelter and ordered to pay court costs and fines totaling $12,000.

Comedian Jackie Mason has been ordered to pay $2,000 a month in child support to a 37-year-old former girlfriend he denies getting pregnant. A state appeals court Tuesday upheld a ruling in favor of Ginger Reiter, who filed a paternity lawsuit three years ago alleging Mason had fathered her 4-year-old daughter, Sheeba. The 60-year-old comic denies he is the father and had appealed the earlier child-support ruling. A judge had ruled that blood tests show there is a 99.94 percent chance that the girl is Mason's daughter. ``I feel thrilled because now I can send Sheeba to a religious school,'' said Reiter, who operates a singing telegram service. ``I have collection agencies hounding me.'' Mason's lawyer, Gerald Mager, declined to comment.

Genie Francis, who played Laura on ``General Hospital'' in the early 1980s, is joining the cast of ABC's ``All My Children.'' The romance between Laura and Luke gave ``General Hospital'' the highest ratings in daytime TV historywhen the characters were married in 1981.The soap opera couple made the cover of ``Newsweek. Francis left the ABC show in 1984. On ``All My Children,'' she will play Ceara Conner, a femme fatale in the fictional town of Pine Valley, the network said Wednesday.

Mr. Universe Matthew Dufresne faces federal charges of conspiring to smuggle body-building steroids into the country. Dufresne, 24, of Hampden was indicted Tuesday on charges of conspiring to import steroids from Belgium and with possession of 5,000 doses of the drug. In October, he was chosen Mr. Universe by the North Atlantic Body Building Association, the second person to win that title in the same year he was Mr. America. Anabolic steroids are used to build muscles and stamina but can have dangerous side-effects and are banned by international athletic organizations. The charges against Dufresne carry up to 13 years in prison and fines of $260,000. Dufresne did not immediately return a call to his home.

A drifter who nearly killed Theresa Saldana in a knife attack eight years ago has been ordered to stand trial on charges of sending the actress threatening letters from prison. Municipal Judge Alma Soper issued the ruling Wednesday in the case of Scottish-born Arthur Jackson, 54. ``I am very grateful,'' Miss Saldana said in a statement. On Tuesday, the actress, who was in the movie ``Raging Bull,'' testified Jackson had sent her terrifying death-threat letters. Jackson, an obsessed fan who stalked the actress and attacked her, was convicted of attempted murder and sentenced to 12 years in prison in 1982. His sentence was cut in half for good behavior and he was due for release in April, but the new charges have kept him behind bars. The charges carry up to six years in prison.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Department Orders New York Waterways Closed
DOC.TEXT: A gasoline barge sprang a leak Wednesday night, spilling at least 1,200 gallons and prompting officials to close two busy waterways that have been plagued by spills, authorities said. The source of the spill into the Arthur Kill waterway was believed to be a tank on the barge holding more than 222,000 gallons of unleaded gas, said Coast Guard Petty Officer Don Burt. The tank was emptied about two hours after the leak was reported to the Coast Guard at 8:05 p.m., but officials were waiting for divers to confirm no other tanks were leaking into the Arthur Kill waterway dividing New York's Staten Island and New Jersey. It was not immediately known what caused the spill. More than 10 million gallons of fuel were loaded into 10 tanks on the barge at Carteret, N.J., during the afternoon, then the vessel traveled across the Arthur Kill to a Mobil Corp. operation on Staten Island. After the spill, the Fire Department sent about 10 units to the Port Mobil section of Staten Island, spokesman John Mulligan said. The Arthur Kill and adjacent Kill Van Kull were closed shortly after 9 p.m. as a safety precaution while firefighters attempted to disperse the gasoline to speed evaporation. Brooks said it was not immediately known how long the kills would remain closed. Booms were laid at entrances to nearby creeks to prevent the gasoline from spreading inland, he said. He said the barge was owned by Bouchard Transportation of New York. Calls to the company were not answered Wednesday night. The amount of oil accidentally released into the two kills this year is four times as much as was reported in all of 1989. The most recent accident occurred last week when an 811-foot tanker leaked 260,000 gallons of oil into the Kill Van Kull. On Jan. 2, a pipe from an Exxon refinery leaked more than 567,000 gallons of oil into the Arthur Kill.

DOC.HEAD: House Passes Its Version of Multibillion AIDS Bill
DOC.TEXT: Two huge spending bills to help cities and states cope with the AIDS crisis are heading to a conference committee now that the House has approved its $4 billion version. The House bill was approved 408-14 on Wednesday, sending it to a panel that will compromise it with a Senate version that would spend $1 billion less over five years. The overwhelming House vote came in the face of opposition by the Office of Management and Budget, which argued that the bill was too costly and should not have been focused on a single disease. ``The bill's narrow disease-specific approach sets a dangerous precedent, inviting treatment of other diseases through similar ad hoc arrangements,'' a budget office statement said. ``This approach also runs counter to the government's existing health care financing system, which will provide more than $870 million in federal Medicaid payments for HIV disease in 1991,'' it said, referring to the AIDS-causing human immunodeficiency virus. The House bill authorizes $400 million in each of the next five fiscal years for grants to provide a variety of AIDS preventative health services. Half the money would go to state governments, and the rest directly to health care facilities. It authorizes another $275 million a year for the next two years, and ``such sums as may be necessary'' for the following three years, to go directly to cities with the largest number of AIDS cases. The money would go to AIDS health care and support services. The bill authorizes smaller amounts for a series of other AIDS projects, including $20 million a year for research into helping pediatric patients and grants to states for purchasing drugs to treat AIDS and related conditions. The House adopted amendments that scaled back the estimated five-year cost of the bill from $4.6 billion to around $4 billion. It rejected amendments that would have required states to test all citizens annually for the AIDS virus, and would have required institutions to report anyone who tests positive to state authorities. Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., likened AIDS to natural disasters that have prompted Congress to appropriate money to local governments. ``This bill says to cities like New York, which has 25 percent of total AIDS cases in the country, that we understand your problem,'' he said. ``Hospitals are collapsing with the financial burden placed on them'' by AIDS. Besides New York, other cities expected to receive emergency grants under the House bill are: Atlanta, Boston, Chicago, Dallas, Houston, Jersey City, N.J.; Los Angeles, Miami, Newark, Philadelphia, San Diego, San Francisco, San Juan, Puerto Rico; and Washington, D.C. The Senate last month approved, 95-4, to approve a similar bill that would spend an estimated $2.9 billion over five years. The AIDS virus is transmitted through blood and other body fluids. Homosexual contact and intravenous illicit drug use are primary transmitters. The 14 members voting against the bill were all Republicans. They were: Philip Crane, R-Ill.; John Duncan Jr, R-Tenn.; Mickey Edwards, R-Okla.; George Gekas, R-Pa.; Mel Hancock, R-Mo.; Clyde Holloway, R-La.; Duncan Hunter, R-Calif.; Jon Kyl, R-Ariz.; Ron Marlenee, R-Mont.; Carl Pursell, R-Mich.; Dan Schaefer, R-Colo.; Gerald Solomon, R-N.Y.; Bob Stump, R-Ariz.; and Robert Walker, R-Pa. Not voting were: Reps. Bill Frenzel, R-Minn.; Augustus Hawkins, D-Calif.; Joseph Kennedy, D-Mass.; John LaFalce, D-N.Y.; Jim Lightfoot, R-Iowa; Romano Mazzoli, D-Ky.; Bill Nelson, D-Fla.; Charles Rangel, D-N.Y.; Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill.; and Denny Smith, R-Ore. Not voting by tradition was House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney: U.S. Hid List of Secret Noriega Files
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. government is illegally withholding from Manuel Noriega's lawyers file cabinets full of thousands of secret Panamanian documents seized during the American invasion, a defense attorney says. Michael O'Kane, attorney for co-defendant Daniel Miranda, said an inventory that a private investigator found in a U.S. Army warehouse in Panama showed the government gave a shorter list of all seized material to the defense. ``We found wadded up in one of the boxes as garbage what we think is the real inventory,'' O'Kane said Wednesday. He said the defense was given a sanitized list as part of a ``coverup effectuated in Panama by unknown elements within the government of the United States.'' Omitting evidence would violate a U.S. magistrate's order that an inventory of all Noriega-related documents seized in the December invasion be turned over to the defense, O'Kane said. On Wednesday he filed a motion demanding a full accounting of the files. O'Kane said there was no indication the Miami U.S. attorney's office knew its list was sanitized. Diane Cossin, spokeswoman for the U.S. attorney's office, had no comment on the motion. Nor did Pentagon spokeswoman Maj. Kathy Woods. The newly discovered list indicates the Army confiscated file cabinets containing Panamanian intelligence files, weapons import-export records, confidential correspondence and files on anti-Noriega coup plotters, O'Kane said. The lawyer emphasized that many of the missing documents appeared to be essential. Noriega contends many of his activities were sanctioned by the United States, and that U.S. and Panamanian records would show he cooperated with the CIA, Drug Enforcement Administration and other investigative agencies. Jon May, an attorney for Noriega, said he had not seen O'Kane's list but that the general's defense is eager to examine the lists and documents. O'Kane's client, Miranda, is charged with helping to fly drug profits from Fort Lauderdale to Panama. He faces up to five years in prison. Noriega faces up to 145 years in prison on charges of accepting $4.6 million from Colombia's Medellin drug cartel to turn Panama into a haven for U.S.-bound drugs.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Views Durenberger From Across Divide of Judges and Judged
LaserPhoto WX9
With PM-Durenberger-Charge
DOC.TEXT: Dave Durenberger has been in the Senate for 12 years, but his colleagues now regard him from across a great divide _ they the judges and he the judged. No attempt at mild humor, no appeal to mutual concerns, no allusion to past relationships was enough to evoke a smile or even a change of expression from the six solemn men who will decide Durenberger's future. They are trying one of their own _ a Republican from squeaky-clean Minnesota, a man who has served on good-government panels for decades, a former member of the Senate Ethics Committee itself, and now accused of intentionally skirting and violating Senate rules to make himself richer. The ethics committee had scheduled up to two weeks of hearings, but it agreed to a request Wednesday from Durenberger's lawyer, Jim Hamilton, to end the hearings early because of the legal fees the senator would incur. Instead, Durenberger turned over 23 volumes of documents into evidence for the committee to consider. The panel's lawyer, Robert S. Bennett, has recommended that Durenberger be denounced by the Senate, a severe reprimand that while short of expulsion, usually leads to the end of a lawmaker's career. ``Gentlemen, I don't need to tell you that reputation is the lifeblood of public service,'' Durenberger said amiably as he began his statement of self-defense on Wednesday. No flicker. ``I have never once `worked' the facts in this case with my colleagues, even though we have all of these political and personal relationships,'' he continued. No flicker. Durenberger chuckled that a son's college graduation last weekend had entailed eight years and four different schools. He wondered, jokingly, who in his right mind would try to evade Senate rules by creating an outfit called ``Piranha Press'' to publish his books. No one on the panel smiled. He spoke of his four sons, his first wife's early death, his marriage to a Vietnam War widow, the sorrow that ``made bonding difficult in our family.'' He talked of religion, lessons learned, his ``acute sense of sadness'' and resolve to be a model public servant. His six judges sat impassively. If no sympathy was apparent from those behind the long velvet-draped dais, Durenberger did command some support among spectators in the huge marbled hearing room. There was his youngest son, Dan, 23. And there was Sen. Rudy Boschwitz, R-Minn., a surprising presence to some. Durenberger is too well-liked to have become a pariah, at least not yet. He was appointed last week, as expected, to a conference committee on the clean air bill. He is scheduled to speak Friday at his state's Independent-Republican Party convention. Nevertheless, ``senators aren't rushing to do photo opportunities with him,'' as one Capitol Hill staffer put it. Durenberger defends himself partly by saying he did only what he believed other lawmakers were doing; he also says his aggressive approach to his job created ``strains and vulnerabilities'' in his family life and in his decision-making process. Neither argument seems to be going over well. There is concern that Durenberger's well-publicized troubles will tar an institution that gets little enough respect as it is. There is also a feeling that while many senators have financial and personal problems, they have managed to play by the rules. Durenberger's fans in the audience are worried that his case could be used as a warning to other senators, at his expense. ``It sounds like they feel like they need to make a statement, to say this just can't continue,'' said Meredith Musaus, 33, pastor of a visiting church youth group from Faribault, Minn. In Durenberger's pleasant Senate office, two receptionists and a couple of young aides watched his speech on television. The wall behind the TV set was covered with photographs of prominent Minnesota politicians and a sign that said: ``No man's life, liberty or property are safe while the legislature is in session.'' Business proceeded as usual, except for a smattering of calls from people expressing support for the senator and an occasional right-on sign at the TV screen when Durenberger made an emphatic point. ``My life and my reputation are at stake,'' Durenberger, on television, was saying emotionally as a man walked into his office and plunked down a briefcase. ``For the mistakes I have made, I repeat that I am sorry,'' said the senator, an imploring note in his voice. ``I have an 11:30 appointment with Anthony,'' the man with the briefcase said. He never even glanced at the TV.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Report Cell-Altering DNA `Wand'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 8th graf, `The ``wand ...,' to UPDATE with outside comment; picks up 9th graf, `Using pressurized ...'
DOC.TEXT: Researchers have created a ``wand'' that alters living animal cells by bombarding them with microscopic DNA-coated pellets, Duke University scientists said Wednesday. ``There is a whole range of genetic applications,'' said Stephen Johnston, a molecular biologist at Duke. ``I think we are just at the frontier of realizing what the potentials are of being able to modify cells in the living organism,'' he said. The scientists say the technology could be ready for use within a year and eventually could help treat liver and heart diseases. But they added that its future depends on further breakthroughs and on society's attitude toward genetic engineering. The research results were reported Wednesday at the annual meeting of the Tissue Culture Association in Houston. Duke researchers, in collaboration with scientists at Cornell University and the DuPont Co. used the ``wand'' to alter cells of living mice by injecting new genes, with little or no adverse effects, they said. The ``wand'' eventually may be used to treat some liver diseases by supplying the missing gene that causes certain defects, to alter pancreatic cells to produce insulin, or to alter muscle cells to treat heart diseases, the scientists said. ``It's an interesting new approach to a very important problem in modern molecular biology,'' said Lee Hood, professor of biology at California Institute of Technology. Using pressurized helium gas, the ``wand'' propels, at 1,000 feet a second, microscopic DNA-coated pellets into the tissue. About 10 million pellets, each containing about 30 genes, are introduced. The pellets are so small _ .00003 inches across _ that they do not cause extensive damage, researchers said. DNA, or deoxyribonucleic acid, is the collection of genes in living cells that determine individual characteristics. Because the pellets do not penetrate deep into the tissue, the animal does not suffer any trauma or skin irritation, Johnston said, adding that a human subject might feel a slight stinging sensation. The ``wand'' must be improved before it can be applied to human diseases, researchers said. They said questions remain about whether the altered genes can permanently take hold in animal cells. To date, the genes have been effective only as long as the pellets remained in the tissue, about 10 days in the ear of a mouse. Existing techniques for modifying the DNA of living organisms, such as bone-marrow transplants, involve an indirect process in which cells are removed from the patient, altered and then re-introduced, the researchers said. DuPont said it will make a version of the ``wand'' available to researchers. The precursor to the ``wand'' is a mechanism that uses gunpowder to fire gene-coated tungsten pellets into plant cells, the researchers said. That instrument was invented by John Sanford of Cornell University, who also worked on the ``wand'' team. DuPont bought the rights to the earlier instrument and markets it to agriculture and industry.

DOC.HEAD: Glasnost Slow to Reach Rural Regions, Officials Say
DOC.TEXT: Small-town and rural Soviet citizens are missing out on many of the new freedoms urban residents enjoy under glasnost, a State Department official says. Residents of outlying areas still must contend with the old Communist Party power structure, Richard Schifter, assistant secretary of state for human rights, said Wednesday. In those areas, ``a person's job assignment and housing remain dependent on the good will of the local party boss, who will most assuredly discriminate against anyone who steps out of line,'' Schifter told the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on human rights and international organizations. However, he said, ``What we might refer to as First Amendment freedoms have come to the Soviet Union's urban areas and the clouds of fear which hung over them have lifted.'' Schifter noted that restrictions on religious freedom are not being enforced and that on Tuesday, the Supreme Soviet approved a law ending media censorship. On Wednesday, the Soviets agreed to begin easing its 2-month-old economic embargo against independence-minded Lithuania. The Tass news agency quoted Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene as saying the Soviet government had agreed to restore some fuel and raw material supplies to the Baltic republic. Curtis Kamman, deputy assistant secretary of state for European and Canadian affairs, noted that under the Soviet embargo, ``Lithuania by now should have been brought to its knees, and obviously it has not.'' Lithuania got help from the other two Baltic republics, Latvia and Estonia, and from other sources, he said. Also attending Wednesday's hearing was Mart Niklus, an Estonian who spent most of his adult life in Soviet prisons and labor camps for political dissidence. He said he agreed that conditions are vastly improving, but added that if the Soviet Union removed its troops from the Baltic republics, ``many other problems would be automatically resolved.'' Niklus, who was released from prison in July 1988, is traveling through the United States, Canada and Europe to seek support for Baltic independence. Schifter said the Soviet Union faces serious problems with its economic crisis and severe ethnic conflicts in some areas. But he added, ``One cannot help, when visiting the country, but be encouraged by this resurgence of the human spirit.'' ``Yet, the KGB is still in place,'' Schifter told the House panel. Although it no longer pursues political dissidents, he said there was concern that ``the KGB could quickly revive the apparatus of repression if ordered to do so.'' Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., said the end of censorship means ``there is little that cannot be said or written nowadays in the Soviet Union, provided one can find the paper and ink.''

DOC.HEAD: Durenberger Would Be Ninth Senator to Face Denunciation
With PM-Durenberger Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Dave Durenberger would become the ninth senator to suffer the Senate's second most severe punishment if his colleagues agree he should be denounced for financial misconduct. The Senate Ethics Committee is weighing possible punishments for the Minnesota Republican after abruptly ending trial-like hearings against him on Wednesday by accepting 23 volumes of documents into evidence. The committee's special counsel, Robert S. Bennett, suggested the panel recommend to the Senate that Durenberger be publicly denounced for ``reprehensible'' financial misconduct that brought ``dishonor and disrepute'' on the chamber. Denouncing a senator is tantamount to condemning or censuring him, and it usually leads to the end of the lawmaker's career, authorities said ``In a collegial body, it's a severe reprimand,'' said Don Ritchie, associate Senate historian. The committee had scheduled up to two weeks of hearings, but it agreed to a request from Durenberger's attorney, Jim Hamilton, to end the sessions early because of the legal fees Durenberger would incur. The panel's vice chairman, Sen. Warren B. Rudman, R-N.H., said the committee could make its decision based on written documents and statements by Durenberger, his lawyer and Bennett. ``There is not a great deal of dispute about the facts,'' Rudman said. ``There's obviously a great deal of dispute about what those facts mean.'' A decision is not expected for several weeks. Durenberger made an emotional appeal to the committee Wednesday to show compassion. He denied he intentionally broke ethics rules but acknowledged he had caused the Senate ``real damage.'' The committee has found ``substantial credible evidence'' that Durenberger violated Senate rules and the law by evading honoraria limits through a book promotion deal and hiding his ownership in a Minneapolis condominium so he could collect travel reimbursement for staying there. Ritchie said the committee can essentially render or recommend one of three different punishment for a senator: _A reprimand, also called admonishment or rebuke, that would require only the approval of the committee. _Censure, denunciation or condemnation. This would require a majority vote of the Senate. _Expulsion. A two-thirds vote of the Senate is required to remove a member. The Senate has almost never acted to expel a member who wasn't convicted of a serious crime, Bennett said. Sen. Joseph McCarthy, R-Wis., was ``condemned'' by the Senate in 1954 for his witch hunts of supposed communists. Two others have been censured since then: Thomas Dodd, D-Conn., in 1967; and Herman Talmadge, D-Ga., in 1979, both for financial misconduct. In this century, two others have been censured: Benjamin Tillman and John McLaurin, South Carolina Democrats who were punished for a brawl on the Senate floor, Ritchie said. The damage to a senator's career has almost always been mortal. Tillman is the only censured senator who won re-election.

DOC.HEAD: Library Will be Complete Even Without Documents, Spokesman Says
DOC.TEXT: The Nixon presidential library opening next month will become ``the most complete source of materials about President Nixon and his life and presidency,'' even though it will have no original White House documents, a spokesman says. The White House announced Wednesday that President Bush will attend the library dedication in Yorba Linda, Calif., on July 19, almost 16 years after Nixon resigned the presidency in the wake of the Watergate scandals. Former Presidents Reagan and Ford also will attend. Former President Carter was invited, but said he had another engagement. Nixon's assistant, John Taylor, said from the former president's office in New Jersey that Nixon would be accompanied by former first lady Pat Nixon and members of their family. Only the exhibit portion of the library, along with the restored home in which Nixon was born in 1913, will be immediately opened to the public. The archival portion, containing pre- and post-presidential Nixon papers and copies of White House documents, is scheduled to open sometime next year. Nixon resigned from office on Aug. 8, 1974, after the House Judiciary Committee had voted to impeach him on grounds that included a cover-up of White House involvement in a break-in at Democratic Party headquarters in the Watergate office building. Both Reagan and Bush have conferred at times with the former president, but Bush's appearance in Yorba Linda will mark one of the few times since Nixon's resignation that a president has shared a public platform with him. Reagan spoke at a departure ceremony at the White House on Oct. 9, 1981, as Nixon, Ford and Carter left for Egypt to represent the president at the funeral of slain Egyptian President Anwar Sadat. Nixon has not attended any of the four Republican national conventions since his resignation. Unlike other presidential libraries, the Nixon library will be operated by the private foundation that raised the money to build it. The eight others are run by the National Archives, as the Reagan library will be after it opens its doors next year in Simi Valley, Calif. Also unlike the other libraries, the Nixon library will not contain original White House documents. They are stored in a National Archives building in Alexandria, Va., where they are being processed and made public. Taylor said the library will contain papers from Nixon's years in the House and Senate, his campaigns and the period since he left the White House. He said it will also house some of his vice presidential papers. Some were deeded to the government and are in a National Archives facility in Laguna Niguel, Calif. In addition, the Nixon aide said, preliminary discussions are being held about making copies of some 1.5 million pages of presidential documents now in the Alexandria archives building. ``When the archival level of the library opens in 1991, the Nixon library and birthplace will be the most complete source of materials about President Nixon and his life and presidency,'' Taylor said. ``It will include copies of all critically important presidential documents.'' The National Archives holds about 40 million pages of Nixon White House documents, but Taylor said these ``include a lot of Christmas cards and Life magazine collections of staff members and various less important documents.'' He said copying would focus initially on the special files of the archives' Nixon Project, containing work papers of the president and key staff members. ``We have not even begun to investigate how the copies are going to be made,'' said Taylor. ``It may even be that technology will enable us to transfer the documents to a laser disk at a much reduced cost.'' Jill Brett, public affairs director of the National Archives, said agency regulations permit people to do copying on their own, with approved equipment, under staff supervision. Congress gave control of Nixon's presidential papers to the archives in 1974. Nixon challenged the act's constitutionality, but it was upheld in 1977 by the Supreme Court. The former president also lost a challenge to regulations adopted under the act.

DOC.HEAD: Space Agency Looking for a Few Good Ideas
DOC.TEXT: The agency that put men on the moon, rescued lost satellites and sent spacecraft to distant planets is looking for new worlds to conquer. And it wants ideas from you. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration decided recently to go outside the agency, away from its normal contractors, to get fresh thinking on ways to establish a permanent base on the moon and put humans on Mars. Not only the public, but universities, engineering schools and professional science and engineering organizations were invited to contribute. NASA even set up a toll-free telephone line for the ideas: 800-677-7796. NASA Administrator Richard H. Truly has sent more than 3,200 letters to the heads of schools asking for their help. The Rand Corp. in Santa Monica, Calif., will filter the good ideas from the bad before passing them on to Washington. The toll-free number reaches Rand. The search for ideas, from an agency noted for turning science fiction into reality, started last July with a pledge by President Bush that the United States was headed back to the moon _ ``this time to stay'' _ and would push on to Mars. Bush set that goal in a speech observing the 20th anniversary of man's first footsteps on the moon. More recently, he said the Mars landing should be accomplished by the 50th anniversary of the Neil Armstrong-Buzz Aldrin moon landing _ in the year 2019. A NASA-sponsored study estimated the cost of going to Mars at $500 billion or more, a sum that would require more money each year than the agency's current budget for all space activities Vice President Dan Quayle, as head of the National Space Council, has been pressing NASA officials to go outside normal channels and ``cast their net widely'' for more efficient and cheaper ways to return to the moon and to plant the U.S. flag on Mars. The space agency also has been challenged by others, such as Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory which said astronauts could be landed on Mars for $11 billion using existing rockets and inflatable spacecraft. And the Aerospace Industries Association has urged that a study group be set up outside of NASA to receive proposals and evaluate them. In answer to such unaccustomed outside pressure, Truly announced his agency was organizing a formal search-for-ideas program called the Space Exploration Initiative. He named retired Air Force Lt. Gen. Thomas P. Stafford, a former astronaut who has four times flown in space, including a trip around the moon. The plan calls for Stafford's group to study the ideas after they've been cleared by Rand. Truly said his outreach program ``will leave no stone unturned to reach out the best and brightest in our nation.'' That includes even a phone call to 800-677-7796.

DOC.HEAD: World Markets Edgy Over U.S. Grain Prospects
DOC.TEXT: Foreign countries that rely on imports of corn and other coarse grains are getting edgy about the global supply and price outlook for the year ahead, an Agriculture Department analysis says. ``While the outlook for the 1990 world wheat crop continues to be generally favorable, heavy rains across the major corn-growing areas of the United States have delayed corn planting,'' the report said Wednesday. As a result, it added, this is ``causing concern in the marketplace about prospects for the 1990 U.S. crop and _ because of the United States' dominance _ the world's coarse grain price outlook as well.'' In addition, analysts said there has been ``rather strong late-season import demand'' for coarse grains that ``will result in a large drawdown in world coarse grain stocks'' during the remainder of the 1989-90 season. On Tuesday, the USDA projected 1990 corn production at 8.1 billion bushels, up from 7.53 billion harvested last year. Despite the increase in production, total exports and domestic use are even larger, meaning that the nation's stockpile will dwindle further in 1990-91. Also, the projections are highly tentative and were based on yield trends and planting indications derived from March surveys. Wet weather, however, has delayed planting this spring and has prompted concern about reduced yields and acreages. The department's first official corn estimate will not be released until Aug. 9, along with prospects for soybeans, sorghum, cotton and other 1990 spring-planted crops. Looking further at the global coarse grain situation, which includes sorghum, barley and rye as well as corn, the report said ``shifting trade patterns'' are beginning to affect the outlook for the 1990-91 marketing year. ``Crop shortfalls, especially in Brazil, are already influencing import patterns,'' it said. ``In addition, foreign exportable supplies will be limited until new-crop output is available for export.'' Thus, it said, there will be continued greater reliance on the United States for coarse grain, particularly as the 1990 crops develop. According to the projections, corn prices at the farm may average in the range of $2.35 to $2.75 per bushel in the 1990-91 marketing year that will begin Sept. 1. Prices in the current season are forecast to average $2.35 to $2.40 per bushel.

Five researchers have been inducted into the Agriculture Department's science hall of fame. The five were recognized this week by the Agricultural Research Service, the department's chief scientific agency. To be eligible for the hall of fame, scientists must either be retired or eligible to retire and to have gained recognitions by national and international colleagues for their work. R. Dean Plowman, administrator of the agency, said the achievements of the five ``are worthy of being emulated by younger agricultural scientists.'' The five new inductees included: _Retired biologist Theodore C. Byerly, who died May 17, for his investigations of how nutrition, genetics and the environment affect the hatching of chicken eggs. His findings helped boost the hatching rate to 85 percent from 65 percent. His studies were based at the agency's Beltsville, Md., research center until 1963 when he left for a series of high-level USDA administrative posts. _Retired geneticist Gordon E. Dickerson, who was responsible for developing major concepts and methods to genetically improve productivity in cattle, sheep, swine and poultry. Before retiring in 1987, Dickerson worked at the Roman L. Hruska Meat Animal Research Center in Clay Center, Neb. _Chemist Robert W. Holley, who won the 1968 Nobel Prize in physiology and medicine. He discovered the class of ribonucleic acids now known as transfer RNA, one of the essential building blocks in the body's instruction system for the production of protein. Holley's work for the agency was based at the Plant, Soil and Nutrition Laboratory in Ithaca, N.Y. He is now with the Salk Institute in San Diego. _Wheat researcher Virgil A. Johnson, co-developer of 28 improved wheat varieties that have set new standards of productivity for hard red winter wheat. Varieties that he worked on have, at times, made up as much as 25 percent of the total U.S. wheat acreage. Before retiring in 1986, Johnson worked at the agency's Wheat Research Unit in Lincoln, Neb. _Corn researcher George F. Sprague, whose integration of theoretical quantitative genetics and applied plant breeding led him to develop methods that have resulted in the production of superior corn hybrids. Sprague was leader of the Corn and Sorghum Investigations Laboratory at the Beltsville center before he retired in 1973.

Public comment is being sought on an Agriculture Department proposal to allow salty whey to be covered by federal whey standards. Salty whey is the moisture removed from cheese curd through a salting process. The standards would apply to whey after the salt is removed. Daniel D. Haley, administrator of the department's Agricultural Marketing Service, said Wednesday that current rules allow U.S. grading only on whey that originates as saltless. At present, salty whey represents a small amount of the total whey that results from cheesemaking and is discarded because it is so salty, he said. But new technology can economically remove the salt from salted whey. Dried and condensed whey are significant sources of vitamins and protein for humans and are used to some extent in animal feed, Haley said. Comments on the proposal can be sent by Aug. 13 to: Director, Dairy Division, AMS, USDA, Room 2968-S, P.O. Box 96456, Washington, D.C. 20090-6456. Copies of the proposal are available from that office, or telephone 202-447-4392.

DOC.HEAD: Cat Bashed to Death; Owner's Friends Charged
DOC.TEXT: A cat owner whose pet was bashed to death by his friends says he may have inadvertently spurred the attack when he shouted the animal's name _ Killer. ``I yelled out, `Killer!' and I think they misunderstood what I said,'' said Gary Hegler, 43, of Fort Gratiot Township. Michael Wood, 34, and John Zeros, 33, were arraigned Wednesday on charges of maliciously destroying an animal belonging to someone else. The offense carries up to four years in prison. They were released on $3,000 bond. Hegler, who wasn't charged, said his two friends were at his house Firday. ``One guy was petting the cat and it scratched him. The cat was thrown and it stunned the cat,'' he said. ``I called out her name _ `Killer!' I don't think they understood what I said.''

DOC.HEAD: Barbara Bush Quotes Michael Jackson in High School Commencement Speech
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush capped her springtime round on the commencement circuit exhorting black high school graduates to remember their most important role model ``is the man or the woman in the mirror.'' ``If you want to make the world a better place, take a look at yourself and make a change,'' the first lady said, quoting a line from a Michael Jackson song, at the graduation ceremony Wednesday at Dunbar High School. She proffered much the same advice about the importance of family, joie de vivre and altruism that she gave the graduates of Wellesley College in a nationally televised address June 1. But if some seniors at that exclusive women's college had misgivings about whether President Bush's homemaker wife was a suitable role model, the 287 Dunbar graduates gathered in Constitution Hall seemed thrilled to hear from her. Senior class president Michael Watts said he was ``proud that such an outstanding lady, and the first lady of our nation, cares so much to take the time to encourage, motivate and demonstrate to us that we can better ourselves.'' Dunbar once was a showcase school for the District of Columbia's brightest black students in an era of official segregation. Today it is a regular public school in a crime-ridden neighborhood. Mrs. Bush read from the roster of such famous graduates as blood plasma pioneer Dr. Charles Drew and Brig. Gen. Benjamin O. Davis and called Dunbar ``one of the most illustrious high schools in the country.'' She urged the graduates to ``believe in something bigger than yourself. Get involved in some of the big ideas of our time,'' such as cleaning up the environment or fighting hunger and homelessness. ``The most important role model you will ever have is the man or the woman in the mirror,'' she said. ``If you think you can't, you won't. And if you think you can, you will.'' She reminded the graduates that life is ``supposed to be fun. Find the joy in life.'' And finally, as she told Wellesley graduates, she admonished the Dunbar students to put family ahead of career. ``However important your obligations as a doctor, a lawyer, or business leader will be, you are a son or a daughter first, a husband or a wife first, a mother or a father first,'' she said. ``If you decide to have children, love them, listen to them, put them first.'' Mrs. Bush also was the commencement speaker at Southeast Community College in Cumberland, Ky., the University of Pennsylvania and St. Louis University last month, and she spoke at Kennebunk High School near her summer home in Maine last Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Two Horses, One Rear End, Two Politicians
DOC.TEXT: It was a rare sight on Capitol Hill: a Hungarian teaching a Texan about horses. It started when Rep. Tom Lantos, a Hungarian-born Democrat from California, used a Hungarian proverb to illustrate to Secretary of State James A. Baker III why the United States should stop its dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organization. Unfortunately, it backfired. ``It seems to me that there comes a point where we cannot square the circle, and our desire to continue the dialogue (with the PLO) and our desire to live up to our own commitments and fight terrorism conflict,'' Lantos said at a hearing of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. The United States has threatened to cut off the dialogue begun in 1988 because of a thwarted attack by a PLO faction on an Israeli beach May 30. ``As an old Hungarian proverb says, `You can't ride two horses with one rear end.' And I believe that that's really what we have been attempting to do for some time. And if you think about it, that's an awkward posture,'' Lantos said. ``I've never seen two horses with only one rear end,'' responded Baker, a Houston lawyer-turned-politician. ``No, riding _ the rider has to have one rear end,'' Lantos tried to explain. ``I understand,'' said Baker, laughing. But Lantos wasn't sure. ``Two separate horses, one rider,'' he insisted. ``I understand. One rear end. I was only ...'' Baker said before being interrupted. ``OK, I just want to be sure.''
