DOC.HEAD: White House Says Soviets Haven't Gone Far Enough
LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: The White House says Moscow's easing of economic pressure on Lithuania is a positive step but doesn't go far enough. ``It's better than doing nothing,'' presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. ``It's not the ultimate objective.'' Even so, the administration clearly was pleased by an announcement Wednesday that the Kremlin would restore 15 percent of Lithuania's natural gas supplies. The fuel and other raw materials were cut off April 18 to pressure Lithuania to abandon its drive to secede from the Soviet Union. The crisis over Lithuania has emerged as a major stumbling block in U.S.-Soviet relations. Bush has called on the Soviet Union to lift the sanctions and conduct a dialogue with leaders of Lithuania, as well as the other Baltic republics of Estonia and Latvia. Bush told a news conference it was ``good news'' that Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev had met Tuesday with the leaders of three Baltic states. ``I hope that what we saw ... is a first step in a dialogue that will lead to the self-determination that we strongly support,'' he said. The president did not comment on the easing of the economic sanctions, but his national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, said, ``It's encouraging.'' On Capitol Hill, Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said, ``I am hopeful that the Soviet Union will lift its economic blockade against Lithuania and I welcome Soviet steps toward that end. Both sides should exert every effort to ensure that negotiations are conducted in an equitable and respectful manner.'' However, Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., said: ``I think 15 percent is a slap in the face; you're trifling with people. The embargo remains in place.'' Fitzwater said the administration still wants a full lifting of the embargo. ``Our role is to nurture this process toward a dialogue that will result in self-determination,'' he said. Fitzwater said the easing of the embargo was a positive step. ``How significant it is, we don't know. It may not be a big step.'' Lithuanian officials said Moscow offered to lift the embargo only if they agreed to stop implementing the March 11 declaration of independence for the duration of negotiations over the future of the Lithuania. At his news conference, Bush said the United States hopes for a ``peaceful resolution of this confrontation, one that will result in dialogue, negotiation ... in lifting of this economic blockade against Lithuania.'' Referring to Gorbachev's meeting with the Baltic leaders, he said, ``I don't want to overstate it, but I was very, very pleased to see this occur in the wake of ... what I think was a successful summit meeting.'' The reporters, representing newspapers outside of Washington, also quizzed Bush on several other subjects, including offshore oil drilling and the fate of the northern spotted owl. Bush said his long-delayed decision on restricting oil drilling off the coasts of Florida and California would be made within days. He said he wanted to make sure he had all the information he needs. ``We're still getting opinions,'' the president said. ``It's a very hot item, as you know.'' Bush said protection of the northern spotted owl under the Endangered Species Act left him ``very much concerned about the potential loss of jobs.'' Vast tracts of forest in the Pacific Northwest would be shut to timber operations if the owl is deemed endangered, and Bush said the law gives the administration ``very limited control'' in making such a determination. On another subject, the president said the Soviet Union should stop subsidizing the government of Cuba, which he said receives $5 billion a year. ``If that totalitarian and brutal society were not propped up by an enormous subsidy from the Soviet Union, I have every reason to believe that Cuban people would have a right to achieve the freedom that other countries have achieved,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Music Industry Seeking to Head Off Sales of Improved Recorders
DOC.TEXT: Composers and publishers are making a last-ditch effort in Congress to ban U.S. sale of tape recorders that can make near-perfect copies of musical recordings. With foreign manufacturers poised to introduce so-called digital audio tape _ or DAT _ recorders this summer, a group of music publishers, writers and composers urged a Senate panel Wednesday to reject legislation that would allow the machines to be sold if they incorporated anti-copying technology. The bill before the Senate Commerce communications subcommittee, sponsored by Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., would require manufacturers to install computer-chip technology called a Serial Copy Management System on DAT machines. This system would allow a user to copy a compact disc onto as many digital audio tapes as desired, but the tapes could not be copied. The bill is based upon an agreement reached in Athens last year between manufacturers and record companies. But songwriters and composers, who like musicians earn a percentage of the price of each recording sold in stores, complained that their interests were disregarded. The artists believe the virtually perfect copying ability of DAT machines will make them more popular than today's relatively inferior tape recording systems that use ``analog'' technology to duplicate sound waves. Digital taping use the 0s and 1s of computer language to re-create sound. Artists claim the bill for the first time would legalize home copying _ a gray area of copyright law that Congress increasingly is being pressed to resolve through legislation. George David Weiss, representing the Copyright Coalition, said the bill ``forces songwriters to give away copies of our music without payment of any kind.'' Manufacturers say these claims are unfounded and that home taping actually stimulates record sales. However, the artists found sympathy Wednesday from several subcommittee members, including the panel's chairman, Sen. Daniel Inouye, D-Hawaii. ``The time has come for the people who create to get a piece of the action,'' Inouye said. A move for quick passage of the Senate DAT bill hit another snag Wednesday when a recording industry executive said he wanted to hold talks with manufacturers on a new technology called ``digital compact cassette.'' The new compact cassette machines from Philips Consumer Electronics will record and play both digital and analog tapes. Jay Berman, president of the Recording Industry Association of America, said the Philips machine had not been discussed in Athens and he wanted to talk to manufacturers about it. He suggested an amendment to the Senate bill that would allow the commerce secretary to bring such new technology under the proposed DAT law. Berman said 380 million blank tapes are sold in this country each year and that home taping costs record companies at least $1 billion in lost sales annually. But he said Japanese manufacturers oppose a royalty system for copying. Ralph Oman, U.S. register of copyrights, told the hearing that because of the unresolved issues on DAT, ``It is questionable whether it will ever be mass produced.'' Edward Murphy, president of the National Music Publishers Association, said the coalition had asked Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher and U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills to ``look at the DAT problem.'' He also said the coalition still was considering suing to block imports of DAT machines.

DOC.HEAD: House Vote on Flag-Burning Amendment Likely to be Close, Both Sides Say
DOC.NOTE: EDs: ``Tuesday'' in 10th graf is cq
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: A House vote on a proposed constitutional amendment to ban flag burning is likely to be close, even though a powerful subcommittee is recommending against tampering with the Bill of Rights. ``I don't want to see it change and become America, the land of the free as long as you agree _ that loses me,'' Rep. Pat Schroeder, D-Colo., said Wednesday as the plan emerged with an ``adverse'' recommendation from the House Judiciary subcommittee on constitutional and civil rights. Supporters said the flag deserves special protection. It ``represents all that America stands for, embodies all that American means,'' Rep. Craig James, R-Fla., told the subcommittee. The panel voted 5-3 to send the proposed amendment to the Judiciary Committee with an ``adverse'' recommendation. The ``adverse'' label is guaranteed to have little or no impact as the measure races toward the floor where both sides say the real decision will be made. Five subcommittee Democrats, all critics of the amendment, voted in favor of sending it forward with the ``adverse'' recommendation. Three Republicans voted against, because they wanted a ``favorable'' recommendation. Plans call for a House floor vote as soon as the amendment clears the Judiciary Committee, perhaps as early as next week. Both sides say the vote is likely to be close. House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., says he plans to break custom and participate in the vote. Aides said Wednesday that in the year he has been speaker he has voted only once, on Nov. 16 for a governmental ethics bill. ``As much as I deplore and decry flag burning, much as I am alienated and annoyed and repulsed by it as are other Americans, this is not a time when we should rush to tamper with the most sacred political document of our country's tradition,'' Foley told reporters on Tuesday. Supporters are openly threatening to use this fall's campaign season to bombard critics with television ads in a rerun of the flag-waving politics of the 1988 presidential campaign. To become part of the Constitution, the measure would have to win two-thirds majorities in both houses and approval in 38 state legislatures. Retired Supreme Court Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, who has cautioned against amending the Constitution, declined to give advice to his former colleagues or anyone else on the subject as he appeared with Barbara Bush on the White House lawn along with students who won a poster contest honoring the Constitution. ``Retired justices shouldn't have any thoughts as to what present justices should do,'' Burger said. The proposed amendment will not come under Senate scrutiny until June 21 when Judiciary Chairman Joseph R. Biden Jr., D-Del., plans a hearing. ``I don't think its going to be an overwhelming vote, but we will get the two-thirds,'' said Rep. James Sensenbrenner, R-Wis. Subcommittee Chairman Don Edwards, D-Calif., a leading opponent of the amendment, merely said it would be ``very close.'' The amendment would allow the federal government and the states to pass laws outlawing desecration of the flag. The Supreme Court on Monday threw out last year's statute barring flag mutilation, saying it violated the right to free speech. Edwards was asked if Democratic critics were hurrying the measure to the floor to head off lobbying campaigns by supporters. ``We ought to get it behind us so we can go on with the country's business,'' he replied. Edwards told of passing out copies of the Constitution to students in Prague recently and how eagerly those young people snatched up the document. ``I hate to think that I'd have to stand before the same students and say, yes, here's the Bill of Rights, but we've just weakened it, we've just mutilated it,'' Edwards said.

DOC.HEAD: Southern Baptists Bring Bibles, Tracts to French Quarter
DOC.TEXT: When the saints come marching in, Southern Baptist evangelists hope a few Bourbon Street regulars will be among them. The blue-suited evangelists who have been attending a convention by day descended into the notorious French Quarter at night Wednesday to distribute Bibles and religious tracts outside such places as Le Booze Bar and The Orgy. ``I was here eight years ago, and Bourbon Street was still Bourbon Street. Not one thing has changed,'' said Glen Harlin of Odessa, Texas. ``Our witnessing may not have an effect on the atmosphere of this part of the city _ this street _ but it will affect the individuals we reached.'' The more than 40,000 Southern Baptists in the city for their annual meeting this week have proved to be a mixed blessing. Bar owners, for example, were singing the blues. ``I think they ought to go back to where they belong,'' said C.W. Williams, as he stood idle in one of the doorway bars along Bourbon Street. ``It's the worst week I've had since December.'' Tourism officials said the Baptists nevertheless are filling hotel rooms and restaurants during a traditionally slow period. ``They might not be the highest ticket items, but they're certainly a boost at this time of year,'' said Beverly Gianna, spokeswoman for the Greater New Orleans Tourist Commission. ``We love them anyway.'' So do those assigned to keep the peace in the French Quarter. John Laine, a security guard, said things are a lot quieter on Bourbon Street since the Baptists came to town. ``It makes things a lot easier for us,'' he said. Still, the scattered evangelists along Bourbon Street only served as a reminder of the dismal business being done this week by the strip joints and bars in what one Southern Baptist referred to as ``the edge of hell.'' Jim Monaghan, owner of Molly's at the Market, said he and other bar owners would prefer a convention of auto dealers. ``We're looking for two-fisted hard drinkers,'' he said. A woman who gave her name only as Bunny said a group of Baptists insulted her and other dancers at the Bourbon Burlesque Club. ``I think they should stay out of our club,'' she said. Jay Strack, president of the Conference of Southern Baptist Evangelists, said he was able to reach an amiable agreement with a youth trying to con him into paying $30 for a shoeshine. ``I said, `Would you settle for $5 and I won't preach to you more than 15 minutes?' He said, `It's a deal.''' Before he went to Bourbon Street on Wednesday, Strack challenged thousands of church workers attending the Conference of Southern Baptist Evangelists to distribute 10,000 New Testaments and religious tracts on city streets. Strack, who said he was physically and sexually abused as a child and once participated in the seamier side of life in the French Quarter, said it is important for Baptists to evangelize in such places. ``I think one of the things that's happening to a lot of Southern Baptists is we're against those sins, but not against those people,'' he said. Some doubted whether visiting religious groups such as the Southern Baptists would have any lasting impact. ``They think they'll go down there and convert a few pimps and prostitutes and drunken people, but they've done it before. And it hasn't worked,'' said the Rev. Robert Fisher of St. Augustine Catholic Church. ``And it probably won't work now.''

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 32,668.11, up 296.34 points, or 0.92 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Decision Revives Flag Day
DOC.TEXT: Two huge flags were being unfurled in New York City and tiny banners were being planted on lawns in a Minnesota town for Flag Day today _ a practically forgotten holiday until the Supreme Court helped stir affection for Old Glory. Shopkeepers reported flag sales are up as well since the high court on Monday struck down a federal law against flag burning. The ruling has spurred the drive for a constitutional amendment against desecrating the flag. In Philadelphia, 14-year-old Katie Appelget was to read her winning essay in the annual ``What the Flag Means'' contest. The ceremony was sponsored by the museum and home of Betsy Ross, who legend has it made the first Stars and Stripes. ``The American flag unites us all,'' wrote Katie. ``Even though we may speak different dialects or come from different backgrounds, we share one common element, the American flag.'' Two 20-by-30-foot flags were to be hoisted today at the site of the 1964 World's Fair in New York City, the first time flags of that size have been flown since the fair. Later in the day, 100 newly arrived Soviet Jews were to be given American flags and a boat ride past Ellis Island and the Statue of Liberty, courtesy of a tourist boat company and the New York Association for New Americans. In Northfield, Minn., some 25 workers at a realty planned to place 3,000 plastic flags on residents' lawns. Broker Millie Berg said city officials and police have given the go-ahead, but flag-planters will skip the homes of two people who complained. Not everyone in the town of 10,000 was happy with the ``intrusive political statement,'' as resident Gloria Stier put it. In Omaha, Neb., merchants said flag sales have been booming since the Supreme Court ruling. ``A lot of it has to do with the flag controversy,'' Paul Cullen, sales manager at Cosgrave Church Goods, said Tuesday. Cullen said the store sold 40 flags in two days this week, compared to just five on an average day. Although sales increase around Memorial Day and the Fourth of July, he said, customers usually forget about Flag Day. Buyers this year seem to be ``making a statement'' by buying flags for Flag Day, said Dave Anderson, owner of Anderson Catholic Supplies.

DOC.HEAD: Collapsed Firm Sells Coat Racks, Refrigerators to Highest Bidder
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report; also on financial wire. Ross-Dove cq with hyphen in 16th graf.
DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. has gone from junk bond king to junkyard dog. Once the envy of Wall Street, the investment house known for its financial wizardry and hardball tactics came under the auctioneer's gavel Wednesday in a sale of items from the corporate kitchen to the CEO's rolltop desk. Lot 1, Power Shred model 410 paper shredder, went for $450. Bidding was brisk. ``Now Drexel never had to shred any documents, so it's probably never been used,'' motor-mouthed auctioneer Ross Dove said to laughter from thousands of potential bidders at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. The one-day auction included office furniture, brass coat racks, stock trading desks, personal computers and other paraphernalia from the firm, the epitome of American corporate finance in the go-go 1980s. The auction, the first involving a Wall Street firm's leftovers, was expected to raise a few million dollars _ a pittance compared to Drexel's megadeals and megasalaries but money nonetheless for hungry creditors. In a three-day preview, prospective buyers and curious others, the sorts of people attracted to movie stars' funerals, wandered through Drexel's deserted headquarters near Wall Street examining items tagged for sale. ``Some of the conference rooms make you wonder why they didn't go under sooner,'' said Michael Reilly, a systems developer at the brokerage Murphy & Durieu, who planned to bid on computer equipment. A framed bond from a $100 million New Jersey municipal offering hung in one office, cardboard charts detailed a proposal to the Idaho Power Authority, resumes were scattered on a desk. Cabinets bulged with files no one bothered to empty when the firm went out of business in February. ``You could start a business picking through these files,'' said Barry Newman, a real estate broker from Pawling, N.Y., who videotaped choice pieces of furniture. Spooky reminders of the firm's ascent and fall were scattered about. A Wall Street Journal dated Feb. 14 detailed the firm's decision to file for bankruptcy court protection a day earlier. Two bound volumes of confidential documents from a big 1985 takeover sat in a conference room. They apparently belonged to top Drexel dealmaker Leon Black, whose name was etched in gold leaf in the lower right-hand corner. But most didn't care that Mike Milken May Have Sat Here. Some knew only bits of the Drexel saga _ ``What was his name? Mitchell?'' said J.C. Riemer, a video producer from Lebanon, N.J., who planned to bid on office furniture. ``I felt there was a certain amount of arrogance there,'' said Linda Armani, whose market research firm was hoping to grab 10 personal computers. ``Everything was in fabulous shape. Meanwhile the company was teetering.'' More than 8,000 people registered to bid at the auction conducted by Ross-Dove Co. of Foster City, Calif. Slides depicting items on the block were projected on a big screen. A total of 4,022 lots were tagged. Still looking for the best deal, Drexel expects to make far more at auction than by selling off its innards on its own. ``They'll get a lot more money this way,'' said Ross Dove, chairman of the auction house whose next sale is a $100 million piece of Arizona land. Some prospective buyers were turned off by the escalating bids. Joe Loiacono, a Brooklyn accountant, hoped to spend $1,500 on Lot 26 to furnish a six-person office. He dropped out long before the winning bid of $3,500. ``There's no bargains here,'' Loiacono said, leaving the hall. Then again, on Wall Street, Drexel never was known for giving away something for nothing.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Would Discuss Final Settlement of World War II in Berlin
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A Baker III wants to discuss elements of a final settlement of World War II at a major meeting in Berlin June 22, a State Department official says. Baker will meet with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze and their counterparts from France, Britain and East and West Germany. Raymond G.H. Seitz, assistant secretary for European affairs, said at a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee hearing Wednesday that Baker will not present a draft treaty. He said possible topics include ``the principles that will guide the resolution of the borders issue of Germany _ part of that affects the Polish question, of course. ``And secondly there will be an effort to at least have a discussion of the elements that would make up a final settlement.'' Poland is eager to have a reaffirmation of Germany's present eastern border to forestall any future claim by a united Germany of territory that is now Polish. Seitz said the United States wants to terminate the rights of the four victors of World War II over Germany, such as their occupation of Berlin. That would be part of the final settlement, he added. ``Our belief is that (the victors' rights) ought to be terminated as quickly as possible and probably at the time of German unification,'' he said. The United States would then recognize the unification though it may not be legally necessary, he said, explaining that was because the United States already recognizes West Germany as the successor state to Adolf Hitler's Third Reich, which included both East and West Germany. Earlier in the day Baker outlined to the full Foreign Affairs Committee his ideas on a settlement. ``It would be counterproductive to perpetuate a special status for Germany or to prolong any limitations on German sovereignty,'' he said. ``Discriminatory limitations could only sow the seeds for future instability. For this reason we are opposed to using these discussions to put limits on strictly German military capabilities.'' He added that limits could be discussed at different negotiations at the same time as other ``confidence building measures.'' Such measures are usually discussed at the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. They include advance notice of military maneuvers, arrangements for foreign officers to observe them and other ways to assure governments that they will not be the victims of a surprise attack. Many Europeans see CSCE as the major security organization of the future. It includes the United States, Canada, the Soviet Union and 32 European governments. Seitz said that at its meeting in Copenhagen, Denmark, last week the United States approved observer status for Albania, the only European government which has not joined. Seitz told the subcommittee that Baker would support making the conference into an international organization with a permanent headquarters. An aide told a reporter that Germans would like to see the headquarters in Berlin, while Czechoslovaks are pushing for their capital.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Likely to Oppose Bush Effort to Shield NASA From Cuts
DOC.TEXT: Congressional Democrats are likely to react negatively if the Bush administration tries to use high-level budget talks to help shield the space agency from spending cuts. Officials said Wednesday that the White House will ask congressional negotiators at the talks to give special treatment to the space program, which is one of President Bush's top domestic priorities. But following the latest session of the bargaining on Wednesday, Democrats said opposition was likely if the administration wants its favorite programs singled out for protection from budget slashes. ``We've had a lot of committee chairmen who say, `Hey, I want mine''' protected as well, said Sen. Wyche Fowler, D-Ga., a budget negotiator. Officials speaking on condition they not be identified said the White House would propose that negotiators work out a specific spending figure for next year's budget for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. In budget summits of past years, administration and congressional officials agreed to a single spending amount covering thousands of domestic programs, including NASA. The budgets for individual agencies were then determined by Congress during the regular legislative process. Bush would thus greatly enhance his role in determining NASA's budget if it is negotiated directly between White House and congressional negotiators. That would be important to the administration because Congress does not want to increase the space agency's budget by as much as the president would like. The administration's proposal to consider NASA separately would also leave the thousands of remaining domestic programs vulnerable to cuts that may be agreed to by budget bargainers. Negotiators are looking for ways to shrink next year's federal deficit by $45 billion to $60 billion. In his budget for fiscal 1991, beginning Oct. 1, Bush proposed giving NASA $15.2 billion, a 24 percent increase over this year's $12.3 billion. That was the largest increase requested for any of the government's major agencies. ``The exploration of space has benefits for the United States that go far beyond the quantifiable,'' the president said in the budget plan he presented in January. The Democratic-controlled Congress has been less generous with the space agency. NASA would receive $14 billion next year under a spending blueprint approved in May by the House. A separate plan developed by the Senate Budget Committee last month would give the agency $14.2 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Logging Restriction Will Help U.S. Influence Abroad, Senator Says
DOC.TEXT: A Senate-passed bill to restrict logging in America's largest national forest will make the United States better able to argue for protection of rain forests elsewhere in the world, a leading sponsor says. ``No longer are we going to be embarrassed about what we're doing in the Tongass,'' Sen. Timothy E. Wirth, D-Colo., said after the Senate voted 99-0 Wednesday to approve the Tongass Timber Reform Act. The bill would ban logging on more than 670,000 acres of old-growth timber in the 17-million-acre Alaskan forest, which besides being the largest U.S. forest is the largest remaining rain forest in the temperate zone. The rain forest, larger than West Virginia, shelters bald eagles, grizzly bears and prime salmon-spawning grounds. But it also sustains a logging industry that provides 3,400 jobs and sustains 25 percent of the economy in southeastern Alaska, the state's two senators argued. Sponsors say the bill was needed because too much timber was being cut from the public land and taxpayers were receiving too little in fees because of old exclusive contracts favorable to the logging industry. Sens. Frank H. Murkowski and Ted Stevens, R-Alaska, said they supported the Senate compromise version over a stricter version passed by the House. The White House has also endorsed the Senate bill, which must be reconciled with the House version in negotiations. The vote came after senators set aside a disputed amendment that would have required the U.S. Forest Service to trade mining rights in the Greens Creek area of Admiralty Island in southeastern Alaska. The exchange with the native-Alaskan owned Sealaska Corp. would have given the government other mining rights and land, including the last 6,000 acres of old-growth timber on Admiralty Island. Under an agreement worked out among senators, the secretary of agriculture will try to speed up negotiations on a voluntary land and mining-rights trade. Also, the Senate Energy and Commerce Committee will hold hearings beginning June 28 to determine if the items to be traded are of comparable value. The Senate bill would modify rather than cancel two existing timber sale contracts. Canceling the exclusive contracts with the Alaska Pulp Co. and Louisiana Pacific-Ketchikan would require the government to pay higher compensation payments to the two companies, the Office of Management and Budget says. Besides setting aside protected areas and modifying the major contracts, the Senate bill would eliminate a timber harvest quota of 4.5 billion board feet each decade. Instead, the harvest will be more actively managed by the Forest Service. Wirth and others argued that the current contract enabled the two companies to cut only the highest grade timber and sell it at below market prices. The bill also prohibits logging in so-called buffer zones along spawning streams.

DOC.HEAD: Bill Would Put New Limits on Loans to China
DOC.TEXT: A $15.8 billion foreign aid bill for the coming year includes new penalties aimed at discouraging the World Bank from making loans to China for anything other than basic human needs. The House Appropriations foreign aid subcommittee approved the sanctions on a voice vote late Wednesday, saying the United States must hold back its share of any amount lent to China beginning this year from whatever contributions it normally would make to the world lender. U.S. contributions amount to about 20 percent of money the World Bank lends, and the gesture underscored Congress' continuing impatience over what it sees as an inadequate American response to China's bloody crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators a year ago. ``This provides the bank some incentive not to go forward with these loans,'' said Rep. Matthew McHugh, D-N.J., sponsor of the amendment. ``If they disregard it, inevitably we are going to be talking about heavier punishment next year.'' Two weeks ago, the World Bank approved a $300 million loan for a tree-planting program, the largest approved since the crackdown in and around Tiananmen Square. That brought the total of loans approved for China since the massacre to $440 million. The overall foreign aid bill for the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1 seeks to begin what subcommittee Chairman David Obey, D-Wis., called an adjustment of foreign aid to new world realities. It would shift some $200 million from funds the administration had sought for military aid to support the political and economic reforms in Eastern Europe. Rep. Mickey Edwards, R-Okla., sought and failed to boost the military aid total from $3.8 billion to $4.1 billion to bring it closer to this year's $4.25 billion and to the nearly $5 billion sought by President Bush. ``The threat to the West is not from Soviet tanks,'' Obey argued in a vehement rebuttal, but from the possibility that Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev's reform efforts could fail. ``The world has changed,'' he said. For Eastern Europe, the bill would provide $430 million for economic development of countries undergoing the transition to market economies, and $70 million for the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. The bank contribution would be made contingent on forgiveness of what Obey termed uncollectable debts owed by Poland to foreign creditors, primarily in West Germany. The subcommittee also moved to grant to Pakistan another one-year waiver of a requirement that it refrain from developing nuclear weapons in order to be eligible for U.S. aid. But even Pakistan's supporters abandoned what one lawmaker called a long-running charade that the weapons do not exist. Rather than contend that Pakistan does not possess nuclear weapons, as supporters have in the past, Rep. Charles Wilson, D-Texas, argued that the country has not detonated one. The bill also includes a provision that would withhold half of El Salvador's expected $85 million in military aid and make further cuts or release of the withheld amount dependent on the progress of peace talks between the government and the leftist rebels who have waged a 10-year civil war. That provision was seen primarily as an incentive for the Bush administration to resume discussions with congressional Democrats aimed at finding a new bipartisan policy toward El Salvador, where 70,000 have died in the decade of fighting. The bill also would reduce the aid now flowing to Turkey and Greece to $400 million and $280 million, respectively. Turkey is getting $500 million this year, and Greece $350 million.

DOC.HEAD: Plane Crash, High-Speed Chase in Two Days
DOC.TEXT: Peter Elchaar and Karen Hopwood can be forgiven for wanting a couple of quiet nights at home. In less than 48 hours, they have survived a plane crash and found themselves in the middle of a high-speed car chase. ``I think we've had enough excitement for one week,'' said Elchaar, 25. On Tuesday, they were among five passengers in a light plane that lost power at 7,000 feet and plunged into a swamp. No one was injured. So they went to visit friends on Wednesday night to describe their miraculous escape. Driving home at 2 a.m., they found themselves behind a speeding stolen car and in front of a pursuing police cruiser. As Elchaar pulled over to get out of the officers' way, the driver of the stolen car dodged traffic, skidded on wet pavement and veered across several lanes to make a turn. ``He nearly collected us,'' said Ms. Hopwood, 20. The stolen car stopped shortly afterward, and police arrested the 19-year-old driver.

DOC.HEAD: Burned Paint, Gas Fumes After Night of Violence
With PM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Throughout the city the smell of burned paint mixed with the odor of gasoline fumes, recalling a day and night of violent clashes between police and anti-government protesters. The streets were no longer so crowded. Still, about 400 pro-government demonstrators, just as many soldiers and police occupied Victory Square in front of government headquarters early today. They had responded to a call by President-elect Ion Iliescu to protect the building _ and were backed by armored personnel carriers. Government supporter Alexandru Nicolae was diverting cars from the square, much the same way people did during the December revolution that toppled Nicolae Ceausescu. He said his people had to be very careful. ``We apprehended someone who was about to set the cars parked here on fire and shouted `Death to Communists.' Is this democracy?,'' he asked. Dan Iosif, a leader of Iliescu's ruling National Salvation Front, announced over a loudspeaker that workers would come from various counties, including 27 trainloads of miners, to protect the government. The square was rather quiet. Not so at television headquarers, where cordons of soldiers blocked the entrance and ambulances went in and out, taking injured people to the hospital. ``They provoked us and we planned not to answer back. But when they hurt our colonel we could not take it any more,'' said a steel-helmeted soldier at the gate. At a different part of the station, about 200 demonstrators threw stones and firebombs. The protesters accuse state television of biased programming and have demanded that an independent station be established. Someone poured water down from the upper floors to keep the fire under control. But the demonstrators persisted, and every time a bottle touched the wall or a window, the crowd gave a loud ``hurrah!'' Later, the army advanced far enough to make the firebomb-throwing impossible. The situation took a more dramatic turn at the devastated police headquarters, where demonstrators threw firebombs at soldiers and two tanks, which fired lengthy rounds to repel them. It was impossible to get too close to the building because of the firing. Demonstrators had earlier ransacked the headquarters and set it ablaze, along with cars and other vehicles parked nearby. Finally, it was back to University Square, where the violence started before dawn Wednesday when police cleared a square where anti-Communist demonstrators had held out and blocked traffic for 53 days. With the pro- and anti-government demonstrators scattered in different parts of the capital, the square was very peaceful. Only about 50 people were there, along with charred buses, trucks and cars. Nearby streets looked like they had been through a civil war: thousands of bits of shattered glass, tracks on the asphalt from passing tanks, a big pool of blood on a boulevard, traces of gasoline from the firebombs. Asked what the few people in the square thought they were going to do next, Marian Falticeanu shrugged his shoulders. ``Let's wait and see what the new morning brings,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: World War II Love Story Helps Soften ``Ugly Japanese'' Image
DOC.TEXT: When Lt. Kobori of the Japanese Imperial Army died in the arms of his pregnant Thai wife, blase teen-agers and staid society matrons alike confessed to breaking down in tears. And millions of other Thais were left with images of the Japanese very different from those they previously held: the fanatical, samurai-style warriors of World War II or today's aggressive economic leaders. Since January, the Thai public has become addicted to a serialized TV drama called ``Khuu Kam,'' or ``Star-Crossed Lovers.'' The series ended last weekend. Bangkok's notorious traffic jams thinned when episodes were broadcast, and social engagements often were canceled. Senior government officials have reportedly cut meetings short in order not to miss the program. Fans wrote the producers, pleading for a change to the tragic ending. Others proposed marriage to the stars. The series was based on a still enormously popular novel penned by Vimol Siripaiboon in the late 1960s. It tells of a Japanese officer who falls in love with a Thai college undergraduate during World War II. Although Kobori carries his army sword even into the bedroom, he is willing to do anything for his love, even neglect some of his soldierly duties. Angsumalin, the Thai woman, hides her own strong feelings for him out of Thai patriotism until the moment Kobori dies in an Allied bombing raid. Thais already have seen the novel adapted twice on the screen and twice for television. The popularity of the latest version has stemmed in large part from the appeal of Tongchai McIntyre, one of Thailand's top pop singers. The handsome son of a Thai mother and Scottish father put in a soulful performance. Many Thais say the portrayal of the hero is an effective antidote to the hard-edged image of Japanese in Thailand. Japanese are resented by many Thais for their aggressive business dealings and what Thais see as an attempt to gain an economic stranglehold on the country. One Thai who has criticized aspects of Japanese behavior is Mechai Viravaiyda, a leading development expert and former actor who portrayed Kobori in the first adaptation in 1969. ``This is very, very good public relations for the Japanese,'' he said. ``But if you look at Kobori's character this type of Japanese has yet to be born.'' ``With Kobori's notions about the heart being more important than flag and country, he would have been put in jail _ or at least given a low-ranking job in a Japanese corporation,'' Mechai said. Some in the large Japanese community here agree that ``Khuu Kam'' makes for some of the best public relations for Japanese in years. But some have reportedly taken offense at a scene in which Kobori releases an American prisoner of war, as well as depictions of Japanese soldiers as lax and rude. Nonetheless, it is unlikely that such a basically sympathetic portrayal would be featured in countries like South Korea, the Philippines, Indonesia and other Asian countries which suffered at the hands of the Japanese army in the last world war. Thailand's wartime experience was mixed. The Japanese army was allowed to use Thai territory to invade neighboring Burma and in 1942 Bangkok declared war on the Allies. The Thai ambassador in Washington, however, refused to deliver the declaration and started an anti-Japanese ``Free Thai'' movement. As the war drew to an end the Japanese in Thailand became increasingly harsher, but many were unaffected. Some of Thailand's wealthiest families owe their fortunes to dealings with the Japanese. Among most Thais today, ``Khuu Kam'' evokes emotion rather than history. ``I've read the book several times and every time I have to cry,'' said Pharadee Narkkarphunchiwan, an office administrator. Her father, she said, was due to have an eye cataract operation but postponed it so he could watch the final episode.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Edge Up, Dollar Down
RETRANSMITTING a0461 to CORRECT cycle designator.
DOC.TEXT: The key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange edged up Thursday, while the dollar closed lower against the Japanese yen. The dollar ended at 153.53 yen, down 1.02 yen from Wednesday's close of 154.55 yen. It opened at 153.90 yen and ranged between 153.35 yen and 154.25 yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average rose 296.34 points, or 0.92 percent, ending the day at 32,668.11. The index gained 49.46 points Wednesday. Securities traders attributed the Nikkei index's gain to the yen's strength against the dollar. ``Most participants were assured by the yen's rise, and some investors made index-linked large-scale purchases,'' said Kozo Hasunuma, a trader with Yamaichi Securities Co. But the strength waned as investors became cautious ahead of a series of releases of U.S. economic indicators due later Thursday and Friday, he said. Producer prices for May are scheduled to be released later Thursday, with consumer prices for May and trade for April due Friday. Currency dealers said the dollar's low opening followed its weakness in New York overnight. Masato Hayashi, a Bank of Tokyo trader, said a rumor that the Bank of Japan sold dollars in the Sydney market prompted selling of the U.S. currency in Tokyo. Yuichi Tsuchiko, a dealer with Fuji Bank, said the dollar's decline resulted from market players buying the yen in exchange for the British pound to take profits on the pound's recent appreciation. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond rose to 87.98 points from Wednesday's close of 87.62. The yield fell to 6.975 percent from 7.05 percent.

DOC.HEAD: EPA Announces New Air Pollution Rules
DOC.TEXT: New or remodeled chemical plants will have to meet tighter standards to cut the release of smog-producing compounds under new Environmental Protection Agency rules. The agency also announced new requirements Wednesday for 1,400 hazardous waste treatment, storage and disposal facilities that should cut emissions by 76 percent. The synthetic organic chemical industry will need to spend $38.5 million initially to comply with the new anti-smog rules, designed to cut emissions by 30 percent and will bear an additional $21.6 million in annual costs, the agency said in a statement. The rules require use of ``best demonstrated technology'' for air oxidation, distillation, and reactor processes involving production of more than 200 chemicals. The EPA estimates the rules will reduce the emissions of smog-forming volatile organic compounds by 58,000 tons per year on equipment built or substantially modified since 1983. About 70 percent of the 3,300 plants likely to be affected by the new rules are in Texas, Louisiana and New Jersey. The hazardous waste rules are supposed to cut emissions by about 28,000 tons per year from all affected installations, no matter when built. Complying with the rules will cost the industry $128 million to $151 million initially and then $33 million to $46 million per year, the EPA said. In many cities, waste treatment plants are major sources of air pollution because chemicals stripped out of the sewage stream are released into the atmosphere.

DOC.HEAD: Eighteen Tons Of Chicken Roll Recalled
DOC.TEXT: Charlie's Meat Products of Amarillo, Texas, is recalling 18 tons of deli-sliced chicken roll from three southwestern states because it may be contaminated with food poisoning organisms. The Agriculture Department said Wednesday the recall involves 36,000 pounds of ``Charlie's Country Smokehouse German Brand Breast of Chicken.'' The chicken roll is carried by ABCO and Safeway stores in Arizona, Homeland stores in Oklahoma, Kroger in Dallas and Fort Worth, Texas, and Homeland and Tom Thumb stores in Texas. The chicken roll is sold to the stores in 7{-lb. plastic packages carrying the establishment number ``EST. 13301'' in the label's USDA inspection seal. The product is shipped in 15-lb. cartons containing two packages, the agency said. Consumers usually buy the product sliced at deli counters. Consumers with questions about the recall may call the toll-free USDA meat and poultry hotline at 1-800-535-4555 from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. EDT, Monday through Friday. Recorded information will be provided at other times.
DOC.HEAD: Marine Deserter Turns Himself In After 21 Years In Canada
DOC.TEXT: A former U.S. Marine private who fled to Canada after basic training has ended 21 years of self-exile and is awaiting a decision on his fate. Ron Jacko, a Cleveland native who has lived in Toronto since 1969, turned himself Wednesday in at the Marine base in Quantico, Va., said Capt. Betsy Sweatt. Jacko, 42, said he would ask the base commander, Lt. Gen. W.R. Etnyre, to allow him to avoid a court-martial and leave the Marine Corps with an ``other-than-honorable discharge.'' If Etnyre grants that request, Jacko could be free in a few weeks, Sweatt said. ``Every case is handled individually,'' the spokeswoman said. In the meantime, the Marines will check Jacko's background to make sure no other charges are pending against him. He will not be imprisoned but will be confined to the base, living in a barracks with other privates. ``He'll be treated as any other Marine PFC,'' Sweatt said. ``He'll be in what's called a casual status. He can see his civilian lawyer any time he needs to and a military lawyer will also be assigned to assist him.'' Returned deserters are no novelty at Quantico. ``We average about three a week,'' she said.
DOC.HEAD: Bush Nominates Ambassadors To Uruguay And Mozambique
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has selected new U.S. ambassadors for Uruguay and Mozambique. He announced his intention Wednesday to nominate Richard C. Brown, 50, a career diplomat, to the South American post. He is currently special advisor for international security at the Defense Department and is a former deputy chief of mission at the American Embassy in Montevideo, Uruguay. He would succeed Malcolm Richard Wilkey. Bush announced he would nominate career diplomat Townsend B. Friedman Jr., 50, as ambassador to Mozambique, succeeding Melissa Foelsch Wells. Since 1987, Friedman has served as director of Southern European affairs at the State Department.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Barry Trial, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts from Mayor Marion Barry's broadcast speech Wednesday in which he announced he would not seek re-election this year.

I've come to realize that I cannot neglect the spiritual side of my life. That is, I take one day at a time; I must take it with God as my guide. ... Now is a time for healing for me personally and for you politically. And whatever I can do to help you heal, I'm willing to do it. I'm willing to go to any lengths. ... My supporters and political polls have indicated, that if I were to run, I could win. But what good does it do to win the battle, if in the process I lose my soul? And in my heart I believe it's time for me to serve you, and God, in other ways. Therefore, tonight I'm announcing that Marion Barry would not be a candidate for re-election for my fourth term. ... I'm proud to say to you tonight with the grace of God, and a good treatment program, today is my 145th day clean of any chemicals. For some, that's a short time. For those of us in the recovery community, it's a long time. I continue to try to keep this achievement _ one day at a time. In terms of my decision, I know many of you probably feel that my decision not to seek re-election is the wrong thing for me to do. But I hope that you will let go of your strong feelings and believe that my announcement tonight is the best thing for me personally, best for my family _ that is, my wife and son _ but also for my beloved city that I respect so deeply. I prayed on this. And I think it's the best decision. Let me say to you in strong terms, this decision is not related to my legal situation. It is related to my recovery and to what I know is best for my wife and son, who've suffered so long in this ordeal. ... The candidates who've announced for political offices in the district, particularly those who are running for mayor, have not been able to address the issues to the full time and attention of you all, because of the distraction that my personal situation has caused. I want to assure you though, that even though I'm not seeking re-election, I'm not abandoning my commitment to the city. I've not forsaken you. I've been reminded over and over that God is not through with me yet. And in my heart I believe it's time for me to serve God and you in other ways.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls, Nikkei Edges Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar plunged against the Japanese yen today after rising for more than two weeks, while the key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange edged higher. The dollar closed at 153.53 yen, down 1.02 yen from Wednesday's 154.55-yen finish. It opened at 153.90 yen and ranged between 153.35 yen and 154.25 yen. Since May 28, it had climbed on 11 of 12 trading days, gaining a total of 5.10 yen before today's fall. The dollar opened lower in Tokyo after an overnight decline in New York, and fell further on a rumor that the Australian and Japanese central banks had intervened in the Sydney market by selling dollars, dealers said. Toru Kanai, a foreign exchange analyst with New Japan Securities Co., said the dollar continued to fall in the afternoon as trading houses sold the currency at around 153.50 yen. ``But the currency did not fall much further because many participants picked it up around 153.40 yen,'' he said. ``Market players are basically inclined to sell the dollar because they think U.S. economic growth has been slowing. But participants are waiting to see a series of economic figures coming out later today and Friday,'' Kanai said. The United States was to announce its May wholesale price index later today, followed by the May consumer price index and April trade figures on Friday. About $15.9 billion changed hands in spot trading, up from Wednesday's $10.6 billion. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average climbed 296.34 points, or 0.92 percent, closing at 32,668.11. The index rose 49.46 points the previous day. Traders said share prices were higher across the board. ``The Nikkei's increase was largely due to the yen's strength against the dollar, which reassured market players,'' said a trader with Nomura Securities Co., speaking on condition of anonymity. But some market players remained on the sidelines to await the U.S. economic indicators, he added. First section volume was estimated at 450 million shares, unchanged from the previous day. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 88.09 points at 5 p.m. (4 a.m. EDT) from Wednesday's 87.62-point close. The yield fell to 6.955 percent from 7.050 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Smashed Car of Quake Freeway Collapse Survivor to Be in Museum
DOC.TEXT: Believe it or not, Ripley's plans to feature in its new museum the smashed car in which a 57-year-old man survived for 89 hours in the rubble of an earthquake-flattened Oakland freeway. Buck Helm, the burly Oakland longshoreman who survived without food or water, was rescued on Oct. 21 but died less than a month later of respiratory failure. Ripley's Believe It Or Not said Wednesday that displaying the smashed Chevy Sprint at its new Buena Park museum would be a tribute to Helm's heroism. The museum opens in August. Dubbed ``Lucky Bucky,'' Helm gave hope to weary rescuers and came to symbolize human indomitability, said Edward Meyers, vice president for exhibits and archives for Ripley Entertainment Inc. in Toronto. ``That's the whole angle, a memorial to the will to survive, one man's heroism amid widespread devastation,'' he said. Helm's car will be displayed amid twisted metal bars and actual pieces of the freeway to offer a sense of what it was like in the tiny pocket of rubble, Meyers said. Until two weeks ago, Helm's car had been stored with 55 other vehicles towed from the fallen freeway at an auto yard in East Oakland. Helm's ex-wife, Lorrie Helm, donated the car to Ripley's in December. She said she she hoped the exhibit would be a reminder of nature's fury and of the alleged faulty construction that led to the freeway collapse. ``Because of Buck and all the people who died, there should be something out there to remind us that it could happen again,'' she said. The quake that struck Northern California on Oct. 17 had a magnitude of 7.1 on the Richter scale, killed 67 people and caused an estimated $7 billion in damage.

DOC.HEAD: Fighting Reported Fierce As Latest Bid For Talks Fails
DOC.TEXT: Government troops backed by helicopter gunships, artillery and thousands of reinforcements fought fierce battles with Tamil rebels today in the embattled north and east, witnesses and officials said. The government's latest bid to end the fighting collapsed when rebel leaders said they were unwilling to come to the strife-torn eastern town of Batticaloa for talks, said Deputy Defense Minister Ranjan Wijeratne. Defense Secretary Gen. Cyril Ranatunge told a news conference that government troops were launching aerial attacks against the rebels in Batticaloa. ``In such a situation there should be civilian casualties,'' he said. So far, at least 90 government troops, rebels and civilians are believed to have died in four days of fighting, the worst violence since negotiations began between the government and the dominant rebel Tiger militia in May 1989. One unconfirmed report said Tiger rebels also killed 125 to 150 policemen who were among 600 officers captured by the Tigers when they overran 11 police stations Monday. The bloodshed has raised the specter of a return to the all-out war between Tigers and government forces that prevailed before India sent thousands of peacekeeping troops to Sri Lanka in July 1987. India withdrew its forces in March on Sri Lanka's request after an unsuccessful 32-month effort to disarm the Tigers. Tamil rebels have been fighting for more political autonomy in Sri Lanka since 1983. They claim they are discriminated against by the majority Sinhalese. Tamils form 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people, while Sinhalese make up 75 percent. Today, residents of Vavuniya, 135 miles north of Colombo, said Tamil Tiger rebels continued their seige on police stations in the east and northwest. Vavuniya was the only northern town reachable by telephone from Colombo. Residents said government troops using helicopter gunships, artillery and reinforcements were repulsing attacks by the rebels. They said the rebels lost at least 15 men in an abortive attack on the Kilinochchi garrison, 45 miles north of Vavuniya. Two defending soldiers were also killed. Wijeratne described the fighting as ``fierce'' but said that did not mean the government had ``closed the doors on negotiations.'' Still, the prospect for a quick settlement appeared bleak. A cease-fire announced Tuesday night for Wednesday was ignored. And the government has rushed about 4,500 fresh troops to the region. Wijeratne said that while President Ranasinghe Premadasa hoped to resolve the problem through discussions, military steps were being taken to protect lives and government property. He said he was confident government troops would defeat the Tigers if war again broke out. The Tigers took virtual control of the northeastern districts after Indian peacekeeping forces withdrew. At least 11,000 people, including 1,200 Indian soldiers, have been killed in the Tamil war since it started in 1983. Another 6,000 have been killed since 1987 in a backlash to Tamil demands whipped up by ultranationalist Sinhalese guerrillas.

DOC.HEAD: Storms Rumble Through Midwest, Northern Plains
DOC.TEXT: Storms rumbled through the Midwest and northern Great Plains today, while much of the rest of the nation enjoyed fair weather. Today's forecast called for thunderstorms over Michigan, Illinois and Missouri, and rain and storms stretching from Idaho and Nevada into Nebraska and South Dakota. Storms and high winds raced across Illinois on Wednesday, damaging several small planes at Rockford's airport, downing trees and damaging roofs. Temperatures rose above 80 degrees in most areas east of the Rockies, with readings in the 90s as far north as Illinois and Indiana. In the desert Southwest and in parts of Texas, the mercury edged above 100. The high for the nation was 105 at Phoenix. DOC.HEAD: Landslide Kills 11 In Southern China
DOC.TEXT: Eleven people, including seven children, were killed when a landslide sent huge boulders crashing into a mountain village in southern China, the official Xinhua News Agency said. Six others were seriously injured and 65 buildings destroyed in the June 9 disaster in Jiang village in the Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region, the report said. It said homes were demolished and trees uprooted by boulders as 23 feet in diamete. The report did not say what caused the avalanche, which sent about 7,800 cubic yards of dirt and rocks down the mountainside.

DOC.HEAD: Clear Majority for Fundamenalists, Gov't Says
DOC.TEXT: The government said today that the fundamentalist Islamic opposition has won a clear majority of seats in Algeria's municipal and provincial elections. The fundamentalist victory in the country's first multiparty elections since independence from France in 1962 was the first outright election victory for an Islamic fundamentalist party in any Arab country. In neighboring Tunisia and Morocco, which have refused to recognize the fundamentalists as political parties, leaders expressed fears that the apparent success of extremism in Algeria would eventually affect all the countries of northern Africa. In France, the ruling Socialist Party called the fundamentalist victory ``cause for deep concern.'' It cited the fact that numerous women had their right to vote ``confiscated'' by their fathers or husbands. Under the Islamic family code, men can vote on behalf of their wives or daughters without their permission. Sheikh Abassi Madani, president of the victorious Islamic Liberation Front, thanked the Algerian people and government Wednesday for the ``high level of political maturity'' that made his victory in Tuesday's voting possible. He demanded the dissolution of the National People's Assembly, to be followed by legislative elections. But he stopped short of asking for the resignation of President Chadli Bendjedid. National elections are now scheduled for February 1992. The government had no immediate response to Abassi Madani's demand. The ruling National Liberation Front, for 28 years Algeria's only political party, had been widely expected to win because of its grip on government machinery and the media, as well as its greater financial resources. It holds every seat in Parliament. But the official Algerian News Agency said today that with a third of the official results tabulated _ including those from most of the large cities _ the 16-month-old Islamic Salvation Front had won by absolute or relative majorities. Earlier, Interior Minister Mohamed Salah Mohamedi told reporters the fundamentalists had won 327 seats of the first 612 races tabulated. The ruling party was running second with 208 seats. The French news agency Agence France-Presse, citing sources, said the fundamentalists captured councils in Algeria's four largest cities _ Algiers, Oran, Constantine and Annaba _ and swept 45 of the 48 provincial councils. Final official results were expected this evening. Abassi Madani dismissed as ``incidental'' the decision of two of Algeria's major political parties to call for a boycott of the elections. However, it was the boycott by former President Ahmed Ben Bella's Movement for Democracy in Algeria and Berber leader Ait Ahmed's Front of Socialist Forces that made the fundamentalist victory possible. The average total of abstentions was above 45 percent, the highest in any Algerian election since the end of colonial rule. In the Kabylie region which is Ait Ahmed's homeland, average voter participation was less than 15 percent. The parties urged the boycott because they feared the balloting was rigged in favor of the ruling party. They also objected to the short period of time they were given to prepare for the ballot. The boycott ``weighed heavily in the (Islamic fundamentalist) victory,'' the state news agency said. Officials of all parties complained Wednesday of widespread irregularities, including multiple voting, missing ballots and interference at polling places by outsiders and election officials. It was not clear exactly what the impact of the fundamentalist victory would be in Algeria, a country of 24 million. Politically, most major decisions are made by the central government _ local councils cannot, for example, impose Islamic law on a local basis. But the victory clearly has emboldened the fundamentalists, who are now likely to operate as a government-in-waiting and expect their demands will be taken seriously. Socially, the victory is likely to make Algerians concentrate more on the issue of what kind of society they want. Non-fundamentalists are likely to realize they will need to become more active and organized if they want stop the fundamentalists' advance. Abassi Madani, a 59-year-old philosophy professor, denied his movement wishes to turn the country into a one-party religious state. ``We guarantee the freedom of all who have ideas on Algeria's future,'' he said. The Islamic Salvation Front seeks to establish the Islamic legal code, the Sharia, as law. The party assigns women to a subservient role. None of the front's 12,000 candidates for office in Tuesday's voting were women. For months, fundamentalist supporters have been accused of harassing single women and disrupting nightclubs in Algiers. The party boasts 650,000 members. Many are drawn from the ranks of unemployed youth, who are attracted by the party's fiery mix of Islam and politics. The National Liberation Front was the sole political party until constitutional changes in February 1989 opened the way to competing parties. The party was forced to end its monopoly on power after soldiers killed scores of people in October 1988 riots sparked by deteriorating economic conditions.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Named Assistant Men's Basketball Coach
DOC.TEXT: Bernadette Locke has been named an assistant men's basketball coach at the University of Kentucky, the first woman to hold such a post in a major collegiate sports program. Locke, 31, has been an assistant coach of the women's basketball team at the University of Georgia since 1985. She was the university's first female All-American in 1980-81. Kentucky head coach Rick Pitino said Wednesday that Locke's duties would be the same as those of his other assistants but that she would have special emphasis on career placement. ``After today I'm part of the team and I want to be treated like the other coaches,'' Locke said. Mary Fenlon was an assistant for the men's basketball team at Georgetown University, but ``her purview was the academic side of things,'' said Georgetown spokesman Bill Shapland. Pitino said he expects no problems involving Locke's access to the locker room. ``There are a lot of men's coaches in women's sports today,'' he said. ``As soon as they shower up, they're in the locker room. Before the game it's no problem because they're all dressed.''

DOC.HEAD: British Legislators Approve Passports for Thousands From Hong Kong
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4 grafs for 3rd pvs, `Conservative lawmaker...' to UPDATE with Chinese reax. Picks up 4th pvs, Foreign Secretary...'
DOC.TEXT: The House of Commons early today approved legislation to allow 50,000 heads of households from Hong Kong and their families to enter Britain when the colony is handed back to China in 1997. Some members of the Conservative Party fought their government's proposal, saying it would flood the country with Hong Kong refugees. In Beijing, the Chinese government reiterated its objection to the plan. ``The Chinese government has repeatedly expressed its just and solemn position and demands with regard to this question,'' Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Li Jinhua said at a weekly briefing. ``Now the British side still is pursuing its plans to change the citizenship of some Chinese citizens in Hong Kong. The British side will be held responsible for all the consequences arising therefrom,'' she said without elaborating. In London, Conservative lawmaker Tony Marlow said the household heads and their families could total 250,000 people of different culture and ethnic background. He said the government's duty was to put Britain first. Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd has said he wants key people to remain in Hong Kong after Chinese rule. He says the best way to achieve that is to guarantee them a British passport so they know they can always leave. The House passed the bill by a voice vote, sending it for consideration to the House of Lords, the non-elected upper chamber of Parliament. The Lords can approve the bill, amend it with the Commons' approval or reject it. Rejection, which is unusual, would probably result in the government trying to reintroduce the proposal with a new bill. Under an agreement with Britain, the colony on China's southeastern coast reverts to Chinese rule in 1997. China has pledged to retain Hong Kong's capitalistic and legal systems for 50 years after the takeover, but fear has mounted in the territory that Beijing may renege on its promises. Those fears grew deeper after the Chinese government's bloody crackdown on the pro-democracy movement in Beijing one year ago, in which troops killed hundreds of unarmed civilians. Former Conservative Party chairman Norman Tebbit led opposition to the bill and tried with other Tories to persuade legislators to reduce the number of immigrants from Hong Kong. Labor legislators opposed the bill on opposite grounds, calling it elitist and divisive.

DOC.HEAD: Oil-Eating Bacteria to Be Tested on Supertanker Spill
With PM-Tanker Blast, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Coast Guard has tentatively approved the experimental use of oil-eating bacteria on the spill from the supertanker Mega Borg. State officials had suggested the approach and discussed it Wednesday with the Environmental Protection Agency, Coast Guard and other agencies. ``It's worth a try. Anything we can do to clean up the spill, we'll try,'' Coast Guard Capt. Thomas Greene said. He said, however, he did not consider the technique a major part of the cleanup, which also involves skimmers, booms and chemical dispersants. As the federal on-scene coordinator, he asked state officials to submit a plan today on how they will conduct the test without interfering with the salvage efforts in the Gulf of Mexico. The process, called bioremediation, uses naturally occurring bacteria to reduce oil to an emulsion of fatty acids. This emulsion sinks and is consumed by marine life. Bioremediation has been used for years to clean up hazardous waste sites, treat sewage and wastewater, extract oil from tight geologic formations and clean some rocks on shore after the Exxon Valdez accident in Alaska last year, said Texas Land Commissioner Garry Mauro. But this will be the first time bioremediation has been used in the water to clean up an oil spill, he said. ``Now we have the chance to put to real use innovation and new technology that can provide all of us with a means to avoid the potential environmental devastation of an oil spill,'' Mauro said. Greene said the Coast Guard would provide a boat to scientists to apply the sandlike bacteria to the oil slick. B.J. ``Buck'' Wynne III, chairman of the Texas Water Commission, said he expected to mix the bacteria in 100-gallon tanks of salt water and shoot it through hoses from a Coast Guard cutter. Wynne and Mauro suggested using 100 pounds of the bacteria a day for three to four days on freshly spilled oil near the vessel. The test will cost the state about $50,000, Mauro said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Pleads Guilty to Killing Goats, Poodle
DOC.TEXT: A man was sentenced to a month in jail for killing a woman's poodle and two goats with an ax after she refused to date him. Darrell Wayne Williams, 33, had pleaded guilty Wednesday. He was also ordered to pay $235 in restitution. The dog and goats found mutilated Aug. 2 belonged to Rosie Maynor, a friend and neighbor of Williams.

DOC.HEAD: This Dick Tracy Loved the Movie But Couldn't Solve the Crime
DOC.TEXT: Capt. Dick Tracy of the Chicago Police Department loved the movie. But he couldn't solve the crime. ``I suspected somebody else,'' said Tracy after watching the movie ``Dick Tracy.'' Judging from the gasps from the audience, very few people suspected the culprit. Tracy _ yes, that's really his name _ was among 500 guests at a preview of the movie here Wednesday night. Woodstock was the home of Chester Gould, who created the Dick Tracy comic strip. The movie opens nationally Friday. ``It was great,'' said Tracy, who at 56 is just two years younger than the comic strip. ``It had an interesting plot, lots of action, the scenes were uniquely done.'' Others agreed. ``It was fabulous,'' said Woodstock resident Betty Hamilton. ``I was never a Dick Tracy fan, but now I am. I'm going to go back and read all the comic books.'' ``The cinematography is phenomenal and Madonna is great,'' said Bob Billimack, a real estate broker from Woodstock. Guests paid $100 each for seats at the Woodstock Opera House. Proceeds will benefit the Chester Gould Memorial Library, a museum planned to commemorate the late cartoonist and his famous characters like 88 Keys, Mumbles, Breathless and Pruneface. Black-haired, steely-eyed Dick Tracy first appeared during the Depression, the first comic strip to deviate from the ``funnies'' approach and venture into graphic violence. Gould created _ and knocked off _ enough bad guys and really bad guys for Woodstock and the whole country. ``I told myself, `I'm gonna draw a guy that shoots them,''' Gould said before his death at age 84 in 1985. ``It was kind of nice to have a cop who would shoot first and ask questions later.'' There's plenty of shooting in this fast-paced, rock 'em sock 'em Walt Disney movie, but it's not graphic enough to jeopardize the PG rating. On the other hand, Madonna, playing the sultry speakeasy singer Breathless, has some racy scenes that probably wouldn't make the comic pages of a family newspaper. Capt. Tracy, a 34-year veteran officer, said the ``flirtatious'' scenes were important. ``The fact that Dick Tracy didn't succumb to that is part of the movie. Warren Beatty played the role the way we would like to imagine police were in that time. At least Dick Tracy wasn't wearing an earring,'' Tracy said, alluding to two Peotone, Ill., police officers disciplined recently. ``Besides, Madonna was in town and unfortunately, she didn't crawl around on my desk like that,'' Tracy said, laughing. The movie culminated a week of Dick Tracy Days in this town 50 miles northwest of Chicago. Disney officials were adamant that the real premiere, with stars, 3,000 invited journalists and all, is today at Florida's Walt Disney World. But Woodstock Mayor Jim Shoemaker said that showing won't be the same. ``You'll see brighter red carpet, bigger celebrities, fancier limousines,'' he told Jean O'Connell, Gould's daughter, who planned to travel to Orlando for the premiere. ``The one thing that Orlando's not going to have is 14,000 people who loved your dad. Dick Tracy, you're finally home,'' Shoemaker said, his voice choking with emotion.

DOC.HEAD: Groom's Cold Feet Turn Wedding Reception Into Party for Homeless
DOC.TEXT: A bride-to-be whose fiance got cold feet has decided to hold the reception anyway _ and invite the homeless. Kathleen Gooley, 41, said she stood to lose the caterer's $4,000 non-refundable deposit when her husband-to-be backed out of the June 23 wedding. ``The money is tied up anyway,'' she said. ``Why not give it to the needy?'' Her best friend and would-be maid of honor, Rinda Farnham, contacted homeless shelters and drug rehabilitation clinics. So far, about 30 people are on the guest list, and there is room for 118. ``I hope we can make people who are less fortunate have a nice dinner and a nice day,'' said Farnham.

DOC.HEAD: Minister Denies Blaming Low Birthrate on Educated Women
DOC.TEXT: A highly influential Cabinet minister is denying he blamed Japan's plunging birthrate on the higher educational levels being reached by women, news reports and government officials said. The alleged remark received extensive news coverage, and one women's leader said Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto had no understanding of the concept of equality between women and men. Hashimoto was quoted as telling a Cabinet meeting Tuesday that Japanese women are having fewer babies in part because more are receiving higher educations. Hashimoto acknowledged Wednesday that he had called for a review of education policies in view of the dropping birthrate, but denied having singled out women's educational levels, Kyodo News Service reported. ``I am afraid we will not be able to discuss this matter seriously now,'' it quoted him as saying. A senior administration official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the government ``has no intention of denying the need for a high academic level for women.'' The comments appeared intended to head off further criticism of the reported remarks by Hashimoto, a powerful figure in the governing Liberal Democratic Party and a likely future candidate for prime minister. Liberal Democrats remember the so-called ``madonna boom'' in last year's upper house elections. Women voters, dissatisfied with a series of governing party bribery and sex scandals, propelled a record number of opposition women candidates into office. Last week, a government report said only 1.25 million babies were born last year and the average Japanese woman had only 1.57 children, the lowest levels since statistics were first compiled in 1899. Cabinet members reportedly expressed worry that a lower birthrate would result in a smaller work force, unable to support Japan's growing number of older people. Hashimoto reportedly was quoted by several Cabinet ministers, including Health and Welfare Minister Yuji Tsushima, as having questioned whether all young people needed higher education, and adding that ``women's higher education may also be related to the matter.'' But a Health and Welfare Ministry official denied today that Tsushima had reported such a comment by Hashimoto. Another Cabinet minister, Management and Coordination Agency head Jun Shiozaki, said he had misunderstood and therefore misstated Hashimoto's remarks. ``Hashimoto has no understanding of the concept of equality between women and men,'' said Aiko Carter, secretary of the Women's Committee of the National Christian Council of Japan. ``He hasn't learned the real lesson of last year's election. Women are advancing in society, and it's the men who can't keep up.'' In 1925, the average Japanese woman gave birth to 5.1 children. The birth rate has dropped since as population pressures have compressed housing space, average marriage ages have risen, costs of educating and raising children have climbed and fewer people depend on children for support in old age. In 1989, 24.5 percent of 847,153 male high school graduates entered universities and 36.7 percent of 853,636 female high school graduates entered two-year or four-year colleges, the Education Ministry says.

DOC.HEAD: Police Say Pastor Burned Down Church
DOC.TEXT: A Seventh-day Adventist pastor set a fire that destroyed his 60-year-old church in a scheme to collect insurance money for remodeling, authorities said. Paul Bray Jr., 32, was booked for investigation of arson Wednesday and held on $10,000 bail after he admitted starting the gasoline fire Sunday morning, authorities said. ``He apparently planned to burn only a portion of the church, but it got away from him,'' Assistant Fire Chief Keith Marshall said. The pastor turned himself in after investigators told him he was a suspect. ``He seemed happy to be confessing,'' Inspector Pete Tokarski said. The blaze caused an estimated $1 million damage to the wooden church, where Bray had been pastor for three years.

DOC.HEAD: Woman to Buy Ads Apologizing to Man Falsely Accused of Rape
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tod is cq.
DOC.TEXT: A woman who falsely accused a man of raping her has been ordered to run advertisements apologizing to him. District Judge John Murphy also sentenced Elizabeth Irene Richardson to six months in jail for perjury. Ms. Richardson, 24, of Lexington is sorry about the incident and will spend about $1,000 fulfilling the judge's order Friday that she run half-page ads in each newspaper in the county and 10 radio spots, said her attorney, Tod McKeone. Ms. Richardson told authorities she was raped in 1988 by a painter who had visited her home inquiring about a job. Gary Nitsch, 44, of Overton was arrested several days later. Ms. Richardson identified him from a police photo and later testified he raped her. Charges against Nitsch were dropped in February after Ms. Richardson admitted she made the accusation up to get attention from her husband, Charles K. Kenning, a truck driver often away from home. ``She was desperate to get him back and acted very impulsively without giving consideration to the thing, and it kind of snowballed on her,'' McKeone said Wednesday. Nitsch said Wednesday that although the judge is letting him approve the wording of the ads, they won't make a difference. ``You can't change a wrong to a right. And I think the sentence could have been stiffer,'' he said. ``I lost a job. I had to get a lawyer. The kids at school were saying to my kids, `Your dad's a rapist.''' Nitsch has sued four sheriff's deputies for $100,000, alleging they arrested him and searched his home without sufficient cause.

DOC.HEAD: Eleven-Year-Old Jewish Boy Stabbed In East Jerusalem
DOC.TEXT: A Palestinian woman stabbed an 11-year-old Jewish boy in the back today as he stood at a bus stop in Arab east Jerusalem, police said. The attack came two days after a Palestinian stabbed a 17-year-old Jewish seminary student outside east Jerusalem's walled Old City. The 11-year-old, identified as Idan Mizrahi, was being operated on at Jerusalem's Hadassah Ein Karem Hospital, said police spokesman Yitzhak Greif. Hospital officials said his life was apparently not in danger. The stabbing occurred at the edge of the Jewish neighborhood of East Talpiot in the Israeli-annexed eastern sector of the disputed city.
