Nir Avrahami, 8, who witnessed the attack, said the Palestinian woman, dressed in jeans and a white shirt, was also waiting at the bus stop. ``I saw her take out a knife and saw her stabbing him (Idan) in a downward direction,'' Avrahami said on Israel's army radio. Police said the suspect ran toward the nearby Arab neighborhood of Tzur Baher. Police cordoned off the Arab neighborhood and conducted searches. In other developments, a military prosecutor on Wednesday ordered that three soldiers and a civilian army employee be charged with assault and brutality in the beating of a Western news agency photographer. The prosecutor, Lt. Col. Rachel Dolev, also said four other soldiers would face disciplinary action in the March 22 attack on Havakuk Levinson of the Reuters news agency. The incident occurred near the West Bank town of Ramallah after a bus carrying soldiers and civilian army employees was stoned. Some passengers got off the bus and started chasing suspects, Dolev wrote in her decision. Levinson witnessed the chase and photographed a soldier as he led away a Palestinian youth, the prosecutor said. ``One of the soldiers charged Levinson and kicked him to the ground. The other soldiers assaulted him and tried to take his camera away,'' Dolev wrote. A reporter from Israel radio who witnessed the event said at the time soldiers beat and kicked Levinson as they shouted: ``You have to kill all the journalists and then kill the Arabs.''

DOC.HEAD: Terrorist Suspect Says Secret Police Let Her Live in East Germany
DOC.TEXT: A reputed West German terrorist told investigators that East Germany's former secret police furnished her with a phony identity and allowed her to live in the country, officials said today. Susanne Albrecht, wanted in the 1977 shooting death of a top West German banker, was arrested June 6 outside her apartment in East Berlin. On Wednesday, officials arrested another reputed West German terrorist, Inge Viett, who had been living in the East German city of Magdeburg. Both women are linked to the left-wing Red Army Faction, which has claimed responsibility for a string of bombings and killings of prominent West German businessmen over the past two decades. Both women had been living in East Germany under assumed names. East German Interior Minister Peter-Michael Diestel told a news conference today that Albrecht said she was set up with a new identity by the feared Stasi secret police of the old Communist regime. In a police statement, she said she was sent by the Red Army Faction to live in East Germany in 1979 because she believed she posed a security risk after the 1977 slaying of Dresdener Bank President Juergen Ponto outside Frankfurt, West Germany. Diestel did not say whether Albrecht admitted a role in the killing. She said she later met with a contact of the secret police in the East German city of Frankfurt an der Oder, Diestel said. She said she was informed that the East German government disapproved of the group's methods but agreed with its anti-imperialist objectives, the interior minister said. Both Albrecht and Viett are being held pending expected extradition proceedings to West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Lower, Gold Rallies after Plunge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Other European...' to correct that quoted rates are morning rates. Pick up 5th pvs, ``_1.6845 West German...'
DOC.TEXT: The dollar dropped lower against key currencies in European trading this morning. Gold prices plunged to the lowest level in four years before rallying. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 153.53 yen, down 1.02 yen from Wednesday's finish. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 153.57. Other European dollar rates compared with late Wednesday: _1.6845 West German marks, down from 1.6925 _1.4255 Swiss francs, down from 1.4335 _5.6705 French francs, down from 5.6880 _1.8945 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9045 _1,237.00 Italian lire, down from 1,241.00 _$1.1705 Canadian, down from $1.1722 The British pound was quoted at $1.7133, up from $1.7070 late Wednesday. Before today's fall, the dollar had gained 5.10 yen in Tokyo since May 28. Toru Kanai, a foreign exchange analyst with New Japan Securities Co., said the dollar found buyers at around 153.40 yen. ``Market players are basically inclined to sell the dollar because they think U.S. economic growth has been slowing. But participants are waiting to see a series of economic figures coming out later today and Friday,'' Kanai said. Spot gold crashed through the psychological barrier of $350 an ounce this morning, bottoming at $341.00 in early trading. At mid-morning, London's five major gold dealers fixed a recommended price at the higher level of $346.75 per troy ounce this morning, down from $350.15 a troy ounce late Wednesday. Gold traded at $346.00 per ounce in Zurich at 6 a.m. EDT, down from $350.50 bid per troy ounce. In Hong Kong, gold dropped $4.36 an ounce today, to close at $350.80. Some dealers said the biggest orders in the market were coming from Middle East interests, most prominently commercial players in Saudi Arabia. Arab selling was not confirmed, but analysts said developments were in line with recent moves by Arab investors who sold when gold was exposed at key technical points. Silver bullion traded late in London at a bid $4.90 a troy ounce, down from $4.95 late Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: General Strike Paralyzes Israel, Workers Demand Speedy Talks
DOC.TEXT: Israeli workers staged a general strike today to press for a new wage agreement, paralyzing the country only three days after the new right-wing government was installed. The job action by 900,000 of Israel's 1.5 million workers shut down schools, banks, government offices, the airport and the stock exchange. State-run Israel radio and television stayed off the air. Chaim Haberfeld, the No. 2 official in the Histadrut Trade Union Federation, warned that job actions would continue if the one-day strike did not lead to a quick wage agreement. ``I hope that this strike will produce some results. There is no point in striking today and then doing nothing for several months,'' Haberfeld said on Israel army radio. Finance Minister Yitzhak Modai had appealed to the Histadrut to call off the strike, saying it would cost the economy up to $150 million, the radio report said. The strike was seen as a show of strength by the left-leaning Labor Party, which controls the Histadrut and was relegated to the opposition this week after Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir formed a right-wing government. The strike, the first major job action in five years, was called to press for new wage contracts for public sector employees and workers in state-run companies. All government offices were closed, expect for the Finance Ministry whose employees defied the strike order. Public transportation operated, and shops in some areas were crowded with workers using the day off to go shopping.

DOC.HEAD: Logging Plan Attacked From All Sides
DOC.TEXT: A plan that would cut logging by almost half in Washington's largest national forest came under attack by representatives of the timber industry, environmental and landowner groups. The groups said they would appeal various aspects of the plan by the U.S. Forest Service for the Mount Baker-Snoqualmie National Forest. It will determine logging rights there for the next 10 to 15 years. The plan revealed Wednesday is a major shift in favor of recreation, and deals a ``very severe'' blow to the timber industry, said Doug MacWilliams, supervisor of the forest. He told interest group representatives at a briefing the proposed 46 percent reduction in timber harvesting would increase retail lumber costs and affect 1,800 jobs. Although representatives of affected groups had not seen copies of the complete plan, they said the would appeal. The plan was made after 10 years of research and debate. It takes effect 90 days after publication Friday. The plan can be appealed to the Forest Service. ``It's not the last action we'll take on this plan,'' MacWilliams said. Ted J. LaDoux, director of forestry affairs for Northwest Independent Forest Manufacturers in Tacoma, said his group was ``very disappointed'' by the plan. ``By no means do we consider this a balanced plan,'' he said. ``What's more, they clearly ignored the public sentiment.'' Ron D. Morgenthaler of Woodinville, chairman of the Public Land Users Society, said he felt ``shock when I look at what it did to landowners and public land users.'' Both said they would appeal. Wilderness Society Director Jean Durning said the planners made ``great steps forward'' in addressing recreational concerns. But greater logging reductions were needed, regardless of an expected decision June 23 on the Northern spotted owl, which could further reduce the timber harvest. Under the plan, about 95 percent of the roadless acreage would remain intact and 97 percent of old growth trees would remain in the year 2000. The plan also calls for construction of 220 miles of trails, rebuilding of 493 miles and maintenance of 891.

DOC.HEAD: West Germany's Hannover Chosen Over Toronto As Expo 2000 Site
DOC.TEXT: Hanover, a West German industrial city seeking a higher international profile, was chosen by a one-vote margin today to be host of Expo 2000, an ecologically oriented turn-of-the century world's fair. Hanover was selected by the Paris-based International Bureau of Expositions in a 21-20 vote over Toronto, Canada, the only other candidate after the Italian government decided to drop a campaign on behalf of Venice. Hanover, a northern city of 500,000 known for an annual trade fair, was considered a strong contender because many of the exposition bureau's member countries have close economic ties to West Germany. The bureau's 43 members, who vote by secret ballot, include 25 from Europe, 11 from the Western Hemisphere, four from Africa, two from Asia and one from Australia. It was not known which two members did not vote today. Toronto had argued that it was North America's turn, since the next two fairs are in Europe _ Seville, Spain, in 1992 and Vienna-Budapest in 1995. The bureau, formed in 1928, seeks to ensure that contending cities have an appropriate site, adequate transit, government backing and enough hotel rooms. The winning country then draws up final plans and finds sponsors, financial and public support. Hanover was the first West German city to contend for the right to host an officially sanctioned ``universal'' exposition _ the largest type of event overseen by the bureau. The city has proposed a theme of ``Man, Nature, Technology'' for the fair. The event is tentatively scheduled to run from June 1 to Oct. 31, providing an estimated 70,000 new jobs in the region and costing roughly $1 billion. In the past, some cities have backed out, as Moscow did in the 1960s, clearing the way for Canada to play host to its first fair in Montreal. Late last year, Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney wrote to the exposition bureau, extolling Toronto as ``a vibrant symbol of excellence, tolerance, humanity and pluralism.'' At that time, Venice was also in the running, but the Italian government withdrew the candidacy earlier this week. Venetians, as well as the Italian government, were divided as to whether the exposition's estimated 60,000 daily visitors would help revive the canal city or create unmanageable environmental problems.

DOC.HEAD: Convicted Officer's Partner Charged with Lying on Stand
DOC.TEXT: The partner of a Miami police officer convicted of manslaughter in two deaths that sparked a race riot was charged with lying during her testimony in the trial. Officer Dawn Campbell, 25, was relieved of duty with pay and released on her own recognizance Wednesday after the Dade County state attorney's office charged her with two felony counts of perjury during a judicial proceeding. Each count is punishable by five years in prison and a $5,000 fine. Prosecutors were openly skeptical of Campbell's testimony last November during the trial of Officer William Lozano, 31, who is appealing a seven-year state prison sentence. He was dismissed earlier this year. Lozano has said the perjury charges were filed to hurt his appeal. Campbell allegedly changed her version about the night Lozano fatally shot a speeding motorcyclist, who crashed. The crash killed a passenger, and the deaths triggered three nights of racial violence in January 1989. Lozano is a white officer born in Colombia, and the two victims were black. Campbell testified she was standing in the street and did not duck behind her patrol car when Lozano fired, an affidavit filed with the arrest warrant said. Six other witnesses testified she was on the sidewalk and ducked during the shooting, calling into question her view of the incident and her conclusion that Lozano fired in self-defense.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs first item to CORRECT Khashoggi, sted Kashoggi in 3rd graf.
DOC.TEXT: Steven A. Martindale, Washington lawyer and lobbyist known for the parties he threw, died Wednesday after complications from AIDS at age 46. He served on the staff of then Sen. Charles Goodell, R-N.Y., and turned to public relations when Goodell left the Senate in 1971. Recently he had been associated with Saudi billionaire Adnan Khashoggi and wrote a book about him published last year in Britain with the title, ``By Hook or By Crook.'' Martindale was the subject of a 1974 profile in The Washington Post describing how his parties gained him entree into the circles of the powerful.

DOC.HEAD: Former Communists Win a Majority in First Round
DOC.TEXT: A political party made up of former Communists won the opening round of voting for Bulgaria's first freely elected Parliament in more than five decades, according to final results released today. The governing Socialist Party, formerly known as the Communist Party, won the most seats in the 400-seat Parliament, defeating the main opposition alliance in direct balloting for candidates and in voting for parties. The Socialists won 172 of the 319 seats decided in last weekend's first round voting, final results showed. Under Bulgaria's complex electoral law, half the seats are distributed according to the percentage of votes each party receives. The other half go to individual candidates elected by direct ballot. The results mean the Socialist Party only needs to win 29 of 81 candidate races that will be decided in Sunday's runoff to capture an absolute majority in the unicameral Grand National Assembly, or Parliament. Bulgaria was the only country in the disintegrating Soviet bloc where the Communists, who changed their party's name in April, remained the strongest political force. The Socialist Party gained 47 percent of the proportionally distributed votes for 97 of the 200 seats contested among the parties, Zhivko Stalev, head of the Central Electoral Commission, told reporters. The main opposition Union of Democratic Forces was a distant second with 36 percent or 75 seats. Finishing third was the mainstream Agrarian Party with 8 percent and thus 16 seats, and fourth was the mostly ethnic-Turkish Movement for Rights and Freedoms with 6 percent and 12 seats, he said. Despite recurrent charges of alleged manipulation and other irregularities, Union of Democratic Forces leaders accepted the returns in principle. When the Socialist victory was first signaled by projections earlier this week, anti-Communist and Union of Democratic Forces protesters blocked traffic in Sofia, claiming the election was rigged. However, a majority of Western observers said Monday that the balloting process was essentially fair, although some of them pinpointed individual cases of infringement of the rules.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuania Plans To Call Back Workers if Embargo Eases
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with no sign yet of promised gas; officials hoping to restart fertilizer plant. Pickup 6th graf `Ryzhkov made...'
DOC.TEXT: Lithuanian officials said today that more than 1,600 workers who were laid off at a fertilizer plant will be called back to work if Moscow eases its embargo and steps up natural gas supplies. Leaders of the Baltic republic's 3-month-old independence drive said Wednesday that Moscow promised to restore 15 percent of Lithuania's natural gas needs as the two sides tried to reach a compromise. Moscow imposed a crippling embargo on many natural resources after Lithuania declared independence. Also today, Lithuanians paused to mark 49 years since the Soviets deported thousands of people to Siberia after seizing control of the republic. Lithuanian Parliament spokeswoman Rita Dapkus said there was no sign the additional gas was being provided today. However, ``Today is not a working day,'' she said in reference to the memorial day. ``And I don't think something like that would be done overnight anyway,'' she said in a telephone interview from the Lithuanian capital, Vilnius. The promised supply of 122 million cubic feet of natural gas per day, which will bring Lithuania back to about 30 percent of its usual level, will allow a fertilizer plant to reopen and 1,650 workers to return to their jobs, she said. The Soviet Union cut off the republic's entire oil supply, most of its natural gas and some raw materials in mid-April to try to force the republic's leaders to back away from their March 11 independence declaration. The shortages have forced factories to close, putting 26,000 people out of work. Ms. Dapkus said Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov on Wednesday told his Lithuanian counterpart, Kazimiera Prunskiene, some gas would be restored. Ryzhkov made no promises on restoring other supplies, Ms. Dapkus said. But the official Soviet news agency Tass quoted Mrs. Prunskiene as saying after meeting Ryzhkov in the Kremlin that the embargo would probably be lifted. The conciliatory gesture came as Ryzhkov and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev offered Lithuania a trade: cancellation of the embargo and negotiations on independence if Lithuania agrees to freeze the implementation of its independence drive during the talks. Gorbachev ``is not insisting on this precise formula,'' his spokesman, Arkady Maslennikov, told a news conference Wednesday. ``We are searching for critical solutions acceptable to all sides without degrading the dignity of people who elected the parliament that adopted those acts,'' Maslennikov said. Gorbachev and Ryzhkov met with the presidents of all three Baltic states Tuesday and, significantly softening their stance on secession, offered deals that would lead toward negotiations on the republics' independence demands. In Washington, the White House applauded the moves toward compromise. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater called them ``positive steps.'' U.S. lawmakers have suggested they would not approve a trade pact signed during the superpower summit in Washington until Gorbachev opens negotiations with the Baltic states and lifts the economic embargo on Lithuania. The trade agreement is considered important to Gorbachev's efforts to turn the ailing Soviet economy around. Estonian President Arnold Ruutel told his republic's parliament the situation was ``far from euphoric'' but that ``a tremendous change'' had taken place in the Soviet view of the secessionist demands of the three Baltic states, the Estonian news agency ETA reported. Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia were forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940 and are seeking restored independence _ Lithuania most stridently. Ryzhkov favors having Lithuania remain part of the Soviet Union under a new treaty granting the republic special status or privileges, Ms. Dapkus said. Mrs. Prunskiene did not immediately respond to Ryzhkov's plan, but the presidents of Latvia and Estonia were both reported on Wednesday to have repeated their calls for full independence. On Tuesday, Gorbachev proposed the transformation of the Soviet Union into a looser federation of more independent republics. The Soviet leader is trying to keep together his huge, economically troubled union of 15 republics with more than 100 nationalities and 289 million people.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Cholesterol-Cutting Most Important for Heart Disease Patients
DOC.TEXT: The much-touted benefits of lowering cholesterol may be especially effective for people who already have heart disease, according to a study published today. The findings, based on a 10-year research project, confirm the widely held belief that people with low levels of cholesterol in their blood are far less likely to die of heart disease than those with high cholesterol. But the study in the New England Journal of Medicine also shows that high cholesterol is especially dangerous when heart arteries are already partially clogged with cholesterol buildups. The study was not intended to see what happens when people change their cholesterol levels. The researchers wrote, however, that it suggests that ``the potential impact of changes in lipid (cholesterol) levels on the risk of death from cardiovascular disease may be considerably greater for men with pre-existing cardiovascular disease than for healthy men.'' The analysis, based on the Lipid Research Clinics Prevalence Study, was conducted by Dr. Juha Pekkanen and others from the University of North Carolina. In the study, desirable cholesterol levels were under 200, while high levels were over 240.

DOC.HEAD: The Baker Challenge Yields A Wrong Number
DOC.TEXT: A reporter who tried to take up a State Department challenge for Israel to call the White House when it was serious about peace was told today he had reached the wrong number. The sound of the White House phone ringing was played over the Army Radio's morning news show. A woman operator answered: ``White House.'' The reporter, Yaacov Eilon, told her he was following up on a statement by Secretary of State James A. Baker III on Wednesday that Israeli leaders should phone the White House ``when you're serious about this (peace talks).'' But the the operator replied: ``You would have to call the State Department. ... That number is 647-4000.'' ``You mean he (Baker) made a mistake?'' Eilon asked. ``Yes sir,'' she responded. Baker made the challenge before the House Foreign Affairs Committee. He hoped to persuade the Israelis to begin peace talks with the Palestinians.

DOC.HEAD: Europarliament Urges Member Nations To Keep Sanctions In Place
DOC.TEXT: The European Parliament today passed a resolution urging European Community governments to maintain all sanctions against South Africa until apartheid is abolished. The Parliament approved the measure 177-to-47 with 5 abstentions, a day after black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela told them a lifting of sanctions would undermine his drive to end South Africa's policy of racial separation. Mandela, deputy president of the African National Congress, is on a six-week tour of Europe and North America, calling on governments to maintain sanctions despite reforms adopted by South African President F.W. de Klerk. Jean-Pierre Cot, leader of the Socialist group, the largest in the assembly, told reporters after today's vote that ``Nelson Mandela's message was heard by the Parliament.'' The parliamentarians appealed to the 12 European Community governments to continue ``all sanctions, including economic, cultural and sporting sanctions ... until apartheid is completely and irrevocably abolished.'' The resolution also called on EC governments and the EC Executive Commission to make more money available to South Africans returning home from exile and for a ``negotiations trust fund'' to support the democratic process. The Parliament's members are elected by voters in the 12 European Community nations but have little real power. In 1986, the EC banned imports of iron, steel and gold coins from South Africa, then valued at $600 million a year. They also banned new investments in South Africa but did not halt imports of South African coal, then valued at $1.3 billion a year. Britain has lifted the ban on new investments after South Africa in February freed Mandela, who spent 27 years in prison. The 71-year-old leader was convicted of sabotage and plotting to overthrow the government. Mandela tours the United States from June 20 to July 1.

DOC.HEAD: Skeletons Claimed To Be Americans Handed Over to U.S. Embassy
LaserPhoto JBO1
DOC.TEXT: Skeletons that Vietnamese refugees said were those of 30 Americans killed in the Vietnam War were handed over to the U.S. Embassy today, officials said. The bones were to be flown to Hawaii for tests, but embassy officials said they did not know when that would happen. The bones, stuffed into seven barrels, were handed over to Malaysian police by nine Vietnamese boat people who landed Monday on the beach at Tanjung Sedili, 150 miles southeast of Kuala Lumpur. Red Cross officials said they sent the bones by truck to the U.S. Embassy. The embassy's charge d'affaires, Paul Blakeburn, said earlier he doubted the bones could be those of mising American servicemen, but that only forensic tests in Hawaii could determine whether they were. Other embassy officials said boat people previously claimed to have bones of Americans, but the claims had been proved false. The Vietnamese brought along with the latest bones identification tags bearing names and other details. They said they were found on the skeletons. Police said the refugees hoped to get preferential treatment for settlement in the United States for bringing the bones. U.S. Embassy press officer, Mary Ellen T. Gilroy, said no preference would be given even if the bones turned out to be those of Americans. Malaysian officials said the boat people would face the normal screening process, under which those deemed to be fleeing politican persecution are approved for resettlement in Western countries, and those considered economic migrants face repatriation. The nine Vietnamese have been placed in a temporary refugee camp in Mersing, near Tanjung Sedili. They were to be moved in the next few days to the Pulau Bidong refugee camp, 180 miles northeast of Kuala Lumpur, for screening. Malaysia accepts boat people only for temporary asylum. There are about 20,000 Vietnamese refugees in Malaysian camps. Police said the refugees were on their way to Singapore to hand in the skeletons to the U.S. Embassy there when their boat sprang a leak. They were forced to land at Tanjung Sedili, about 60 miles from Singapore. The Vietnamese had painted signs on the boat saying they were carrying the remains of Americans.

DOC.HEAD: India Escapes Sanctions for Trade Barriers
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration announced today it will not impose economic sanctions on India for trade barriers the United States deems offensive. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills termed India's barriers to investment by Americans and other foreigners and its exclusion of U.S. insurance companies as an unreasonable burden on U.S. commerce. But she said that retaliation was inappropriate at this time given ongoing global free trade talks. She said the administration would try to resolve its dispute with India as part of those discussions. Those discussions, being held under the auspices of the 96-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, are due to wrap up at the end of this year. India is considered a key participant in these talks, known as the Uruguay Round, because of its influence over other developing countries. Hills said India's announcement on May 31 that it would remove some of its barriers to foreign investment was a hopeful sign. ``Our message that foreign investment brings jobs, technology and prosperity may be getting through,'' Hills said. ``I hope this attitude will be reflected in India's approach to these issues in the Uruguay Round.'' The administration's decision was relayed on Wednesday to Abid Hussain, India's new ambassador to Washington. The administration faced a June 16 deadline to decide whether to boost tariffs on Indian imports or impose other retaliatory trade sanctions because of India's refusal to negotiate the dispute. The case against India involves that nation's barriers to foreign investment and its refusal to allow American insurance companies to do business in the country. India was one of three countries placed on a trade ``hit list'' last year by the administration for erecting the most offensive trade barriers against American products. The other two countries, Japan and Brazil, both successfully reached agreements with the United States to remove the offending barriers. However, India has refused to negotiate under threat of U.S. sanctions which are provided by a section of the 1988 trade law known as Super 301. While the decision removes the possibility of economic retaliation immediately, the administration in April renamed India to a ``hit list'' for the current year, citing the same trade barriers. The deadline for reaching a conclusion on that action will not come until June 1991. The decision to cite only India in the second round of negotiations and to leave Japan off the list triggered heavy protests in Congress, where Japan's huge $49 billion trade surplus with the United States has attracted attention. The administration contended that Japan had negotiated in good faith to remove barriers to sales of American satellites, supercomputers and wood products in Japan and therefore should not be targeted again. The administration also pledged to press forward with separate discussions on broad-ranging structural trade barriers with Japan. Those discussions are focusing on such issues as increasing penalties for anti-monopolistic practices, streamlining the country's retail distribution procedures and making other changes to expand opportunities for foreign businesses. There have been complaints in recent days that the talks with Japan on structural impediments to trade had bogged down. A final report on these talks is scheduled to be issued in July.

DOC.HEAD: Cardinal Warns Catholic Politicians on Abortion Issue
DOC.TEXT: Roman Catholic politicians who support abortion rights risk excommunication, warned New York's Cardinal John O'Connor in this week's archdiocesan newspaper. ``Where Catholics are perceived not only as treating Church teaching on abortion with contempt, but helping to multiply abortions by advocating legislation supporting abortion, or by making public funds available for abortion, bishops may decide ... such Catholics must be warned that they are at risk of excommunication,'' O'Connor wrote in a 12-page article on abortion. ``If such actions persist, bishops may consider excommunication the only option,' he added in the publication, Catholic New York. O'Connor has discussed the excommunication of pro-choice Catholic politicians in the past, but the newspaper article appeared his strongest and clearest statement yet on the subject. O'Connor is also the chairman of the U.S. bishops' Committee for Pro-Life Activities. The statement appeared several days after the archdiocese rescinded an invitation to Rep. Charles Rangel, D-N.Y., who is Catholic, to speak at a Catholic high school graduation ceremony because of his support for abortion rights. O'Connor also wrote that some bishops, hoping to avoid severe penalties such as excommunication, are imposing lighter penalties as a warning. He cited barring speakers from church events is one such tactic. In his statement, the cardinal specifically criticized politicians who have what he described as a ``personally opposed to, but'' position on the issue. Some politicians, including Gov. Mario Cuomo, have said although they personally oppose abortion, they support a woman's right to make a choice. ``The `personally opposed' phrase says, in effect: `In public life I will act indistinguishable from someone who sees abortion as a positive social good, but please know that I will do so with personal regret,'' the cardinal wrote. ``This agenda is hardly effective, since ... it serves the agenda of those who actively favor abortion,'' he concluded. The actions of Catholic politicians, O'Connor wrote, ``should be consistent with the faith and moral principles taught by the Church in which they claim membership.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Calls in Survey Team to Look for Second Drug Tunnel
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Customs Service has called in a survey team to help search for a possible second drug-smuggling tunnel. U.S. and Mexican authorities last month raided a warehouse in Douglas and a home in Agua Prieta, Mexico. They found a tunnel which officials have said was used to smuggle drugs from Mexico into the United States. The Customs Service received information about a possible second tunnel from documents seized after the first tunnel was found, the agency's hot line, and other means. In the search for a second tunnel, authorities raided a vacant home in Douglas and an occupied home in Agua Prieta last week, but found nothing. The team arrived late Wednesday and will use seismic equipment to look for irregularities beneath the earth's surface at sites officials think might contain another tunnel, Customs spokeswoman Judy Turner said.

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovak Politician Suspended From Party Leadership
DOC.TEXT: A political party that fared poorly in the nation's historic election suspended its chairman today after he was accused of being a former secret police agent. The People's Party also declined to join the new coalition government being formed by incumbent Premier Marian Calfa, a former Communist. On the eve of the weekend election, aides to President Vaclav Havel publicly accused People's Party Chairman Josef Bartoncik of having worked for the recently disbanded secret police for the last 17 years. This is ``not a matter of trust, but a practical decision,'' said deputy People's Party chairman, Bohumil Svoboda. He indicated the Bartoncik affair affected the party's election results. The People's Party, a former Communist ally that broke with the Communists just before last winter's pro-democracy revolution, was one of three in a Christian Democrat coalition that finished third in last weekend's election. Jiri Cerny, party general secretary, said the election results were ``some 10 percent below what we expected.'' Havel's Civic Forum and its Slovak ally, Calfa's Public Against Violence, won 170 of the 300 seats in Parliament, but fell short of the three-fifths majority it needs to pass key constitutional changes. Bartoncik's suspension will remain in force at least until the party's national conference in September, People's Party officials said. The party has failed to defend Bartoncik against the allegations, but has attacked Havel for the way in which they were made public. On June 5, Bartoncik was hospitalized, apparently suffering a heart attack after a meeting with Havel at which he reportedly promised the president he would resign because of his alleged secret police links. The People's Party said he would probably be released from the hospital within one or two weeks. Bartoncik was elected to Parliament in last weekend's vote. His party said the legislature's immunity commission will decide whether to remove his mandate. Cerny said the People's Party would not take part in Calfa's coalition government because it had been offered too few posts. ``A party must have a guarantee that it will be able to influence the decisions of the government'' if it takes part, he said. On Tuesday, Jan Carnogursky, a leader of the Christian Democrats in Slovakia, said his Slovak party would not participate in the new government.

DOC.HEAD: Court Limits Manufacturers in Giving Discounts in Texaco Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today barred manufacturers from giving discounts to wholesalers and not to retailers when the discounts are unrelated to any savings for the supplier or to the wholesaler's costs. The court unanimously upheld a $1.35 million antitrust award Texaco Inc. was ordered to pay to 12 service stations in the Spokane, Wash., area. Justice John Paul Stevens, writing for the court, said there was no evidence that Texaco's discounts ``constituted a reasonable reimbursement for the value to Texaco of (the wholesalers') marketing functions.'' Texaco's appeal had been supported by leading business groups, including the National Association of Manufacturers and the American Petroleum Institute. They had said a defeat for Texaco could undermine ``the most common distributional arrangement in American business: the dual channel system in which a manufacturer or supplier sells to wholesalers at discounted prices lower than those it charges direct purchasing retailers.'' But the court today said Texaco's discounts amounted to illegal price discrimination barred by a federal antitrust law, the Robinson-Patman Act. A federal jury ordered Texaco to pay $449,900, a sum that was tripled by the judge to $1.35 million in accord with the act. The 12 service station dealers that sued said from 1972 to 1981 they were placed at an unfair competitive disadvantage because Texaco supplied gasoline to two Spokane-area wholesalers, John Dompier Oil Co. and Gull Oil Co., at discounts ranging from 2.5 cents to 5.75 cents per gallon less than Texaco charged the retailers. Dompier sold the gasoline to other retailers under the Texaco trademark. Gull marketed it under private brand names. The 12 service stations said they suffered because at least part of the discounts were passed on to consumers by competing retailers who bought from Dompier and Gull. Texaco argued that the discounts were legitimate since they were available to all wholesalers who purchased from the oil comany giant. Stevens today noted there was evidence the services offered by Gull and Dompier were insubstantial and did not justify the discount. For example, there was evidence that Gull's role as a middleman amounted only to engaging in paper transactions and, in fact, Texaco delivered gasoline directly to some of Dompier's customers. The case is Texaco vs. Hasbrouck, 87-2048.

DOC.HEAD: Court Allows Administration to Limit Welfare Aid in Virginia Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today allowed the Bush administration to limit how much welfare aid some needy families receive. By a 5-4 vote, the court said Social Security benefits paid to children must be considered in determining a family's eligibility for benefits under the government's Aid to Families with Dependent Children (AFDC) program. The decision reversed a federal appeals court ruling in a Virginia case last year that favored welfare families in a dispute over how AFDC eligibility is to be determined. At issue was whether the first $50 in Social Security benefits received by a family's children each month must be taken into account when calculating the family's eligibility for AFDC benefits. The Richmond-based 4th U.S Circuit Court of Appeals said no. Today, the Supreme Court said yes. Today's decision is a defeat for the Virginia welfare families who had successfully challenged the Bush administration's interpretation of the relevant law. The disputed welfare law language says participating states are to ``disregard the first $50 of any child support payments.'' Writing for the court today, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist said Bush administration officials were correct in limiting that language to payments from absent parents _ and not applying it to Social Security benefits received by children. ``Congress used `child support' throughout (the relevant welfare law) as a term of art referring exclusively to payments from absent parents,'' Rehnquist said. He was joined by Justices Byron R. White, Sandra Day O'Connor, Antonin Scalia and Anthony M. Kennedy. Justices Harry A. Blackmun, William J. Brennan, Thurgood Marshall and John Paul Stevens dissented. ``This crabbed interpretation of the statute is neither compelled by its language nor consistent with its purpose,'' Blackmun wrote, ``and arbitrarily deprives certain families of a modest but urgently needed welfare benefit.'' Justice Department lawyers had told the court that the $50-disregard provision, enacted in 1974, could cost $44 million more each year in AFDC benefits if interpreted as the 4th Circuit court had. The case is Sullivan vs. Stroop, 89-535.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Legislature Delays Increase in Bread Price
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet legislature today delayed for at least two months the government's plan for a controversial increase in the price of bread, the main staple of the nation's diet. The Supreme Soviet, in a rebuff to the government of Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, said that plans to triple the price of bread in stages starting July 1 would have to wait until September or later. The vote was 319-33. Government officials had said the price increase would have brought in $24 billion, but that all the money would be turned back to Soviet consumers by other means. However, they acknowledged that they had not fully worked out plans to turn the money back to them. The bread price increase was one of the most visible and controversial parts of an economic program presented to the Supreme Soviet by Ryzhkov last month. The program touched off panic buying in Moscow and led the capital's government to require proof of residence to make purchases. On Wednesday, the Supreme Soviet ordered the government to have other elements of the plan to move toward a market economy ready by October. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has said that bread is so cheap that children sometimes use a loaf for a soccer ball. In the meantime, the country spends its hard currency reserves to buy grain from foreign countries. One deputy complained after the vote that because producer prices for grain already have been raised, keeping bread prices constant would swell the government budget deficit by several billion rubles. But the lawmakers, rushing toward a summer adjournment with a slate of several other pieces of major legislation still pending, voted against lowering the producer price again. The producer price increase is to provide farmers with an additional $12.6 billion in an effort to improve agricultural incentives. The government needed the Supreme Soviet's approval for the price increases because of its 1989 pledge it would not raise prices on any essential items throughout this year.

DOC.HEAD: White House Foreign Policy Adviser Leaving for Harvard Post
DOC.TEXT: Robert D. Blackwill, a senior foreign policy adviser to President Bush, will return to Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government as a lecturer in late July, the White House announced today. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said that President Bush ``accepts his departure with great appreciation for his role in shaping U.S. policy towards Europe in these dramatic times.'' ``Bob was instrumental in the success of both Gorbachev summits and in the president's many deliberations on NATO,'' the spokesman said. Blackwill, 49, is senior director for European and Soviet affairs in the office of the White House national security adviser. Fitzwater said no replacement has been selected yet. However, Condoleezza Rice, Blackwill's deputy and a top adviser on Soviet affairs, is widely believed to be in line for the post. Blackwill is a former associate dean and faculty member at the Kennedy School.

DOC.HEAD: Observations Show What May Be Black Hole Sucking in Stars
DOC.TEXT: Scientists say they have made the most detailed look at the center of the Milky Way galaxy and found what appears to be a massive black hole gobbling up one star every 5,000 to 10,000 years. Computer-generated pictures released Wednesday at a American Astronomical Society meeting show an object 1 million times the size of the sun that seems to be spinning off what appears to be clusters of gas, said Northwestern University astronomer Farhad Yusef-Zadeh. ``This is the most detailed look at the center of our galaxy, and it is similar, in a scaled-down version, to what we expect to see in the nuclei of active galaxies,'' said Yusef-Zadeh in a telephone interview Wednesday night.``Super-massive black holes are believed to be imbedded at the center of these galaxies.'' A black hole is believed to be an imploded star, a massive object so dense that even light cannot escape its gravitational pull. It is sucking in one star every 5,000 to 10,000 years, he said. It is 25,000 light years from Earth. ``It's an arena where gravity has a complete triumph over all other forces,'' he said of his research that involved three years of observations through the Very Large Array radiotelescope. The pictures of the object, called Sagittarius A, show at least seven clumps of gas surrounding it and seeming to spiral outward from it, as if being sprayed out from something rapidly spinning. ``This is the first time you can actually see bloblike sources near the galactic center,'' Yusef-Zadeh said. Until now, he said, it had not been clear whether Sagittarius A or a star cluster called IRS 16 was really at the center of the galaxy. ``We believe that we have good evidence that Sagittarius A is truly at the center of our galaxy and is responsible for energizing its immediate vicinity,'' he said. Although nothing can escape the interior of a black hole, Yusef-Zadeh said that gas, dust and stars drawn toward it are believed to form a swirling disc. The black hole's gravity, astronomers believe, heats this material to such an extent that some of the matter is blown back outward by the radiation pressure and by a wind similar to solar wind. Scientists cannot actually see the black hole but can record the energy spewing out from it _ an amount roughly equal to the power that would be radiated by 10 million suns. The radiotelescope can measure radio waves and infrared radiation. The study was done in collaboration with astronomers Mark Morris, of University of California, Los Angeles, and Ron Ekers of the Australian Telescope at Epping, Australia.

DOC.HEAD: White House Chief of Staff Takes Assignment in Kremlin
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS 4th graf, Fitzwater said... to make it Gorbachev, sted Sununu
DOC.TEXT: White House Chief of Staff John Sununu has accepted an invitation to go to Moscow to help Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev organize his office, a spokesman said today. Sununu already has been offering advice, meeting this week with a delegation of visiting Soviet officials who are interested in how the White House works. Bush's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said Sununu was invited by a member of the group to visit Moscow and had accepted. The date of his trip has not been set. Fitzwater said Sununu would advise Gorbachev on organizational matters related to the executive office of the president. Gorbachev was elected to the new post of president this year, in addition to his position as general secretary of the Communist Party. ``I think that they would like him to come to the Soviet Union to take a look at their ideas and their plans and see if he has any advice,'' Fitzwater said.

DOC.HEAD: Raunchy Rappers Meet Geraldo and Phil
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, ``I'm a little...' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with album banned in South Carolina county. Picks up 11th graf, `Campbell and ...'
DOC.TEXT: He's been arrested in Florida and attacked in Texas, but the leader of the raunchy 2 Live Crew band found two friends in the Big Apple: Geraldo and Phil. Lead singer Luther Campbell on Wednesday unleashed a fiery, foul-mouthed defense of the group's album ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be.'' Campbell appeared live on ``Donahue'' and did a taping for a Friday ``Geraldo.'' With Geraldo Rivera, Campbell spouted a torrent of obscenities at the sheriff who arrested him, denounced a black Florida judge as an ``Uncle Tom,'' and questioned the credentials of the sheriff's legal adviser. ``He hasn't given more to the black community than I have,'' Campbell said of the adviser, then attacked Broward County Sheriff Nick Navarro over the police shooting of a black in Fort Lauderdale earlier this year. ``It will definitely be our most bleeped show ever. No question,'' said Jeff Erdel, the publicist for the show. But Campbell wasn't finished. He went live on the syndicated ``Donahue'' show, where he was joined by previously censored performers Jello Biafra and Wendy O. Williams. Campbell kept it clean for Phil Donahue's show. But Bob DeMoss, director of the conservative Focus on Family, stunned viewers with an expletive broadcast live into millions of homes. ``I'd like to keep this job,'' Donahue said in asking his guests to calm down. DeMoss later apologized, and NBC received dozens of phone calls about the expletive. Biafra and Williams vigorously defended Campbell. ``I'm a little sick of the system,'' said Williams, who once wore only electrical tape above her waist at a show. ``What are we going to do next?'' The twin TV appearances should keep fueling sales of ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be,'' which are fast approaching the 2 million mark. A federal judge in Florida has declared the album obscene, and San Antonio store owners pulled the record from shelves this week after they were threatened with arrest. In Columbia, S.C., solicitor James Anders on Wednesday deemed ``Nasty As They Wanna Be'' obscene and said he will give Richland County record store owners 10 days to clear the album from their shelves. Campbell and two other band members were arrested Sunday after a live gig at a Florida club. The judge has called the band obscene, but Campbell and his supporters claim First Amendment protection and suggest they are victims of racism. Band members are black. Navarro has denied the racism charges, as he has done repeatedly since the arrests. ``I'm not after anybody because of race,'' Navarro said.

DOC.HEAD: Mozambique, Rebels Postpone Direct Peace Talks
DOC.TEXT: The first direct peace talks between Mozambique's government and right-wing rebels have been postponed. A communique Wednesday by officials of Mozambique's leftist government and mediating countries said the talks did not begin as scheduled Tuesday in Malawi, which borders the troubled southeast African nation. The discussions were to include Mozambican Cabinet ministers and Alfonso Dhlakama, head of the Mozambique National Resistance guerrilla army, known by its Portuguese acronym Renamo. The communique said without elaboration that the talks were postponed because of ``difficulties experienced by the Kenya and Renamo delegations.'' ``Efforts are continuing to set a new date in the near future for the process to begin in Malawi,'' said the statement, published by the official Malawi News Agency, Mana. Renamo has been fighting for control of the territory for 13 years and opposes the one-party rule of President Joaquim Chissano. The war has left hundreds of thousands of people dead, mostly civilians. The Mozambique national news agency, AIM, had reported from Blantyre on Tuesday that Mozambican Cabinet ministers and the leader of the guerrillas had gathered in the city for the talks. But Renamo did not sign Wednesday's communique. The host government for several days declined to grant visas for Western correspondents seeking to report on the meeting. Renamo has opposed Malawi as a venue, favoring either Kenya or Portugal, Mozambique's former colonial ruler that granted independence in 1975. Malawian officials, contacted by telephone from the Zimbabwean capital, Harare, said they were not authorized to discuss the aborted meeting beyond what was published in the communique. The Blantyre talks were expected to focus on President Chissano's proposals for a new constitution to allow independents to oppose the ruling Front for the Liberation of Mozambique at elections. But Chissano has rejected demands for the creation of opposition parties. Kenya and Zimbabwe have for several months brokered low-level peace talks.

DOC.HEAD: White House Phone Lines Overloaded After Baker Gives Out Number
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS 3 grafs after 4th graf pvs, `Baker gave out ...' Adds byline
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of telephone calls clogged the White House switchboard after Secretary of State James A. Baker III gave out the phone number Wednesday in a public hearing, a spokesman said today. During a time period when the White House might typically receive 100 or 200 calls, between 6,000 and 8,000 callers dialed the presidential residence after Baker sarcastically recited the number in a Senate hearing. ``The switchboard was finally blocked to the point where it couldn't handle it anymore. And they had to put it on automatic thank-you tape,'' White House Press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said. Baker gave out the number, 202 456-1414, as he prodded Israel on its commitment to the Mideast peace process. He said that when the Israeli government was ready to talk seriously about peace, it could call the president's number. Fitzwater amplified today on Baker's comments. Asked if the United States questions Israel's commitment to peace, he said, ``We have not yet seen the dialogue start. There is a question, certainly _ on both sides.'' The United States wants to help the peace process and has tried to get the warring parties to the negotiation table, Fitzwater said. However, he said, ``In the final analysis the parties of the region have to want peace for it to happen. We can't want it for them. But he was saying basically that if they want peace enough to get a dialogue going, it will happen and give us a call.'' Baker's unusually blunt statements did not produce any calls from Israel's new conservative government, Fitzwater said. But the broadcast of his remarks on television and radio news programs all day Wednesday prompted thousands of calls from the public. ``They were all over the issue on all sides,'' he said. ``It's a fairly incredible volume.'' Apparently the White House operators tired of taking calls prompted by Baker, who works several blocks away at the State Department. A reporter from Israel, Yaacov Eilon, said that when he called in and said he was calling in response to Baker's comment, the operator told him, ``You would have to call the State Department. ... That number is 647-4000.'' Asked what all this meant, Fitzwater quipped, ``It means the White House operators can expect a thick Christmas present this year from the State Department.''

DOC.HEAD: Bucharest Shaken By Fierce Political Clashes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with U.S. comment. Pickup 6th graf pvs, `The pro-government...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY6,XBUC2,4, LaserColor XBUC7
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of workers responded to a call for help in putting down anti-government protests by streaming into Bucharest today, clubbing people and ransacking opposition party offices. Health Ministry officials said five people were killed and 277 injured in two days of violence, the country's worst since the December revolution that toppled and executed dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. There were unconfirmed reports of more than a dozen deaths. Deputy Health Minister Radu Dop said 80 people were hospitalized. The clashes began before dawn Wednesday, when club-wielding police broke up a nearly two-month, anti-government protest in central University Square. Later, police opened fire on demonstrators who attacked state television, the Interior Ministry and the headquarters of the new intelligence service. Early today, soldiers fired at demonstrators who threw firebombs at police headquarters and sporadic gunfire echoed across Bucharest. In Washington, the Bush administration condemned ``in the strongest possible terms'' what it called ``government inspired vigilante violence.'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said the violence ``departs from the commonly accepted norms of democracy and the rule of law.'' The pro-government workers who streamed into Bucharest today heeded a call from President-elect Ion Iliescu in a televised speech to put down what he termed an attempt by ``fascists'' to overthrow the government. He repeated the call today in a speech to supporters outside government headquarters. Thousands of miners packed University Square, clubbing reporters and people they thought were opposition sympathizers. After the clash, state TV said Interior Minister Mihai Chitac had been replaced. Chitac, a general, was criticized for alleged involvement in the suppression of the pro-democracy revolution last year and for the way police put down protests Wednesday. But no reason was given for his dimissal. Chitac was replaced by Doru Viorel Ursu, chief judge of the three-man panel in Sibiu residing over the trial of Nicu Ceausescu, the son of the former dictator. He is charged with complicity to genocide. During the violence today, people in military trucks handed the government supporters milk and bread. Unidentified people in a van carrying loudspeakers warned passers-by: ``don't incite the miners ... you would thus give birth to fierce violence.'' The speakers also instructed the miners, some of whom were armed with police truncheons, to get hold of cameramen, photographers and reporters and take them into the van. ``We will take care of them,'' the speaker said. Ovidiu Bogdan, 28, a photographer for Gamma, said he was attacked by men armed with iron-ended clubs a few hundred yards from the square. Associated Press reporter Christina Pirvulescu was clubbed and had her press card seized before being rescued by an acquaintance in the army. Other government suporters ransacked the headquarters of the opposition Liberal Party and Peasant Party _ which they accused of instigating Wednesday's rioting _ as well as buildings such as the Bucharest University's Faculty of Foreign Languages. Iliescu is the first ex-Communist to win a popular presidential election in Eastern Europe. He and the National Salvation Front took power in the bloody December revolution, then won May 20 elections by a landslide. Anti-government protesters claim the Front is dominated by Communists and accuse it of the same heavy-handed tactics of the Ceausescu regime. Iliescu is among several top Front leaders who were once high-ranking Communists. A Front statement carried by the Rompres state news agency said ``journalists who use lies and slander to incite open violence and destabilizing actions'' were partly to blame for Wednesday's rioting. Anti-government demonstrators on Wednesday ransacked and set fire to police headquarters, set a smaller government building ablaze and forced their way into television headquarters, halting all broadcasting for an hour. Along the way, they overturned and set fire to cars and other vehicles. Soldiers and police defending government buildings or moving to retake them periodically fired on demonstrators. Rompres reported ``many'' arrests. State media estimated damage to the television headquarters from firebombs at $2 million. The demonstrators who held a round-the-clock vigil in University Square for 53 days claim Iliescu doesn't want a free market and Western-style democracy, which they advocate. They also demanded a 10-year ban on ex-Communists holding public office and an independent television station. The pro-government demonstrators, mostly workers from the capital's factories and mines, chanted: ``Iliescu, the workers are with you.'' ``It is all their fault ... they have injected shame and distrust in people,'' construction worker Ioan Marcovei said of opposition leaders, who issued statements denying any responsibility for Wednesday's unrest. Marcovei spoke as a crowd of workers shouted slogans against the main opposition leaders, Ion Ratiu and Radu Campeanu. Vasile Sima, a miner from Livezeni, carried a police truncheon as he crowded with his colleagues into University Square. He said the miners wouldn't leave until they ``put things in order.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush To Campaign In Two Southern Cities
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will visit Huntsville, Ala., and Charlotte, N.C., next Wednesday to help raise funds for Republican candidates, the White House said Thursday. In Huntsville, he will attend a fundraising luncheon for Republican Gov. Guy Hunt, then visit the Marshall Space Flight Center and address employees, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. In Charlotte, Bush will attend a fundraising dinner for the re-election of Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C.

DOC.HEAD: Numero Uno Numbers Book Issued
DOC.TEXT: The 110th edition of the book statistics fans consider ``numero uno'' is out, and it says California, Nevada, Utah, Florida and North Dakota are all number one. It should surprise no one that the Statistical Abstract of the United States shows California with the largest population of any state with an estimated 29 million residents. But Nevada has been growing fastest, increasing by nearly 39 percent during the 1980s, according to the Abstract. Utah has the largest share of people under age 18, 37 percent, while Florida has the biggest representation in the over-65 category, 18 percent. And North Dakota has the most hospital beds available at 878 per 100,000 residents. Those represent just a minor sample of the massive collection of facts found in the 1990 edition of the Statistical Abstract. Compiled by the Census Bureau from a variety of sources, this year's volume crams 1,532 tables into 991-pages. Sources of the information are cited with each table and many tables contain information not available elsewhere. The book is on sale from government bookstores or from the Superintendent of Documents, Washington, D.C., 20402. The price is $28 for the paperback or $34 for the hard-bound edition.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Votes To Subpoena Texas Developer In HUD Investigation
DOC.TEXT: A House investigative panel voted Thursday to subpoena Texas developer Leonard Briscoe to testify about his dealings with the Department of Housing and Urban Development and former HUD officials. Rep. Tom Lantos, D-Calif., chairman of the subcommittee that has spent more than a year probing the HUD scandal, said Briscoe would be compelled to appear June 21. The subpoena was approved by a unanimous 5-0 vote of the employment and housing subcommittee of the Government Operations Committee. Lantos said that despite Briscoe's initial statements that he was willing to testify voluntarily, the panel had been unable to gain a commitment from him and Briscoe's attorneys had sent conflicting signals about whether he would appear. ``In order to put an end to this childish game of `red light-green light,' and to ensure Mr. Briscoe's appearance before the subcommittee on June 21, I'm requesting a subpoena be issued,'' Lantos said. DuBois Gilliam, a former deputy assistant secretary of HUD now serving a prison sentence, testified under immunity last month and named Briscoe in describing how lucrative federal housing and community development grants were steered to favored developers. Briscoe is a former Texas state legislator and Fort Worth city council member. He was a business associate of Lance Wilson, once a top aide to former HUD Secretary Samuel Pierce, and was involved in development of projects in Texas and Florida that benefited from HUD grants.

DOC.HEAD: East and West Close to Overcoming Major Hurdle Toward Agreement
DOC.TEXT: Negotiators at East-West talks on reducing conventional forces in Europe are close to agreement on limits for tanks and armored combat vehicles for each military bloc, diplomats said today. An accord would push ahead the overall talks, and an initial agreement might be reached by the end of the year, they said. The East-West talks are to cut troops and non-nuclear weapons of the two military alliances from the Atlantic Ocean to the Ural mountains. The 16 NATO and seven Warsaw Pact countries are taking part. The breakthrough proposal came from the French and the Poles. It suggests an overall ceiling for each side of 30,000 armored combat vehicles and 20,000 tanks. French chief delegate Francois Plaisant said at a news conference given jointly with Polish chief delegate Wlodzimierz Konarski today there was ``informal but overall consensus'' on the proposal. Diplomats said they expected imminent formal agreement on ceilings in the two categories. Negotiators from both sides had charged petty bargaining was slowing the talks. Western diplomats said the Soviets appeared to be foot-dragging until the future security allegiance of a united Germany was decided. But both sides hope to have an agreement ready for signing by December, when leaders from 35 nations are scheduled to meet in Paris. The other 12 participants in the Paris talks are neutral and non-aligned European countries. In his plenary statement, Konarski said discussions between U.S. and Soviet experts during last month's Washington summit had ``produced results which made it easier to formulate a `compromise package.''' One of the toughest issues has been finding common definitions for tanks and other armaments, diplomats said. The French-Polish proposal also sets weight limits of 16.5 tons for all tanks and it would no longer distinguish between armored troop carriers, and other armored vehicles. According to U.S. estimates, the West has 23,600 tanks to the Warsaw Pact's 52,500; NATO has 34,025 armored combat vehicls and the Warsaw Pact has 59,400. Konarski said the use of broader categories of definitions was the only way to conclude a deal ``in a situation where there is such a pluralism in Europe of types of weapons.'' But Konarski and Plaisant said there were still many issues to be resolved before a final agreement can be signed. Konarski said the issue of ceilings and definitions on aircraft and helicopters, and terms for verification still must be resolved. NATO has proposed a maximum of 4,700 combat aircraft for each side, with an additional 500 air defense interceptors, but the East would like a higher ceiling. The superpowers have agreed to a ceiling of 195,000 troops each in Central Europe, with the United States permitted to maintain up to 30,000 troops elsewhere in Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Paupers' Graveyard: Only the Dead Know Hart Island
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `A ferry...', to give island location.
DOC.TEXT: The city couldn't provide them homes when they were alive. But after the two men died _ killed when their cave beneath a razed building collapsed _ they were given a final resting place on a grassy, quiet island. Quiet because only the dead reside on Hart Island. About 700,000 bodies are buried on the 100-acre island. A paupers' graveyard for 121 years, it is among the most intensively used pieces of real estate in New York City. Miguel Marrero and Jose Diaz were buried Wednesday, 34 days after the shelter they dug collapsed in a rainstorm. The body of a third man who died with them was claimed by his family. But because the bodies of Marrero and Diaz lay unclaimed in the morgue for more than two weeks, they were sent to Hart Island. A ferry bearing a stack of 14 pine caskets containing the bodies of Marrero, Diaz and other indigents chugged to the island in Long Island Sound, about a mile from the borough of the Bronx. Diaz's and Marrero's names were written in black marker on their rough-hewn caskets. Another casket had the markings UNK WHT M, for unknown white male. The bodies headed for Hart Island are not embalmed and the caskets are thin. That way, nature can reclaim them and the burial plots can be used again in a few decades, in a macabre recycling program. ``A box sometimes falls apart as we're moving it and a body rolls out,'' said Jerome DiSisto, a corrections officer accompanying the burial detail. ``If that happens, we just get an empty box, put the body in and that's all.'' Capt. Gene Ruppert, another corrections official, said an average of 1,500 adults are buried each year on the island, in addition to 1,500 infants, most of them stillborn. A quarter or more of those buried are believed to have been homeless. The Corrections Department manages the island and all burials are performed by inmates, who earn 50 cents an hour, department spokesman Tom Antenen said. The few buildings on the island, such as a onetime insane asylum, are overgrown with vegetation, except for a recently abandoned prison barracks, which still has fences with concertina wire. Every plot of 150 bodies has a white marker. The location of each body is recorded in case a relative comes to claim it. About 90 bodies are exhumed each year. Al Saunders, a city employee, uses a backhoe to dig the trench where the caskets are laid two across and stacked three high. He has buried thousands of coffins since 1984 _ and has had to dig a few up. ``It isn't the nicest job going, but it has to be done,'' he said. ``You have to develop a callous attitude, because how much death can you see without it having an effect on you?'' Saunders said one of his predecessors became so preoccupied with death he had nightmares and quit. The prisoners, many shirtless in the sun, hoisted Diaz's casket into the trench, then put three more inside. No words were said as Diaz and Marrero were buried. The inmates reached for the next casket and the next until their chore was done. Saunders dropped the soil onto the common grave with his backhoe. The prisoners smoothed out the loam with rakes and shovels. Diaz and Marrero were known as Mike and Joe, according to a New York Newsday article that appeared shortly after their deaths. ``They were good people,'' one friend, Daisy Aldebedo, told the newspaper. ``They got high, but they worked for their money. They never robbed anyone.'' The city planned to build low-income housing on the lot where Diaz, Marrero and the third man, Benjamin Olivera, were killed. There are an estimated 70,000 homeless people in New York City. In recent weeks, hundreds of homeless people have been evicted from train stations and bank-machine vestibules. City shelters have a reputation for violence, and many homeless people shun them because of rules that residents must be drug- and alcohol-free, said Marjorie Valleau, a spokeswoman for the city Human Resources Administration.

DOC.HEAD: Big Board Plans Off-Hours, Electronic Trading Later This Year
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with plan confirmed. Picks up 5th graf, `NYSE spokesman ...' A version also moved on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: The New York Stock Exchange will begin trading stocks outside its normal hours and off its trading floor later this year, a first in its nearly 200-year history, sources confirmed today. The plans are an attempt to recapture trading volume in Big Board stocks from foreign markets, especially London and Tokyo, as the world moves toward around-the-clock trading. The new trading will be conducted electronically and may bypass the specialists, the floor traders through whom stock transactions are routed currently, said officials familiar with the plan who asked not to be named. The plan first was reported in The New York Times. NYSE spokesman Richard Torrenzano declined to confirm the report. However, he said the exchange has been studying the possibility of off-hours trading for two years. ``If we see a need by our customers to have an off-hour trading system, we will move very innovatively and quickly to meet that customer demand,'' he said. The Times said the exchange plans to begin two limited after-hours trading sessions sometime this year, with different rules applying than during daytime trading. Sometime in 1991, the exchange plans to conduct auctions of each Big Board stock at 8 p.m., midnight and 5 a.m. New York time, the newspaper said. Each stock would trade only once at each auction, with all trades combined at a single agreed price. The three auction times would coincide with the start of the Tokyo business day, the middle of the Tokyo day and the early part of the London business day. It is estimated that 15 million to 20 million shares of NYSE stocks trade each day outside of exchange hours. Average volume during the exchange's 9:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. session has been running at about 160 million shares recently.

DOC.HEAD: Chronology Of Key Events In Romania Since World War II
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of events in Romania since the Communists took power after World War II: 1947 _ Communists backed by Soviet forces who invaded at the close of the war take power in a virtual coup, forcing abdication of King Michael. Tens of thousands of people die in a bloody repression. 1965 _ Communist leader Gheorghe Gheorghiu-Dej dies, Nicolae Ceausescu takes over. 1968 _ Ceausescu denounces Soviet-led crackdown against reform in Czechoslovakia. His foreign policy moves independent of Moscow put him on good terms with the West despite repressive measures at home. 1977 _ Troops break up strike by 30,000 coal miners, arrest leaders. Nov. 1987 _ Forces break up pro-reform rally in Brasov by 10,000 people, rally leaders arrested and dissappear. Dec. 17, 1989 _ Security forces open fire on protesters in Timisoara, triggering nationwide protests that reach Bucharest Dec. 21. Dec. 22 _ Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, flee capital after anti-government protesters take over streets and get army on their side. The National Salvation Front, a group uniting anti-Ceausescu Communists, dissidents and intellectuals, takes control of TV station. The army fights Ceausescu's security forces. Dec. 25 _ Committee announces it has tried, convicted and executed Ceausescu and his wife for crimes including genocide and destruction of the national economy. Dec. 26 _ Ion Iliescu, an ex-member of the Ceausescu regime and a leader of the revolution, is named chairman of council of National Salvation Committee. Fighting subsides. Jan. 12 _ Iliescu says the Communist Party is outlawed, but government retracts the ban a week later. Feb. 1 _ The government proposes creation of interim ``mini-parliament'' with veto power over the ruling council until elections May 20. It meets for the first time Feb. 9. Feb. 19 _ Anti-Communist demonstrators saying country still led by holdovers of the Ceaucescu regime temporarily seize government headquarters. March 2 _ Twenty-one officers of Securitate go on trial in Timisoara, death toll there said to be 94 rather than up to 4,000 as rumored during the revolution. March 13 _ Provisional parliament rules out election candidacies by any members of Ceausescu's old guard. March 15 _ Iliescu, at first post-revolutionary press conference, does not repudiate Marxism-Leninism, but pledges transition to multiparty system and market economy April 22 _ Anti-Communist demonstration starts in Bucharest's University Square. May 20 _ Front and Iliescu win overwhelming victory in elections tainted by charges of violence and unfair media advantage being used against the opposition. June 13 _ Police break up the anti-Communist demonstration at University Square, beating some protesters. Rioting erupts and police open fire. At least four people are killed. June 14 _ More clashes reported. Tens of thousands of workers turn out in support of the government, some beating members of the opposition and ransacking opposition parties' offices.

DOC.HEAD: Police Kill Reputed Leader of Medellin Cartel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with car bomb killing two. Pickup 6th graf, ``He served...''
DOC.TEXT: Police have shot and killed the mastermind of the Medellin cocaine cartel's 10-month-old war against the government that has left hundreds of people dead, authorities said today. The killing occurred Wednesday night in an exclusive Medellin suburb, and this morning a car bomb went off near a police post in the suburb, killing at least two people and injuring 20, the RCN radio network reported. No one immediately claimed responsibility for the blast. John Jairo Arias Tascon, considered the cartel's No. 5 leader, was killed in the El Poblado neighborhood when police, acting on a trip, found and tried to arrest him, said Gen. Octavio Vargas, operational police director. The killing was the biggest victory for the government's war on drugs since the slaying of Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, the cartel's No. 2 boss in December. Vargas did not say if any police were hurt in the shootout, but he said four more law officers were killed in Medellin Wednesday night. Their deaths bring to 110 the number of Medellin policemen assassinated so far this year. Arias, 28, led a terrorist organization that killed scores of Colombians, including an attorney general, a state governor, a judge and a leading journalist, Vargas said in an interview today on RCN. ``He served as chief of the armed organization of the Medellin cartel,'' Vargas said, and was considered the cartel's fifth most important leader. He said Arias was also responsible for two car bomb attacks on Colombia's secret police chief, Gen. Miguel Maza Marquez. The blasts killed at least 70 people, but Maza escaped unharmed. Authorities blame drug traffickers for killing more than 400 Colombians since August, when the government begn a sweeping anti-drug crackdown. Vargas said police relied on cooperation from Medellin's residents to locate Arias. He said the person who provided the crucial information will receive a $200,000 reward. The terror campaign came in response to a crackdown on the cartels that President Virgilio Barco began in August after a leading presidential candidate was assassinated and the traffickers were blamed for the killing. Since then Barco's administration has extradited 15 drug suspects and confiscated hundreds of properties belonging to the cocaine magnates. On Wednesday, the government announced it would dispatch 570 more police officers and soldiers to the trafficking center of Medellin, where cartel-hired assassins have killed 106 police officers this year. Drug traffickers in April offered a $4,300 bounty for each officer killed. Medellin, Colombia's second largest city, has about 3 million residents. At one time, the Medellin cartel was believed responsible for most of the cocaine that is smuggled into the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Solidarity Leader Caught in Local Farmers' Blockade
DOC.TEXT: Solidarity leader Lech Walesa ran into a little labor trouble himself Thursday en route to a flight to Switzerland for a meeting of the International Labor Organization. Walesa's auto was stopped four times in successive roadblocks organized by farmers to protest low milk prices. The delays took place near Mlawa, about 80 miles northeast of Warsaw on the main highway from his home in Gdansk to Warsaw. Farmers were protesting low milk prices paid by their local dairy cooperative, a monopoly. Walesa talked to the farmers, calling their protest ``justified'' and promising to help them on his return from Geneva. ``A process of dissatisfaction is taking place in many groups of society,'' Walesa said in Warsaw. ``It worries me a little because there _ in Mlawa _ it is a local problem. But they are all cursing the government.'' Under Poland's radical economic reform plan, prices have risen while real incomes have plunged. Walesa is to address the union organization Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Veterinary Drug Being Recalled
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday warned cattle producers against using a non-prescription veterinary product designed to prevent copper deficiency in beef cattle and calves. The FDA said it had received reports of about 240 cattle deaths from copper toxicity after injections of Bovi-Cu. Veterinary Research and Development Inc. of Truckee, Calif., which developed Bovi-Cu, is recalling the product. The product is made by Anthony Products of Arcadia, Calif. Cattle producers should return it to the place of purchase, the FDA said. The manufacturer shipped 3,723 100-milligram vials to distributors in California, Colorado, Idaho, Kansas, Missouri, Nebraska, New Mexico, Oregon and Texas, the FDA said.
