Those distributors sell the product to farms from Kansas to Hawaii, the agency said. About 2,211 vials are still in distribution channels, the FDA said.

DOC.HEAD: Demonstrators in Square a Varied Collection
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The demonstrators who held out on Bucharest's central University Square for more than 50 days were students, pro-democracy activists and rowdies who seemed unclear what they wanted. They claimed that more than 5 million people across the country had signed a petition backing their chief demand _ a 10-year ban on former Communist leaders such as President-elect Ion Iliescu from entering politics. That demand is supported by some of the country's leading intellectuals, who also don't trust Iliescu's promises of democracy and believe he and other ex-Communists in his National Salvation Front have usurped the revolution. But Bucharest and Timisoara are the only cities since December to have seen demonstrations of more than a few hundred people against the government. The overwhelming victory of Iliescu and his Front in last month's elections suggest the demonstrators' demands found little support in other areas, where citizens see Iliescu as the man who rid them of the hated Nicolae Ceausescu. More than 100 of the 200 demonstrators on University Square were arrested when police moved against them on the 53rd day of their protest Wednesday. It remains unclear who the demonstrators were who later set fire to police headquarters and attacked other key buildings such as the state television.

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty International Urges Hong Kong To Scrap Death Penalty
DOC.TEXT: A human rights group urged the Hong Kong authorities Thursday to abolish capital punishment before this British colony reverts to Chinese rule in 1997. Although the law still exists, Hong Kong has not carried out capital punishment since 1966, and death sentences are commuted to life imprisonment. The Hong Kong branch of Amnesty International said it was apprehensive of the use of the penalty after 1997 because it is still widely imposed and carried out in China. ``Amnesty International opposes the death penalty as a violation of the right of life,'' it said in a statement. ``It is also the ultimate form of cruel, inhumane and degrading punishment.'' The call for its abolishment was contained in the human rights group's submission on the territory's proposed Bill of Rights, which is expected to be enacted into law this year. The bill was unveiled by the government in March in a move to reassure people here that their human rights will be safeguarded after the Chinese takeover. China has warned it would repeal the bill if contravenes the Basic Law, the constitution for Hong Kong's post-1997 administration. The Chinese government has pledged to retain Hong Kong's legal and capitalistic systems for 50 years after 1997.

DOC.HEAD: Three Military Officers Arrested in Bribery Scandal
DOC.TEXT: Three army officers accused of sharing bribes linked to the purchase of 2.5 million pairs of black socks for troops could face execution if convicted, court officials said Thursday. The officers, among seven arrested in the scandal, allegedly received a portion of $109,000 in bribes paid by a hosiery dealer last year to win the $1.82 million socks contract, prosecutors at Taipei District Court charge. Some of the bribe money reached Chiang Chung-lien, a cousin of the chief of staff to President Lee Teng-hui, officials allege. Chiang Chung-lien was arrested Wednesday. The socks supplier, Hsiao Chun-liang, told court prosecutors the three officers also had demanded $218,200 in kickbacks to accept a shipment of substandard socks, but he refused to pay them. Hsiao and Chiang Chung-lien's son, Ching-hsiung, were arrested Wednesday, along with Tsai Hsiung, head of the National Assembly's Public Relations Department. The three arrested officers were identified as Maj. Gen. Liu Pao, Col. Chen Tao-ming and Col. Liao Yun-hsun. All three supervised military purchases. If convicted of bribery, the military officers could be sentenced to death and the civilians could receive a maximum seven-year prison sentence. Formal charges will be filed when the investigation is completed, prosecutors said. Prosecutors said Hsiao complained it was difficult to meet all the standards set by the military for the socks, including a guarantee the black socks would not fade even if soaked in hot water for 40 minutes. Hsiao said some of the socks were manufactured at factories in Shanghai, China, to lower production costs.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rules in Favor of Sobriety Checkpoints in Michigan Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 18-19, Nadine Strosser, with reaction.
DOC.TEXT: The privacy rights of motorists are not violated when police try to curb drunken driving by stopping them at sobriety checkpoints, the Supreme Court ruled today. The 6-3 ruling upheld Michigan's sobriety checkpoint program and, by extension, similar programs in most states. In another decision, the court allowed the Bush administration to limit how much welfare aid some needy families receive. By a 5-4 vote, the court said Social Security benefits paid to children must be considered in determining a family's eligibility for benefits under the government's Aid to Families with Dependent Chidren program. The court also ruled the government may impose severe fines against air polluters even when federal officials are slow to decide on proposals for cleaning up the atmosphere. And it ruled that hospitals and nursing homes may sue in federal court to challenge how a state-run Medicaid program reimburses their costs. Lower courts had split on the sobriety-checkpoint issue. Some had upheld the use of checkpoints, at which all motorists are pulled off the road and checked for signs of intoxication. Other courts, like those in Michigan, had barred police from using checkpoints. ``No one can seriously dispute the magnitude of the drunken driving problem or the states' interest in eradicating it,'' Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote for the court. ``Conversely, the weight bearing on the other scale _ the measure of the intrusion on motorists stopped briefly at sobriety checkpoints _ is slight,'' he added. Drunken drivers killed 23,000 people nationwide last year. President Bush called drunken driving a problem ``as crippling as crack'' cocaine, and last December asked state and local governments to step up the fight against drunken drivers. ``It's as crippling as crack, as random as gang violence, and it's killing more kids than both combined,'' the president said then as he noted that federal aid was being given to promote the use of sobriety checkpoints. Today's ruling echoed the president's concern. Joining Rehnquist were Justices Byron R. White, Sandra Day O'Connor, Antonin Scalia and Anthony M. Kennedy. Justice Harry A. Blackmun joined in the result but not in Rehnquist's majority opinion. Justices William J. Brennan, Thurgood Marshall and John Paul Stevens dissented. ``I do not dispute the immense social cost caused by drunken drivers, nor do I slight the government's efforts to prevent such tragic losses,'' Brennan wrote. But he added, ``In the face of the `momentary evil' of drunken driving, the court today abdicates its role as the protector of'' the fundamental right of individual privacy. In a separate dissenting opinion, Stevens said, ``The most disturbing aspect of the court's decision today is that it appears to give no weight to the citizen's interest in freedom from suspicionless, unannounced investigatory seizures.'' ``Sobriety checkpoints are elaborate, and disquieting, publicity stunts,'' Stevens said. ``This is a case that is driven by nothing more than symbolic state action _ an insufficient justification for an otherwise unreasonable program of random seizures.'' Nadine Strosser, general counsel of the American Civil Liberties Union, said today's ruling ``strikes at the heart of the Fourth Amendment,'' which bans unreasonable police searches and seizures. ``This is the first time in American history that the government is allowed to conduct searches and seizures with a view of enforcing criminal laws without any individualized suspicion at all that the person is committing or about to commit a crime,'' she said. The traditional method police use to identify suspected drunken drivers is to observe traffic. Determining that method is not wholly effective, states in recent years began experimenting with other detection methods. Michigan state police first used sobriety checkpoints, which they modeled after a program in Maryland, in 1986. At a checkpoint site, police directed all traffic headed in one direction to a roadside area where officers talked to motorists. If there was no immediate evidence of intoxication, the motorist was given a traffic safety brochure and allowed to drive away. The average delay was about 30 seconds. If some signs of intoxication were detected, a driver was directed to another area for further questioning and perhaps a breath test. At one such checkpoint, Michigan state police troopers stopped 126 cars in less than an hour and detained two drivers for sobriety field tests. One driver was arrested on drunken-driving charges. Six Michigan legislators sued state police soon after the checkpoint program began. Their lawsuit alleged that the checkpoints violated the Fourth Amendment's ban on unreasonable police seizures and searches. State courts struck down the practice, citing ``the potential for an unreasonable subjective intrusion on individual liberty interests.'' Today, the nation's highest court said the Michigan courts were wrong. The Supreme Court in 1979 barred police from randomly stopping vehicles to check registration papers. In that Delaware case, officers had total discretion over which vehicles were stopped. But the 1979 decision did not rule out spot checks in which an officer's discretion was not so unconstrained. ``Questioning of all oncoming traffic at roadblock-type stops is one possible alternative,'' the court said 11 years ago. In this case, Michigan courts relied on another 1979 Supreme Court ruling in which the justices said the constitutionality of a police seizure made without ``probable cause'' to suspect a crime should be determined by three factors: _The gravity of the public concerns being served. _How the seizure advances the public interest. _The severity of the police interference with individual liberty. Today, the court said the Michigan sobriety checkpoint program satisfies all three factors. ``The balance of the state's interest in preventing drunken driving, the extent to which this system can reasonably be said to advance that interest, and the degree of intrusion upon individual motorists who are briefly stopped weighs in favor of the state program,'' Rehnquist wrote. In the pollution case, the justices upheld by a 9-0 vote the Environmental Protection Agency's power to seek fines of up to $25,000 a day against a General Motors plant in Massachusetts. However, the impact of the ruling for future cases may be limited. The House and Senate have passed separate bills revising the federal Clean Air Act that establish new timetables to address the kind of problem at issue in the General Motors case. In the Medicaid case, the justices by a 5-4 vote let a Virginia hospital association invoke a federal civil rights law in suing the state over Virginia's Medicaid reimbursement rates. Officials from most of the 50 states had urged the court to rule against the association. They said allowing such lawsuits could affect hundreds of millions of dollars in federal and state funding, and lead to a litigation explosion. The checkpoint case is State Police vs. Sitz, 88-1897.

DOC.HEAD: Salvagers Deploy Skimmers, Foam, Bacteria As Oil Slick Doubles
LaserPhoto HT1
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with four grafs to UPDATE with inquiry testimony that ship passed Coast Guard inspection in April; picks up 3rd graf, `Fireboats showered ...'; SUBS 15th graf `The ship ... ' to CLARIFY when accident reported. SUBS 16th graf, `The government ...' to conform.
DOC.TEXT: As many as 60 boats attacked a spreading oil slick with skimmers and booms to try to protect the shoreline today as fuel leaked from a 5.5 million-gallon tank on the burning Mega Borg. The oil slick about 30 miles off Galveston was an estimated 30 miles long and 10 miles wide in spots. Officials said they could not determine where the oil might wash ashore or how soon. A Coast Guard officer said at an inquiry today that the Mega Borg was in good condition in April when it passed a Coast Guard inspection. ``Both the engine and the pump rooms were in very good condition,'' said Coast Guard Petty Officer Richard Miles of the April inspection. ``I didn't see any excessive leaks. The bilges were clean and the vents were intact.'' Fireboats showered water on a ``low-level fire'' still burning in the engine room this morning. Firefighters were to return to the vessel later today to try spraying flame-smothering foam on the blaze again, the Coast Guard said. About 880 gallons of foam was used on the fire Wednesday, but the operation was halted when it caused the fire to flare. The oil slick was the rusty brown remains of about 3 million gallons of light African crude that the Coast Guard says leaked from the tanker in the five days since the first of a series of explosions aboard the Norwegian ship. Coast Guard officials said most of the spilled oil had either burned or evaporated, but as the ship's fire diminished, the slick from the 886-foot ship nearly doubled in length because oil was no longer being consumed by flames. The oil was spewing from a hole in the vessel's center tank, Coast Guard Capt. Thomas Greene said. ``I don't see any risk of losing cargo from the other tanks,'' he said. The leaking tank's capacity is 5.5 million gallons, but it wasn't known whether it had been full or how much oil remained, Ensign David Nichols said. Jim O'Brien, of O'Brien's Oil Production Services, said his company, also known as OOPS, had recovered about 30,000 gallons. Along with skimming, officials turned to an experimental procedure of dropping oil-consuming bacteria into the water. ``We're going to try it,'' Greene said. ``Anything we can do to clean up the spill, we'll try.'' But he said that the process, called bioremediation, is a new technology and is not considered a major part of the cleanup. A day after the ship fire was declared under control, firefighters Wednesday tried blanketing hot spots with foam. But the heat was so intense it ignited trapped vapors and caused a flare-up, forcing salvage crews to return to spraying water on the ship. ``The reflash is a minor setback,'' Coast Guard Chief Petty Officer Todd Nelson said. ``There is very little fire left on the ship.'' The ship's superstructure and stack are collapsed, its rear has dropped more than 60 feet and waves wash over the deck. The ship was carrying 38 million gallons of oil when its pump room exploded while it was transferring oil to a smaller vessel late Friday. The incident was reported to the Coast Guard about 1 a.m. Saturday. Two of the 41 crew members died, two were missing and presumed dead and 17 were injured, none seriously. The government of Norway started an inquiry Wednesday in Galveston to question crew members. The captain said he didn't know what sparked the explosion and that the crew went over a safety checklist before transferring the fuel. C.M. Mahidhara, 36, a sailor for 17 years and captain for nine, said he was in the radio room alone when he felt a ``sort of a bump'' and moments later ``the door swung open, the lights went out and glass was crashing down.'' In the confusion, Mahidhara moved his wife and children to safety, but he said that thick black smoke kept him from locating and commanding his crew. ``I looked forward and saw bright flames were coming from the pump room and ventilators,'' he said. ``The flames were licking up right over the bridge. The top of the pump room had been completely blown off.'' Mahidhara said the explosion occurred around 11:30 p.m. Friday, contrary to earlier reports that it happened early Saturday. Ole Leithe, a Norwegian maritime investigator who questioned the crewmen, said: ``I don't think we can find the reason for the explosion from this hearing. Maybe later when the ship is empty and cleaned we will know more.'' Officials said that when the fire is out it will take days for the superstructure to cool enough to start unloading oil. An 825-foot British-registered tanker stoody by to begin receiving the remainder of the ship's $22 million cargo from Angola.

DOC.HEAD: World Theater Announces Layoffs of All but Two Employees
DOC.TEXT: Money problems have forced the World Theater, former home for Garrison Keillor's ``A Prairie Home Companion,'' to lay off 10 of its 12 full-time employees. The decision became public Wednesday when employees of the elegant, 76-year-old former vaudeville show house were informed. The layoffs are effective on different dates through July 15. Of the theater's full-time employees, only Director Patrick Ruble and Operations Manager Ken Schumacher will remain. The World was restored as a permanent home for Keillor's radio program even though an effort to raise $3.5 million fell short. The city helped out with a $250,000, 12-year loan at 3 percent interest. The theater was left without a show when Keillor left St. Paul about a year after it reopened in 1986. The changes announced Wednesday mean the World will no longer present programs under its own auspices, but will continue to be available for rental, theater officials said. Previously booked events also will go on, said Ruble.

DOC.HEAD: Moonshiner Fined $1,500 for Producing `The Best'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Dollars are Canadian
DOC.TEXT: A moonshiner who prided himself on the quality of his hooch has been fined $1,500 in provincial court. William Russell Stewart, 46, was sentenced Wednesday after pleading guilty to possessing a still, possessing illegally manufactured liquor and selling liquor illegally. The Royal Canadian Mounted Police discovered Stewart's moonshine business in May. Bookkeeping ledgers found by police indicated an extensive commercial operation, prosecutor Anthony Allman told the court. Stewart sold 40-ounce bottles of his distilled product for $20 and pint bottles for $7. ``Was it good stuff?'' asked the judge. ``The best,'' said Stewart.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Makes Flag Day Visit to Vietnam Memorial
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new grafs 12-16, bgng, After attending... to UPDATE with Flag Day proclamation
DOC.TEXT: President Bush visited the Vietnam War Memorial at daybreak today to watch one U.S. flag being lowered and another raised. ``It was an appropriate way to observe Flag Day,'' said spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. Bush, who has been outspoken over the past few days in pressing for a constitutional amendment protecting the flag, did not speak at the brief ceremony and would not take questions from reporters. The White House renewed its push this week for the flmendment after the Supreme Court on Monday struck down the 1989 federal law against flag-desecration. Fitzwater later said no link was intended between Bush's active lobbying for the flag-protection amag protection aendment and his decision to visit Vietnam Memorial to be photographed watching the flag being raised. ``He went to the memorial because he thought it was an appropriate place to commemorate Flag Day,'' Fitzwater said. He denied that the White House was seeking to politicize the issue. But, on Capitol Hill, Senate Democrats used Flag Day speeches to criticize the proposed amendment and Bush's support for the change. ``We will be whimpering wimps if we at the Justice Department is committed to the investigation, prosecution and incarceration of those who ripped off our financial institutions and have left the taxpayers of the United States holding the bag,'' U.S. Attorney Dick Thornburgh said in a statement. Dixon was accused of encouraging employees to make about $7,000 in political contributions and then reimbursing them with expense money or phony bonuses to skirt restrictions on corporate campaign contributions. Among other things, Dixon was charged with conspiring with other Vernon officials to give money to Texas Democrat Jim Wright, the former House speaker who was pressing federal regulators to stop trying to close insolvent Texas thrifts. The indictment alleged Dixon also billed Vernon $10,500 for prostitutes for himself and others at a 1985 Vernon board of directors' party at Dixon's Solana Beach, Calif., beach house and on a yacht cruise in San Diego harbor. In 1985, Dixon allegedly used Vernon money for hunting trips with senior Vernon officials to Kansas and San Diego. L. Linton Bowman III, then commissioner of the Texas Savings and Loan Department, went along, the indictment said. Lodging, meals, female companionship and other expenses cost $4,866, the indictment said. Dixon also was accused of using his airplane for an illegal activity _ transporting prostitutes from Texas to California. Former Vernon vice president Patrick Malone testified at King's 1989 trial that contributions were solicited from King and other top thrift executives. The money was for the 1986 gubernatorial primary campaign of former Rep. Tom Loeffler, R-Texas, and the re-election bids of Wright, who resigned after a House ethics investigation unrelated to the Vernon case; former Rep. Jack Kemp, R-N.Y., now secretary of Housing and Urban Development; Sen. Jake Garn, R-Utah, and Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif. Dixon threw parties for other S&L operators aboard his yacht on the Potomac River in Washington to raise money for the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, chaired by then-Rep. Tony Coelho, D-Calif., the indictment said. At Coelho's request, Wright intervened with federal regulators to discuss Vernon, according to a report to the House Ethics Committee by Richard J. Phelan, an outside counsel hired to investigate Wright. Phelan reported that Wright telephoned Edwin Gray, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, and asked if Vernon were going to be shut down. Wright told the ethics panel he did not know Dixon. But Phelan's investigation produced a picture of Wright and Dixon aboard the yacht. The photograph bore the inscription, ``My best personal regards, Jim Wright.'' Wright's administrative assistant in Fort Worth did not immediately return phone calls seeking comment today. Dixon was the lead defendant in a $540 million federal fraud lawsuit brought after the Vernon shutdown but had not faced criminal charges until Wednesday. The lawsuit alleged that Dixon and other thrift officers grossly overstated Vernon's profits and net worth in order to pay $22.1 million in illegal dividends to Dondi Financial Corp., a holding company headed by Dixon. The Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp. lawsuit said top officials ``began to loot Vernon for their personal financial benefit and defraud its depositors, creditors and the FSLIC.''

DOC.HEAD: Congressman Wants Israel to Reopen West Bank Schools
DOC.TEXT: Like food, education should not be used as a military weapon, Rep. Howard Nielson said Thursday as he pushed for a congressional resolution pressuring Israel to reopen schools in the West Bank and Gaza. Nielson, at a news conference opening a conference of The Palestinian Academic Freedom Network, said he has introduced a resolution that urges Israel to take immediate steps to reopen all six universities in the West Bank and Gaza, which have been closed for more than two years. Israel captured the territories from Jordan and Egypt in the 1967 Middle East war and has maintained military control there. Israeli military authorities closed all Palestinian institutions of higher education when the intifadah, or Palestinian uprising, began in December 1987. Israeli authorities, arguing that the schools served as the focal point of the stone-throwing campaign against Israeli soldiers, also sometimes have closed all primary and secondary schools in the West Bank, including those run by the United Nations Relief and Works Agency. ``I think it's important that we continue to send the message to the Israeli government that education should not be used as a political tool,'' Nielson said. ``Education ought to transcend politics. It's as fundamental a basic human need as food. I understand the security concerns of the Israeli government, but I still find it unacceptable that school closings be used as a weapon against the intifadah.'' Although Israel has reopened West Bank primary and secondary schools, Michel Shehadeh of the Palestinian Network said 40,000 high school graduates are now languishing because they are not allowed to study at a university.

Here, at a glance, are highlights of actions taken Thursday by the Supreme Court.
SOBRIETY CHECKPOINTS
The court ruled that privacy rights of motorists are not violated when police try to curb drunken driving by stopping them at sobriety checkpoints, the Supreme Court ruled today. The 6-3 ruling upheld Michigan's sobriety checkpoint program and, by extension, similar programs in most states. The case is State Police vs. Sitz, 88-1897.
WELFARE
The court allowed the Bush administration to limit how much welfare aid some needy families receive. By a 5-4 vote, the court said Social Security benefits paid to children must be considered in determining a family's eligibility for benefits under the government's Aid to Families with Dependent Chidren program. The case is Sullivan vs. Stroop, 89-535.
POLLUTION
The court ruled the government may impose severe fines against air polluters even when federal officials are slow to decide on proposals for cleaning up the atmosphere. In the pollution case, the justices upheld by a 9-0 vote the Environmental Protection Agency's power to seek fines of up to $25,000 a day against a General Motors plant in Massachusetts. However, the impact of the ruling for future cases may be limited. The House and Senate have passed separate bills revising the federal Clean Air Act that establish new timetables to address the kind of problem at issue in the General Motors case. The case is General Motors vs. U.S., 89-369.
MEDICAID
The court ruled that hospitals and nursing homes may sue in federal court to challenge how a state-run Medicaid program reimburses their costs. The justices by a 5-4 vote let a Virginia hospital association invoke a federal civil rights law in suing the state over Virginia's Medicaid reimbursement rates. Officials from most of the 50 states had urged the court to rule against the association. They said allowing such lawsuits could affect hundreds of millions of dollars in federal and state funding, and lead to a litigation explosion. The case is Wilder vs. Virginia Hospital Association, 88-2043.
DISCOUNTS
The court barred manufacturers from giving discounts to wholesalers and not to retailers when the discounts are unrelated to any savings for the supplier or to the wholesaler's costs. The court unanimously upheld a $1.35 million antitrust award Texaco Inc. was ordered to pay to 12 service stations in the Spokane, Wash., area. The case is Texaco vs. Hasbrouck, 87-2048.

DOC.HEAD: Requiring Burglar to Buy Victim a Burglar Alarm Upheld
DOC.TEXT: A convicted burglar can be ordered to pay for a new burglar alarm for his victims as part of restitution, the Wisconsin Supreme Court ruled. In a 5-2 decision Wednesday, justices upheld a lower court order that Louis J. Heyn pay $4,000 for the purchase and installation of a burglar alarm. Heyn had been ordered to pay $4,082 in restitution for the items he stole. He argued that he could not be ordered to pay for the alarm because it not covered by state restitution laws. But the high court majority said such a payment ``aids the offender's reformation by educating him or her that a burglary is not simply a taking or destruction of personal property,'' but also ``destroys the sense of security that each person has a right to expect in his or her home.'' The victimized couple had told the trial court that the Nov. 13, 1987, burglary was traumatic, forcing the woman to seek medical care, so they installed the alarm system to ease their fears.

DOC.HEAD: Need Civic Pride? Adopt A Light Bulb
DOC.TEXT: You can get your name on a brick if you help fund the building. Now you can boost civic pride by adopting a light bulb. City Councilwoman Michelle Madoff says she is serious about her bright idea. The ``Adopt a Bulb'' project is designed to maintain bulbs that will decorate 11 city bridges. A donor who pays the cost of maintaining a single bridge light bulb would take great pleasure in pointing out their bulb to friends as they drive past, Ms. Madoff said. ``It may sound silly, but it could save us money,'' she said. ``It's workable.'' Pittsburgh officials want to decorate the city's bridges with lights as a tourist attraction, but no one knows how to finance the project. Officials have estimated it will cost about $5 million to wire 11 bridges, $330,000 per year for electricity and $220,000 for bulbs and maintenance.

DOC.HEAD: Ransom Dispute Holds Up Release of Kidnapped U.S. Miner
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with eight grafs to UPDATE with letter to family. Picks up 6th graf, `Scott Heimdal....'.
DOC.TEXT: An American miner held captive by Colombian guerillas is surviving on armadillo and monkey meat, according to a letter his family released today. Scott Heimdal told his family he is being moved daily in the jungle by his captors. The handwritten letter was dated June 2 and delivered late Wednesday to his parents, Roy and Marge Heimdal, in Peoria. The family learned Wednesday that the kidnappers wanted $612,000, more than 10 times the $60,000 ransom paid. ``We understood that $60,000 is what they wanted,'' Roy Heimdal said. ``There's no way we could raise $612,000. That's impossible.'' Scott Heimdal's letter confirmed reports that the kidnappers became angry after seeing a television report week about fund-raising efforts in Peoria. In his letter, the Heimdal said the kidnappers think the family lied about their finances after seeing their modest rented home. ``I have to do everything in my power to convince them we don't have anything,'' Scott Heimdal wrote. He said his infected feet are healing and believes ``somehow this nightmare will be over soon.'' Scott Heimdal was working as a gold miner for the Ecuadoran company IMINCO when he was abducted by armed men April 28 while traveling by boat in the jungle near the Colombian border. The boat driver was killed in the attack. The guerrillas have identified themselves as members of the People's Liberation Army. The elder Heimdal said the family had done everything possible to convince the kidnappers it doesn't have any money. The family raised the ransom during a furious, four-day public appeal. Donations came in from around the country. ``We sold everything we had and had to get help from strangers to raise $60,000. We don't have anymore,'' Mrs. Heimdal said. ``I'm on the verge of losing my sanity. I'm a nervous wreck. This added pressure is overwhelming.'' Jeffrey Fino, IMINCO general manager, said from his office in Quito, Ecuador, that the $60,000 was only a down payment ``to guarantee his life.'' Fino said a meeting with rebels Monday ended in failure. The guerrillas were upset because the go-between had tried to deliver the payment in dollars instead of Colombian pesos even though they originally demanded dollars, Fino said. ``To make clear how irrational and unlogical these guys are, they told our intermediary to take the dollars from the middle of the jungle and be back within three hours with Colombian pesos or they were going to kill Scott,'' Fino said. ``He had to get back in a canoe, go back to the little river port he had left from, grab a taxi and go into the main town of Lago Agrio. He cleaned out the town of pesos.'' But there was not enough Colombian currency in the tiny Ecuadoran oil town 25 miles from the rendezvous site. The guerrillas set a date later this month for the balance of the payment. Fino would not reveal the date. ``At that time we will demand Scott's release for that amount of money,'' he said. ``They need to understand that's all the money they're going to get.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Meets With Thailand's Prime Minister
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Top 15 grafs new with leaders' quotes after meeting; picks up 6th graf pvs, It is...
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Thai Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan today pledged to work together to fight narcotics and bring peace to war-ravaged Cambodia through ``free and fair elections'' under the United Nations' lead. The two leaders, in nearly 2{ hours of meetings and a working luncheon at the White House, also agreed to forge new ties between their commerce ministers to promote investment and defuse trade disputes. Bush called Thailand ``one of America's oldest friends and closest allies.'' ``What is most remarkable about Thailand is that it has combined a double-digit economic growth with the emergence of parliamentary democracy,'' said Bush. Bush said he and Chatichai agreed to keep pressing for a comprehensive solution under the United Nations' auspices to ``the tragic conflict in Cambodia.'' Both nations will ``continue our diplomatic efforts to end the violence'' and assure ``genuine self-determination through free and fair elections under U.N. auspices and in the presence of an international peacekeeping force'' in Cambodia, Bush said. Chatichai, speaking in English, said, ``Our two countries are committed more than ever to work together in bringing peace to Cambodia and to end the suffering of the Cambodian people.'' Bush said the two countries' commerce ministers will form a new Joint U.S.-Thai Committee for Commercial Cooperation. Chatichai said they were seeking to establish ``a new framework for economic cooperation ... (that) would allow us to regularly discuss any potential trade issues before they become trade disputes.'' The United States currently imposes duties on $165 million of Thai products to pressure the country to stop infringement of U.S. patent and intellectual property rights on products ranging from computers to Hollywood videotapes to pharmaceuticals. Bush expressed ``profound appreciation'' for Thailand's providing asylum to Indochinese refugees and assured Chatichai that America will welcome ``our share of Vietnamese refugees.'' Bush said there is ``one kind of business we agree we will not tolerate and that is narcotics.'' He promised to keep working to reduce U.S. demand for drugs. Chatichai said drugs are ``tearing apart the very fabrics of our societies. ... I pledge to you the full support of the Thai government in the war against drug trafficking.'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III also joined the leaders for the talks. Chatichai was also meeting with leaders of Congress and addressing the National Press Club on Friday. Thailand boasted the world's fastest growing economy last year, burgeoning at nearly an 11 percent rate. It is a transit point for half the heroin reaching the United States from the so-called Burma-Laos-Thailand ``golden triangle.'' The United States has applauded asset seizure and anticonspiracy measures that Chatichai's government recently introduced in parliament to crack down on drug traffickers. Thailand also bears the burden of 300,000 temporary refugees from the civil war in neighboring Cambodia. It has drawn criticism from some human rights groups for turning away Vietnamese boat people. The pullout of Vietnam's occupying forces from Cambodia has eased the immediate threat to Thailand's own security, a senior U.S. official said Wednesday, making this ``an opportune time'' to press for a diplomatic solution to the strife in Cambodia. The United States and Thailand have worked together to encourage a settlement under the auspices of the United Nations. Thailand recently helped arrange talks in Tokyo between Prince Sihanouk and Hun Sen, installed as head of Cambodia's government after the Vietnamese invasion in 1978. Chatichai also conferred recently with Xu Dunxin, a top Chinese official who recently traveled to both Bangkok and Vietnam. The United States has opposed the flow of Chinese arms to the communist Khmer Rouge, strongest of the warring Cambodian factions, who are blamed for killing more than 1 million of their countrymen during their bloody 1975-78 rule. Some environmental groups were staging a protest march today against what they called ``crass hypocrisy'' by Chatichai's government in prohibiting logging within Thailand while granting more than 40 licenses to Thai companies to harvest teak and other rain forest timber in Burma.

DOC.HEAD: Coal Miners Call for Prime Minister to Resign
DOC.TEXT: Coal miners from across the Soviet Union, gathered to debate the formation of an independent union and a possible strike, have urged Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov and his government to resign. ``The government of the U.S.S.R. does not have our trust,'' read a telegram sent to the national Supreme Soviet legislature by the First Congress of Miners of the Soviet Union, meeting at the largest Soviet coal field. ``We urge workers in other industries to quickly cut their ties with the government,'' said the resolution, which was sent Wednesday and read Thursday at the Supreme Soviet in Moscow. The telegram also criticized an economic reform plan proposed last month by Ryzhkov and defended on national TV by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. In the Ukrainian city of Donetsk, Mining Minister Mikhail Shchadov fielded angry questions from the workers, then stormed from the conference hall after the delegates voted by a 330-14 margin to disband an advisory committee he had appointed and replace it with one named by the union Congress. ``Resign! Resign!'' delegates shouted as Shchadov took their questions and accusations for some 30 minutes. One miner, shouting from the floor of the conference hall, demanded to know why Shchadov remained minister of the mining industry despite his failure to fulfill promises made to end the nationwide coal strike last summer. ``I think I am qualified to be mining minister,'' Shchadov replied. But his answer was cut off by the acting speaker of the congress, Bulat Mukhazanov, who accused him of not responding directly to the miners' questions. The miners were expected to vote Friday on whether to form a new union in place of the old union that they say is controlled by the ministry, which owns all mines and most related industries in the Soviet Union. The miners also were divided on whether to organize a strike this summer to protest the government's failure to fulfill promises made to end last summer's nationwide walkout. The telegram to the Supreme Soviet mentioned neither Ryzkov nor Gorbachev by name, but in Soviet political parlance the term ``government'' generally refers to the Council of Ministers headed by the premier. It accuses the government of being responsible for the ``worsening of the social-economic system in the country,'' and lacking the ability to make crucial decisions ``to lead the country out of the economic crisis with a minimum of social suffering.'' The miners' congress, consisting of 712 delegates representing every coal shaft and pit in the country, was organized following strikes that shut down coal production last summer and crippled heavy industry. Delegates said they might be swayed by the newly elected president of the Russian Federation, Boris N. Yeltsin, who last week urged the miners not to strike. However, the miners are angry. They said the government has failed to fulfill promises to increase their supply of food and consumer goods, improve mine safety or give them greater power in setting prices. The agreement ``is hardly being implemented,'' said Yuri L. Makarov, a member of the organizing committee. ``The biggest thing is the purchase price of coal. Now the price is 24 rubles a ton. We want it increased to 80-85 rubles.'' At a realistic exchange rate, that would still be lower than the world price of $32 a ton for Soviet coal. The official exchange rate puts 80 rubles at $133, but it is just $13 at the government's tourist rate, and less than $10 at the black market rate. ``They offer us economic independence but leave the old prices fixed. That is absurd,'' he said. Safety does not appear to have improved either, as fatal accidents have been reported this month in the two largest Soviet coal fields, the Kuznetsk Basin in Western Siberia and the Donetsk Basin. In the Donetsk, ``Each million tons of coal cost the lives of two or three coal miners,'' the newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda reported Wednesday in a dispatch from the congress.

DOC.HEAD: US Says Bulgarian Election May Have Been Tainted
DOC.TEXT: Widespread intimidation of voters may have plagued the balloting in which the party of former Communists won opening round victories in Bulgaria's parliamentary elections, the State Department said Thursday. Results announced Thursday showed that the former communists, running under the Socialist Party banner, won 172 of the 319 seats in the Bulgarian Parliament that were decided in the first round of voting. A runoff election is scheduled for Sunday to decide the remaining 81 seats. The problems that have come to light ``raise serious questions about the electoral process,'' State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said. ``There are many reports of local officials threatening voters with loss of jobs, pensions or other benefits,'' she said. ``In addition, proper measures to ensure secrecy were not taken in all locations, with un-curtained polling stations and transparent ballot envelopes reported in some places.'' In some villages, Ms. Tutwiler said, local officials reportedly handed out Socialist Party ballots to voters in polling places. She said American observers noted the atmosphere of fear in the countryside during the election process. Bulgaria was the only country in the Soviet bloc where the Communists, who changed their party's name in April, remained the strongest political force.

DOC.HEAD: Drugs, Migration Could Be Part of US-Mexico Trade Talks, Official Says
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration will consider including problems of drugs and migration in free-trade talks with Mexico, U.S. Trade Representative Carla A. Hills told congressmen Thursday. She said Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, who deals with illegal migration, and William J. Bennett, head of the Office of National Drug Control Policy, had been in on recent talks with Mexican officials. ``They were heartened by the kind of cooperation they got,'' she said. ``I think that two areas where we will benefit from the free trade agreement in the drugs area is by the creation of jobs and opportunities. There will be less reason to turn to drugs as a means of well-being, and cooperation is enhanced where you have a good economic relationship between governments,'' Hills said in testimony before the House Ways and Means subcommittee on trade. She was pressed by Rep. Frank J. Guarini, D-N.J., whose district is just across the Hudson River from New York City, where drugs and migration are major problems. ``Why not put them on the table at this point?'' he asked. ``Why miss this opportunity?'' He suggested that Thornburgh and Bennett join in the free trade talks, agreed to earlier this week by President Bush and Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gortari. ``Well, we'll consider that,'' Hills said. ``There are so many problems you could have quite a table and... ``I know. But what an opportunity, what an opportunity to become better neighbors,'' Guarini interrupted. Rep. Charles B. Rangel, D-N.Y., also pressed Hills on the drug issue. ``To have it inferred that a threat to our national security would not be on the table as we talk with our friends who are joining us in trying to prevent the hundreds of tons of opium, marijuana and cocaine that are pouring across this border, to me would be sending a wrong message to our friends in Mexico,'' he said. Hills said she intends to work with Congress on the trade talks, which she said would begin in earnest next year. Her prepared testimony mentioned neither drugs nor migration. She reviewed and praised President Salinas' new economic policies but said liberalization could go further by: _Further lowering of Mexican tariffs and other barriers to imports. _Passage of laws favorable to foreign investment, rather than present regulations. _Greater opening by Mexico to activity of foreign firms in banking, securities, insurance and transport. _Changes in Mexican patent and copyright laws to protect foreign rights.

DOC.HEAD: Man Wins Over Feminists at NOW
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `Before his ...' to CORRECT to Macomb, sted McComb
DOC.TEXT: He's one of their highest officers, but some National Organization for Women members suspect Dave Stewart is like the wolf dressed in grandma's clothing trying to trick Little Red Riding Hood. ``I think David knows that anytime he meets new women, there's a certain suspicion,'' admitted Kathy Sandrock of Bettendorf, former president of the Quad-City NOW Chapter. ``There's a hint of, `What's he doing here? How can he know our issues?''' But one after another, Stewart has knocked down those suspicions and last month he was elected to a seat on NOW's 30-member governing board, representing the Prairie States region of Iowa, Minnesota, Nebraska and the Dakotas. There is only one other man on the board, John Katz, representing the Washington, D.C., area. ``I don't have any personal goals,'' he said in a telephone interview from his home in Davenport. ``My goals are NOW's goals. I didn't use my sex to get elected. ... When you're involved as long as I have been, you prove your point that you're not involved for the fun of it, not just there to have friends and parties. After a while, your sex becomes moot. They can see you're not a flash in the pan.'' As for the suspicions, Ms. Sandrock said Stewart puts most wary women at ease within minutes. ``He debunks the suspicions within 10, 15 minutes,'' she said. ``He has never treated anybody with less than respect. There are still some women who resent him, but they're the women who have been so mistreated and abused by the system that the only way they can translate it is that men are bad.'' She said Stewart handles these women with patience, asking only to be heard. Stewart, 33, joined NOW in 1982 and became active in the drive to ratify the national Equal Rights Amendment, which eventually failed. ``For many people, that was burn-out time, but since I was new, I just stayed involved,'' he explained. Before his NOW days, Stewart was active in campus issues at Western Illinois University in Macomb. It was the ERA that drew his interest to NOW. ``It just made such common sense; I couldn't see the controversy.'' Stewart predicts the ERA will rise again, but he is now concentrating on preserving abortion rights. Stewart said he never thought it unusual to pursue feminist issues with one of the more outspoken women's groups, saying that it's important for people to act on their beliefs. ``Some men might say, `Well, I couldn't join that group.' And I say, `If you agree with their issues, you should walk your talk.' That's why my bumper sticker says, `Walk Your Talk,''' he said. Past chapter president Nita Eagle-Frink of Rock Island, Ill., said Stewart has convinced even the more skeptical members that he is sincere. She said Stewart does have to be coached now and then. For instance, he once said he liked the annual Sports Illustrated swimsuit issue, she said. ``We'd say, `Oh, David,' Ms. Sandrock said. ```OK, David, here's why we don't do that.' ``But he took it with grace.'' Aside from his NOW activities, Stewart works at a group home where he counsels adults with physical and mental disabilities. He is single. ``I've got two cats, 13 plants and NOW. There's no time for anything else,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: After 40 Years, Beetle Bailey Wins Over The Army
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto WX24
DOC.TEXT: Beetle Bailey, the lazy but lovable GI who has stumbled through comic pages for the past 40 years, finally won an admiring salute Thursday from the U.S. Army. In a Flag Day ceremony at the Pentagon, cartoonist Mort Walker received a framed ``certificate of appreciation for patriotic civilian service'' from Brig. Gen. Bill McClain, who declared an armistice in the Army's decades-old hostilities against the slovenly buck private. ``Through it all, you have entertained us, although sometimes we haven't always liked it,'' said McClain, the Army's public affairs chief. He observed: ``If you can't laugh at yourself, something is intrinsically wrong with you.'' Tongue in cheek, Walker replied that it was always ``the dream of Gen. Halftrack and mine to hear from the Pentagon,'' and it took 40 years to get the call. ``I can't believe I'm actually here,'' Walker said. ``As hard as it is to find anything in the Pentagon, they finally found a sense of humor.'' Since Walker created the popular comic strip in 1950, based on his experiences as an Army draftee in World War II, Beetle Bailey and his cartoon friends have annoyed some Pentagon brass who complained they presented an unflattering image of Army life. In 1954, the Tokyo edition of The Stars and Stripes military newspaper drummed Beetle off its pages because the strip poked fun at officers. The official explanation was that ``Beetle Bailey had a low interest value,'' but the move was denounced in newspaper editorials as silly. Stars and Stripes banned the strip again in 1970, as did some Southern newspapers, when Walker introduced Lt. Flap, a feisty black character. Miss Buxley, the bosomy secretary to Gen. Halftrack, drew protests from feminists. Putting the controversy behind, the Army heaped praise on Walker in its citation Thursday. ``His ingenuity in portraying Army members in a humorous manner has contributed significantly to the morale of our soldiers as they provide for our national security,'' it read. ``I read it and laugh at it, and others do, too,'' McClain confessed afterward. Said Maj. Gen. Richard E. Stephenson, who attended the ceremony: ``Beetle Bailey is the vehicle that enables us to see the lighter side of our profession and keeps us from taking ourselves too seriously.'' Accompanied by life-size Beetle and Sarge characters, Walker gave Army officials a cartoon diorama based on his special Flag Day strip. It appeared Thursday in the more than 1,800 newspapers worldwide that carry Beetle Bailey. The diorama will hang on permanent display in a Pentagon hallway near the main entrance. While the Beetle and Sarge characters roamed the corridors waving to Pentagon secretaries and taking salutes from passing generals and admirals, Walker was a guest at a cake-cutting ceremony in the Pentagon's inner courtyard marking the 215th birthday of the U.S. Army on Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Two Cows Hoisted From Sinkhole
DOC.TEXT: Two cows were stuck in a 25-foot-deep sinkhole for six hours until crews using a crane rescued them Thursday, authorities said. ``They mooed some but they didn't seem to be distracted in any way,'' said Alachua County spokesman Steve Russell. County emergency workers, volunteer firefighters, paramedics and a veterinarian spent six hours trying to figure out how to get the cows out. Until the crane pulled them out, the cows were given hay and water to keep them calm. The cows' owner was walking around his pasture Wednesday night when he found a 10-foot wide sinkhole and spotted his cows in it. ``We have had sinkholes before ... but to my knowledge, I don't remember a sinkhole with two cows,'' Russell said. ``They were just in the pasture and they happened to go. They were in the wrong place at the wrong time.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: She's gone from co-star to girlfriend, but actress Nicole Kidman isn't kissing and telling about beau Tom Cruise. Miss Kidman co-stars in Cruise's ``Days of Thunder,'' a soon-to-be released auto-racing drama, and attended this year's Oscars ceremonies with him in the wake of his marital split with actress Mimi Rogers. But the Australian-born actress isn't boasting about her relationship with the star of ``Rain Man,'' who was nominated for best actor in ``Born on the Fourth of July.'' ``There's nothing more to say except, yeah, we're together,'' the actress tells Rolling Stone in its July 12 issue. She says she and Cruise have gone skydiving but she doesn't share his passion for the automotive world. Cruise has driven competitively, and he portrays a race car driver in ``Days of Thunder.'' ``I'm not a very good driver,'' she said. ``There's a scene in the film where I have to drive an automatic BMW, and I had trouble doing even that.''

``Gonzo'' journalist Hunter S. Thompson was more than fashionably late to a free-form ``lecture,'' but the packed house that waited for him didn't care. The irreverent writer and syndicated columnist arrived two hours late before fielding questions Wednesday from a feisty crowd of 700 who paid $17.50 each for an evening with the literary anti-hero. He was asked about his recent court case in Colorado that started when a former X-rated film producer accused him of sexual assault. ``I wouldn't have taken her to a concert around the corner,'' he said. All charges were dropped in that case last month. Thompson, the author of ``Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas,'' ``The Great Shark Hunt,'' and ``Generations of Swine: Tales of Shame and Degradation in the '80s,'' was introduced by longtime friend C. David Burgin, editor in chief of The Houston Post. Thompson's lecture never materialized in a conventional sense. He ranted for a few moments about American youth and then opened up the evening to questions.

Actress Suzanne Somers told lawmakers that alcoholism crushed her self-esteem as a child and would have made her entertainment career impossible had she not sought professional help. ``If you don't feel good about yourself, you can't win,'' Miss Somers told the House Subcommittee on Substance Abuse on Wednesday. She urged them to create programs to help children of alcoholics seek treatment. She said she and members of her family would cower in a locked closet during her father's drunken rages. She said she would dream of being on stage entertaining an audience to shut out her father's screaming. ``I remember every crazy violent night,'' she said. ``I remember every time he hit my mother, and I remember every time he hit me. I remember walking home from school and seeing my father passed out on a street corner.'' The anti-alcoholism crusader and star of TV's old ``Three's Company,'' wrote ``Keeping Secrets'' two years ago. The book tells about her life as the child of an alcoholic and how her family changed because of treatment programs.

Donald Trump's casino tour for tennis star Gabriela Sabatini broke state gaming rules because she's too young to go into the pit, but no action is planned against him, authorities said. The Argentinian athlete was 19 when Trump led her on a tour of the Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino in September. Visitors to casino gambling areas must be 21, but officials said no one is complaining. ``If we get a legitimate complaint, we'll investigate it,'' said Wayne Marlin, spokesman for New Jersey's Division of Gaming Enforcement. A casino official who spoke on condition of anonymity said Ms. Sabatini had not gambled. The official said Trump merely showed her around the casino. Trump aide Norma Foerderer said the Manhattan developer and casino owner would not comment on the incident, first reported Wednesday by the New York Post. The casino tour came after Ms. Sabatini, now 20, lost a U.S. Open match in New York, Casino Control Commission spokesman Tom Flynn said Wednesday.

The governor's husband is the author of a cookbook but he lost the not-so-coveted title of ``His Blinding Magnificence, the King of Cornhusker Cookery'' in a cookoff on main street. The spoof culinary showdown pitted Bill Orr, husband of Gov. Kay Orr and author of ``The First Gentleman's Cookbook,'' against Roger Welsch, a regular contributor on CBS' ``Sunday Morning.'' Welsch first named Orr the Cornhusker cooking king and promptly challenged him for the title. The challenger provided both competitors' entries, offering a plump mesquite-broiled steak for himself, while Orr was judged on a scrawny piece of meat spotted with green food coloring and accompanied by a pail of cow chips as seasonings. ``I came in a close second while Welsch finished next to last,'' Orr said after the gag Wednesday. Proceeds from Orr's book are being used for a planned remodeling of the governor's mansion.

DOC.HEAD: Harlem Dance Company Gets $1 Million Grant
DOC.TEXT: The Dance Theater of Harlem, the ballet company that canceled two tours this year because a financial crisis, received a $1 million conditional grant Thursday. The Lila Wallace-Reader's Digest Fund will give $600,000 to help reduce the company's deficit and $400,000 for dancers' salaries and company operations _ provided the company raises additional funds by Sept. 30, the end of its fiscal year, said M. Christine DeVita, president of the fund. Officials declined to say how much money the company needed to raise. In January, after two tours by the company were canceled, the board voted to cancel the New York season and lay off 51 dancers. ``The Dance Theater of Harlem is a world-class ballet company and clearly a national treasure,'' DeVita said. ``Given the fund's interest in building bridges between artists and communities, we would be remiss if we did not come forward to help DTH.'' The Dance Theater of Harlem was the first American ballet company to tour the Soviet Union and for two decades it has performed on stages around the world. Its artistic director is Arthur Mitchell, former principal dancer with the New York City Ballet.

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Vetoes Public Funds for High Speed Rail Link
DOC.TEXT: The government on Thursday said it would not pay for a proposed multibillion-dollar, high-speed rail link between London and an English Channel tunnel. The decision, announced in the House of Commons by Transport Secretary Cecil Parkinson, cast doubt on whether such a link to the capital would be built in Britain. One is being built in France. Critics say failure to construct such a line would hurt Britain's trade prospects with the Continent and increase the misery of tens of millions of commuters who will have to share already crowded roads and trains with millions more foreign visitors. Parkinson said the link's builders, European Rail Link, have declined to proceed without public money. Rail Link is led by government-owned British Rail, but Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher hopes to privatize the railway. The opposition Labor Party attacked the government's decision. ``Britain will enter the 21st century with an inadequate 19th century railway link,'' Labor lawmaker John Prescott said. France already is building a high-speed link from Paris to Calais, which will hook up the tunnel's freight and passenger traffic to a high-speed system being planned across Europe. The French railways SNCF last year offered to help finance a British high-speed rail link from London to Folkestone. British Rail currently is negotiating with that company, the British Rail spokesman said. In addition, European Rail Link had sought about $600 million in public funds toward the project in return for commuter use of the new line. British Rail has not publicly announced how much a link would cost, but estimates put the price tag at $4.4 billion to $6.2 billion. One reason the French are more enthusiastic is that their tunnel entrance is in one of the most depressed areas of France. The British end is in England's rural and prosperous southeast. Many Britons cling to their insularity and are ambivalent toward ``the Chunnel,'' which some think would allow an invasion of England. Mrs. Thatcher defended her Cabinet's decision, telling the House of Commons that British legislation prohibits the government from subsidizing international travel links. Mrs. Thatcher said the government already was spending $3.4 billion on roads and railways to and from the tunnel. The veto is another blow for the beleaguered Anglo-French consortium which is building the 31-mile rail tunnel under the English Channel entirely with private funds. Eurotunnel has suffered from soaring costs, which are forcing it to seek extra funding from its banks and shareholders. The latest cost estimate is $13.1 billion. The tunnel is still targeted to open in June 1993. When finished, Eurotunnel will carry passengers from London to Paris in about three hours, about the same time as an air flight _ inlcuding time getting to and from the airport _ and half the time of a car-ferry journey.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Agents Investigate Walrus Kills off Alaska
DOC.TEXT: Federal investigators are looking into what appears to be poaching and mutilation of walruses for ivory in the Bering Sea. Officials first learned of the kills Tuesday after Coast Guard safety inspectors boarded a fishing boat that recently had returned to port from the Bering Sea herring fishery. They found two walrus skulls and two sets of tusks aboard. ``They were in the process of cleaning them out, boiling them,'' said Coast Guard Chief Petty Officer Ed Moore. The evidence has been turned over to the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. A second seizure of walrus remains was reported Wednesday by a Coast Guard boarding group after a safety inspection of the fishing vessel Maverick. Both seizures were made at Naknek, a port city about 300 miles southwest of Anchorage, where the Coast Guard had set up a temporary safety inspection detachment. According to the Coast Guard, Maverick skipper Delton Repnow said walrus parts were retrieved after they were found floating in the water. And Steven J. Hansen, the skipper of the first vessel, the tender Chichigoff, told investigators that on June 4 his vessel found a dozen walrus carcasses floating about 40 miles south of Nome in Norton Sound. Ten walrus carcasses were headless and two still had their heads, said Walter E. Soroka, a fish and wildlife field supervisor. In the process of cleaning the heads and removing the tusks, the crewmen found at least one small-caliber bullet in one of the walruses, officials said. Crew members told the Coast Guard they thought they legally could keep the walrus ivory and had intended to report their find as required by law. The Coast Guard said discovery of the carcasses had been entered in the vessel's log book. The Marine Mammal Protection Act makes it a federal crime to recover ivory from walruses found at sea, Soroka said. It is legal to recover walrus carcasses found on shorelines. Eskimos and other Alaska natives are allowed to hunt walruses for subsistence use, but cutting off walrus heads and leaving the rest of the carcass is illegal, even for natives, said Soroka. ``We don't know who removed the heads,'' he said. ``We plan to find out. That's something that we look at seriously.'' Soroka said Hansen has cooperated in the investigation. ``He contacted me. ... He told me he misconstrued the laws,'' Soroka said. Robert Brophy, president of Seattle-based Icicle Seafoods Inc., the owner of the vessel, said he doubted his employees intentionally broke the law. Walrus ivory is used in Alaska and around the world as a craft substitute for elephant ivory. With the recent crackdown on illegal elephant hunting in Africa, Alaska ivory has become more popular among carvers. Penalties for poaching are strict. If the crew of a fishing vessel is found to have been poaching walruses, the government may seize the vessel, Soroka said. Individuals convicted of violating the Marine Mammal Protection Act face up to a year in prison and $100,000 fine.

DOC.HEAD: A New Monument for the City of Monuments
DOC.TEXT: This city of monuments, statues and memorials has a new attraction to stir the emotions and evoke the glories of the past. This newest of Washington's monuments, 22 of the original 24 columns from the U.S. Capitol, literally had to be pulled from the mud of the Anacostia River and painstakingly stripped of 35 coats of white paint. Now, after a mighty effort by a few people, the columns stand on the highest point of a great meadow at the National Arboretum, cleaned up, repaired and splendid again, holding up nothing but sky and glory. Set between the columns are 500 marble slabs once used as steps on the Senate wing of the Capitol. In the middle of all this is a small fountain, from which water flows into a reflecting pool designed so that the full image of the columns is mirrored in the water. The National Capitol Columns, as they are called, were dedicated Wednesday with all the pomp due a newborn shrine. The Air Force Band played, an all-service color guard presented the flag, the president sent a message and heat put the audience into a patriotic sweat. ``It is most fitting that the columns will have a permanent new home,'' said Clayton Yeutter, the secretary of agriculture. ``They are a spectacular addition to the scenery of our great city.'' Bill Allen, architectural historian of the Capitol, was on hand to supply the history of the 10-ton sandstone columns _ and a long one they have had. Twenty-seven presidents, from Martin van Buren to Dwight D. Eisenhower, took the oath of office in their shadow. When they were first installed on the east front of the Capitol in 1826, congressmen left their benches to help pull the ``strong carriage'' on which the columns had been placed up Capitol Hill. The columns were the finishing touch to the rebuilding of the Capitol after the British burned the House and Senate wings in 1814. The columns were put between the two wings, in the rotunda, which was completed in 1824. Sam Rayburn, the longtime speaker of the House, went out of the Capitol every evening to look at and be inspired by the columns, which are unadorned except for acanthus leaves carved into the caps. The columns were the principal feature of the Capitol until a new front was put on in 1958 and completed just in time for John F. Kennedy's inauguration in 1961. The columns, replaced by bigger ones made of marble, were unceremoniously taken to the Capitol power plant and lay there for 15 years. In 1973, they were trucked to the banks of the Anacostia River and left to sink in the mud. A determined woman, Ethel Garrett, campaigned for more than 20 years to have the columns put on public display at the arboretum. She died without seeing her plan come to fruition. Betty Rae, chairman of the project, said all of the nearly $2 million spent on the project was raised from private donors, many of whom were at the ceremony Wednesday. The columns ``will draw people to the arboretum who never would have come to the arboretum,'' she said. The National Arboretum, 300 acres of great trees and shrubs, is one of Washington's best-kept secrets, located miles away from the city's more famous attractions.

DOC.HEAD: White House Phone Lines Jammed After Baker Gives Out Number
DOC.TEXT: Calls swamped the White House switchboard after Secretary of State James A. Baker's public entreaty for Israeli officials to call the number ``when you're serious about peace,'' a spokesman said Thursday. Baker publicly gave out the number during a Senate committee hearing on Wednesday, and by the end of the day, some 6,000 to 8,000 calls had clogged the White House lines, said President Bush's press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater. ``The switchboard was finally blocked to the point where it couldn't handle it anymore. And they had to put it on automatic thank-you tape,'' Fitzwater told reporters. On Thursday, the call volume remained heavy. It took 24 rings for a switchboard operator to answer one call. ``It's busy here today,'' she acknowledged. Baker, whose State Department office is at a different location and different phone number, sent flowers Thursday to the operators, his spokeswoman, Margaret Tutwiler said. Although Baker's remark about the telephone number came during a discussion of Israel, Tutwiler made the point that at several times in his testimony he referred to the ``parties'' in the peace process, in the plural. As to whether Baker intended to pinpoint the Israeli government, she said, he ``intended the phone number to be used by all.'' Asked if the Bush administration questions whether Israel wants peace, Fitzwater said, ``We have not yet seen the dialogues start, so there is a question, certainly, on both sides.'' Baker sarcastically recited the White House number, 202 456-1414, in the Senate hearing where he bluntly prodded Israel on its commitment to peacefully settling the Mideast turmoil. Asked about giving out that number instead of his own, Baker told reporters on Thursday, ``I worked over here four years and I had that one memorized.'' Baker was chief of staff to President Reagan. He said in his testimony Wednesday that his message to ``everybody over there,'' was ``when you're serious about peace, call us.'' But the Israeli government did not call, said Fitzwater. Instead, the broadcast of Baker's remarks on television and radio news brought thousands of calls from the public, wanting to talk ``all over the issue on all sides.'' Typically, the switchboard might get 100 or 200 calls in the time period that saw thousands after Baker's Wednesday comments. An Israeli reporter, Yaacov Eilon, said the White House operator who answered his call on Wednesday said, ``You would have to call the State Department. ... That number is 647-4000.''

DOC.HEAD: Plane Slips Past Border Guards to Leave Flowers for Gorbachev
DOC.TEXT: As flower deliveries go, it was spectacular. A light plane swooped from the Soviet sky without warning and dropped off flowers for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev at an airport near Turkey before zipping back across the frontier, Soviet media said Thursday. Clearly, at least some Soviets have gained a sense of humor since a 19-year-old West German youth buzzed the Kremlin and landed his Cessna on Red Square before startled KGB guards in May 1988. That young man, Mathias Rust, spent 14 months in a Soviet prison after the photo of his plane in front of St. Basil's Cathedral made front pages around the world. Soviet authorities fired their defense minister and air defense chief after Rust flew from Finland to Moscow undetected. The latest incident was reported in a mocking article in Izvestia under the headline, ``Rust Number Two?'' Izvestia and Tass, quoting the labor newspaper Trud, said that on June 9, a Cessna sneaked into Soviet airspace undetected by flying barely 600 feet above the mountainous southern border with Turkey. It touched down at the Batumi municipal airport for less than 40 seconds, just long enough to drop off a bouquet of carnations, greetings for Gorbachev, and a $20 bill. ``We Germans are very grateful to him,'' said the note to Gorbachev. The author signed the note, ``Hans Schneider.'' The Ministry of Defense said air defenses ``did not act,'' Izvestia reported. ``Translating this into simple language, we dare to say this means they failed to notice him,'' the newspaper concluded. ``Thank God, the second Rust had enough tact not to land at a military base!'' Trud said border guards and air defenders failed to coordinate their actions. It said helicopters should have been sent after the plane. ``After all, he is still a violator, even though he has an excellent sense of humor,'' Trud said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Legislature Delays Increase in Bread Price
DOC.TEXT: The legislature ordered a two-month delay Thursday in an unpopular threefold increase in bread prices, a centerpiece of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's market reforms. The Supreme Soviet voted 319-33 that the government should produce another version of the plan in September, easing the effect of price increases. Bread prices, the staple of the Soviet diet, would have increased July 1. Gorbachev had indicated the price increase was a test of the Soviet Union's willingness to tolerate a free market. It was intended to help pay the cost of recently increased payments to grain farmers. The increase was part of an economic program that touched off panic buying in Moscow and led the capital's government to require proof of residence before allowing purchases. Lawmakers rejected the measure because of its great unpopularity among voters, said one deputy, Alexei Boiko, a member of the committee that examined government proposals on economic reform. ``The people have been cheated more than once, they're mistrustful, and they feared they would be cheated again,'' he said. Boiko said delegates from poor regions of Central Asia, where consumption of bread is particularly high, ``are really afraid. They're worried that this will give rise to real discontent.'' He said the decision also was influenced by violent ethnic clashes _ fueled by poverty _ in Central Asia. In the republic of Kirghizia, 155 people died in ethnic fighting in the past two weeks, the Soviet Interior Ministry said. Government officials had promised that all $28 billion brought in by the price increase would be handed back to consumers through compensation programs. However, officials acknowledged they had not fully worked out such programs. The bread price increase was one of the most visible and controversial aspects of the economic program, presented to the Supreme Soviet by Premier Nikolai Ryzhkov last month. On Wednesday, the Supreme Soviet gave Gorbachev a mandate to speed economic reforms. It said the government had until October to prepare more radical measures to move the country toward a market economy. The July 1 price increases would have applied to all grain-based products, including pasta. Soviet bread comes in dozens of varieties and is virtually the only foodstuff that is almost always readily available without long lines. It remains extremely cheap at less than 33 cents a loaf. Gorbachev has said that bread is so cheap children sometimes use loaves for soccer balls. At the same time, the country spends its scarce foreign currency to buy grain from foreign countries. One deputy said that because prices paid to grain farmers already have been raised, keeping bread prices constant would swell the government budget deficit. But the lawmakers, rushing toward a summer adjournment with several other pieces of major legislation still pending, voted against lowering the price to producers again. The producer price increase will provide farmers with an additional $15 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Allow Visas For American Labor Officials
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union, which has repeatedly balked at allowing the entry of U.S. labor leaders, has issued visas for two AFL-CIO representatives, Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole said Thursday. Soviet Labor Minister V.I. Shcherbakov agreed to the visas after a private meeting with Mrs. Dole in Geneva, Switzerland, Mrs. Dole's office said. They were in Geneva for the annual International Labor Organization meeting. Dick Wilson, the AFL-CIO's coordinator of Central and Eastern European affairs, and John J. Banovic, secretary treasurer of the United Mine Workers, become the first AFL-CIO representatives to ever officially visit the Soviet Union. They plan to meet with Soviet independent mine workers. The Soviet government has still refused AFL-CIO President Lane Kirkland's official delegation request. Kirkland also had sought visas for Lynn Williams, president of the United Steelworkers of America, and Al Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers. The AFL-CIO, which represents 14.2 million Americans belonging to 90 U.S. trade unions, has been a longtime critic of the Soviet Union. ``We don't know that one granting of visas will make a policy. It certainly is a step in the right direction. We hope it is the start of a free and open relationship,'' said AFL-CIO spokesman Rex Hardesty. Mrs. Dole said Wilson and Banovic left for the Soviet Union immediately after the visas were granted Wednesday. ``Their sole purpose is to talk to Soviet workers about the free trade union movement _ not to foment unrest,'' Mrs. Dole said in a statement. Earlier this year, the AFL-CIO hosted a month-long visit by nine Soviet miners trying to form independent unions. Kirkland has compared the struggle of Soviet miners to that of Solidarity organizers in Poland in the early 1980s. He pledged to offer the federation's support, even if it meant defying the Soviet government. The AFL-CIO's support of Solidarity included the smuggling of printing and other communications equipment into Poland when Solidarity was outlawed. In all, the federation gave about $5 million worth of equipment and other assistance to Solidarity.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Scotus Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision that said police do not violate motorists' privacy rights by stopping them at sobriety checkpoints.

From Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist's opinion for the majority: This case poses the question whether a state's use of highway sobriety checkpoints violates the Fourth and 14th Amendments to the U.S. Constitution. We hold that it does not and therefore reverse the contrary holding of the Court of Appeals of Michigan. No one can seriously dispute the magnitude of the drunken driving problem or the states' interest in eradicating it. Media reports of alcohol-related death and mutilation on the nation's roads are legion. The anecdotal is confirmed by the statistical. Drunken drivers cause an annual death toll of over 25,000 and in the same time span cause nearly one million personal injuries and more than $5 billion in property damage. Conversely, the weight bearing on the other scale _ the measure of the intrusion on motorists stopped briefly at sobriety checkpoints _ is slight. We reached a similar conclusion as to the intrusion on motorists subjected to a brief stop at a highway checkpoint for detecting illegal aliens (in a 1976 ruling). Experts in police science might disagree over which of several methods of apprehending drunken drivers is preferable as an ideal. But for purposes of Fourth Amendment analysis, the choice among such reasonable alternatives remains with the governmental officials who have a unique understanding of, and a responsibility for, limited public resources, including a finite number of police officers. In sum, the balance of the state's interest in preventing drunken driving, the extent to which this system can reasonably be said to advance that interest, and the degree of intrusion upon individual motorists who are briefly stopped weighs in favor of the state program. We therefore hold that it is consistent with the Fourth Amendment.

From Justice Harry A. Blackmun's concurring opinion: I concur only in the judgment. I fully agree with the court's lamentations about the slaughter on our highways and about the dangers posed to almost everyone by the driver who is under the influence of alcohol or other drug. I add this comment only to remind the court that it has been almost 20 years since in (a 1971 ruling) I noted that the slaughter on the highways of this nation exceeds the death toll of all our wars.

From Justice William J. Brennan's dissenting opinion: I do not dispute the immense social cost caused by drunken drivers, nor do I slight the government's efforts to prevent such tragic losses.
