Indeed, I would hazard a guess that today's opinion will be received favorably by a majority of our society, who would willingly suffer the minimal intrusion of a sobriety checkpoint stop in order to prevent drunken driving. But consensus that a particular law enforcement technique serves a laudable purpose has never been the touchstone of constitutional analysis. The Fourth Amendment rests on the principle that a true balance between the individual and society depends on the recognition of the right to be let alone _ the most comprehensive of rights and the right most valued by civilized men. In the face of the `momentary evil' of drunken driving, the court today abdicates its role as the protector of that fundamental right.

From Justice John Paul Stevens' dissenting opinion: The court overvalues the law enforcement interest in using sobriety checkpoints, undervalues the citizen's interest in freedom from random, unannounced investigatory seizures and mistakenly assumes that there is virtually no difference between a routine stop at a permanent, fixed checkpoint (as was at issue in the 1976 ruling involving aliens) and a surprise stop at a sobriety checkpoint. In my opinion, unannounced investigatory seizures are, particularly when they take place at night, the hallmark of regimes far different from ours; the surprise intrusion upon individual liberty is not minimal. The most disturbing aspect of the court's decision today is that it appears to give no weight to the citizen's interest in freedom from unannounced investigatory seizures. The decision that seems diaphanous today may be intolerable tomorrow. Sobriety checkpoints are elaborate, and disquieting, publicity stunts. The net effect of sobriety checkpoints on traffic safety is infinitesimal and possibly negative. This is a case that is driven by nothing more than symbolic state action _ an insufficient justification for an otherwise unreasonable program of random seizures. Unfortunately, the court is transfixed by the wrong symbol _ the illusory prospect of punishing countless intoxicated motorists _ when it should keep its eye on the road plainly marked by the Constitution.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Thai Prime Minister Address Trade Disputes
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Thailand's Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan agreed Thursday to a new Cabinet-level committee to defuse trade disputes and promised to press for free elections in war-torn Cambodia under the U.N. flag. The two leaders emerged from nearly 2{ hours of talks and a luncheon at the White House promising to work together to stem both the U.S. thirst for drugs and their flow from Southeast Asia. The visit from the leader of what Bush called ``one of America's oldest friends and closest allies'' came at a time of intensified diplomatic efforts to bring peace to Cambodia. Four different factions are fighting to topple the Cambodian government of Hun Sen, installed by Vietnamese invaders in 1978. Bush said the common U.S.-Thai aim is to assure the Cambodia people ``genuine self-determination through free and fair elections under U.N. auspices and in the presence of an international peacekeeping force.'' ``We will do all we can to accelerate the on-going peace process,'' said Chatichai, adding that ``we are prepared to work'' with the U.N. Security Council on a peace initiative. Bush said the two countries' commerce ministers will form a Joint U.S.-Thai Committee for Commercial Cooperation to promote trade. Chatichai said its aim will be to establish ``a new framework for economic cooperation ... (that) would allow us to regularly discuss any potential trade issues before they become trade disputes.'' Thailand is on the U.S. trade representative's ``priority watch list'' for pirating products from computer software to Hollywood videotapes to pharmaceuticals. The United States retaliates with duties on $165 million of Thai products. Thailand is leading an economic resurgence in Southeast Asia, and its 10.7 percent growth in 1989 was the fastest in the world. Assistant Secretary of State for East Asia Richard Solomon said Chatichai asked Bush to help convince the Chinese to stop arming the Khmer Rouge, the communists blamed for the genocide of 1 million Cambodians during their bloody rule in 1975-78. Bush told Chatichai the United States remains strongly opposed to any role for the Khmer Rouge in a possible coalition government in Phnom Penh. Thailand recently helped arrange talks in Tokyo between Prince Sihanouk and Hun Sen, installed as head of Cambodia's government after the Vietnamese invasion in 1978. Bush expressed ``profound appreciation'' for Thailand's providing asylum to Indochinese refugees, and assured Chatichai the United States will welcome ``our share of Vietnamese refugees.'' Chatichai, whose country is the transit point for half the heroin reaching the United States from Burma and Laos, pledged ``the full support of the Thai government in the war against drug trafficking.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Anti-Jewish Posters to be Seen at Capitol
DOC.TEXT: Pre-glasnost Soviet propaganda posters will be displayed on Capitol Hill later this month as a reminder of the anti-Semitism that still pervades Soviet society, exhibition sponsors said Thursday. More than two dozen anti-American and anti-Jewish posters, cartoons and other materials collected secretly by Evgeny Lein and his wife, Irina, two prominent ``refuseniks'' from Leningrad, will be exhibited June 25-26 in the foyer of the Rayburn House Office Building. The materials, published mostly in the early 1980s, were secretly brought to the United States two years ago by Abraham Sofaer. Sofaer, outgoing legal adviser to the State Department, and his wife, Marian, are friends of the Leins. The Soviet couple were allowed to emigrate to Israel last December after a decade-long fight. Rep. James Scheuer, D-N.Y., a congressional sponsor of the exhibit, told a news conference that the documents betray a deep, persistent strain of anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union that is flourishing under President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's glasnost policy of openness. In the 70 years since the Communists seized power in Moscow, Scheuer said, the Soviet government has ``adroitly and cynically manipulated the anti-Semitic genes'' of its people through state-subsidized propaganda materials. He said he hoped President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker III would urge Gorbachev to denounce anti-Semitism and allow the Soviet Union to become ``a cradle for nurturing freedom'' for all its people. One poster, published in 1982 and titled ``Zionism _ Today's Fascism,'' shows the skeleton of Adolf Hitler goose-stepping across the bodies of mutilated Lebanese with a blood-stained Israeli soldier carring a U.S.-made missile. Another poster depicts the CIA using religion and Radio Free Europe as anti-Soviet tools, with caricatures of a Jew, a Christian and a CIA agent collaborating as spies. Recent additions to the exhibition include two anti-Jewish cartoons published this year in the magazine of Komsomol, the Soviet Communist youth organization. Mrs. Sofaer, who organized the exhibition with the help of private donations, said the posters were printed by Soviet government agencies and sold at subsidized prices in local Soviet bookstores as part of the government's domestic propaganda effort.

DOC.HEAD: Farm Exports Highest In Five Years, Government Says
DOC.TEXT: Exports accounted for more than 18 percent of last year's U.S. farm production value, the highest rating in five years, an Agriculture Department report said Thursday. The farm value of exports in calendar 1989 was $31.8 billion, said the report by the department's Economic Research Service. Farmers had a gross cash income of $174 billion. That meant the farm value of exports was 18.3 percent of last year's gross income, the largest share since 1984 when the farm export value was $30.4 billion and the gross was $155.3 billion _ a share of 19.6 percent. The indicator dropped after peaking at 24 percent in the early 1980s, reaching a low of 13.8 percent in 1986 and 1987. It rose to 16.5 percent in 1988. The report means farmers exported the production of two out of every five acres last year, matching the record set in 1984.

DOC.HEAD: Strong Earthquake Registered in East Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake struck a lightly populated area near the Soviet nuclear test range and the Chinese and Mongolian borders Thursday, but Soviet authorities reported no injuries or damages. The Defense Ministry denied rumors circulating around the Semipalatinsk test range that it had exploded a nuclear bomb, the Soviet news agency Tass reported. The Swedish national news agency TT quoted the Seismological Institute in Uppsala as saying the quake measured 7 on the Richter scale. That is a major quake, capable of causing widespread, heavy damage in populated areas. The Hong Kong Observatory recorded the quake as a 6.8 on the open-ended scale, which measures the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by ground motion recorded on a seismograph. Tass said the quake was centered 30 miles north of the village of Zaisan in Kazakhstan, about 1,900 miles southeast of Moscow. There were no reports of injuries or damage, according to both Tass and Sergei Bogdanov, a duty officer at the Communist Party headquarters in Alma Ata, the Kazakh capital, about 450 miles from the epicenter. The shock was registered 15 miles below the earth's surface, Tass said.

DOC.HEAD: Massacre Survivor Reveals Horror
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to fix typo on number of police stations overrun.
DOC.TEXT: A young policeman who was shot by Tamil separatists and left for dead among the bodies of his colleagues said Thursday he crawled into the jungle and hid while more policemen were killed. Piyeratna Ranaweera said he was one of 115 policemen who were captured at Kalmunai police station Monday when the rebels overran 11 police stations in the Eastern Province. The fighting, which began Monday, was the worst violence since negotiations began between the government and the Tigers in May 1989. At least 110 government troops have died, but one unconfirmed report said the Tamil Tiger rebels also killed 125 to 150 policemen who were among the 600 officers captured. A spokesman for the Tigers said the report could be anti-rebel propaganda. Ranaweera said that all 115 policemen captured with him were blindfolded and the Tigers took their watches and wallets, tied their hands and gave them water. They were then taken in three buses from Kalmunai, 135 miles east of Colombo, to a rebel camp 20 miles to the south. Ranaweera, lying in a hospital bed with his broken left arm in a sling and bloodstained cotton on the bullet wound in his left ear, said one busload of the captive policemen were taken from the Tiger camp shortly before midnight Monday. ``At 12:45 (that) night they took the second busload again to the jungle,'' he said in a weak voice. He said he was blindfolded when he got off the bus so he could not see if the men from the first bus were there. ``They lined us all up and made us lie on the ground face down and they opened fire with T-56 rifles. Then they held a torch to our heads and if they heard a cry they shot again.'' Ranaweera said the bullet grazed his left ear. The Tigers apparently thought he was dead and left. He said he crawled into the jungle and realised his left arm was broken and he fixed a sling for it. While he was lying in the jungle he heard the third bus arrive and then he heard more shots. He estimated it was about 3 a.m. He said he saw no one else alive. After the third bus left he started making his way inland towards government lines but ``I fainted a couple of times. I was very thirsty. I found a lake with elephans ... and I drank.'' The young Sinhalese policeman said he came to a small farmer's hut. ``Some Tamil people were there. I explained what happened but they left me.'' About 3 p.m. Tuesday, when he estimated he had walked about 14 miles towards Damana, a Sinhalese-dominated town 18 miles southwest of Kalmunai, he reached a second hut, he said. ``I saw a Sinhalese man and he took me and there were Sinhalese boys and they took me on a motorcycle to Damana.'' Ranaweera was admitted to the Government Hospital in Kandy, the largest town near Damana. The spokesman for the Tigers, Dominic, said the mass killings of policemen ``could have happened or it could be anti-Tiger propaganda. Communications are difficult and we are trying to find out what really took place.'' Dominic, who uses only one name, was speaking to reporters in the northern town of Jaffna, the headquarters of the Tigers. The Tamils, who are mainly Hindu, have been fighting for an independent nation, claiming discrimination by the majority Sinhalese, who are mainly Buddhist. At least 11,000 people, including 1,200 Indian soldiers sent to the region as peacekeepers, have been killed in the Tamil war since it started in 1983.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Approves Drunken Driving Checkpoints
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with state constitutional situation in Michigan, inserting 1 graf after 12th graf, But the
DOC.TEXT: Police seeking to curb drunken driving do not violate motorists' privacy rights by stopping them at sobriety checkpoints, the Supreme Court ruled Thursday. The 6-3 decision upheld Michigan's checkpoint program and, by extension, similar operations in most states. ``The balance of the state's interest in preventing drunken driving ... and the degree of intrusion upon individual motorists who are briefly stopped weighs in favor of the state program,'' Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote for the court. The three dissenters said the decision sacrificed individual liberty in favor of a police tactic that might not make any difference in the fight against drunken driving. In other decisions, the court: _Ruled, 5-4, in a Virginia case that hospitals and nursing homes may sue in federal court to challenge how a state-run Medicaid program reimburses their costs. _Ruled unanimously in a case from Massachusetts that the federal government may impose severe fines against air polluters even when regulators are slow to decide on clean-air proposals. _Allowed the Bush administration, by a 5-4 vote in a Virginia case, to limit how much welfare aid some needy families receive. The sobriety-checkpoint ruling was hailed by various groups seeking greater crackdowns on drunken drivers, but was denounced by the American Civil Liberties Union. Micky Sadoff, national president of Mothers Against Drunk Driving, called the decision ``a great victory for all of us who care about the safety of our loved ones on the highways.'' The chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board, also applauded the ruling but said, ``More needs to be done.'' He called on states to allow police to confiscate licenses on the spot if motorists fail or refuse to take chemical tests. But the ruling will have no effect in at least one state. Louisiana State Police said Thursday they are barred from setting up sobriety checkpoints by their state constitution, which affords greater individual privacy than does the federal Constitution. And police in Michigan may not be able to reinstate their checkpoint program until a challenge based on that state's constitution is resolved. Nadine Strosser, the ACLU's general counsel, said the ruling ``is fundamentally wrong, both as a matter of constitutional principle and as a matter of public policy.'' ``This strikes at the heart of the Fourth Amendment,'' which bans unreasonable police searches and seizures, Ms. Strosser said. Writing for the court, Rehnquist said, ``No one can seriously dispute the magnitude of the drunken driving problem or the states' interest in eradicating it.'' He said drunken drivers ``cause an annual death toll of over 25,000 and in the same time span cause nearly one million personal injuries and more than $5 billion in property damage.'' The court's dissenters, however, cited statistics indicating that those figures have been declining steadily. ``Conversely, the weight bearing on the other scale _ the measure of the intrusion on motorists stopped briefly at sobriety checkpoints _ is slight,'' Rehnquist said. He was joined by Justices Byron R. White, Sandra Day O'Connor, Antonin Scalia and Anthony M. Kennedy. Justice Harry A. Blackmun joined in the result but not in Rehnquist's opinion. The decision echoed President Bush's stated concern about drunken driving. ``It's as crippling as crack, as random as gang violence, and it's killing more kids than both combined,'' the president said last year as he noted that federal aid was being given to promote the use of sobriety checkpoints. Justices William J. Brennan, Thurgood Marshall and John Paul Stevens dissented from Thursday's ruling. Calling sobriety checkpoints no more than ``elaborate and disquieting publicity stunts,'' Stevens said the net effect ``on traffic safety is infinitesimal and possibly negative. This is a case that is driven by nothing more than symbolic state action _ an insufficient justification for an otherwise unreasonable program of random seizures.'' He added: ``The court is transfixed by the wrong symbol _ the illusory prospect of punishing countless intoxicated motorists _ when it should keep its eyes on the road plainly marked by the Constitution.'' The traditional method police use to identify suspected drunken drivers is to observe traffic. Determining that method is not wholly effective, states in recent years began experimenting with other detection methods. In Michigan, police who set up such a checkpoint directed all traffic headed in one direction to a roadside area where officers talked to motorists. If there was no immediate evidence of intoxication, the motorist was given a traffic safety brochure and allowed to drive away. The average delay was about 30 seconds. Six Michigan legislators sued state police soon after the checkpoint program began. Michigan courts banned the checkpoints, relying on a 1979 Supreme Court ruling in which the justices said the constitutionality of a police seizure made without ``probable cause'' to suspect a crime should be determined by three factors: _The gravity of the public concerns being served. _How the seizure advances the public interest. _The severity of the police interference with individual liberty. The court Thursday said the Michigan checkpoint program satisfies all three factors.

DOC.HEAD: Britain Attacks U.S. On Boat People Issue
DOC.TEXT: Britain on Thursday said Hong Kong will have to forcibly return more Vietnamese boat people to their Communist homeland unless the United States agrees to house about 9,000 of the refugees on Guam. In the Philippines, the government allowed more than 250 boat people to debark from U.S. Navy ships only after U.S. and other foreign officials agreed to resettle them outside the Philippines within three years. Britain, representing its colony Hong Kong, and six Asian nations are expected soon to warn the U.S. State Department formally that they will abolish boat people's right to debark unless they can send the would-be migrants back forcibly. Tens of thousands who fled Vietnam since the Communists defeated ths U.S.-backed South Vietnamese government in 1975 have jammed refugee centers in neighboring countries. ``The United States has a responsibility it can't evade,'' Foreign Office Minister Francis Maude said in an interview. ``Either it joins in the consensus of other nations (on forced repatriation) ... or it provides an alternative.'' ``But it is quite indefensible to block the consensus and at the same time to refuse what one might call an intermediate solution,'' he added, referring to the Guam proposal, which Washington rejected three weeks ago. Maude, however, will press his proposal for U.S.-controlled holding centers in Guam during a U.S. visit next week. Last December, 51 Vietnamese were sent home from the Hong Kong camps against their will _ bundled on to an aircraft in tearful scenes that caused an international uproar. On Monday, a Philippine envoy delivered a formal warning to the Vietnamese Foreign Ministry in Hanoi that Britain and the six-member Association of South East Asian Nations may abolish landing rights for new arrivals, the Foreign Office said. The warning carried no deadline but amounts to an ultimatum that drastic action may follow. The State Department will get a similar warning within days. The Asian group comprises Brunei, Indonesia, Malayasia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand. Some have warned they will push boatloads of refugees back out to sea. In the Philippines, more than 250 Vietnamese rescued on the high seas last month by U.S. Navy ships were allowed to leave the ships Thursday, ending a two-week dispute. The Philippine government said it received assurances from the U.S. ambassador, the British ambassador and the Manila representative of the U.N. High Commissioner on Refugees that the refugees will be resettled in another country within three years. The issue has been a sensitive one for the U.S. Navy since a military jury at Subic Bay convicted a Navy captain of dereliction of duty for turning away a boatload of Vietnamese in the South China Sea in June 1988. Thirty-one of the Vietnamese died, and survivors turned to cannibalism to stay alive. There are more than 109,000 boat people in camps in Southeast Asian countries, including 54,541 in Hong Kong, according to U.N. and British figures. Britain has classified 10,500 of the Vietnamese in Hong Kong as genuine political refugees. Britain wants to send to Guam about 9,000 it says are purely seeking a better way of life and have no right to asylum. The rest are awaiting screening and British officials expect nearly 90 percent to be classifed as economic migrants.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Group Criticizes Army Over Shootings, Investigations
DOC.TEXT: An Israeli human rights group said Thursday that soldiers violated firing orders by shooting 14 Palestinians in the head, chest or back despite regulations calling for them to aim for their legs. The Israeli Center for Human Rights in the Occupied Territories said another woman reportedly died after a solider hit her with a club, and that the army failed to investigate how all the deaths occurred. An army statement attributed to military sources did not respond to allegations that firing procedures were violated and said investigations into the deaths were incomplete. The human rights group examined deaths that occurred during 11 days of disturbances following the May 20 massacre of seven unarmed Arab laborers by an Israeli civilian. The study showed that 14 of the 18 people killed in the subsequent unrest were shot in the head, chest or back, although regulations call for aiming at rioters' legs. Many victims were shot at close range, according to the 23-page report based on medical reports and witness testimony. Those killed included an 8-year-old boy, four children aged 13 to 16, and three women, it said. Army orders were tightened three days into the rioting, requiring soldiers to get permission from senior officers before shooting. ``It was obvious that they didn't stick to the regulations in this case,'' said Zehava Galon, the director of the rights group. ``It wasn't necessary ... to shoot at the upper body.'' The group said it could not investigate all 18 deaths because army curfews kept researchers from reaching witnesses. The army also blocked journalists from visiting the shooting scenes for more than a week. Victims' families also complained that soldiers broke into their homes and beat them, that live ammunition was often used instead of plastic and rubber bullets and that some soldiers provoked rioting and humiliated grieving families. The rights group said that in at least six of the deaths, military police had not talked to the victims' families more than two weeks after the killings. Reporters who have inquired into other deaths have often been told for months that investigations were not complete. An army officer said: ``We investigate every single case. You can hardly say that in cases where a few days or a couple of weeks have passed, we can be criticized for not speaking to all the people involved.'' The officer spoke on condition of anonymity. The army said 107 soldiers had been indicted for misuse of force in the 30-month uprising against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Seventy have been found guilty. The rights group apparently got wrong information on at least one case _ the shooting death of 16-year-old Mohammed Halhuli from the West Bank village of Qibya, whose uncle said soldiers entered the village and opened fire. The AP interviewed more than a dozen people _ including the youth's father _who all said he was shot and killed when he and about 50 other youths stoned an army base in neighboring Burdus village, and some tried to climb the fence. In its overall judgment on May's riots, the report said soldiers did not give Palestinians enough latitude to express their anger at the massacre and instead tried ``to nip any signs of protest in the bud.'' The report rejected army contentions that bloodshed was kept to a minimum because soldiers had gained experience in handling disturbances during the Palestinian uprising. The rights group said 12 people were killed and 800 wounded in the first three days of the May riots. It said four Palestinians were killed and dozens wounded in the first three days of the uprising that began in December 1987. During the uprising, 717 Palestinians have been killed by Israelis, and 45 Israelis have been slain by Palestinians.

DOC.HEAD: Radio Hacker Giving Police Fits
DOC.TEXT: When state police received an urgent dispatch last fall from a desperate officer pleading for help, dispatchers frantically tried to find off-duty police units to see if any were in trouble. None were. The call turned out to be a hoax. It also started a string of sporadic calls on police frequencies from a hacker that so far has eluded capture. ``He's back big-time and it's a real headache,'' Trooper Lon Fields, spokesman for the state police in Morehead, said Thursday. ``It's aggravating for the troopers in the field and also the dispatchers.'' And it's a dangerous problem, said Capt. John Lile, a state police spokesman. ``When they put out some false information as far as pursuits and things like that ... it can place some officer and citizens in danger,'' Lile said. Fields said that earlier this week a dispatcher in Morehead received a call at about 9:30 p.m. from Unit 960. With sirens wailing in the background, the officer in the car said he was under fire from automatic weapons and requested assistance. One problem: There's no unit 960. ``For about an hour, he really wreaked havoc,'' Fields said. Identical calls were received in Cincinnati and Columbus, Ohio. The transmissions ended about 11:30 p.m., when police sent a helicopter out to canvass the area and made each officer check in. The hacker also has taunted officers, telling them to wake up and call headquarters. He has been cutting into transmissions since September, but until this week, he had been silent for several months. The hacker can only be traced when he is transmitting. And since his calls are sporadic and he changes frequencies, he's hard to trace, Lile said. Irby Tallant, engineer in charge with the Federal Communications Commission in Detroit, said it's difficult to say how often something like the situation in Kentucky and Ohio occurs. But if it's a one-time thing, Tallant said, it's very difficult to pursue. When the calls occur on a continual basis, the FCC is able to trace signals electronically. In that case, Tallant said, ``you have to have a scanner up listening to all the frequencies he may bother.'' Fields said state police are trying to trace the hacker. Interfering with police broadcasts or unauthorized use of a police radio is a misdemeanor, carrying a sentence of up to a year in jail, a $500 fine and forfeiture of equipment. Federal penalties include a fine of up to $100,000 and a year in prison.

DOC.HEAD: Harvard Threatens to Cancel 1992 AIDS Meeting to Protest Restrictions
DOC.TEXT: Harvard University said Thursday it will cancel the annual international AIDS conference in 1992 unless the United States removes travel restrictions on people infected with the AIDS virus. The university is scheduled to be host of the meeting, the principal forum for presenting scientific information on the fight against the disease. Many groups have protested U.S. policy that makes AIDS infection one of several contagious diseases for which foreigners can be barred from the country. Almost 100 organizations are boycotting this year's meeting, scheduled to begin next week in San Francisco. ``We don't believe we can host a conference dedicated to the elimination of AIDS to which people with AIDS cannot freely travel,'' said Harvard's Alan Fein, director of the 1992 meeting. ``A conference that was held under these circumstances would be so contentious and ineffective that it would render it not very productive.'' Dr. Max Essex, chairman of the Harvard AIDS Institute, disclosed the threatened withdrawal from the meeting in a letter to Dr. Lars Kallings of the Swedish Ministry of Health, who is president of the International AIDS Society. ``Unless it becomes clear that the restrictions will be lifted shortly, we will withdraw as sponsor for the next U.S.-based meeting and cancel the conference scheduled for Boston in 1992,'' Essex wrote. While Harvard did not set a specific deadline, Fein said it will scrap the meeting unless it sees an indication of ``swift movement'' by Congress or the administration to eliminate the travel restrictions. A Senate amendment three years ago ordered the Public Health Service to add infection by the AIDS virus to the list of diseases, including leprosy and tuberculosis, that may bar foreigners. In response to an outcry against the rule, the Immigration and Naturalization Service announced a waiver policy that allows people infected with the virus to stay in the United States up to 30 days for business, conferences, medical treatment or family visits. The policy eliminated the requirement of permanent identifying marks on their passports. In April, it said it would issue 10-day visas for those coming to this country for professional or scientific conferences. Those applying do not have to say whether they are infected with the AIDS virus. ``We have been trying our best, as have a lot of others, to see some sign that our federal government will change its policy,'' Essex said in an interview. ``But after talking to everybody we could find who would talk to us, we came to the conclusion reluctantly that there is not a lot of action occurring.'' He said the International AIDS Society will decide during the San Francisco meeting whether to try to relocate the 1992 meeting or cancel it. Whether the meeting could be held somewhere else is unclear. Fein said it would be difficult for another institution to put together a meeting with only two years' planning. He said that Boston's major convention hall and 8,000 hotel rooms were reserved a year ago. Dr. Robert M. Wachter of the University of California, San Francisco, program director of the San Francisco meeting, said that even though the travel restrictions have eased considerably, he still considers them to be unacceptable and discriminatory. ``They (Harvard) have laid their cards on the table,'' said Wachter. ``We agree.'' The announced boycott is expected to have little effect on the scientific reports at the San Francisco meeting. Few presentations have been withdrawn, and 12,000 people are expected. The 1991 AIDS meeting will be held in Florence, Italy.

DOC.HEAD: Sununu To Help Gorbachev Organize Office
DOC.TEXT: White House chief of staff John Sununu, writing a new chapter in East-West cooperation, will go to Moscow to help Mikhail S. Gorbachev organize his new office as president of the Soviet Union, it was announced Thursday. Sununu, who oversees a White House staff of more than 400 people, has been meeting this week with a visiting delegation of Soviet officials, explaining details of presidential scheduling, communications systems and personnel organization. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said a member of the delegation, Mikhail Shkabardnya, had invited Sununu to Moscow for further consultations and that he had accepted. The date has not been set. Fitzwater said Sununu would offer advice on organizational matters related to the office of the presidency. ``I think they would like him to come to the Soviet Union to take a look at their ideas and their plans ... if he has any advice for them.'' Gorbachev, the general secretary of the Communist Party, expanded his powers earlier this year when he was elected to the new post of president.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Minister David Levy Hospitalized in Intensive Care Unit
DOC.TEXT: Israel's new foreign minister, David Levy, was hospitalized Thursday in the intensive care unit following complaints of weakness, hospital officials in Afula said. Levy, 52, was taken to Haemek Hospital in the northern Israeli city near his hometown of Bet Shean, said the hospital's deputy director, Dr. Udi Kantor. Kantor said there was no sign of immediate danger, adding that Levy was hospitalized for medical observation. ``We hope to release him as soon as possible,'' Kantor said. Israel army radio and the national Itim news agency said Levy was under great strain in recent days following the formation of a new government Monday and his appointment to the foreign minister's post. The Moroccan-born Levy, a captivating orator, began his career in the ranks of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc as a labor union boss championing the causes of the disadvantaged. Levy, a fluent Arabic speaker, quickly gained prominence in the party and is regarded by some as a possible successor to Shamir.

DOC.HEAD: Age, Changing Lifestyles Lead to Demise of 100-Year-Old Reading Club
DOC.TEXT: The century-old Ladies Reading Circle, its membership whittled down by age and changing lifestyles, on Thursday closed the book on a tradition dating back to a more genteel era. A luncheon at the Gideon Putnam Hotel in this city famed for its mineral waters and horse racing was the last meeting for the literary club, which is disbanding after watching its ranks shrink over the years from 25 to 10 active members. ``We're all getting older,'' said club president Ellen Qua, a member since 1957 who turns 80 in September. ``I'm one of the young kids.'' The last book read by the club was Bruce Courtenay's ``The Power of One,'' about South Africa. The first was ``In Darkest Africa'' by Henry V. Stanley, the famed explorer who published the two-volume work in 1890. The club was founded that year by women parishioners at the local Baptist church. ``That was before television, radio and telephone. That's the way they got together. Reading circles were common then,'' Ms. Qua said. The club met once a week, but over the years that was reduced to every other week, then every month and finally whenever members could get together. The last meeting before Thursday's was in February, although winter meetings became infrequent as more members spent the season in Florida, Ms. Qua said. Club meetings featured readings and discussions of books on history, architecture, geology, economics, poetry, as well as biographies and various works of fiction. ``Everything from cooking to Mozart,'' said vice president Althea Moncsko. Members chose the books they wanted to read, with no restrictions. ``Even if you don't like a writer, you should read him anyway to find out what his views are,'' Ms. Qua said. ``The written word is sort of holy.'' Today's women have less time to devote to meet and talk about books, members said. ``Women are too busy with families and businesses to carry on in the afternoon with something like this, reading and reviewing books,'' Ms. Qua said. Ladies Reading Circle meetings offered an opportunity for afternoon get-togethers for its elderly members, who don't like to go out at night, Ms. Moncsko said. ``It has been quite a social, close-knit group,'' she said. ``We do just hate to give that up.''

DOC.HEAD: Request For More S&L Bailout Money Draws Fire
DOC.TEXT: Members of Congress on Thursday attacked the administration's request for more money to rescue savings and loans, accusing the White House of bungling the first bailout and failing to pursue fraud vigorously. A torrent of criticism greeted Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady after he warned the House Banking Committee that the thrift cleanup likely would run out of money before the end of the year. Brady, testifying three weeks after the administration doubled its estimate of S&L cleanup costs to a range of $89 billion to $132 billion, said the administration would need from ``about $30 billion to slightly over $50 billion'' more in the next fiscal year alone. Panel members, clearly worried about a backlash from angry constituents, attacked the administration for delays in prosecuting the growing backlog of fraud cases and selling the mountain of sour loans and problem real estate inherited from failed thrifts. ``I think we're sitting on a volcano of public opinion on this issue,'' said Rep. Richard E. Neal, D-Mass. ``I hear continuously at the corner store and the supermarket and at the gas station, `When are you guys going to do something about putting the crooks in jail?''' Neal's criticism spurred Housing Secretary Jack Kemp, along with Brady a member of an administration board overseeing the bailout, to warn Democrats not to make S&Ls a partisan issue. ``I think there's enough blame to go around and I just hope this is not going to erupt into the kind of political attack ... on either side,'' he said. However, Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., distinguished between blame for the first bailout, enacted last August, and the coming second bailout. He said President Bush has paid scant attention to the S&L cleanup and has allowed it to founder. ``The first one ... there was plenty of blame to go around. ... In this second S&L crisis, there's not plenty of blame to go around. ... We've heard more from the president about broccoli than we've heard about this crisis,'' he said. Even Republicans, including Rep. Chalmers Wylie of Ohio, the senior GOP member on the panel, joined in the assault. ``The Department of Justice's efforts to prosecute thrift fraud are well intentioned but fall way short of the mark,'' Wylie said. ``Apparently, S&L crimes are not a high priority for federal prosecutors.'' He, like Democrats, complained that the administration was spending only $50 million on increased fraud prosecution, rather than the $75 million Congress authorized. Brady defended the administration's performance, pointing to Wednesday's 38-count indictment in Texas of Don Dixon, former owner of Vernon Savings and Loan Association, a collapsed institution that cost taxpayers $1.3 billion. Dixon, if convicted, faces a jail sentence of up to 190 years. ``As important as the number of scalps we hang on our belts, is the fact that when we get one, they're dealt with firmly, harshly and with the appropriate justice for the kind of crime that they've committed,'' Brady said. He pointed out that it took four years of work before Dixon could be charged and said 17,000 suspected cases of fraud have been referred to the Justice Department. ``We, like everyone, want to make sure the crooks are prosecuted. But we have to realize these are white collar cases. It isn't like a bank robbery where a guy comes in with a gun, sticks up a bank ... and there's cameras taking pictures of him. ... When you're talking about bringing one of these (white collar) people to justice, you're talking about an enormous amount of time with accountants, lawyers and files,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Kan. Governor, State Attorney General Bark Back at California Critics
DOC.TEXT: Critics of a new law that's designed to protect Kansas laboratories that use animals for testing are ``bozos from California,'' the state's attorney general says. ``Any self-respecting Kansan would tell them to go to hell,'' said Attorney General Bob Stephan. The legislation makes it a crime to photograph or destroy property at an animal research laboratory, testing or breeding grounds. The law was crafted to keep animal-rights activists from entering a research lab and photographing animals for their campaigns against animal testing, officials say. Much of the criticism led by a California assemblyman has centered on allegations that Kansas protects ``puppy mills,'' substandard breeding operations that ship sick animals out of state. Stephan said the measure, which was signed into law last month, does not apply to commercial dog kennels. ``It's very easy to say Kansas has a problem, because we're dealing with those problems up front,'' Stephan told reporters Wednesday. ``Meanwhile, California does nothing. Frankly, I think it's very clear. If those folks in California who are complaining could read, they could read the bill.'' A truck carrying 5,000 pounds of dog biscuits set out from Sonora, Calif., for Topeka on Tuesday to protest the legislation. Organizers in California would not disclose when it would arrive. The protesters originally planned to send 9,000 pounds of dog bones but worried they would be turned back as a health hazard. ``Why shouldn't we react this way when some bozos from California decide at first to send some bones to our state, then some dog biscuits?'' Stephan asked. Gov. Mike Hayden said he would donate the biscuits to the Humane Society. The two Kansas officials say the state's animal inspection laws are stronger than those in California. They also say California officials cannot cite a single complaint involving dogs bred in Kansas. California state Assemblyman Sam Farr has led the protest, introducing legislation that would require California pet stores to post where dogs were bred and that would make it illegal for the pet stores to knowingly sell a sick dog. ``We're very disappointed that the governor and the attorney general had to resort to name calling to avoid the fact that Kansas has a lot of puppy mills that send a lot of sick puppies to California,'' said Farr's aide, Darryl Young. ``There's a real problem in Kansas,'' Young said. ``The governor and attorney general are heavily into denial and not the problem.'' The protesters want a repeal of the Kansas legislation. Stephan said the 1990 Kansas law does not apply to dog breeders but only those animals used in food, fur or fiber production, agriculture, testing or education. Stephan also noted that a 1988 Kansas law, under which the state inspects federally licensed animal laboratories once a year, and those not licensed by the federal government twice a year, was left untouched. Hayden noted that California law does not call for that state to license or inspect animal dealers at all. But some critics say the Kansas inspection program is underfinanced, understaffed and ineffective.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Calls For Soviet Dialogue With Baltic Republics
DOC.TEXT: President Bush proclaimed Thursday ``Baltic Freedom Day'' and renewed his call for Moscow to engage in ``productive dialogue'' with Baltic leaders aimed at ending unrest in those Soviet republics. Bush signed a proclamation the Senate had requested in a resolution. ``The right to liberty and self-determination, free and fair elections, a better life for themselves and for their children, these are just aspirations of the people of Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania. On this Baltic Freedom Day, we reaffirm our support for them,'' Bush said in the proclamation. He reiterated the U.S. position, which does not recognize the forced incorporation of the three countries by the Soviet Union in 1940. ``During that fateful summer, Soviet troops invaded and occupied the Baltic States. The rigged elections that followed put an end to Baltic self-determination.'' Bush noted, however, the self-determination moves in Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania in the past year and the democratic elections held. ``In decisions reflecting the will of the Baltic people, Lithuania, Estonia, and Latvia have asserted their intention to restore their independence.'' ``We support self-determination for the Baltic peoples and we call upon the Soviet Union to enter a good-faith dialogue with representatives of the Baltic governments who received popular mandates in free and fair elections. We are encouraged by recent steps in that direction and hope that a full and productive dialogue will materialize,'' Bush's proclamation said. Bush earlier in the week lauded Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev's talks with Lithuanian leaders as ``a significant change.'' The Baltic states all are struggling for independence from the Soviet Union. In Lithuania, the most aggressive in its breakaway move, the Soviets retaliated with an economic blockade, but began to lift the blockade by restoring a small amount of fuel export on Wednesday. The Bush administration has tried to walk a fine line in its reaction to the Soviets' heavyhandedness in the Baltics so as not to further weaken the domestically embattled Gorbachev. Administration officials initially raised Lithuania as a stumbling block to normalizing trade relations with the Soviet Union, but subsequently eased off that demand, saying Lithuania was never directly linked to U.S. willingness to enter a trade pact.

DOC.HEAD: Off-Duty Cop Shot Dead After Confronting Gunman
DOC.TEXT: A police officer shot during off-duty heroics died Thursday, becoming the second off-duty officer fatally shot in the last 10 days. Officer Joaquin ``Jack'' Montijo, 35, was shot in the head Wednesday night and died Thursday afternoon when life support systems were shut off at Temple University Hospital, officials said. Doctors said Montijo showed no vital signs when he was brought to the hospital emergency room, and was resuscitated twice. A bullet struck him between the eyes and lodged in the back of his skull. Michael Lacava, 25, was arrested Thursday for investigation in the slaying, said police Lt. Joseph Witte. The incident began when the officer heard a gunshot. Montijo dashed out of the house with his gun drawn, went up to an armed man and ordered him to drop his pistol, witnesses said. A gun battle ensued. ``He took actions when he saw someone with the weapon,'' police Commissioner Willie L. Williams said. ``He thought someone was in trouble and immediately put himself on duty and attempted to make an apprehension.'' Montijo, who joined the force 19 months ago, was visiting his girlfriend, Zoreida Perez, who lives with her sister and brother-in-law. They pleaded with him not to go after the gunman, but were unable to stop him. ``I guess he wanted to be a hero,'' said Gladys Sanchez, Ms. Perez's sister. ``He didn't want nobody else to get hurt.'' It was the second shooting of off-duty officers in 10 days. Officer Winfred Hunter was shot to death and Officer Kelvin Merritt was seriously wounded June 4 in a gun battle outside an after-hours club.

DOC.HEAD: Neighbors Blast Coastal Commission Ruling on Singer's House
DOC.TEXT: Singer Olivia Newton-John was honored this week by the United Nations as a special ambassador for the environment, then was slammed by Malibu neighbors who call her seaside home-under-construction a mess. The California Coastal Commission on Wednesday ruled that a seawall built to protect the 6,000-square-foot home is taking too long to finish, but found no fault with methods used to make it. Neighbors had complained about the seawall, calling the massive pile of sand an eyesore and an environmental hazard. Gretchen Buck, who lives several hundred feet away, said the seawall construction involved dumping dirt, sand and debris on the beach. Some washed out to sea, she said, and the ocean was so muddied for a time that she was forced to suspend her daily swims in the exclusive Paradise Cove area of Malibu. The commission ruling angered her. ``A railroad job, that's what I'd call it,'' she said. Investigators for the state panel acknowledged that Miss Newton-John and her husband, Matt Lattanzi, had violated the Coastal Act by carrying out construction without a permit extension. But no penalties were levied. ``I'm glad it's over and I know Olivia is,'' said Lattanzi. ``Neither of us would knowingly do anything to hurt the environment.'' The couple bought the property in 1981. They're building a solar-powered house designed to resemble a sand castle. The commission might seek civil fines later, said Nancy Cave, the agency's chief enforcement officer. It can seek penalties of up to $5,000 a day in cases where applicants knowingly violate coastal building codes. The commission issued a permit for the seawall last June. It expired Nov. 1. The panel approved an after-the-fact permit for the work Wednesday, criticizing the couple for not requesting an extension. ``This is a project out of control,'' said William Litvak, an attorney for several neighbors who also contend that grading has destabilized bluffs overlooking their properties. An attorney for the couple disagreed. ``Because we're dealing with a celebrity who also happens to be an environmentalist, the whole issue has been blown out of proportion,'' Elizabeth Watson said. ``It's a hullabaloo about nothing.'' Critics said the singer was receiving special consideration because she is a celebrity. Miss Newton-John received the United Nations tribute this week for her work furthering environmental causes.

DOC.HEAD: House Democrats Seek Look At Allegations Of Pierce Perjury
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf pvs, `The 21 ...' to UPDATE with all 22 Democratic members of committee signing letter
DOC.TEXT: A group of House Democrats sought Thursday to expand a special prosecutor's investigation to include allegations that former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr. lied to Congress. All 22 Democratic members of the House Judiciary Committee urged Attorney General Dick Thornburgh to refer the issue of whether Pierce lied last year in congressional testimony to the independent counsel, who is already investigating other allegations of criminal wrongdoing by the former housing secretary. The lawmakers cited recent testimony by DuBois L. Gilliam, a former assistant housing secretary, who said Pierce ordered him to award federal housing grants to politically connected developers. Thornburgh was attending an anti-terrorism conference in Ireland and his spokesman, Dan Eramian said ``we would have to evaluate the letter before we made any comment.'' Gilliam recently told a House subcommittee that Pierce used the Department of Housing and Urban Development's discretionary grant program as ``a private political slush fund.'' Gilliam's testimony last month prompted Thornburgh to ask independent counsel Arlin M. Adams to investigate allegations of political favoritism in the operation of the discretionary fund and the Urban Development Action Grant Program. Adams has issued a series of grand jury subpoenas to Pierce and former HUD aides, according to sources who spoke on condition of anonymity. The independent counsel, who is preparing to widen his investigation, has decided to grant immunity to Gilliam, who is already serving an 18-month prison term for conspiracy and accepting illegal gratuities, said one source familiar with the case. Adams was originally appointed to determine if Pierce and other top HUD officials committed crimes by showing political favoritism in the operation of the Moderate Rehabilitation Program. The latest request by the lawmakers triggers a provision of the independent counsel statute that forces the Justice Department to determine if there is a ``specific and credible'' allegation that should be referred to the special prosecutor. When he sought Adams' appointment earlier this year, Thornburgh declined to include allegations of perjury in the independent counsel's mandate. Thornburgh said at the time that the questions Pierce was asked by the House Government Operations employment and housing subcommittee and the answers the former secretary gave were not specific enough to provide evidence of perjury. Pierce told the subcommittee that he ``did not have hands on'' involvement in disbursing money through the Moderate Rehabilitation Program, adding that he ``never told these people to fund anything.'' In their letter to Thornburgh, the 21 Democrats said that Gilliam ``described at least two instances in which Mr. Pierce was directly involved in abuses of the Moderate Rehabilitation Program.'' But Robert Plotkin, one of Pierce's defense attorneys, said that Gilliam's testimony does not amount to evidence that Pierce lied to the subcommittee. Gilliam ``was never asked directly about anything that Pierce testified about that was of a specific enough nature for him to be able to contradict anything,'' Plotkin said. But Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., who circulated the letter he and his colleagues signed, said ``Gilliam has added new cause to look into perjury.''

DOC.HEAD: Thugs Attack Gov't Opponent's Home, Injure His Wife
DOC.TEXT: Thugs wielding guns and machetes broke into the home of a former Cabinet minister who advocates an end to one-party rule, seriously injuring his wife, the former official said Thursday. The former official, Kenneth Matiba, said the attack may be linked to his political stand, which has incensed the ruling party. ``I do not want to make any insinuations, but let me say it is very hard for me and my family not to associate my stand in public affairs with this attack,'' he told a news conference. Matiba, who was not home at the time, said the attack occurred at about midnight Wednesday at his 40-acre farm and residence 15 miles north of Nairobi, the capital. He said a group of about 15 men ``calling each other corporal and captain,'' broke through heavy iron grills over the windows and into his bedroom where his daughter and maid had sought refuge with his wife. The attackers, who repeatedly asked for Matiba, rifled through some drawers, took a handbag and necklace of little value, and hit his wife, Edith, on the head with an instrument heavy enough to fracture her skull, he said. The Swahili-speaking attackers also beat up his daughter and maid, neither of whom required hospitalization. The thugs fired two shots at neighbors who came to help, and then fled, Matiba said. While residential break-ins are not uncommon in Kenya, Matiba said the attack at his house was not over valuables. ``Seeing that they stole nothing, what else did they want? It's me, they made it clear,'' he said. Matiba, a prosperous hotelier who was at one of his establishments on Kenya's coast at the time of the attack, said his daughter described the intruders as ranging in age between 25 and 35 years old. He said police were investigating the incident. Since launching his campaign earlier this year calling for public debate on returning Kenya to multiparty politics, Matiba has been condemned repeatedly by ruling party leaders and parliamentarians. He said he also had been threatened and regularly is followed by what he believes are government intelligence officers. President Daniel arap Moi, who has described Matiba's campaign as divisive, in 1982 pushed a law through parliament making the ruling Kenya African National Union the sole legal political party. Moi is president of the party, which has ruled the former British colony since independence in 1963. This is not the first time Matiba has riled the government. He was expelled from the ruling party early last year after he refused to back down on claims that party elections the previous year were rigged. He resigned his Cabinet post as minister of transport and communication over the same issue in late 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Backs Off Economic Sanctions Against India
With AM-US-Japan, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration said Thursday it would not impose economic sanctions against India even though that country has refused to negotiate over trade barriers the United States deems offensive. In announcing the decision, the administration said it would pursue the issues in the current round of global free-trade talks but would not retaliate by boosting tariffs on imports by India into the United States. India was targeted last year along with Japan and Brazil for a possible sanctions under the toughest section of the 1988 trade law. Known as Super 301, the provision required the administration to draw up a priority ``hit list'' of the most offensive barriers to U.S. trade exports. Both Japan and Brazil negotiated their way off the Super 301 list by reaching market-opening agreements. However, India has steadfastly refused to negotiate over U.S. claims that it is unfairly blocking foreign investment and operation of foreign insurance companies. But U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills said the administration was encouraged by India's announcement on May 31 that it would remove some of its investment barriers. ``Our message that foreign investment brings jobs, technology and prosperity may be getting through. I hope this attitude will be reflected in India's approach to these issues in the Uruguay Round,'' she said. The administration has made the Uruguay Round, named for the country where the talks began in 1986, its top trade priority for the year. India is considered a key participant in those talks, being held under the auspices of the 96-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, because of its influence over other developing countries. The United States hopes to win support from developing countries for its push to eliminate farm subsidies, strengthen copyright protection for U.S. companies and expand GATT rules to cover trade in services such as banking and insurance. The Indian government, which has contended that the United States was violating global trading rules through its unilateral threats of retaliation, praised the U.S. decision. ``One would hope this decision marks the return of the United States to the multilateral process,'' said Shipra Biswas, a spokeswoman for the Indian Commerce Ministry in New Delhi. ``Few would argue that our policies on investment and insurance are unreasonable, because they have to be in line with our socio-economic goals.'' While Thursday's decision removes the possibility of economic retaliation immediately, the administration in April renamed India to a ``hit list'' for the current year, citing the same trade barriers. The deadline for reaching a conclusion on that action will not come until June 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Proclamation Praises Fathers
DOC.TEXT: President Bush praised fathers Thursday as playing ``a very important role in shaping the character of our nation.'' In a proclamation recognizing Sunday's celebration of Fathers Day, Bush said the day is a time to ``thank dads everywhere for all they do.'' ``As children, we cannot fully fathom the depth of our father's love for us. Neither can we fully realize the weight of his responsibilities,'' said the president, himself a father of five and grandfather of 12. Children rarely ``perceive in their father's tender gaze the worries, frustrations and concerns'' that are a part of parenting, the proclamation said. ``With each passing year, and especially as we have children of our own, we become ever more grateful for our father's love and discipline, and for the many sacrifices he has made. We begin to see clearly how being a father requires faith and fortitude,'' Bush said. He called Father's Day a time to ``thank dads everywhere for all they do, throughout the year, for our families and country.''

DOC.HEAD: East and West Move Toward Arms Cut Agreement
DOC.TEXT: Negotiators at East-West talks on reducing Europe's conventional forces are close to agreement on overall limits for the number of tanks and armored combat vehicles, diplomats said Thursday. They said they expected imminent formal agreement on ceilings in the two weapons categories and said this would speed negotiations for an initial agreement at the talks by the end of the year. The negotiations on Conventional Forces in Europe are designed to reduce troops and non-nuclear weapons of the two military alliances from the Atlantic Ocean to the Ural mountains. The 16 member nations of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and seven Warsaw Pact countries are taking part. The breakthrough came from the French and the Poles. Their proposal suggests an overall ceiling for armored combat vehicles of 30,000 for each side and a ceiling of 20,000 tanks for each side. It sets minimum weight parameters of 16.5 tons for tanks regardless of whether they have tracks or wheels. French chief delegate Francois Plaisant said at a joint news conference with Poland's Wlodzimierz Konarski there was ``informal but overall consensus'' on the proposal. A press statement by Soviet delegation leader Oleg A. Grinevski said ``an important step has doubtlessly been made. ... This solution means substantial progress at the Vienna negotiations.'' A minor setback occurred, however, at a closed-door meeting of delegates from all 23 countries at which the proposal had been expected to be made final, said a Western diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity. The Soviet side said it first wanted to see an equipment list that is to accompany the agreement, the diplomat said. No one at the Soviet delegation could be reached for comment. The Western diplomat called the development a ``negative step'' but expressed hope it could be worked out quickly at current informal meetings. The breakthrough came after weeks when negotiators from both sides complained petty bargaining was slowing the talks. Western diplomats said the Soviets appeared to be dragging their feet until the future security allegiance of a united Germany is decided. But the diplomats said they had detected a ``willingness to move forward'' in recent weeks. Both sides hope to have an agreement ready for signing by December when leaders from 35 nations _ including the 23 involved in the Vienna talks _ are scheduled to meet in Paris. The other 12 participants are neutral and non-aligned countries in Europe that also would be affected by reducing tensions on the Continent. Finding common definitions for tanks and other armaments has been a contentious issue at the Vienna talks. Thursday's proposal no longer makes a distinction between armored troop carriers and other armored vehicles, removing a further obstacle. Konarski said the text in a future treaty will include a list of the arms they would carry, classifying all the weapons the two sides now have. He said this would be unprecedented in East-West relations. He said these lists would then become the basis for the reductions. According to U.S. estimates, the West now has 23,600 tanks and the Warsaw Pact, 52,500, and 34,025 armored combat vehicles to the Warsaw Pact's 59,400. Konarski said the use of broader categories of definitions was the only way to conclude a deal under the circumstances. But he and Plaisant said many issues remain to be resolved before a final agreement can be signed.

DOC.HEAD: Denials of Report About JFK Jr. and TV Project
DOC.TEXT: A report that John F. Kennedy Jr. was negotiating to appear in a soap opera was incorrect, a spokesman for Kennedy said Thursday. A producer who was quoted as the source of the report has since said he did not provide the information. A man who identified himself as producer Ruben Malaret told The Associated Press on Monday that he had negotiated with the late president's son about a part in a projected soap opera, ``Families.'' In a telephone conversation on Wednesday, a man identifying himself as Malaret denied he had ever spoken to Kennedy about the part, and denied he had discussed the subject with the AP. He agreed to meet with an AP reporter on Thursday, but did not appear. AP reporters said the caller identifying himself as Malaret on Monday and Wednesday sounded like the same person. Kennedy's office referred questions about the report to Michael Berman, who acts as his spokesman. Berman said Kennedy had never talked with anyone about the soap opera and would not consider such an appearance. ``That story is just absolutely not true,'' he said. Kennedy works as an assistant district attorney in New York.

DOC.HEAD: Court Allows Hospitals To Sue States Over Medicaid Rates
With AM-Scotus Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Hospitals and nursing homes may challenge a state's Medicaid reimbursement system, the Supreme Court ruled Thursday in a decision that could have a major financial impact. The justices, in a 5-4 vote, said the Virginia Hospital Association may use a federal civil rights law to sue Virginia over the state's Medicaid payment rates. At a time of soaring medical costs and an increasing demand for Medicaid services, the decision could force the federal and state governments to cough up more money for the program that provides medical care for the poor. ``This should increase ... the amount of reimbursement that hospitals will get for providing Medicaid patients with care,'' said Fredric J. Entin, general counsel for the American Hospital Association. He said he could not estimate how much reimbursements might rise if hospitals are successful with their lawsuits. If the hospital association wins its case in federal court, the state's hospitals would get $25 million to $27 million more per year in Medicaid reimbursements, said Laurens Sartoris, association president. About half would come from the federal government and half from state coffers. Virginia hospitals now get about $230 million from Medicaid, he said. In this fiscal year, total Medicaid expenses for the nation are expected to approach $71 billion, about 56 percent borne by the federal government and the rest by the states. Hospitals in Colorado, Pennsylvania and Michigan have won lawsuits similar to the Virginia Hospital Association's, though some of the decisions are on appeal. Cases also are pending in Wisconsin, Oregon and Ohio, said Mary Babich, a spokeswoman for the American Hospital Association. Officials from most states had urged the Supreme Court to rule against the Virginia association. They said allowing such lawsuits could affect hundreds of millions of dollars in federal and state funding, and lead to a litigation explosion. ``The Medicaid program in almost every state is having financial difficulties,'' said Jeff Harris, a researcher for the Medicaid Management Institute, which is part of the American Public Welfare Association. ``This opens the door to tremendous increases in costs,'' he said, adding that it also ties the hands of state legislatures by allowing ``judicial rate setting for hospitals, nursing homes and doctors.'' Sartoris disagreed, saying: ``I don't think the floodgates are going to open.'' He added that ``it wouldn't surprise me that some (states) would'' file suit, but he said providers have a ``tremendous burden to prove that the state's program doesn't meet the federal standard. Whether the Supreme Court decision would help physicians who might challenge Medicaid reimbursements was unclear. Harris said it would, but Martin A. Donlan, an attorney for the Virginia association, was doubtful. The court, led by Justice William J. Brennan, said Congress never intended to bar Medicaid care providers from suing in federal court when reimbursement disputes arise. The court said Congress gave health care providers the right to sue in federal court when it amended the Medicaid Act in 1980. That amendment, introduced by Sen. David Boren, D-Okla., requires states to reimburse health care providers according to rates ``the state finds, and makes assurances satisfactory to the secretary (of Health and Human Services) are reasonable and adequate.'' Writing for the majority, Brennan said the amendment ``creates a right, enforceable in a private cause of action ... to have the state adopt rates that it finds are reasonable and adequate rates to meet the costs of an efficient and economical health care provider.'' Brennan was joined by Justices Byron R. White, Thurgood Marshall, Harry A. Blackmun and John Paul Stevens. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Sandra Day O'Connor, Antonin Scalia and Anthony M. Kennedy dissented. In its 1986 lawsuit, the Virginia Hospital Association sued the state, alleging that the too-low rates violate the federal Medicaid Act and the rights of participating hospitals to due process. Virginia officials sought to have the suit dismissed, contending that only health care recipients _ not individual or associated health care providers _ have the right to sue under the Medicaid Act.

DOC.HEAD: Imelda Marcos Weeps at Trial, Examined by Doctors
DOC.TEXT: Imelda Marcos began weeping Thursday when a witness at her federal racketeering trial mentioned one of her daughters while tracing funds Mrs. Marcos allegedly used to buy lavish gifts. The judge immediately broke for lunch, and Mrs. Marcos was examined by her doctors at the nurse's office in the courthouse. Lawyers said Mrs. Marcos' blood pressure had shot up but then stabilized, and the trial continued after the lunch recess. The trial in U.S. District Court was adjourned three times before because of Mrs. Marcos' health problems, most recently on May 31 when she was hospitalized for a stomach ailment related to stress. Earlier, she experienced two attacks of high blood pressure. A doctor's report submitted to U.S. District Judge John F. Keenan last week said Mrs. Marcos's blood pressure and heartbeat increased when she discussed ``her strong desire to vindicate her family name.'' On Thursday, Mrs. Marcos became upset when an accountant for the Philippine government explained charts that traced millions of dollars allegedly stolen from a government-owned bank to personal purchases for Mrs. Marcos. Mrs. Marcos, who was seated at the defense table, began crying when the witness, Maria Goreddi Jimenez, said some of the money was used to buy Nautilus exercise equipment for her eldest daughter, Imee Marcos Manotoc. Lawyers said Mrs. Marcos became distraught at any mention of her family, especially Imee, whom she hasn't seen in four years and who reportedly is living in Northern Africa. Mrs. Marcos' two other children, Ferdinand Marcos Jr. and Irene Marcos Araneta, have periodically attended the trial. The funds outlined on the charts were part of the $222 million that the government alleges was siphoned out of the Philippines treasury by Mrs. Marcos and her late husband, President Ferdinand Marcos. Mrs. Marcos is accused of having used the stolen money for luxury purchases and secret investments in New York real estate. Her co-defendant, Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi, is alleged to have backdated documents to help the Marcoses protect the real estate holdings from a 1986 court order freezing their U.S. assets. The charts showed $28.6 million deposited into a New York bank account of Mrs. Marcos' personal secretary, Fe Roa Gimenez, between 1980 and 1986. The accountant said the money included about $6.7 million from the New York branch of the government-owned Philippine National Bank, of which more than $3 million was used to buy jewelry for Mrs. Marcos. The remaining money was used to buy designer clothes for Mrs. Marcos and her daughters, fur coats and other expenses such as hotel and limousine bills, the accountant said. Prosecutors have said Mrs. Marcos used the Philippine National Bank's New York office as her ``personal piggy bank'' for spending sprees during visits to New York. Jimenez said she was an accountant for the Philippine Commission on Good Government, which was established after Marcos was deposed in February 1986 to trace money he allegedly took from the treasury.

DOC.HEAD: Irish-Language Writer Dead at 89
DOC.TEXT: Seosamh Mac Grianna, who adapted simple folk tales into Irish-language stories before virtually abandoning writing 55 years ago, has died near his boyhood home. He was 89. Mac Grianna died in a hospital Monday in Letterkenny in northwest Ireland, The Irish Times reported. Cause of death was not given. Mac Grianna wrote his last book, ``Mo Bhealach Fein'' (My Own Way), in 1935. Some of his most important work, thogh, was not published until 1969. He entered a mental hospital in 1935 for treatment of depression and wrote little afterward. ``Mac Grianna sought isolation, he was ready to accept the reputation of being eccentric and unsociable, because he sought a vision of which he could never speak,'' wrote critic Seamus Deane in 1940 following the publication of ``Mo Bhealach Fein,'' a partly fictionalized autobiography. Mac Grianna was born Joseph Green on Jan. 15, 1901, in an Irish-speaking community in County Donegal. His family was known for generations as storytellers, singers and poets. After leaving school, he taught school briefly and was involved in the fight for Irish independence from Britain in the early 1920s, spending time in jail before becoming a full-time writer. As a young man, Mac Grianna contributed to newspapers and periodicals and wrote several novels and short stories. He also prepared Irish translations of a dozen books, including ``Ivanhoe'' and ``Ben Hur.'' One of his best-known works, ``An Druma Mor'' (The Big Drum), tells of an Irish community in the 1920s wrangling over a marching band. It was not published until 1969. Two years later, it was awarded the Irish-American Butler prize and became required reading in university Irish courses. In recent years, Mac Grianna had appeared at literary festivals. Mac Grianna was the brother of Seamus O Grianna, who wrote under the name ``Maire'' and died in 1969. The Irish language, often called Gaelic, is spoken frequently now by only about 5 to 10 percent of Ireland's 3.5 million people. Funeral arrangements were incomplete.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Moves As Oil Leaks
DOC.TEXT: Even as crews tried to lasso a widening oil slick off the Texas coast Thursday, lawmakers in Washington tried to patch up legislation designed to prevent future oil spills. Rep. Gerry Studds, D-Mass., proposed a compromise that he hopes will break a legislative logjam holding up such legislation. The bill would toughen penalties against oil spillers, quadruple limits on liability for tanker operators, require double hulls on new oil tankers and establish a $1 billion fund available for cleanup emergencies. The legislative manuvering comes amid a spate of oil spills. In the past week, a fire and spill on the Norwegian tanker Mega Borg off Galveston, Texas, threatened the gulf coastline with a major environmental disaster. A tanker grounding off Staten Island, N.Y., sent tar balls up on the Jersey Shore. And a cruise ship that struck rocks near the Cape Cod Canal spilled 7,500 gallons of fuel oil, soiling nearby Cape Cod beaches. But a House-Senate conference committee has run aground on whether to participate in international oil-spill protocols. The House version would have the U.S. participate, even though the protocols are somewhat more lenient toward ship owners responsible for spills in international waters. The Senate wants to hold ship owners entirely responsible when spills harm the U.S. coast. ``Unfortunately, the debate over the international convention is exactly where it was six months ago and six years ago,'' Studds said. ``If we don't do something to break the logjam, we'll be debating this issue until every beach in America has been coated with oil.'' Studds wrote to 100 members of the conference committee Thursday to explain his compromise proposal. Under Studds' compromise, the United States would participate in the international protocols for up to five years and during that time would try to strengthen their oil spill provisions. ``If the negotiations are successful, we would continue to participate in the global agreements,'' Studds said. ``If not, we would go our own way.''

DOC.HEAD: House OKs Amendment to Water-Projects Bill
DOC.TEXT: The House overwhelmingly passed legislation Thursday that would prevent huge corporate farms from receiving federally subsidized water and force growers to chose between crop price supports and low-cost water. The two measures, directed primarily at farmers in California and other western states, aim at curbing what critics say is an abuse of the Bureau of Reclamation system. The federal government has been building dams in the West since early in this century to supply water for farming. Both measures were amendments to a routine water projects bill that passed by a voice vote. The projects bill authorized spending for modifications to the Buffalo Bill Dam and reservoir in Wyoming. The first of the two amendments, which passed by a 316-97 vote, would tighten ownership rules to end abuses of size limit on farms that can receive federally subsidized water. The General Accounting Office and other investigations found that corporate farms of as much as 23,000 acres were receiving subsidized water, despite a 960-acre limit. This was done through creating a patchwork quilt of farms that were separately owned only on paper. ``We're not telling people they have to get rid of their land or their water,'' said Rep. George Miller, D-Calif., sponsor of the amendment. ``We're saying that a farmer reaches a certain point where he no longer needs to receive a costly federal subsidy.'' The second of the two amendments, which passed 338-55, would phase out irrigation subsidies to grow surplus crops. That amendment was introduced by Rep. Sam Gejdenson, D-Conn. ``It does not do away with irrigation subsidies altogether,'' said Rep. Thomas E. Petri, R-Wis., in support of the amendment. ``It merely requires farmers to chose one subsidy or the other.'' The Agriculture Department says that in 1986, commodity payments of nearly $380 million went to farmers using Bureau of Reclamation projects. At the same time, according to the Interior Department figures cited by backers of the amendment, farmers growing surplus crops received $830 million worth of irrigation subsidies. Rep. Charles Pashayan Jr., R-Calif., said the subsidy bill could be particularly harmful to small farmers. ``It is an amendment whose result will be to discourage production of that very thing at which Americans are the very best at in the world: namely food and fiber,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: GAO: Vocational Education Lacking
DOC.TEXT: Government and education officials said Thursday that the nation has failed non-college bound youth but efforts are underway to better connect the path students travel from school to the work force. ``From birth to the end of their working lives, we invest less in our blue collar work force than any of the major countries with which we compete,'' said Marc Tucker, president of the National Center on Education and the Economy. ``We give them less care when they are infants and children. We expect less of them in school. We give them less job training when they start out. We let them sink or swim when they try to get into the work force. And we provide them with less training once they are at work.'' Tucker's comments echoed a report by the General Accounting Office that claimed the attention of a hearing by a Joint Economic subcommittee. The report said 9 million Americans are ill-equipped to hold entry-level jobs, while England, Germany, Japan and Sweden all do a better job of preparing non-college bound youth for employment.
