Raymond Uhalde of the Department of Labor said the agency ``generally agrees with the findings'' but stressed the upcoming reauthorization of the Carl D. Perkins Vocational Education Act ``is likely to promote new connections between academic and occupational skills and curricula.'' Uhalde said the legislation would encourage the development of new curricula and technology that teach basic skills in the context of occupationally oriented education. Franklin Frazier, director of the GAO Office of Education and Employment Issues, said the study found the four competitor nations have national policies that guide students' transition from school to work. Many of the countries establish competency-based national training standards that they use to certify skill competency. The common U.S. practice is to certify only program completion. The study also found that competitors invest extensively in jobless out-of-school youth to assure them a job or further education and training. U.S. employment and training programs reach only a modest proportion of youth in need. The study had been requested by Rep. James Scheuer, D-N.Y., chairman of the committee's Education and Health Subcommittee, and Rep. Augustus Hawkins, D-Calif., a JEC member and chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee. They asked for a comparison of how the United States and competitor countries prepare non-college youth for employment because of the perception that foreign competitors excel in world trade with better-educated workers. Gordon Ambach, executive director of the Council of Chief State School Officers, said resolving the problem has become the group's top priority for the next year. Ambach, noting action should begin in November, said the council is designing new ways for youth to enter the work force, including apprenticeships.

DOC.HEAD: Former Cable Network Official To Join Kennedy Center
DOC.TEXT: Carolyn Reynolds, former program director of the Arts & Entertainment cable television network, will become director of television and special projects for the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, it was announced Thursday. Neither James D. Wolfensohn, the Kennedy Center's new chairman, nor the center's press office would say what Wolfensohn had in mind for the TV venture that Ms. Reynolds will direct. It was not known whether he envisions televising the center's regular theater, dance and music programs, or whether the center would originate its own TV productions. Wolfensohn had said previously he wanted to expand the Kennedy Center's audiences nationwide. Television ``holds great promise for the center,'' he said in a statement. ``Reaching beyond the six wonderful theaters we have in the building, television offers us a ``seventh stage,' a stage with tremendous possibility for the performing arts to reach millions of people the world over.'' Ms. Reynolds, who also was community development director in her six years at A&E, also will be responsible for planning and supervising such special projects as the Kennedy Center's Texas Festival in June 1991 and the Festival of the Americas planned for 1992.

DOC.HEAD: John Philip Sousa Gets Star on Hollywood's Walk of Fame
DOC.TEXT: Composer John Philip Sousa got his star on Hollywood's Walk of Fame on Thursday, while the U.S. Marine Corps Band played one of his best known marches, ``Stars and Stripes Forever.'' ``It's our second national anthem for me and I think a lot of people,'' said Art Bartner, director of the University of Southern California marching band. Members of the USC marching band and local high school bands also played at the ceremony, held on Flag Day. ``It was terrific,'' Bartner said. ``When I heard `Stars and Stripes,' it was goose-bump city.'' Sousa, who died in 1932, directed the U.S. Marine Band during five presidential administrations. His is the 1,914th star on the Walk of Fame.

DOC.HEAD: Jews Riot, Attack Arab Homes After Jewish Boy Stabbed
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of rioting Jews rushed into a Palestinian neighborhood and hurled stones at homes Thursday after an Arab woman stabbed an 11-year-old Jew in east Jerusalem. The wounding of the boy was the second such attack in mostly Arab east Jerusalem in three days. Mayor Teddy Kollek blamed the stabbing on Arab fears of Israel's new right-wing government. After dark, angry Jewish residents blocked a major road in East Talpiot, the Jewish neighborhood where the stabbing took place. They shouted ``Death to the Arabs!'' while others drove around in their cars, honking the horns, witnesses and police said. Police brought in reinforcements, but some rioters broke through police lines and threw stones at houses in neighboring Sur Baher, an Arab village. They also set fire to bushes and an olive grove there, police reports said. Groups of Palestinians from Sur Baher met the attackers with a barrage of stones, and paramilitary border police fired tear gas to disperse them. Police then forced the Jewish protesters back to East Talpiot. There were no immediate reports of any injuries or arrests in the riot, which lasted for about three hours. The national Itim news agency estimated about 500 Jews took part in the protest. The stabbed boy, Idan Mizrahi, was waiting at a bus stop at the edge of East Talpiot in Israeli-annexed east Jerusalem when the woman approached and stabbed him, according to authorities and media reports. Idan was reported in good condition at a hospital after surgeons removed the knife from his back. Police said the woman fled toward Sur Baher. Police cordoned off the area and searched for her, taking 25 Palestinian women in for questioning, Police Chief Arye Bibi said. Bibi said the attacker was motivated by Palestinian nationalism. On Tuesday, a Palestinian knifed and wounded a 17-year-old Jewish seminary student outside east Jerusalem's walled Old City. Police said they are holding a suspect who confessed. Before Thursday's riots, Jewish residents in the East Talpiot area, angry about the stabbing, had demanded better security from Police Minister Ronnie Milo. ``There is no doubt this is a serious incident, and it requires us to think again ... how to recruit the full amount of resources and forces to confront the problem of uprising here in Jerusalem, in Israel and other places,'' Milo said. Palestinians in December 1987 began fighting occupation of territories seized by Israel from neighboring Arab states in the 1967 Middle East War. Most of the violence has been confined to the Gaza Strip and West Bank, but some Palestinians want resistance stepped up in Arab east Jerusalem. Israeli also seized east Jerusalem in 1967, later annexing it and declaring Jerusalem the capital of the Jewish state. Kollek, a Jew, blamed Thursday's stabbing on the breakdown of the peace process and also cited the formation of a new right-wing government in Israel. ``I imagine the Arabs are scared and worried. ... I'm certain there won't be war, and this government would do all it can to bring peace about. But until something happens, people who are scared do all kinds of foolish things,'' Kollek said. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, leader of the right-wing Likud bloc, took the helm of a new government this week with backing from hard-line religious parties. The left-of-center Labor Party brought down the previous government, saying it should have accepted U.S. proposals to open peace talks with Palestinians. In the occupied West Bank on Thursday, the decapitated body of Ibrahim Sahnawi, a suspected Arab informer, was found on a hilltop near Jenin refugee camp, Arab reporters said. The army confirmed the death. In the 30-month-old uprising, 717 Palestinians have been killed by Israelis, and 45 Israelis have been killed.

DOC.HEAD: Retired Teacher Defends Right to Rock
With AM-2 Live Crew
LaserPhoto CX4
DOC.TEXT: You say 2 Live Crew's too bad for you? Meet Mary Morello, a 66-year-old retired school teacher organizing some like-minded folk in Chicago's suburbs and beyond to defend the right to rock from those who would might rather have it muzzled. ``I think we have to be really careful about ... freedom of speech, '' said Morello, who has sent about 350 letters to rally support for her fledgling group, Parents for Rock and Rap. ``It seems sometimes people don't notice if some of their rights are taken away,'' she said recently. The former teacher of African Studies and World History went to work for rock after seeing a promotional film by the Arlington, Va.-based Parents' Music Resource Center, which has helped in the fight against explicit lyrics. The film, shown by a police officer at a PTA meeting in her town of Libertyville, a suburb northwest of Chicago, was ``a little dull,'' but nonetheless sensationalized the impact of rock and rap music on young people's thinking, she said. ``I introduced myself ... and spoke for about 10 minutes about the right of artists to have their music and art be uncensored,'' she said. She got another push from her son, Tom, a 26-year-old Harvard University graduate and full-time musician in Lock Up, a hard-rock band, who sent his mother some material on music censorship. The elder Morello last month obtained a mailing list from Long Beach, Calif.-based Rock and Roll Confidential, which distributes an anti-censorship pamphlet. Using $100 in seed money, she asked people on the mailing list to be on the alert for possible censorship and to join her coalition. So far, she has received about 30 responses to the initial mailing, and envisions a state-by-state organization that will monitor legislation and ``be an alternate voice on this issue of censoring.'' ``I don't think anyone should feel fear about writing something or performing something in a democracy,'' Morello said. However, the Parents' Music Resource Center said the issue is not censorship, but an entertainment culture that is increasingly violent and explicit. ``We need to work with parents to help teach their children to be more critical and to make better choices,'' Executive Director Jennifer Norwood said Thursday. Morello's son, lead guitarist for Lock Up, said his mother comes to her cause naturally. ``My mom has always been a very independent thinker,'' Tom said from Dallas, where his band was performing. ``She introduced me to the Temptations and Stevie Wonder. I returned the favor by introducing her to Jimi Hendrix and Led Zepplin.'' The elder Morello said she even defends 2 Live Crew, a raunchy rap band thrust into the national spotlight after a federal judge in Florida last week declared their last album, ``As Nasty as They Wanna Be,'' obscene. ``I bought their album, I listened to it,'' she said. ``Have you heard it? Well, that isn't the way I talk or the way people talk to me,'' she said. ``But that's the album _ and that's 2 Live Crew's own business.''

DOC.HEAD: Little Leaguer Allowed to Finish Season With His Team
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to CORRECT date of season finale to June 20, sted June 10.
DOC.TEXT: He's only 9, but Michael Hanner already is a hot sports commodity _ playing hardball on the field and at the bargaining table. The Little Leaguer raised a ruckus when he refused to join a team competing in a higher division after it drafted him in mid-season. League officials then tried to enforce a rule to keep the pitcher-shortstop from playing with his original team, the Phillies. ``The rule still stands,'' said his lawyer, Paul Carey. ``But Michael gets to play baseball, and that was the outcome we wanted from day one.'' Attorney David Berkey, who represented Kirkland National Little League, said it settled the case because a legal battle would have been too costly. ``The Little League couldn't see spending a bunch of money to see if the rule was valid,'' Berkey said. The Phillies have three more games, including the season finale on June 20, Michael's 10th birthday.

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Storms in Plains, Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms and showers fell Thursday from Nebraska to Illinois, including 4{ inches of rain in two hours at Warrensburg, Mo. There was flooding in parts of Iowa, Kansas, and North Carolina. More than a foot of water rushed through downtown Warrensburg after the early-morning storms. Rain swept a car from the road near Holden, Mo., but the driver was not injured. Dense fog blinded boaters on the St. Marys River on Michigan's Upper Peninsula, prompting the Coast Guard to close the heavily used 77-mile waterway for several hours. The lower Roanoke River flooded near Williamston, N.C., while the Nishnabotna River overran its banks near Hamburg, Iowa, as did the Blue River at Blue Rapids, Kansas. Thunderstorms fell in Nebraska, Arkansas and southern Illinois. Rain and thunderstorms fell in parts of Kentucky, Tennessee, Indiana, Ohio, Lower Michigan, New Jersey, Louisiana, Texas, Nebraska, South Dakota, Nevada, Montana, Wyoming and North Dakota. A tornado touched down near Murphysboro, Ill., but caused no injuries or damage. Low-temperature records for the date were broken in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., where it was 66 degrees, and Pendleton, Ore., where it was 39. The low temperature for the Lower 48 was 31 degrees in West Yellowstone, Mont.

DOC.HEAD: Explosion Causes Damage at British Military Area
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with device identified as bomb, details, background on IRA. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A powerful bomb exploded at a British Army training area outside Hanover on Thursday, badly damaging an unoccupied building and breaking windows in nearby homes. There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the attack. However, the British military has been the target of a rash of bombings and shooting attacks in Western Europe carried out by the Irish Republican Army as part of its terror campaign to end British rule in Northern Ireland. Maj. Leslie Hutchison, spokesman for the 4th Armored Division, said no one was near the site of Thursday's explosion. However, he added, ``There was quite severe damage to the side of an unoccupied building which is normally used as a lecture hall.'' The training area is on the Weser River 12 miles southwest of Hanover in Lower Saxony state. Hutchinson said it is used primarily by the British Army's 35th Engineer Regiment and the 28th Amphibious Regiment. A 4th Armored Division spokeswoman, Lynne Gammond, later told The Associated Press in a telephone interview that investigators had determined the explosion was caused by ``a bomb, probably made up of plastic explosives.'' She said the bomb also broke windows in German homes across a busy highway about 25 yards away. ``It's a wonder some Germans were not injured,'' Ms. Gammond said. She said it was too early to determine who had carried out the attack. ``To say at this point it was the IRA would be speculation. The investigation is still being conducted,'' Ms. Gammond said. Thursday's explosion comes 12 days after the IRA claimed responsibility for the shooting death of British Army Maj. Michael John Dillon-Lee as he was returning to his home in Dortmund before dawn on June 2. The same day one British soldier was shot to death and two soldiers were wounded in a daylight attack at a rail station in Lichfield, central England. Dillon-Lee was the 14th person killed by the IRA in Europe since 1978. The predominantly Catholic IRA is fighting to unite Northern Ireland, which is 60 percent Protestant, with the 95 percent Catholic Irish Republic.

DOC.HEAD: Gore Questions Administration Committment To Combat Global Warning
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration came under renewed attack for its policies on global warming Thursday as a senator charged that oil-rich Saudi Arabia was allowed to scuttle an aggressive response strategy at a recent international conference. Sen. Albert Gore, D-Tenn., questioned why a United Nations panel, headed by the United States, recently failed to include among its option for dealing with global warming specific targets for pollution controls. ``Instead you seemed to be recommending that we do nothing,'' he told the head of the U.S. delegation to the conference, Frederick Bernthal at a Senate hearing on global warming. Bernthal was chairman of the working group that at a conference in Geneva recently drafted a formal series of responses that nations should take to deal with the global warming issue. The final draft which will be released later this year will not include specific recommendations or timetables for pollution controls, Bernthal said. Gore charged that at the conference the delegation from Saudi Arabia repeatedly blocked any attempt to come up with specific pollution controls without the United States responding. The burning of fossil fuels, including oil, is the source of carbon dioxide, which accounts for about half of the global warming pollutants that go into the atmosphere. Gore questioned why the U.S. delegation did not counter the arguments made by the Saudi delegation, which he said was represented that country's oil ministry. ``Instead, the U.S. delegates sat on their hands, saying very little while the Saudis and some others blasted the hell out of any policy option that would have led to (pollution) reductions,'' said Gore. Bernthal said there was no hope of gaining a consensus on specific pollution control goals. ``Every country in the room would have had a different answer,'' he said. Scientists generally agree that manmade pollution, primarily from the burning of fossil fuels, is causing the earth to become warmer. The Bush administration has argued repeatedly, however, that no specific commitments for pollution control should be made until the severity of the threat becomes clearer. Three study groups of the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change have attempted for more than a year to examine the severity of the problem and what responses nations should take. Bernthal's working group is focusing on response strategies. Environmentalists have for months criticized Bush for failing to announce specific reductions in carbon dioxide emissions. Several European countries, including the Dutch, West Germany and Great Britain, have announced such goals.

DOC.HEAD: Governing Party Tries for Breakthrough in Czech Coalition Talks
DOC.TEXT: President Vaclav Havel's Civic Forum, victor in Czechoslovakia`s free elections, refused to take no for an answer Thursday and said it still wants a coalition with the Christian Democratic alliance. The Civic Forum and its Slovak ally, Public Against Violence, won 170 of the 300 seats in Parliament last weekend, but fell short of the three-fifths majority it needs in both chambers to pass major constitutional changes. The Christian Democratic Union, a loose grouping of three parties, won 40 seats, far less than it expected but enough to block constitutional changes in the Slovak part of parliament's 150-seat House of Nations. The Slovak Christian Democratic Movement is the strongest of the three parties. Its leader, Jan Carnogursky, said on TV Tuesday night he will not play ``fifth fiddle'' in the government and wanted half the seats in the new Cabinet. Informed sources close to the coalition talks said Carnogursky also saw himself as a candidate for the job of premier. Havel has already charged the incumbent, ex-Communist Marian Calfa, with forming a government. Observers see the nomination of Calfa, a career Communist Party official who only turned in his party card in January, as the likely source of friction in the talks. Civic Forum officials said they still hope to break the deadlock. Civic Forum spokeswoman Jana Ryslinkova told journalists Thursday, ``During the last talks between the Civic Forum and the Christian Democratic Union, there was nothing said or done that could be considered as the final end of coalition talks. No ultimatums were given on either side. ``On behalf of the Civic Forum, I can confirm that we shall do our best to form a coalition with the Christian Democrats.'' One key issue in the talks is the Interior Ministry. Richard Sacher, a leader of the People's Party, which is in the Christian Democratic Union, is the incumbent minister. But Sacher has come under fire for alleged reluctance to investigate past operations of the hated secret police. He has further been hurt by allegations by Havel aides that People's Party Chairman Josef Bartoncik was a paid secret police agent for 17 years. Bartoncik's party announced his suspension on Thursday. People's Party General Secretary Jiri Cerny resigned hours later over what party officials described as a personal matter. The disarray in not confined to the Christian Democrat camp. Jan Urban abruptly resigned as Civic Forum's campaign manager on Monday, the day after its election victory. At least two prominent people who won parliamentary mandates for Civic Forum said they will not take their seats, meaning lesser known, inexperienced people will become deputies. Talks on forming governments in the country's two republics, the Czech and Slovak republics, proceeded more smoothly. Slovak Interior Minister Vladimir Meciar, a member of Public Against Violence, was given the job of forming the Slovak government on Thursday, the official news agency CTK said.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Secretary Orders Go-Ahead on New Mexico Waste Installation
DOC.TEXT: Energy Secretary James Watkins on Thursday ordered his department to go ahead with development of a radioactive waste repository in New Mexico, saying it meets all required environmental laws. But he said the plant near Carlsbad, N.M., will not receive any radioactive wastes until January at the earliest because of continuing tests. ``I will not compromise health or safety concerns to meet any schedule,'' said Watkins. The department's Waste Isolation Pilot Plant will accept highly radioactive waste over a five year test period beginning next year, he said. Watkins signed a formal ``record of decision'' on a supplement to the environmental impact statement for the plant, certifying that the plant meets federal environmental laws. The department said, however, further tests would be conducted on some environmental issues such as gas generated from metal drums and wastes created as a result of corrosion or bacterial action. The plant will be the country's first central repository for radioactive wastes from nearly a dozen nuclear weapons plants. The wastes will be placed in salt beds 2,150 feet under the ground. The department ``has made significant progress in resolving the issues under our direct control in order to conduct the test phase in an environmentally safe manner,'' said Watkins. ``We have a consensus from the scientific community that DOE should begin the test phase at the earliest time possible commensurate with satisfactory completion of applicable safety requirements,'' he said. In Boise, Idaho, Gov. Cecil D. Andrus said he was encouraged by Watkins' announcement, but ``Idahoans have seen many previous deadlines for opening WIPP come and go.'' Idaho and some other western states have refused to accept more waste from the Energy Department.

DOC.HEAD: FAA Finds Some Fairchild Planes Prone to Mid-Flight Window Loss
DOC.TEXT: Owners of small passenger planes made by Fairchild Aircraft Corp. have been ordered not to let passengers sit by windows that may be prone to break in mid-flight. The Federal Aviation Administration airworthiness directive issued Tuesday bars passengers from riding in seat ``2E'' on the right side of the plane unless a double-paned window is installed. Horizon Air President John Kelly said Tuesday that double-pane windows were being installed on the company's Fairchild Metro III turboprop under a company decision made before the directive was issued. The directive stems from an incident Saturday in which a window broke on a Horizon flight between Portland, Ore., and Yakima, leaving a hole an inch in diameter. Three weeks ago, a Portland man on a Horizon flight from Portland to Seattle was partially sucked out of a Metro III when the window by his seat _ 2E _ shattered about 14,000 feet over Olympia. A similar incident occurred in Europe in 1988. ``The FAA has received three reports of the second passenger window on the right side breaking in flight on Fairchild SA226 and SA227 series airplanes. In each of these reports the airplane was flying in icing conditions,'' the directive said. ``Ice shed from the propeller may have struck the window, causing either holes or cracks. In two reports the weakened window could not contain the cabin pressure, which resulted in rapid cabin decompression.'' Plane owners have 30 days to follow the directive. Until they do, they must post signs at 2E saying: ``Do not occupy this seat at any time.'' Michele Owsley of the FAA in Texas said the problem of mid-flight window breakage may be unique to Fairchild planes. She said concern was raised after a cockpit window blew out and caused an injury in 1988. That incident resulted in an FAA order for inspection of windows to check for cracks after every 2,500 hours of service, roughly five months. Bob Kennison, assistant to the president of Fairchild Aircraft Corp., said Monday he did not know whether the company had more window problems than other manufacturers of small passenger airplanes.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Visits Vietnam Memorial on Flag Day, Senator Blasts Amendment
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS grafs 24-25: ``Dole, the,'' with Mitchell promising vote in Senate before July 4th, House schedule; SUBS last graf to restore dropped matter
DOC.TEXT: President Bush marked Flag Day with a dawn visit to the Vietnam Veterans Memorial Thursday while a Medal of Honor-winning senator said he was ashamed of Bush's recent actions concerning a constitutional amendment on flag burning. ``Today, in quiet glory, the Stars and Stripes continue to proclaim the shining promise of America,'' Bush said in a statement released after he visited the memorial. He proclaimed not only Flag Day but Flag Week. Later, veterans in American Legion and Amvets caps, along with camera-carrying tourists, swarmed over Capitol Hill where rows of American flags hung limp in the heat while lawmakers poured forth Flag Day oratory. On Main Streets across the nation, Americans decked front porches with American flags in honor of the day. Bush called on ``all Americans to observe Flag Day and Flag Week by flying the Stars and Stripes from their homes and other suitable places.'' He said nothing about the proposed constitutional amendment, which passed its first hurdle in the House on Wednesday, two days after the Supreme Court threw out last year's flag protection law. To become part of the Constitution, the amendment will need two-thirds support in both the House and the Senate and ratification by 38 state legislatures. ``On this joyous occasion, may we also renew our determination to uphold the ideals enshrined in our Constitution and Declaration of Independence,'' the president said in his statement. Sen. Bob Kerrey, D-Neb., who won the Medal of Honor in Vietnam, called the push for a flag amendment ``an attempt to divide America, to divide fathers against sons.'' He said it would reopen ``the generation gap'' of the Vietnam era. Kerrey held up a picture of Bush laughing at a White House meeting as Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan., held a flag _ a picture, the senator said, that showed the real point of the debate was to gain ``political advantage.'' ``I am ashamed of what he did,'' Kerrey declared in an impassioned speech on the Senate floor. ``He has chosen to divide his country on an issue that, frankly, in my opinion, should not be given this much attention,'' Kerrey later told a rally of congressional veterans against the amendment. Sen. John C. Danforth, R-Mo., parting company with conservative colleagues, took the Senate floor to oppose the amendment. ``We, thank God, do not live in a brittle, fragile country, because in our country anybody is free to express himself,'' Danforth said. The debate over the flag resounded in incidents across America. Townspeople of Northfield, Minn., awoke to find 3,000 small plastic flags planted in their lawns by employees of a real estate company ``as an important part of our heritage.'' But one local critic grumbled that it was `an intrusive political statement.'' Elsewhere: _Retired Cincinnati librarian Paul Payne, 81, vowed to burn a flag to protest a U.S. policy of ``bullying little nations, supporting murder and massacre.'' But he changed his mind and the scene in Fountain Square turned into a celebration as a radio station gave away small American flags. _Vermont State Archivist Gregory Sanford in Montpelier declared himself ``enflamed by the controversy over flag burning'' and said the government should require flag makers to use fireproof cloth. _Pittsburgh Boy Scouts marched, sang and recited the Pledge of Allegiance as a flag featuring a star cut out by each of the nation's governors was hoisted in a downtown plaza. _Bloomfield, N.J., flag maker Ann Oliver complained about the Supreme Court's decision Monday. ``I understand the legal point, but after 22 years of making the flag, you don't like to see it burned,'' she said. _Harvard law Professor Alan Dershowitz told a Philadelphia Bar Association luncheon that diluting guarantees of free speech would be a mistake: ``I don't believe the constitution should be amended during a time of frenzy.'' _In Omaha, 350 people wearing red, white and blue shirts formed a human version of the American flag. Radio station WOW AM-FM sponsored the early morning flag fest at which American Legion members fired a 21-gun salute. Dole, the Senate Republican leader, won a commitment from Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, to hold a Senate vote on the flag amendment before Congress' Fourth of July recess. In the House, Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., has said a vote could come as early as next week and certainly before the holiday break. The issue was rekindled Monday when the Supreme Court in a 5-4 decision threw out as unconstitutional a federal law approved last year that would have banned burning and other desecration of the American flag. Dole scoffed at the notion that flag burning represents free speech and thus should not be outlawed. ``It's malicious, stupid, irresponsible conduct, not speech,'' Dole said. On the other hand, Sen. Terry Sanford, D-N.C., scorned statements that a flag-burning ban would put only a small limit on free speech. ``That's like saying I'm going to take a little tiny sliver out of your heart,'' Sanfashington-based Paralyzed Veterans of America. Elsewhere, former Solicitor General Erwin N. Griswold joined American Bar Association leaders in denouncing the flag-burning amendment as a dangerous attack on the Bill of Rights. By proposing the amendment Bush ``responded too quickly and too readily to some of his political adisers who saw during the last election campaign what a potent vote getter wrapping yourself in the flag was,'' said Griswold, a former Harvard Law School dean who served Presidents Johnson and Nixon.

DOC.SECOND: AM-Stocks Around the Clock, 1st Ld-Writethru, a0667,0773
DOC.HEAD: Stock Market of the Future: ``We Never Close''?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with official announcement of proposal; picks up 6th graf pvs, `The presumably ...' Also moved on financial wires.
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: With a proposal this week, the New York Stock Exchange has laid plans it hopes will lead to round-the-clock stock trading. Financial observers caution that 24-hour trading, an idea that has been under discussion and study for the past two decades or more, is likely to develop only slowly and in stages. In any event, they say, the image of mad midnight scrambles to buy IBM or sell AT&T remains a distant prospect rather than an impending reality. The NYSE, which now operates from 9:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. Eastern time Monday through Friday, has come up with plans to begin experimenting with after-hours trading later this year. Chairman John J. Phelan Jr. said Thursday the plan could lead to round-the-clock trading by the year 2000. In its early stages, the proposal provides for ``auctions'' to handle orders in individual stocks in batches at 8 p.m., midnight and 5 a.m., starting sometime in 1991. This presumably would provide individual investors with a chance to act more quickly on news that breaks or decisions they make when the market now is closed. But analysts agree that is not the primary driving force behind the plan. Rather, they say, the NYSE is trying to keep or regain business involving large institutional customers that is drifting away to competitors, notably markets in Europe and Japan. Secondly, they add, the proposal is a response to pressure from technological advances that have made international trading by computer and advanced communications systems increasingly attractive and economical. ``This is an awareness by the management of the NYSE that electronic trading will be more and more important as we move through the 1990s,'' said Perrin Long, a securities industry analyst at the firm of Lipper Analytical Services. Wall Street has been moving, however slowly, in the direction of 24-hour stock trading for a long time. In 1974, the NYSE and other, smaller markets based in the eastern United States extended the close of business from 3:30 p.m. to 4 p.m. Then in 1985, the opening was advanced from 10 a.m. to 9:30 a.m., in a direct response to growth of European trading in U.S. stocks. Also, observers point out, as finance has become an increasingly global business, markets for foreign currency exchange and bonds already have gone to what amounts to around-the-clock global trading. Why not just adopt a we-never-close policy for the stock market as well, and be done with the question? Many members of the stock exchange's various constituencies long have had reasons for resisting the idea. Brokers who deal with the public, for example, have been reluctant to take on the extra operating expense without better assurance that there will sufficient demand for their services during the off-hours. At the same time, automation of trades is seen as a threat to the brokers, called specialists, who operate on stock exchange trading floors as a kind of meeting point for buy and sell orders. If their function could somehow be filled at night by ``black boxes,'' the reasoning goes, it probably wouldn't be long before the same machines were taking over in the daytime as well. For their part, specialists maintain that they serve their function better than computers could any time. The prospect of after-hours trading also raises other questions: How would the transactions be reported in the news media, and how would they be accounted for in the market averages and indexes? If stocks can trade at midnight, what about options and futures contracts on stocks and stock indexes? If there no were no official ``closing'' price each day, what substitute standard might be used for such legal purposes as the valuing of gifts and estates? Some of these questions might yield easy answers, and others prove more stubborn. But in the eyes of a good many observers, even the most difficult seem likely only to delay, not to prevent, the movement toward an around-the-clock, around-the-world stock market. ``We are on the road to 24-hour trading,'' said Harrison Roth, a specialist in stock options trading at the New York firm of Cowen & Co. ``There's no doubt about it.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Chet Currier has covered Wall Street for The Associated Press since 1974.

DOC.HEAD: Journalists Clubbed, Newspaper Occupied as Miners Aid Iliescu
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with report party leader beaten up, Romanians asking asylum in France, some miners leave in trucks. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos XBUC1,2,4,7
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of miners called to the capital by President-elect Ion Iliescu to help put down anti-government protests on Thursday clubbed passers-by and journalists and occupied the offices of the main opposition newspaper. Few police and soldiers were visible late Thursday in Bucharest. The miners, armed with cudgels, their faces and work clothes still smudged with coal dust, were apparently left to maintain order in this city of 2.2 million residents as they saw fit. In reaction to the disorder in this capital and violence that left at least five people dead and 350 injured, the state news agency Rompress said the newly elected Parliament, which had been scheduled to meet on Thursday, had delayed its session until Monday. Miners streamed into Bucharest from as far away as 240 miles after two days of unrest in which security forces clashed with demonstrators who claim the governing National Salvation Front of Iliescu is dominated by Communists associated with the ousted regime of dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, were executed Dec. 25, three days after an uprising began when 94 protesters were killed by government forces in the western city of Timisoara. The government says a total of 1,038 civilians and soldiers died in the pro-democratic revolution. The latest casualties occurred when police cleared a 2-month-old demonstration from a central square Wednesday, then fired on protesters who attacked government buildings and overturned cars, setting them ablaze. It was the worst violence in Romania since the uprising paved the way for free elections last month that were won by Iliescu, the interim President, and his National Salvation Front. In Washington, President Bush's office condemned ``in the strongest possible terms'' what it called ``government-inspired vigilante violence.'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said the violence ``departs from the commonly accepted norms of democracy and the rule of law.'' Iliescu late Wednesday called in a televised speech for all ``democraticforces'' to come to the aid of his embattled government. Iliescu shortened the miners' workweek and raised their pay after the revolt, and in return the miners have been staunch supporters of his National Salvation Front. Early Thursday, soldiers fired at demonstrators who threw firebombs at police headquarters and sporadic gunfire echoed across Bucharest. Then the miners arrived, carrying clubs, rubber hoses and other crude weapons. Dozens of people were assaulted, others butted repeatedly by the helmeted miners, estimated to number in the tens of thousands. As a Western radio reporter was pulled away from a group of grim-faced miners in central University Square, a heavy-set woman egged the miners on, urging them to kill the reporter's colleagues. In another development, the government Thursday announced the resignation of Gen. Mihai Chitac as interior minister. No official reason was given, but Chitac had already been under fire for allegedly helping to put down anti-Communist protests in December. Because his ministry is responsible for the police, his replacement also was thought to be linked to the police attack on the demonstrators Wednesday. Less than a mile from the square, about 10 miners besieged the residence of Iliescu critic Dimitru Mazilu for several hours before dispersing, said Mazilu and a neighbor. The former vice president of the post-revolutionary government stepped down following charges that he collabrated with the Securitate, the secret police force that killed hundreds during the revolution. The miners were apparently directed by several men who Mazilu said were ``Securitate or former Securitate'' agents. Mazilu told reporters who arrived at his apartment that the agents urged the miners to kill him. Mazilu said the miners left after he called government officials. In London, the son of Romanian National Peasant Party leader Ion Ratiu told The Associated Press his father had been beaten and taken from his house in Bucharest by miners. Nicolae Ratiu, who lives in London, said his cousin told him by telephone from Bucharest that he saw the miners pummel Ion Ratiu and three other people and drag them from the house. Men who claimed to be police were operating with the miners, he said. In Lyon, France, authorities said Thursday that 23 Romanian tourists fearing a new dictatorship in their country have asked France for political asylum. The miners in Bucharest also occupied opposition party headquarters. Other government suporters ransacked the headquarters of the opposition Liberal Party, as well as Bucharest University's Faculty of Foreign Languages. Miners milled around University Square at nightfall Thursday, demanding identity papers from foreign journalists and those they suspected of being anti-government symphathizers. There was no indication when the miners would return to western Romania. Some were seen leaving early Friday in trucks, but their destination was unknown. Rompress quoted an unidentified miner as saying, ``The hoolingans stayed for a couple of weeks. But we will stay until we are sure that we reinstate order in the Romanian capital.'' Rompres quoted a miners' communique demanding the closure of Romania Libera, the main newspaper critical of Iliescu and his government. Romania Libera said later its editorial offices were occupied by people who claimed they were print workers, a staff member was roughed up, and executive offices were ransacked, according to Rompres. A group of miners took control of the corridor outside the editorial board's offices, disrupting work, and the board appealed to the government in the name of freedom of the press for help, Rompres said. During the violence Thursday, people in military trucks handed the government supporters milk and bread. Unidentified people in a van carrying loudspeakers warned passers-by: ``Don't incite the miners ... you would thus give birth to fierce violence.'' The speakers also instructed the miners to grab journalists and take them into the van. ``We will take care of them,'' the speakers said. Ovidiu Bogdan, 28, a photographer for the Gamma photo agency, said he was attacked by men armed with iron-ended clubs in central Bucharest. An AP reporter was clubbed before being rescued by an acquaintance in the army. Iliescu is the first ex-Communist to win a popular presidential election in Eastern Europe. He and the National Salvation Front won May 20 elections by a landslide.

DOC.HEAD: Police Kill Mastermind of Drug Cartel's Terror Campaign in Shootout
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 8 `A national' to explain what RCN is. Picks up 9th, `He served...'
DOC.TEXT: Police delivered another blow to the powerful Medellin cocaine cartel by killing the man who masterminded a 10-month-old terror campaign that has killed hundreds of people, police said Thursday. Hours after police killed the drug chieftain during a shootout Wednesday night in an exclusive Medellin suburb, a car bomb exploded near a police station in the same area Thursday. The blast killed four people, including two suspected terrorists inside the car, and injured 43, a police spokeswoman said on condition of anonymity. The bomb may have been in retaliation for the police killing of Juan Jairo Arias, who officials said led the Medellin cocaine cartel's vast network of hired killers. Members of Colombia's Elite Police Corps, a group specially trained to fight drug traffickers, were tipped off on Arias's whereabouts and tried to arrest him at a Medellin apartment, the spokeswoman said. Arias resisted arrest and police shot and killed him, said the spokeswoman, who commented on condition of anonymity in line with government practice. A woman and a 6-month-old baby were also in the apartment but no one else was harmed in the shooting, the spokeswoman said. A national police director, Gen. Octavio Vargas, told the national radio network RCN that Arias's killing represented the government's second most important victory in its war on drugs. ``He served as chief of the armed organization of the Medellin cartel,'' Vargas said. The most important victory came in December when the Elite Corps killed Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, the Medellin cartel's No. 2 boss. Vargas said Arias, 28, was the Medellin cartel's fifth most important leader. The police director blamed him for the murders of an attorney general, a state governor, a judge and a leading journalist. Vargas said Arias was responsible for two car bomb attacks against Colombia's secret police chief, Gen. Miguel Maza Marquez. Those blasts killed at least 70 people, but Maza was not harmed. The Medellin cartel's campaign to murder police officers continued Wednesday, when four more lawmen were slain. The cartel said in a statement Tuesday it was killing policemen to avenge the ``tortures and murders'' by police of its associates in Medellin. In April, drug traffickers offered to pay $4,300 to anyone willing to kill a policeman. So far this year, 110 law officers have been assassinated in Medellin, police say. The police spokeswoman said authorities relied on the ``support and cooperation'' of Medellin residents to locate Arias. Police have offered to pay $200,000 for information leading to the capture of cartel leaders. Officials blame drug traffickers for killing around 400 people since last August, when the government of President Virgilio Barco began its most sweeping anti-drug crackdown. The cartel's reputed leader, Pablo Escobar, remains at large despite a massive manhunt to find him. The drug war began in August, when traffickers were blamed for the assassination of leading presidential hopeful Luis Carlos Galan. Two more presidential candidates were assassinated before last month's election, and traffickers were linked to at least one of those. Since August, Barco's administration has extradited 15 drug suspects and confiscated hundreds of properties belonging to the cocaine magnates. Medellin, Colombia's second largest city, has about 3 million residents. At one time, the Medellin cartel was believed responsible for most of the cocaine that is smuggled into the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Confirm Accident at Leningrad Nuclear Plant in 1975
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union confirmed Thursday that a major accident occurred at a nuclear power plant in Leningrad in 1975, Finnish officials said. The officials said the nuclear reactors in the Leningrad plant were similar to those at Chernobyl and that the accident was ``possibly of grade 3 _ in other words, a serious accident.'' Radioactivity spread over parts of northern Europe in April 1986 after the reactor exploded at the Chernobyl nuclear plant in the Soviet republic of Ukraine. At least 31 people were killed as a direct result of that nuclear accident, the worst in history. However, the Finnish Center for Radiation and Nuclear Safety said no radiation from the 1975 accident was detected in Finland, 60 miles at the nearest point from the plant. It made no mention of any casualties. The center said the accident occurred when ``the fuel channel of the number one reactor unit at the Leningrad nuclear plant was damaged on Nov. 30, 1975, when it was started up, and short-term radioactive substances were released into the atmosphere.'' The recorded message said the information came from Soviet nuclear officials after inquiries Thursday by the Finnish center. The message said, according to Soviet authorities, the release of radioactivity was far less than the 1.5 million curies reported in earlier press accounts. The Soviets have said 50 million curies of radiation were released in the Chernobyl accident. ``Officials saw no reason to take special measures in the immediate vicinity of the power plant, and the reactor was back in use two weeks after the incident,'' the message added.

DOC.HEAD: Convention Business Collapses As ``Messengers'' Vanish
DOC.TEXT: Proceedings collapsed Thursday on the final day of the Southern Baptist Convention because most of the delegates had abandoned the scene, with the big battle for the presidency over. Discussion of major moral and social issues _ including a severe condemnation of homosexuals _ had to be scrapped for lack of a quorum, with most of the circular tiers of seats empty in the vast Louisiana Superdome. ``Once the row over election of a president was over, that was it,'' said the Rev. Felix T. Zeigler of Venice, Fla. ``The crowd couldn't be bothered. ``But there are other issues that are more important to Christian faith than the personality of one man.'' Longtime observers said it was the first time in memory that convention decisions had to be dropped because people didn't show up. The main draw was Tuesday's election of the Rev. Morris Chapman, a fundamentalist from Wichita Falls, Texas, as president of the 14.9 million-member denomination. He defeated the moderate candidate, the Rev. Daniel Vestal of the Atlanta suburb of Dunwoody, by a 58 percent to 42 percent margin. Registered attendance at the convention had totalled 38,478, the third largest in the history of the nation's largest Protestant denomination. But under the rules, a quarter of them were needed to conduct business. From 4,000 to 5,000 people were estimated on hand for the morning session Thursday, and the number dwindled as the day went on. The Rev. Mark Corts of Winston-Salem, N.C., chairman of a resolutions committee, apologized from the podium for the impossibility of taking up 11 pending proposals, some keenly controversial. ``We worked through some significant issues and wanted your opinion expressed,'' he said, adding that the untended proposals were left for ``your encouragement and predilection.'' The resolutions included one to oppose ``all efforts to gain civil rights protection for homosexuals on the basis of sexual preference.'' The resolution called homoseuxality a ``morally unconscionable learned behavior and lifesytle, not deserving of government support and special civil rights protection as a minority.'' Other proposals condemned government funding of ``offensive, morally repugnant and sacrilegious'' art; called for changes in tax laws to encourage mothers to stay home with their children; and called for restrictions on broadcast advertising of alcholic beverages. With decision-making on those issues gone by the wayside, the remaining delegates listened to reports from commissions, seminaries, boards and committees, interspersed with music, hymn-singing and preaching. For 12 years running, fundamentalists have won the presidency, whose appointive power determines the administration of the denomination's huge network of agencies and institutions. Chapman said he would insist on adherence to specified standards of belief, elaborated from a literalistic view of the Bible. The campaign watchword of fundamentalists has been that the Bible is ``inerrant,'' without error historically, scientifically and in other fields, that creation, Adam, Eve and biblical miracles happened as as recounted. Screening has been inaugurated for personnel in several agencies to assure conformity with those points, and some seminary professors and others have come under fire for their views.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS item on Snook to restore Long's first name, Chuck. An AMs separate on Severud moved as a0668, on Rybar as a0424, on O'Neill as a0725, and on Freehof as a0423.
DOC.TEXT: Fred Severud, a structural design engineer whose high-profile projects included St. Louis' Gateway Arch and Madison Square Garden in New York, died Monday at age 91. Severud founded his own firm in 1928 in New York City. He worked on plans for the Gateway Arch, completed in 1965. During the 1960s, he also worked on the design of Madison Square Garden. He was structural engineer of the Guggenheim Bandshell, completed in 1969 at New York's Lincoln Center, and for Toronto City Hall, completed in 1965. Severud retired from the firm in 1973.

Terence O'Neill, a former prime minister of Northern Ireland who attempted to reconcile Protestants and Roman Catholics in the 1960s, died Tuesday at his home in Lymington, Hampshire. the government said. He was 75. O'Neill served as the province's prime minister from 1963-69. Britain suspended Northern Ireland's parliament in 1972 in the the face of growing sectarian and political violence and instituted direct rule in 1973. O'Neill was named a lord in 1970, and spoke frequently in Britain's House of Lords on Northern Ireland.

Valerian S. Rybar, known as the world's most expensive interior designer, died Saturday of prostate cancer at age 71. Rybar began his career as a trainee at the Lord & Taylor department store in New York. Soon after he quit, he designed a headdress for an opera singer. Cosmetics company founder Elizabeth Arden saw it and hired him. He stayed at Arden for three years, then began working on party designs and soon was hired by some of his clients to help them with their homes. Rybar's clients included Nicholas and Genvieve DuPont, Samuel and Mitzi Newhouse, Pierre and Sao Schlumberger, Christina Onassis and Stavros Niarchos. Jean-Francois Daigre joined Rybar in 1968. Their company had offices in New York and Paris.

Solomon B. Freehof, a rabbi who was considered one of the world's foremost Reform Jewish leaders, died Tuesday at age 97. Freehof's first congregation was at the Kehillath Anshe Mayriv Temple in Chicago, which he left in 1934 to come to Pittsburgh. He served as rabbi at the Rodef Shalom Temple in the city's Shadyside neighborhood until his retirement in 1966. He was elected president of the World Union for Progressive Judaism in 1959. He was the first American accorded that honor, which was seen as an acknowledgment of his stature in Reform Judaism. He also was president of the Central Conference of American Rabbis and as a member of the executive board of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations. He was honored in 1979 by the National Conference of Christians and Jews.

Gary Snook, who set University of Iowa football passing records that stood for 20 years, died Sunday with throat cancer at age 46. Snook played at Iowa from 1963-65, earning first-team all-Big Ten Conference honors in 1964. He passed for 2,062 yards in 1964 and threw for 3,738 yards in his career. Those figures stood as school records until Chuck Long broke them in the mid-1980s. Before Snook's death, friends and former teammates were raising money to help pay his medical bills, which had exceeded the $1 million limit on his health insurance coverage.

Maud Van Cortlandt Oakes, a well known author and self-taught anthropologist who studied Navajo and Guatemalan Indians, died Sunday after a long illness at age 87. Miss Oakes had embarked on a promising career as a painter when very young, but she gave up that work to study Navajo Indians at Coolidge, N.M., for six years as a member of the Gollingen Foundation. Although Miss Oakes had no formal training in anthropology, she wrote ``Where the Two Came to Their Father,'' one of the first translations of Navajo myths. In 1945, she traveled to Guatemala where she lived and wrote about the Mam Indians in her book called ``The Two Crosses of Todos Santos.'' She gained the Mams' trust by treating the sick with simple remedies such as aspirin, malaria pills, salves and bandages. Her last book, ``The Stone Speaks: The Memoir of a Personal Transformation,'' was published in 1987.

James Edward Goslee III, owner of a trend-setting Manhattan flower shop, died Monday of AIDS at age 39. As owner of Goslee & Co. on the Upper East Side, Goslee designed arrangements for homes and parties. He was in charge of decorations for a White House state dinner given by President Ford in honor of Queen Elizabeth II.

Leslie V. Hall, a newspaperman for 30 years who spent 10 of them on the copy desk of The (Baltimore) Sun, died Monday of heart failure at age 50. Hall began his career after high school as a 17-year-old stringer for the Birmingham Post-Herald in Birmingham, Ala. He continued in newspaper work _ with stints in New Orleans and Charlotte, N.C., and for United Press International _ until 1987, when he retired from The Sun. He was business editor of the Charlotte Observer in the early 1970s. He is survived by a stepson, a stepdaughter, his mother, a brother and a sister.

Willis Peter Bilderback, former Naval Academy lacrosse coach whose teams won eight straight national titles, died Tuesday at age 81. The cause of death was not disclosed. Bilderback was a member of the lacrosse Hall of Fame. In 14 years as Navy's head coach, he led his teams to a 132-26-2 record. In 1959, his first year at Navy, Bilderback coached the Midshipmen to a 6-3-1 record. He went on to lead Navy to an unprecedented and still unmatched eight straight national titles. In 1960 he was named lacrosse coach of the year and led the South squad to a win in the 1962 North-South game. He coached five unbeaten teams before retiring for health reasons in 1972.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Communists Win First Round in Bulgaria, But Opposition Not Out
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with new quotes by opposition leader ruling out coalition, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A party made up of former Communists won the opening round in Bulgaria's first free elections in 58 years, results showed Thursday, and was expected to win an absolute majority in Parliament in weekend runoffs. The United States said widespread voter intimidation may have figured in last Sunday's first-round balloting. But Zhelyu Zhelev, leader of the main opposition alliance, hailed the showing his people made in so short a time. Zhelev late Thursday ruled out any coalition with the governing Socialist Party, though the Socialists said again they were reluctant to go it alone. The Communist Party changed its name to the Socialist Party in April. The opposition has only an outside chance of victory in Sunday's runoff. Bulgaria is the only country in the Soviet Union's disintegrating East bloc where former ruling Communists remain the strongest political force. Final results announced Thursday gave the Socialists 172 of the 319 seats decided in the first round. They need to win 29 of 81 seats at stake next Sunday to capture a two-thirds majority in the single-chamber, 400-seat Grand National Assembly. They already have pledges of support from two independents. Zhelev's 16-party Union of Democratic Forces won 105 seats Sunday and smaller opposition parties shared the rest. Observers said if they teamed up in the runoffs, they conceivably could keep the Socialists from controlling Parliament. Allegations surfaced of election irregularities in last Sunday's balloting. Opposition supporters, angered at the prospect of a victory by the former Communists, held protests and erected traffic blockades in Sofia. In Washington, the State Department cited reports of polling booths without curtains, transparent ballot envelopes and local officials handing out ballots. ``There are many reports of local officials threatening voters with loss of jobs, pensions or other benefits,'' spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said. She said problems that came to light ``raise serious questions about the electoral process.'' Zhelev declared at a news conference, however, ``This is a great victory for the opposition which in only six months has raised itself to become the second political force. ``It is also a great success that more than half of the voters have voted against the Communists. The results are very good,'' He said his alliance does not want to enter any coalition and favors a government of ``competent people and experts.'' Western diplomats here said this was a good possibility. Leaders of two smaller opposition parties, the Agrarian Party and the mostly ethnic-Turkish Movement for Rights and Freedoms, told separate news conferences they opposed a government alliance with just the Socialists. Socialist leader Alexander Lilov predicted ultimate victory for the Socialists after Sunday's runoff and promised faster changes after the new government takes over. But Lilov reiterated at a news conference, ``We think democracy in Bulgaria now needs all political forces'' to unite toward resolving national problems. Prime Minister Andrei Lukanov and other Socialists called earlier for a broad coalition to tackle Bulgaria's deep economic troubles, including rising unemployment, food shortages and a $10 billion foreign debt. Lilov, a veteran Communist ideologist, had been sidelined by Bulgaria's longtime, hard-line Communist leader, Todor Zhivkov. Defense Minister Dobri Dzhurov, a Socialist and the nation's most popular political leader according to opinion polls, said the party ``underwent a profound and positive change'' following November's ouster of Zhivkov. In an interview with the newspaper Duma, Dzhurov said voters endorsed the Socialists because of their new advocacy of parliamentary democracy, a socially oriented market economy and universal human values. Lukanov on Thursday held talks with Goldert Posthumus, executive director of the International Monetary Fund, on Bulgaria's request for IMF membership. The state news agency BTA said Bulgaria could be admitted in September. The new parliament is also expected to draft a revised constitution, which requires a two-thirds majority. It could take up to 18 months to bring reforms to a vote.

DOC.HEAD: Moscow City May Send Gasoline to Lithuania to Ensure Milk Supply
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with six grafs to UPDATE with report Estonia rejecting latest offer. Picks up 5th pvs, `No sign...'
DOC.TEXT: Moscow city council on Thursday talked of sending gasoline to Lithuania in violation of the Kremlin embargo because Lithuania is running out of fuel to deliver milk to the Soviet capital, a local news service reported. It was the latest sign of crumbling support for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's order to cut off all oil, most natural gas and some raw material shipments to the Baltic republic in hope of forcing it to rescind its declaration of independence. On Wednesday, the Kremlin gave the first sign it may be ready to ease the blockade because of mounting domestic opposition. Kremlin leaders offered a compromise that could lead to removal of sanctions which have idled 26,000 workers. Estonian Premier Edgar Savisaar on Thursday rejected the latest Kremlin offers of greater independence within a Soviet confederation, saying Gorbachev was still presenting the Baltic republics with an ``ultimatum'' to suspend their independence drives, Dutch media reported. Savisaar was in the Netherlands to attend a gathering of 12th-century Northern European cities known as the Hansa League. Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov was reported to have told Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene on Wednesday that 15 percent of the republic's natural gas supply would be restored soon. That would bring gas supplies to 30 percent of normal. No sign of the promised gas emerged Thursday, but the fertilizer factory Ryzhkov said would be supplied was closed in any event for a day of mourning, said Rita Dapkus, a spokeswoman for the Lithuanian parliament. Residents in all three Baltic republics held services Thursday remembering the 36,000 Lithuanians and 10,000 Estonians who were deported to Siberia and the Far North on June 14, 1941, on orders from Soviet dictator Josef Stalin. Many died in the harsh conditions there. The three republics were forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union while under army occupation in 1940. The deportations, even of infants, were allegedly due to anti-Soviet agitation. Postfactum news service said the Moscow city council, which is dominated by radical reformers, is considering sending gasoline to Lithuania in rail tank cars guarded by council members. Food is always in short supply in the Soviet Union, but with recent panic buying touched off by the government's plan to raise food prices, Moscow officials are especially concerned about keeping their current sources of dairy products. Newly elected Russian President Boris Yeltsin already has promised to send supplies to Lithuania, and presidents of several other republics reportedly told Gorbachev in a Kremlin meeting Tuesday that the embargo should be stopped. At that Tuesday meeting, Gorbachev suggested transforming the Soviet Union into a new, looser union of ``sovereign states,'' in the hope that will hold his country together. Latvia and Estonia have joined Lithuania in demanding independence, and several other republics have large organizations pushing for secession. Russia challenged Gorbachev's authority on Tuesday by declaring that its laws would take priority over national ones, and the Ukraine may follow suit. A member of Gorbachev's Presidential Council advisory board, Grigory Revenko, was reported as saying on Thursday that the proposal for a new union treaty would allow each of the 15 Soviet republics to set its own conditions for joining the union, on federative or confederative principles. In Russian, these words are used to distinguish between a U.S.-style federation of states within one country and a confederation of independent nations like the European Community. ``Let them join the Common Market if they want it, and if a republic has sufficient potential,'' Tass quoted Revenko as saying. Revenko suggested that the central government be left with minimal duties, including constitutional and human rights, defense and border protection, and part of foreign relations. ``Republics themselves, when joining the union with their treaties, will determine which rights they will delegate to the center,'' Tass quoted Revenko as saying. None of the three republics' parliaments took action Thursday on compromise offers made by Gorbachev. He told Lithuania the Kremlin will lift the embargo and open negotiations on independence if Lithuania agrees to freeze putting its declaration into effect while negotiations are going on. Latvian legislators criticized President Anatoly Gorbunov for saying he is ready to discuss freezing Latvia's May 4 declaration of independence, because he had no authorization, according to the Estonian news service ETA. Estonian President Arnold Ruutel said in a newspaper interview that Gorbachev recognized Estonia's declaration that it is in a transition period to full independence, ETA said.

DOC.HEAD: State Politicians Divide on Party Lines Over Durenberger Events
With AM-Durenberger, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: State Republicans rallied Wednesday behind U.S. Sen. Dave Durenberger, who apologized to his colleagues and constituents as the Senate Ethics Committee ended a hearing and prepared to weigh his financial conduct. Opposition politicians renewed their calls for Durenberger's resignation, saying he ducked his obligation to fully answer allegations of misdeeds. ``He did not tell anything new and apparently did not dispute the evidence,'' said Robert Vanasek, Democratic speaker of the state House. ``It leads me to conclude that the senator has decided he can tough this out. That it can go behind closed doors and that the public will forget about it.'' In an emotional, hourlong speech before the committee, Durenberger said he takes ``full responsibility'' for ethical lapses even though he never set out to break the rules. The committee ended its trial-like proceedings early as requested by Durenberger's attorney, Jim Hamilton, who said prolonging them would cost the senator too much in legal fees. Having accepted 23 volumes of evidence against Durenberger, the committee now will weigh a recommendation by its special counsel, Robert S. Bennett, that the Senate denounce the Minnesota Republican for financial improprieties. The panel's vice chairman, Sen. Warren B. Rudman, R-N.H., said the committee would have no problem making a judgment based on written documents and statements by Durenberger, his lawyer and Bennett. But Vanasek said Minnesota voters deserved to hear from witnesses in an extended trial to better understand the case. He said Durenberger's apology and defense that ``all the key decisions'' were taken with legal advice merely repeated what he has said for five months. ``He should go to the governor, indicate to him he will resign and he will run in a special election this fall,'' Vanasek said. State Democratic Party Chairman Todd Otis also called on Durenberger to resign and let voters decide whether he should return to Washington. ``If he is at peace with what he's done, that should not be a problem,'' Otis said. ``It's just an outrage that a curtain is coming down in front of them (the voters) before the play has even started.'' But Republican Bill Schreiber, state House minority leader, labeled the resignation calls ludicrous. ``I never expected Dave Durenberger to step down,'' Schreiber said. ``The Democratic spin doctors have been playing that resignation game a long time.'' U.S. Rep. Vin Weber, R-Minn., said, ``Today's statement and the decision by the special counsel to seek no greater sanction than denouncement now makes clear that Dave will weather this ordeal and return to his work in the U.S. Senate.''

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Equipment and Tiny Microbes Hauled Out To Battle Leak
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with oil-eating bacteria to be used Friday; report of pump leaking before explosion; oil transferred to undamaged tanks; survivor's report of blast; no pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto staffing; LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Crews used skimmers, booms and chemicals Thursday to battle a 30-mile-long slick from the burning supertanker Mega Borg, and officials geared up to unleash oil-eating bacteria. Officials planned to apply the bacteria Friday, the first use of microbes in water to clean up an oil spill, state officials said. Also Thursday, the Mega Borg's chief engineer told a Norwegian panel meeting in Galveston that one of the vessel's pumps had been leaking about six hours before the blast. Balinder Singh said the pump leaked as the tanker's crude oil cargo was being transferred to a smaller ship. Singh said he had stopped the leak by tightening a coupling about six hours before the Friday blast. Six days after the first of a series of explosions in the area of the engine room, a small fire continued to burn aboard the crippled Norwegian vessel, in the Gulf of Mexico 57 miles offshore. ``It looks like the fire is being contained to a very small area in the engine room,'' Coast Guard spokesman Gene Maestas said. Flames could be seen on the deck's rear section, and four fireboats showered the Mega Borg with water cannon. The rear section, shrouded in smoke, continued to be awash. Oil escaping from a hole in the vessel's 5.5 million-gallon center tank apparently was spilling at a slower rate, although Coast Guard officials had no specifics. No other leaks have been found. The 886-foot Mega Borg, which carried 38 million gallons of light African crude oil, already has lost about 3 million gallons of oil since late Friday's explosion; most of it has burned off or evaporated. About 12,000 gallons remained on the water Thursday, Coast Guard Capt. Thomas Greene said. An oil slick stretched about 12 miles northwest of the ship, with scattered patches extending another 18 miles. Its width varied. The Coast Guard offered no specific figure Thursday. The previous day, it said the width stretched to 10 miles in spots. A plane spread up to 2,000 gallons of dispersant on sections near theship Thursday, and at least a dozen skimmers and several booms sucked oil off the water's surface. Five booms were working in the ship's vicinity. Salvage crews planned to begin transferring oil from the No. 4 cargo tank, where the leak occurred, to the No. 5 cargo tank, which is empty, Greene said. The effort should stop the spill, cut off the fuel feeding the fire, and help correct the listing of the ship. State officials said the experimental microbe process, called bioremediation, would be used as a demonstration and would not be a major part of the cleanup. Bioremediation has been used for years to clean up hazardous waste sites, treat sewage and wastewater, extract oil from tight geologic formations and clean some rocks on shore after the Exxon Valdez accident in Alaska last year, said Texas Land Commissioner Garry Mauro. But this will be the first time bioremediation has been used in the water to clean up an oil spill, he said. The dispersant works by breaking up the oil, creating a light sheen and tar balls _ a rather common sight on Texas beaches. ``Tar balls are ugly but they're not that environmentally damaging,'' said B.J. ``Buck'' Wynne III, chairman of the Texas Water Commission. Coast Guard officials said the slick was about 30 miles from Galveston, but they declined to give any predictions about where the oil might reach the shore, if it does. Sharon Christopherson of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said some of the tar balls could hit the Texas shoreline as early as Friday. Also Thursday, a pumpman testified that he was opening a valve when the blast ripped through the pump and engine room area last Friday. Putham Mahamood, whose left leg was injured in the blast, spoke with inspectors by telephone from his hospital bed. About three minutes before the explosion, Chief Officer Tojo Sagar told Mahamood to open a valve for a crude oil washing, Mahamood said. He did not elaborate on the procedure. As he was trying to open the valve, the explosion occurred, Mahamood said. Sagar, 27, of India, died in the explosion. Mosvold Rederi of Farsund, Norway, owners of the Mega Borg, already have spent $2 million for firefighting, salvage and pollution control efforts, said Robert L. Klawetter, attorney for firm. Two of the 41 crew members died in the blast, two were missing and presumed dead and 17 were injured, none seriously. Klawetter identified the other seaman killed in the blast as Seaman Bernardo T. Cortez, 41, of the Philippines. The missing men, who are presumed dead, were 4th Engineer Wilfredo S. Gulfan, 36, of the Philippines and wiper Vincent M. Pastor, 37, of the Philippines.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Says Override Rule Within Resolution Thrift Corp.'s Authority ^With AM-Vernon Indictment, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A judge Thursday upheld a federal agency's authority to override state branch-banking laws as it sells off failed savings and loans, the first such decision in the nation. The decision by U.S. District Judge Santiago Campos regarding the Resolution Trust Corp.'s authority could have far-reaching effects. The agency controls 248 failed thrifts in 21 states where branching laws for banks that could buy defunct savings and loans are more restrictive than those for thrifts. Campos dismissed a challenge to the regulation by the Independent Community Bankers of New Mexico and the state Financial Institutions Division. The ruling means the sale of the defunct New Mexico Federal Savings and Loan to the First National Bank of Albuquerque can proceed, unless the 10th Circuit Court of Appeals in Denver blocks the transaction on appeal. Officials for the bankers group and the state agency did not say whether they would appeal. The override rule, which took effect June 1, would effectively let First National operate branches in counties outside Bernalillo County, even though inter-county branch banking is prohibited by state law. ``The override is well within (the RTC's) authority,'' Campos said after a half-day hearing. New Mexico law prohibits banks from operating branches outside the bank's headquarters county. But savings and loans may establish branches anywhere. New Mexico Federal has branches in Santa Fe, Espanola and Taos. The Resolution Trust Corp. was set up under the savings-and-loan bailout law to dispose of failed thrifts under federal conservatorship. Campos' ruling is contrary to a judicial decision earlier this year in a similar federal case in Colorado. Bankers and state regulators also have challenged the override rule in Arkansas, said Michael Tucci, senior counsel for the agency. John Bernstein, an attorney for the Resolution Trust Corp., told Campos that the agency was set up to salvage assets and bring private money into the bailout program while minimizing taxpayers' losses. In the Colorado case, splitting the thrift's branches cut the premium bidders paid for the thrift from $675,000 to $75,000, which will cost the taxpayers, said Bernstein. The cost of the nationwide bailout was pegged at $50 billion last year but the Bush administration now estimates the cost at $89 billion to $132 billion. ``The purpose of the override is simply to do what Congress has told the RTC to do,'' said Bernstein. ``To allow the state to come in and restrict these kinds of transactions totally defeats the mandate and authority granted by Congress to the RTC.'' Bernstein said the override rule was designed to head off the chaos that would occur if the agency could not sell an entire network. Dividing branches would mean dividing centralized data processing and other common assets, which would be cumbersome and would lower their value, he said. And if the pending sale falls through, another arrangement may be less satisfactory for New Mexico Federal's 21,000 account-holders, he said. The bankers and the state argued that Congress never intended for banks to violate state branching laws. ``If we lose today, we will have in New Mexico basically an unsupervised dual banking system,'' argued state Assistant Attorney General G.T.S. Khalsa, representing the state regulatory agency. Leonard Rubin, a Washington-based lawyer for the independent bankers, said the override rule violates the federal McFadden Act, which requires national banks to conform to state laws limiting branching. Rubin said the law creating the RTC specifically excludes banks from the section governing the purchase of a failed thrift's branches. ``Congress knew how to override the federal law if it wanted to,'' said Rubin. He told Campos the RTC prefers selling entire thrifts, including branches, with one transaction because they can get rich banks and thrifts to pay a premium for a network of financial institutions. ``They're selling, for a premium, a license to violate state banking laws,'' said Rubin.

DOC.HEAD: Judiciary Panel OKs Balanced-Budget Provision
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 7 grafs with Senate procedural vote on budget; adds byline.
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Judiciary Committee on Thursday endorsed a constitutional amendment to require a balanced federal budget. The amendment was sent to the full Senate by a vote of 11-3. If approved by two-thirds of the Senate and the House, and then by 38 states, the amendment would prohibit federal spending from exceeding revenues except in time of war or if both chambers waive the requirement by a 60 percent vote. It would also require that a majority of each chamber of Congress, instead of just a majority of those present and voting, approve any tax increase. The amendment would take effect in the second fiscal year after ratification. Balanced-budget amendments have been approved before by the committee. The provision most recently was subjected to a full Senate vote in 1986 and failed by one vote. It passed the Senate in 1982 but died in the House. Thursday's action came as House, Senate and White House negotiators continued their budget ``summit'' in the Capitol, aimed at reducing the federal deficit. Democrats and Republicans have been unable to agree on how to bring the fiscal gap below $100 billion, never mind zero. They met for less than two hours and participants said they discussed a variety of budget process reforms without reaching any agreements. The talks are scheduled to resume next Tuesday. Because Congress' normal budget process has been sidetracked during the lengthy negotiations, the Senate approved a resolution Thursday night to keep a legislative backlog from building. By voice vote, the Senate approved the technical equivalent of a budget for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1.
