DOC.HEAD: Small-Scale Farmers Might Profit From Proper Use of Flower Power
DOC.TEXT: Raising specialty flowers could mean the sweet scent of success for small farmers who study markets and learn the tricks of the trade. It can be downright tasty, too. ``Dried or fresh, certain specialty flowers can stimulate not only the eyes but also the sense of taste or smell, empowering new marketing enterprises for small-scale enterprisers,'' says a new report by the Agriculture Department. The overall business of growing flowers and other floriculture crops is nothing to sneeze at. Last year's wholesale value was about $2.43 billion, up 6 percent from 1988. By comparison, corn was the most valuable crop at more than $17 billion. But floriculture, as a group, exceeded the 1989 estimated value of many notable commodities, including sorghum, $1.28 billion; oats, $557.5 million; durum wheat, $319 million; rice, $1.1 billion; and sugar beets, $2.39 billion. Specialty flowers represent a portion of the total floriculture industry, rather like lambs or pigs being part of livestock production. The possibilities of growing and selling specialty flowers are examined in a new one-sheet report, part of a series by the department's Office for Small-Scale Agriculture. Previous topics have included tree farming, sheep, goats, mushrooms, foliage plants, herbs, wildflowers, specialty vegetables and ``exotic'' livestock such as ostriches, llamas, alpacas, water buffalo and European fallow deer. And now specialty flowers. ``Such flowers can be marketed fresh, dried, sugarcoated, in bulk, as singles, or by the pound, ounce, or sometimes gram,'' the report said. ``This exciting market, although subject to whims of designers, chefs or fashion, continues to grow to meet demands.'' Growers meet specific needs, including rare cut flowers, edible flowers for garnishes or salads, potpourri mixes, and medicinal plants. But as in any specialty, flowers must meet consumer expectations reflected in production, packaging and presentation, the report said. Small-scale entrepreneurs also should become acquainted with members of local chefs' associations or state restaurant groups. The report urged would-be specialty growers to read trade journals and other publications to learn more about techniques and demands. Stan and Susan Devoto of Sebastopol, Calif., learned at a local farmers' market how edible flowers could be a marketing aid for produce, they told The Furrow magazine. ``You need something different to get noticed,'' Susan said. Gourmet chefs and discerning grocery shoppers are seeing a wide range of old favorites these days, including calendula, chrysanthemum, dianthus, dandelion, geranium, hibiscus, lily, nasturtium, pansy, rose and blue violets. ``Others include certain herb flowers like mint, sage, basil and bergamot, and even vegetable flowers such as pumpkin, okra and squash,'' the USDA report said. Farmer David Aydelotte of Salisbury, Md., said chefs using his field-grown mint flowers and herb flowers are always looking for new garnishes. ``Many chefs are looking for a social event, a story that goes with the food,'' he said. Another example cited by USDA is the Victorian technique of candying flowers used by Jo and Rob Pendergraph of Midlothian, Va., and reported in the Delmarva Farmer newspaper. In this technique, each flower petal is painted with egg white and sprinkled with granulated sugar. After the sugar has crystalized, the flowers are stored in airtight containers. The Pendergraphs said the candied flowers sell for $45 per 100 at a major New York City department store. Competition is even fiercer in the dried-flower market, the USDA report said. A number of references and guides were listed, along with their costs and addresses for ordering copies. The report was prepared by Thomas S. Handwerker of the University of Maryland-Eastern Shore, and George B. Holcomb of the department's Office of Public Affairs. For free single copies, write to: Howard W. Kerr Jr., Program Director, Office for Small-Scale Agriculture, Cooperative State Research Service, Room 342-D, Aerospace Building, USDA, Washington, D.C. 20250-2200; or telephone 202-447-3640.

DOC.HEAD: Pristine Columbia Now Laced with Dioxins
DOC.TEXT: The Columbia River drains a Texas-sized corner of northwestern North America, its historically pristine waters rushing to the Pacific Ocean. Seemingly spared the industrial pollution threatening other great rivers, the Columbia is the heart of a vast and fertile land. Majestic bald eagles nest along its lower reaches. Salmon fight their way upstream in an annual ritual of renewal. But all may not be well on the river. Environmentalists, armed with federal studies, say a nearly imperceptible adversary threatens to drain the life out of the Columbia. The 1989 studies by the Environmental Protection Agency show six pulp and paper mills on the Columbia in Oregon and Washington dump dioxins and related toxic compounds into the river, where they are accumulating in fish in unprecedented amounts. An EPA official concluded the pollution poses a significant threat to human health and the environment. The EPA sampled bottom fish in the Columbia. Unlike migratory salmon, bottom feeders, such as carp and sturgeon, spend their lives in the river. Dioxins, the chemical that caused the evacuation of Love Canal, cause cancer in laboratory animals, and some scientists are questioning studies that so far have found no cancer link in humans. The compounds also persist in soil for years. Dioxins and other chlorinated organic compounds are byproducts of bleaching wood pulp to make white paper. While many industrial processes produce dioxins, environmentalists say the pulp mills are the greatest offenders on the river. Based on EPA guidelines, the Oregon Department of Environmental Quality and the Washington Department of Ecology are considering limits on discharges of the most toxic of the dioxins, 2,3,7,8-TCDD of 0.013 parts per quadrillion in water just downstream from the mills. A concentration that low cannot be measured using current technology, so the states would use a mathematical formula to calculate whether the mills are in compliance. The limits on dioxin discharges are written into permits for the mills, but final action is being delayed by appeals in Oregon, where new permits have been issued. Washington's Department of Ecology is in the final stages of preparing new permits. The regional pulp and paper industry says meeting the new standards would be too expensive, $815 million over three years for all the mills in the region. And it says its own study shows dioxin levels that are undetectable or well within U.S. Food and Drug Administration limits. Its conclusion: River fish are safe to eat. All this is enough to rile people like Mary O'Brien, staff scientist of the Northwest Coalition for Alternatives to Pesticides in Eugene. ``This is the most toxic compound known to humans,'' she said. ``And if we can't tell the industry `no' to dumping the most toxic compound known to humans into the river for some superfluous purpose like whiteness of paper, what are we willing to regulate in the world?'' O'Brien's group, along with Columbia River United, want dioxin discharges eliminated. ``Stop talking to me about how much dioxin is acceptable,'' O'Brien said, ``and start talking to me about how to get rid of it all.'' Publicly, one of Oregon's top public health officials, Dr. Laurence Foster, has agreed there is no reason to advise most people to eat less fish. But privately, in a March 16 letter to Llewellyn Matthews, executive director of the Northwest Pulp and Paper Association, Foster tore into the industry's study. After several months of review, he said, the Oregon Health Division found the study did not support the conclusion that Columbia River fish are safe. ``It would seem the good citizen's responsibility to do everything possible to prevent future generations from being exposed to ever-increasing body burdens of this toxic chemical,'' said Foster, acting health officer and deputy administrator of the Oregon Health Division. ``I encourage you, for the sake of future Oregonians, to do everything possible to stop all discharge of dioxin into the environment.'' In an interview, Foster said he had no comment beyond the letter, made public by John Bonine of the Western Natural Resources Law Clinic at the University of Oregon. Foster added he did not mean to question the good intentions of the industry, only the science upon which the conclusion that the fish are safe to eat was based. The state eventually plans its own study of the fish. Industry spokesmen say they are reducing dioxin discharges. But they argue it is unfair to set standards at undetectable levels. ``We're going to undertake every reasonable effort to reduce,'' Matthews said. ``We're shooting for 80 percent.'' She said environmentalists blow the danger out of proportion. ``Dioxin is overrated as a carcinogen,'' Matthews said. Alternatives exist to the chlorine bleaching process that produces dioxins. One mill, the James River mill in Camas, has produced dioxin-free paper as an experiment. However, industry officials say consumers want the bright white paper produced by chlorine bleaching. They are reluctant to make the expensive transition to alternatives as long as there are doubts about whether consumers will buy the new products. But that's not good enough for O'Brien. ``These animals just die out silently,'' she said. ``No one comes around and says, `Hey, I'm dying.' ''

DOC.HEAD: Mr. Tornado Creates Violent Storms for Research
DOC.TEXT: Tetsuya Theodore Fujita saw his only natural tornado near Denver in 1982. ``It was like meeting my lover,'' he says. ``Since then, my passion really went up,'' said Fujita, a professor of geophysical science who has been studying tornadoes for 42 years and is considered one of the world's foremost authorities on the violent storms. Fujita, 69, spends much of his time in his lab at the University of Chicago creating tornadoes for research. He creates tornadoes over a large fan, which makes a swirling motion; another fan above simulates a low-pressure system by adding an updraft to the mix. With a bit of steam added to make the phenomenon visible, he gets twisters 6 to 8 feet tall. The miniature versions are as impossible to redirect or squelch as their full-sized cousins, he says. He's tried by crawling right up next to them and using rulers or books to change their direction. Fujita came to the United States from Japan in 1953, partly because there are so many tornadoes in this country. ``Tornadoes are very rare in Japan,'' Fujita said. ``They have just about 10 to 15 a year. But one occurred within about 15 miles of my hometown. I was quite impressed with the localized severity of the wind.'' When he saw his first, he and a team of scientists were studying wind shear and its effect on aircraft. ``It's a beautiful thing,'' Fujita said. ``Of course, I was 20 miles away from that one. ``If you're in it,'' he added, ``it's a terrible thing.'' Forecasters still have trouble predicting tornadoes. But Fujita has helped define the conditions most likely to spawn them. Groups of thunderstorms are not as likely to spawn tornadoes as single, large storms because multiple storms in the same area compete. ``Each one tries to rotate, but they all can't. They're just like human beings: The rich may become richer and the poor may get poorer.'' Fujita also discovered that most strong tornadoes are actually six or seven small twisters he called suction vortices, rotating around the center of a larger tornado. ``A suction vortex can pick up a car or a small house or something, but when you're standing right next to it you can be completely safe.'' He has studied tornadoes that have dropped houses into lakes, made off with one car and left another right next to it untouched, and moved whole flocks of cows and sheep _ which lived through the experience. He also developed a scale for measuring the strength of tornadoes, called the Fujita scale. It runs from zero _ a tornado that might break twigs on trees _ to five _ a twister that can rip houses from their foundations. But Fujita considers his work on other air movements called downbursts and microbursts some of his most significant. Downbursts are powerful drafts of air moving down from a thunderstorm cloud. Scientists long thought the drafts dissipated before reaching the ground. Microbursts are smaller versions of downbursts, which are more dangerous because they give pilots less time to react, Fujita said. The National Transportation Safety Board has cited microbursts, a term coined by Fujita, as the cause of 17 aircraft accidents in the past 15 years, causing 577 fatalities. Among them was the 1985 crash of a Delta L-1011 at Dallas that killed 137 people. A downburst also was implicated in the collapse of a wall at a school in Newburgh, N.Y., that killed nine children. Fujita's work helped persuade the Federal Aviation Administation to begin installing a new radar system at 47 major airports beginning in the early 1990s. The Doppler radar system was credited with helping three jetliners at Denver's airport avoid potentially catastrophic microbursts last year. Fujita retires from teaching this year, but will continue his research at the university. ``In Texas one time, five people were killed when they drove right into a tornado. They just didn't know any better,'' Fujita said. ``I want to make people safer.''

DOC.HEAD: Doghouse, Volcanic Ash Give Clues to Mysterious Mounds Creation
DOC.TEXT: A geologist who built a doghouse with some dusty plywood believes he may have discovered the obvious to explain the mysterious prairie mounds that dot the landscape. The mounds, also known as Mima or pimple mounds, are scattered across Washington, Oregon, California, Wyoming, Colorado, northern New Mexico, southeastern Oklahoma, eastern Texas, Arkansas and western Louisiana. They long have baffled scientists. Andrew Berg, a geologist for the U.S. Bureau of Mines, believes the mounds were formed by earthquakes thousands of years ago. Some other scientists did not discount his theory but said more research is needed. ``Right after the St. Helens ash-fall 10 years ago, I was working in my backyard here in Spokane on a kennel for my dog. There was a plywood board on the ground. It had a little dusting of St. Helens volcanic ash on it,'' Berg said. He laid some 2-by-4s on the board to nail a frame. ``I started hammering away and all of the sudden, I looked at the board and here were these little bumps of ash.'' It's the same principle that clumps sawdust when vibrated by a table saw. Berg, 64, wondered if the vibrations on a larger scale, such as seismic activity, might have created the hillocks. So he tried again, this time with a bread board-sized sheet of plywood and some loess, a fine-grained soil. ``I tapped it with a hammer and sure enough, vibrations caused little miniature mounds,'' Berg said. The hammer creates shock waves. Some parts of the board vibrate hard and others are still as the waves intersect. Similar wave interference during earthquakes could have created Mima mounds in areas where loose soil sits on a hard surface, such as rock, Berg said. The minimounds were not wiped out by subsequent blows of the hammer, leading Berg to believe the mounds are stable. He said his theory could help explain why the mounds, first written about 150 years ago, form in such different climates. At Mima Prairie, south of Olympia, hundreds of mounds range from 8 feet to 50 feet across and up to 6 feet high. They're not always easy to see except from the air. Some scientists have said they were built by gophers or formed by glacial action. No one really knows. ``There's probably almost as many ideas on the origin of these things as there are people who have looked at them,'' said Charles Higgins, a geology professor at the University of California-Davis. Higgins said he doesn't know if Berg is correct, but he admits the theory answers some geological questions. ``I'm inclined to think that the mounds are more the result of some kind of field stress _ desiccation cracking or frost cracking,'' he said. ``I would like to have seismologists either verify it (the theory) or set it aside. I hope it's widely discussed and kicked around,'' Berg said. Albert Lincoln Washburn, a retired geology professor at the University of Washington, said the idea needs research. ``It's intriguing, but the basic evidence remains to be forthcoming,'' Washburn said. ``I don't think it's been proved that all these mounds in different parts of the country have the same origin, by any means.''

DOC.HEAD: Fruit Desserts: Indulgences for the Health-Conscious
DOC.TEXT: One of the things that makes a healthy diet hard to stick to is the feeling that you're missing out. Try fruit. Fruit is, of course, tempting when local fruits are at their peak. Then, they are the ``first and foremost of the fast food desserts,'' say cookbook authors Sheryl and Mel London. But year-round, dressed up, fruit can be elegant and wipe out any sense of deprivation. Herbs or flowers mixed with fruit seems a new combination in American cooking, but, in fact, it's an idea that dates back centuries and is now being revived as cooks search for more local, healthful foods to replace the butter and cream and chocolate that have so often signaled dessert. Sorbets are fat-free, easy to make and can be adapted to just about any fruit. In warm weather, fruit can be grilled. The natural sugars in fruit carmelize over the coals, so all that's needed is to skewer a selection of fruits and place them on the barbecue. A yogurt-based fruit sauce makes it fancy. ``We are both addicted to a healthful diet: low in fat and relying mostly on fish and chicken for our protein needs,'' the Londons write in their new book ``Fresh Fruit Desserts: Classic and Contemporary'' (Prentice Hall Press, $24.95). While theirs is not a diet book, they kept health in mind: ``We have attempted to address our concerns about cholesterol by relying more upon spices, herbs, citrus and liqueurs to provide flavor, while being quite prudent in paring down the amounts of cream, eggs, butter and sour cream.'' To that end, they think about fruits as ``the featured players.'' The flavor is brought out, not disguised. For out-of-season or tropical fruits, shipped from far away, that might mean poaching, baking or gratineeing. In designing recipes, Mrs. London said in a telephone interview, ``We sort of did a countdown backward and eliminated.'' ``We'd look at a recipe and say, `Six eggs! Let's try it with one and egg whites.' You'd be surprised at how often it works,'' London said. A banana souffle, for example, calls for just a half-cup of milk and two egg yolks to serve four. Strawberry witches froth, served in wine glasses, needs just fruit, egg whites and a half-cup of sugar, along with flavorings, to serve eight people.
Among the Londons' desserts without guilt is the following.
DOC.HEAD: Poached Oranges with Green and Red Grapes and Grenadine Orange
DOC.TEXT: Peel

Serves 6 to 8 The oranges are peeled and sliced, poached, and then marinated with pale green and red seedless grapes. The orange peel is cut into julienne strips and steeped separately in a grenadine syrup. It's a colorful and light dessert that is assembled just before serving.
DOC.HEAD: The Oranges
DOC.TEXT: 6 large navel oranges 1 cup water { cup sugar 2 cups seedless green grapes { cup seedless red grapes 3 tablespoons Grand Marnier or other orange-flavored liqueur 2 teaspoons vanilla extract Cut off thin slices from both ends of each orange. With a vegetable parer, remove long strips of orange peel as thinly as possible and set aside. Score the oranges and peel away the thick white pith and then slice across into {-inch slices using a serrated knife. In a skillet large enough to accommodate the oranges in one layer, bring the water and the sugar to a boil. Add the sliced oranges and allow it to come to a boil again, then lower the heat and poach 3 minutes. Remove the slices with a slotted spoon and place in a glass serving dish, and add the grapes. Boil the remaining syrup in the skillet, until reduced to { cup. Remove skillet from the heat and add the liqueur and vanilla. Cool slightly and pour over the oranges and grapes. Cover with plastic wrap and chill in the refrigerator for several hours. During this period, tilt the bowl once or twice and baste with the liquid.
DOC.HEAD: Grenadine Orange Peel
DOC.TEXT: Reserved orange peel strips 1 cup cold water One-third cup grenadine syrup Cut the orange peel into very thin long strips. There should be about 1 cup. Add the cold water to a medium saucepan along with the peel and bring to a boil. Remove from heat and drain in a sieve. Repeat twice more to remove any bitterness. After the third draining, put the peel in a plastic container and pour grenadine syrup over it. Mix well, cover and refrigerate overnight. rve, remove half the orange peel with a slotted spoon and drain on paper towels before sprinkling over fruit. Save remaining peel for another time.

DOC.HEAD: Whites and Older Americans Drink More Coffee, Study Says
DOC.TEXT: Americans drink more than 24 gallons of coffee per man, woman and child annually, but according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture, whites and older people drink more than their share. ``Age and race are factors associated with consumption of coffee,'' said Sharon J. Mickle of the Human Nutrition Service at the Agriculture Department. A USDA study was based on interviews in 2,800 homes around the country from April 1987 to Aes and 35 percent of blacks interviewed said they drank coffee during the three-day survey period. ``I really was surprised by the difference,'' Ms. Mickle said. Ms. Mickle spoke recently at the Fourth Annual Conference of the Association for the Study of Food and Society at Drexel University. The convention featured nutritionists and sociologists from the United States, Europe, Mexico and India. Ms. Mickle said in 1988, the amount of coffee consumed in the nation equaled 24.3 gallons per person. Paul Rozin, a psychology professor at the University of Pennsylvania, said people who prefer black coffee may do so for its stimulating effects. He said his research indicates those who like black coffee often do not favor other coffee products such as coffee ice cream. ``You can't predict from how much someone likes black coffee whether they will like coffee yogurt,'' he said.
DOC.HEAD: Healthy Book for Cafeterias, Caterers
DOC.TEXT: The Center for Science in the Public Interest has published a cookbook to help cafeterias, restaurants and caterers prepare healthy meals. The ``Healthwise Quantity Cookbook'' includes 206 recipes for 50 portions and lists key nutrients. ``Every day, cafeterias, hospitals and other institutions serve 90 millon meals,'' said Michael Jacobson, executive director of CSPI, a non-profit nutrtional and health activist organization. ``All too many of those meals promote heartburn or heart disease, not health.'' The recipes are not fat-, sugar-, or salt-free, but call for small amounts of those ingredients. Authors Stephanie Turner and Vivienne Aronowitz are California nutritionists.
The book is available by sending $29.95, plus $3 shipping, to CSPI-Healthwise Quantity Cookbook, 1501 16th St., NW, Washington, D.C.
DOC.NOTE: End advance for June 18

DOC.TEXT: Retail sales fell again in May, posting their first consecutive three-month decline since the last recession, the government said. The Commerce Department said Wednesday that sales skidded 0.7 percent to a seasonally adjusted $146.84 billion after falling a revised 0.9 percent in April and 0.4 percent in March. Sales had not fallen for three straight months since the fall of 1981. Commerce had said originally that sales were down 0.6 percent in April and 0.2 percent a month earlier. They were unchanged in February after rising 2.8 percent the previous month.

Sales of North American-made cars and trucks slipped 13.1 percent in early June, mainly because there were fewer incentive packages than during the same period last year, automakers said. The automakers reported Wednesday that they sold vehicles at an average daily rate of 30,412 during the early-June period this year, compared with a rate of 34,994 during the same period last year. Sales of domestic cars made by General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. dropped 19.2 percent, while sales of U.S.-made cars with Japanese nameplates rose 34.8 percent.

The former owner of Vernon Savings & Loan, accused of illegally using bank funds to raise money for former House Speaker Jim Wright, was indicted on bank fraud charges in the collapse of his thrift three years ago. A 38-count indictment was handed up Wednesday by a federal grand jury accusing Don Dixon of conspiracy, misapplication of funds, making false statements and false entries, and interstate travel in aid of racketeering. Five other former officials of the defunct thrift have pleaded guilty to various crimes related to the thrift's collapse, which cost the government $1.3 billion.

A House subcommittee approved legislation to scale back exemptions from federal antitrust laws the insurance industry has enjoyed for 45 years. On a 9-6 partisan vote, the Judiciary Committee's subcommittee on economic and commercial law approved a bill Wednesday to subject insurance companies to federal court lawsuits for price fixing and other antitrust provisions.

The Soviet legislature voted to further speed the nation toward a market economy, but a government official told lawmakers that an threefold increase in bread prices would be delayed. Panic-buying has emptied many store shelves since late last month, when the Communist government proposed to cut many price subsidies by January. Prices on bread, the main staple of the Soviet diet, will be raised eventually, but not by July 1 as first planned, Yuri Maslyukov, chairman of the government agency that runs the centralized economy, said Wednesday.

John A. Mulheren Jr. took the stand at his securities fraud trial and denied making an illegal stock ``parking'' transaction with Ivan Boesky. Mulheren, a former business associate of Boesky, testified Wednedsay that he balked when Boesky's chief trader, Michael Davidoff, told him Boesky wanted to sell 330,000 shares of Unocal Corp. stock in 1985 with an agreement to buy it back at a later date. ``You can stop right there,'' Mulheren said he told Davidoff. ``I don't do those trades.''

The Senate voted to restrict logging and set aside 673,000 acres as protected wilderness in Alaska's huge Tongass National Forest. The bill, passed Wednesday, would modify two long-term harvesting contracts to protect old-growth timber and end a $40 million annual incentive promoting high levels of harvesting.

Americans are increasingly worried about their ability to pay their long-term bills and, as far as their pocketbooks, view the 1990s with pessimism, according to a survey. Especially anxious about money are the nation's baby boomers, according to the study conducted by the Gallup Organization for the Atlanta-based International Association for Financial Planners. The results of the survey, released Thursday, confirmed concerns financial planners have seen developing over the last few years, said Robert A. Hewitt, chairman of the IAFP.

Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the investment house known for its financial wizardry and hardball tactics, came under the auctioneer's gavel in a sale of items from the corporate kitchen to the CEO's rolltop desk. The auction Wednesday included office furniture, brass coat racks, stock trading desks, personal computers and other paraphernalia from the firm, the epitome of American corporate finance in the go-go 1980s. Drexel is liquidating most of its assets as part of a Chapter 11 bankruptcy court reorganization.

The stock market posted a small loss Wednesday. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, up about 10 points at its best afternoon level, finished 3.47 points down at 2,929.95. Bond prices soared on news of weak retail sales. The dollar ended weaker against most major currencies and gold fell. Gold and silver futures prices fell sharply; grains and soybeans retreated; oil futures rose; and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Ratings Lowered for Top Calif. Banks; Real Estate, LBO Woes Cited
DOC.TEXT: Worries about the quality of loans to finance takeovers and commercial real estate spread to the West Coast as a leading rating agency downgraded the debt of two top California banks. Moody's Investors Service on Wednesday lowered its ratings on the long-term debt of Security Pacific Corp. and Wells Fargo Corp. by one notch. The action came just two days after the agency downgraded the debt of Chase Manhattan Corp., holding company for the nation's second largest bank, because of concerns about real estate lending. Also in recent weeks, Moody's and rival rating agency Standard & Poor's Corp. have lowered their ratings on Citicorp, the nation's biggest bank, citing real estate and takeover loans. Moody's latest action affected $3.2 billion in debt of Wells Fargo and its subsidiaries, and about $7.4 billion at Security Pacific. Despite the downgrades, the debt retains a solid investment-grade rating. The actions drew protests from the two companies, whose main subsidiaries, Security Pacific National Bank and Wells Fargo Bank, are the second- and third-largest banks in California and among the top ten in the nation. Moody's did not describe specific problem loans, but said ``the California real estate market has only begun to soften.'' Wells Fargo and Security Pacific have diversified real estate portfolios and apparently sound underwriting standards, Moody's said. Both companies may be forced to beef up reserves against losses because of the weakening California market, though, it said. Both companies also have substantial exposure to highly leveraged transactions, such as corporate buyouts and recapitalizations, Moody's said. The adjustments reflected growing concern that California may be about to suffer real estate woes common elsewhere in the country. On Tuesday, for example, San Diego's HomeFed Bank said its nonperforming assets rose by $81 million in May, due mainly to bad commercial real estate loans in California. HomeFed's stock fell $8.25 a share to $25 on the New York Stock Exchange Wednesday, dragging down other California bank and thrift stocks. Wells Fargo, for example, was off $2.37{ at $81.67{; Security Pacific lost 75 cents to close at $40.37{. Moody's announced its downgrades after the market closed. The agency lowered its ratings on the two bank holding company's senior debt to single-a1 from double-a3. Significantly, however, it did not change its ratings on the companies' commercial paper. Banks tend to rely on commercial paper for short-term funding, and a downgrade there could have triggered an immediate rise in funding costs for the two banks. Wells Fargo and Security Pacific officials protested the lower ratings. ``We have maintained a well-balanced loan portfolio consistent with the demands of the marketplace, and with adequate and appropriate levels of reserves,'' Security Pacific Chief Executive Robert H. Smith said in a statement. Leslie Altick, Wells Fargo senior vice president for investor relations, said the bank was not convinced California real estate is headed for new problems. Softness in the office building and hotel markets is well-documented, but Wells Fargo believes California's underlying economy is too strong for a major downturn to occur, she said. As for loans for corporate buyouts, she noted that Wells Fargo's portfolio, while still about $4 billion, had been steadily declining because of the drying up of takeover and buyout activity.

DOC.HEAD: Ameritech, Bell Atlantic in $2.4 Bln Deal to Buy New Zealand's Phone Co. ^Eds: Figures are in U.S. dollars
DOC.TEXT: In the biggest investment to date by any regional Bell telephone company, Ameritech and Bell Atlantic are teaming up with two New Zealand partners to buy New Zealand's state-owned phone company for $2.4 billion. The two Bell companies announced the purchase agreement Thursday morning in Wellington, New Zealand, and issued a news release late Wednesday in the United States. The Telecom Corporation of New Zealand is the country's principal supplier of domestic and international communications services. It is being sold as part of the government's campaign of selling off state-owned enterprises. Steve Ford, a spokesman at Ameritech's headquarters in Chicago, said the two Baby Bell companies and their New Zealand partners won the phone company in a bidding contest against other New Zealand and international companies. He said it was the biggest single investment by any of the regional Bell companies since they were created in the breakup of American Telephone & Telegraph Co. six years ago. ``This represents a significant step forward as we look to become a major global telecommunications company,'' Ford said. The New Zealand company has good growth prospects in its home market and serves as a telecommunications gateway to the Pacific Rim, he said. Raymond W. Smith, chairman and chief executive of Bell Atlantic, said the purchase ``supports our strategy to be a leading international information and communications company.'' Under the deal, Ameritech and Bell Atlantic will buy all of the phone company from the New Zealand government, then reduce their combined stake to 49.9 percent, with each company owning 24.95 percent. The companies' two New Zealand partners _ Fay, Richwhite and Freightways _ will buy 5 percent stakes each from Ameritech and Bell Atlantic. The two American companies then will sell shares for the remaining 40.1 percent on the New Zealand stock market and internationally. The stock offering will be aimed at maximizing participation by New Zealand investors, the companies said. Ameritech's Ford said the companies plan to complete the purchase within 90 days and begin the stock offering in the first quarter of 1991. Telecom of New Zealand had net income of $148 million on revenues of $1.31 in the year ended March 31. Ameritech teamed up with Bell Atlantic because the two companies have a similar strategy and their combined financial strength was needed to make the purchase without affecting domestic operations, Ford said. Ameritech will finance its share of the purchase with its own cash and short-term borrowings, he said. The purchase won't affect phone rates in the Midwest, he said. Ameritech owns Bell companies providing phone service to 12 million customers in Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Ohio and Wisconsin. Bell Atlantic is based in Philadelphia and provides telephone service in the Mid-Atlantic region.

DOC.HEAD: Incentive Decline, Consumer Jitters Hurt Car and Truck Sales
With BC-Auto Sales-Table
DOC.TEXT: Lower incentives and sagging consumer confidence combined to push early-June car and truck sales down 13.1 percent from a year ago, analysts and automakers say. The 10 major U.S. automakers said Wednesday they sold cars and trucks at an average daily rate of 30,412 during the June 1-10 period this year, compared with a rate of 34,994 during the same time last year. Car sales fell 15.5 percent and truck sales were off 8.8 percent. In line with the recent pattern, sales by the Big Three U.S. automakers fell sharply while Japanese companies continued to boost sales from their plants in this country. The main reasons for the overall decline were slow demand and smaller incentive packages this year, said economist Tom Webb of the National Automobile Dealers Association in McLean, Va. ``The reason they are cutting back on incentives is that they haven't overstocked the dealers,'' Webb said of the automakers. Ward's Automotive Reports said that at the end of May, new-car inventories among the 10 major U.S. automakers stood at 59 selling days, considered good for late spring. Meantime, the U.S. Commerce Department reported Wednesday that May retail sales fell 0.7 percent, the third straight month of decline. Some analysts interpreted the drop as an indication of sagging consumer confidence. Sales of the domestic cars made by General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. dropped 19.2 percent in the latest period while sales of U.S.-made cars with Japanese company nameplates rose 34.8 percent. The Big Three held 89.1 percent of the car market in late June and the Japanese ``transplants'' held 10.9 percent. Through June 10 this year, domestic car and truck sales were running 4.4 percent behind last year's pace, with car sales down 5.6 percent and truck sales down 2.2 percent. For the entire year, Big Three car sales were down 10.8 percent and transplant car sales were up 42 percent. Chrysler showed the largest decline in early-June car and light truck sales with an 18 percent decline. The company's vehicle sales so far this year are off 13 percent from last year. GM said its combined early-June car and truck sales were 16.7 percent behind last year's pace. So far this year, GM has sold 4.8 percent fewer vehicles than last year. Ford reported a 12.4 percent drop in early-June and is down 8.8 percent for the year to date.

DOC.HEAD: Big Board Volatility Report Doesn't Win Any Converts on Capitol Hill
DOC.TEXT: A New York Stock Exchange report that found little fault with program trading and recommended the Securities and Exchange Commission rule over stock-index futures did little to advance the political debate over the two issues. Supporters of the embattled Commodity Futures Trading Commission _ engaged in a jurisdictional battle with the SEC over stock-related futures _ said Wedensday the report backed their arguments while some SEC partisans said it doesn't go far enough to support theirs. But politicians and others who have been dealing with proposals for broad market reforms since after the 1987 crash indicated the new study would have little or no effect on positions already taken. Among the recommendations of the stock exchange's 18-member panel was the establishment of a single regulator for stocks and stock-related futures. Legislation for such a change is being considered by Congress. Publicly, Senate and House members were restrained in their comments about the report by the panel, which was ordered to investigate market volatility following the stock market plunge last Oct. 13. Sen. Donald W. Riegle, D-Mich., chairman of the Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee, said the Senate panel would ``review these recommendations carefully.'' Rep. Edward J. Markey, D-Mass., chairman of the House subcommittee that oversees the SEC, called for passage of pending market reform legislation to bolster the SEC's enforcement powers. Congressional aides, who spoke only on the condition of anonymity, said the report would be interpreted differently by supporters of the SEC or CFTC to bolster their respective causes. ``It'll be used on both sides of the argument,'' said one Senate aide familiar with the issues. ``I don't think it's going to have any effect on the pending legislation.'' Recommendations by the panel, headed by General Motors Corp. Chairman Roger B. Smith, included consolidating regulation of stocks and stock-related futures under one federal agency to improve investor confidence. Program trading strategies involving simultaneous trading of huge amounts of stock and stock-index futures have been blamed for causing or worsening big price swings in the stock market. Such trading was criticized after the Oct. 13, 1989 market drop, when the Dow Jones industrial average fell 190 points, and blamed for worsening the Oct. 19, 1987 crash in which the Dow fell 508 points. Legislation to put stocks and index futures under one regulator is bitterly opposed by the CFTC, the Chicago futures exchanges and members of House and Senate agriculture committees that oversee the CFTC. ``I think this bill builds our case against switching jurisdiction,'' said a Senate Agriculture Committee aide. ``The panel found no evidence that a single regulator would affect volatility.'' However, the aide noted, there was no evidence that consolidating regulatory authority would prevent a future stock market crash. ``That contradicts the belief that Congress needs to act (on switching authority) to prevent one,'' said the aide. That point was echoed by a spokesman for the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. ``A couple of the recommendations were not supported by the analysis,'' said CFTC spokesman David Gary. He said the report found no evidence that shifting regulatory authority for stock index futures from the CFTC to the SEC affects market volatility, but recommended doing so ``to improve investor confidence. What's the basis?'' On the issue of program trading, said Gary, ``I think we will be in the same corner'' as the panel. The NYSE panel found nothing inherently wrong with program trading, indicating it was more of a public relations problem than a threat to market stability. A market reform bill passed by the House contains a provision for curbing program trading during periods of extreme market volatility. The Senate version of the bill, which has stalled in committee, contains no program trading provision. Markey, a strong opponent of program trading, didn't address the program trading aspect of the report. But he said the panel's report ``makes a compelling case for cracking down on intermarket trading abuses like front running.'' Front running is the trading practice of taking advantage of advance knowledge of a large and potentially market-moving customer order in one market by taking an offsetting position in another market.

DOC.HEAD: Worried About Paying Your Bills? You're Not Alone, Survey Says
DOC.TEXT: Americans are worried about paying bills run up in the '80s and pessimistic about the '90s, according to a poll done for financial planners. The findings were not unexpected, said Robert A. Hewitt, chairman of the Atlanta-based International Association of Financial Planners. The group commissioned the survey by the Gallup Organization. ``I think those of us who deal with the public on a daily basis ... we've been pretty much aware of it,'' Hewitt said. The poll, being released today, found 46 percent of the respondents expressed worry about their ability to meet all of their financial responsibilities, and 52 percent said they were concerned about outliving their retirement savings. Baby boomers had more anxiety than most. Among respondents between the ages of 35 and 44, 59 percent were worried about their ability to meet financial responsibilities and 62 percent were concerned about outliving their savings, the survey said. Hewitt called that age bracket ``triple squeeze boomers'' because they are having to deal with the costs of raising children and taking care of their aging parents, as well as tending to their own needs and desires. ``All of a sudden they have this discretionary income and discover, `Gosh, I'm going to have to pay for college for little Johnny,''' Hewitt said. College costs have risen beyond the reach of most American families and severe inflation is likely to be a problem in this decade, according to 80 percent of respondents. As a result, 61 percent said they were less inclined to take financial risks than during the 1980s, the survey said. Conducted in April among 1,058 households in a random sample and an additional 600 with incomes of at least $50,000, the survey had a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percent. Along with the concerns about long-term security, Americans are starting to increase their savings rate, Hewitt said, adding that he is a staunch advocate of saving more. ``I'm not suggesting spending less. I'm suggesting we go on a cash and carry basis _ a more prudent spending habit,'' he said in an interview from New York. ``Maybe you're going out to eat three times a week,'' Hewitt said for example. ``Maybe you can go out two times a week, or three times a week at a less expensive place. ``We're not going to kill the restaurant business by doing that.''

DOC.HEAD: FDIC May Restrict or Prohibit Delaware Law on Banks Selling Insurance
DOC.TEXT: Delaware's bank commissioner says the state will cooperate with a federal agency that has suggested banks be prohibited or restricted from underwriting insurance, despite a Delaware law that allows it. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. has proposed regulations on the subject, but they have never been implemented. State Bank Commissioner Keith H. Ellis said Wednesday the writers of the Delaware law had copies of the FDIC's proposals when the law was written. Ellis reviewed the state law Monday with FDIC officials. ``We discussed the safeguards that were in the Delaware legislation and the fact that those were put in the legislation with the proposed rules of the FDIC before us,'' Ellis said. Ellis would not discuss the details of the meeting, but said all parties expressed a spirit of cooperation. ``We discussed what was in the bill and the types of things we'll be looking at as the bill begins to take effect,'' Ellis said, adding he does not foresee any changes in the law. No more meetings are scheduled. ``The scope of regulatory authority (in the state office) and that of the FDIC (is), I believe, to be sufficient to address any concerns that we will discuss,'' he said. Nonetheless, FDIC Chairman William Seidman plans to have his staff recommend that banks either be prohibited from underwriting insurance or the activity be limited to subsidiaries whose sources of capital have been separated from the bank, spokeswoman Caryl A. Austrian said. The Delaware law allows state-chartered banks to sell and underwrite insurance through a subsidiary, department or division. The law allows any bank to put up to 25 percent of its capital into the insurance operation, but the assets, liabilities and records of the insurance subsidiary must be kept separate from the bank. In a statement, Seidman said he was concerned about extending FDIC protection to banks with insurance operations. The Delaware law ``opens up a whole host of issues about safety and soundness and the appropriateness of extending the federal safety net to banks that engage in `new' or nontraditional activities like insurance underwriting,'' Seidman said. ``We started to consider these issues a few years ago _ specifically in regard to real estate development and insurance underwriting activities. I think it is time, given recent developments, to revisit these issues,'' Seidman said. Citibank, the nation's largest bank, and Chase Manhattan Corp., the nation's second-largest, both have plans to open insurance operations in Delaware. Citibank has received approval from Ellis' office, but still must receive approval from the state insurance commissioner. Ellis said preliminary talks have begun with Chase, which must become a state-chartered bank before it can engage in the insurance business. Meanwhile, the Federal Reserve Board has yet to act on a request from five insurance trade organizations to block Citibank from selling insurance from its Delaware offices.

DOC.HEAD: London Stocks Higher at Midday
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices were higher at midday Thursday, pushed up by rising stock-index futures. London's stock market opened a bit lower but soon picked up as futures prices surged ahead. Stocks have been supported lately by growing overseas demand, helped by a steadier British pound and speculation that sterling could soon enter Europe's exchange rate mechanism. Shortly after midday in London, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 12 points, or 0.5 percent, at 2,417.4. Volume was 330.8 million shares at midday, compared with 376.3 million shares at the same time Wednesday.

DOC.BYLINE: Moody's Puts Chrysler Under Review ^By FREDERICK STANDISH
DOC.TEXT: Moody's Investor Services Inc. is reviewing its credit ratings for Chrysler Corp., indicating concern about the company's finances, an official said today. Fitch Investors Service Inc., another New York rating agency, said Chrysler was not under review. Telephone calls to Standard & Poors Corp. officials were not immediately returned this morning. News of Moody's review comes as the nation's No. 3 automaker struggles with declining sales and market share and the loss of key executives. ``There has been deterioration of their performance in the marketplace and competition is making inroads,'' said Harold H. Goldberg, chairman of Moody's corporate rating committee. He said new minivans and sport-utility vehicles other automakers are beginning to sell are pointed directly at Chrysler's popular Dodge and Plymouth minivans and Jeeps. Much of Chrysler's profit stems from sales of those vehicles. Chrysler said Wednesday it had sold 752,935 North American-made cars and trucks through June 10, down 13 percent from the same period last year. The company's share of the U.S. car market is 11.4 percent, down from 13.1 percent a year ago, and its portion of the truck market dropped to 21.8 percent this year from 23.2 percent last. Goldberg said he expected Moody's would decide whether to change Chrysler's Baa2 rating by the end of the month. The Baa2 rating reflects a medium level of investment-grade securities. Chrysler issued a statement calling Moody's review ``inappropriate and unwarranted.'' ``Chrysler believes that its first-quarter profitability was impressive given the massive reduction in dealer inventories and points out that the company's $1.5-billion ongoing cost-cutting program contributed substantially to those results,'' the company's statement said. Chrysler said it earned $71 million in the first quarter of this year, down 80 percent from year-ago profits. In January, the automaker's earnings were dented severely by a big incentive program featuring $1,000 rebates on Dodge Caravan and Plymouth Voyager minivans. Big incentive programs and temporary production cuts during January by Chrysler, No. 1 General Motors Corp. and No. 2 Ford Motor Co. slashed a huge buildup of unsold new vehicles. Meantime, a report in Wednesday's Wall Street Journal said Chrysler is considering buying Dollar car rental, one of the few remaining rental car companies not owned in large share by an automaker. Officials from Dollar and Chrysler, which already owns Thrifty Rent-A-Car System Inc. and Snappy Rental Inc., declined to confirm or deny the report. Goldberg said such an acquisition could be good for Chrysler since rental car companies provide stable markets for automakers. ``Any further participation in the rental business would be at a modest cost and we would view it relatively positively,'' Goldberg said. Goldberg also said Moody's was concerned about the recent drain on top executives at Chrysler. During the past six weeks, Gerald Greenwald quit as vice chairman to head a $4.54-billion union bid to buy United Airlines, and Michael Hammes left as vice president for international operations to run Black & Decker Corp.'s huge toolmaking operations. Chrysler Motors Chairman Bennett Bidwell said he will retire at the end of the year and Treasurer Frederick Zuckerman has said he will leave this summer. ``It's a disappointment to see all of the defections, mainly because they have this challenge on their plate to restore the degree of profitability and market share they had before,'' Goldberg said.

DOC.HEAD: Wholesale Prices Increase 0.3 Percent in May
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs files, f0016-31-32-35. New throughout with analyst reaction. No pickup. A version moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Wholesale prices rose a moderate 0.3 percent in May as a fourth consecutive drop in energy prices helped offset a rise in food costs, the government said today. Energy costs fell 1 percent last month while food costs increased 0.6 percent, according to the Labor Department's Producer Price Index for finished goods, one stop short of retail. Today's report was roughly in line with economists' projections. It was the fourth straight moderate report since a severe cold snap sent prices spiraling 1.9 percent in January, a 15-year record. For the first five months of the year, inflation at the wholesale level was running at a 4.0 percent annual rate, down from 4.8 percent for all of 1989, the government said. Private analysts viewed the report as good news on the inflation front, especially after the huge price increases caused by the last winter's freeze. ``We're back on trend after the wiggles of December and January,'' said Donald Ratajczak, director of economic forecasting at Georgia State University. ``The inflationary fears that picked up in the winter months clearly did not have a good foundation,'' Ratajczak said. Today's moderate inflation data might strengthen arguments that the Federal Reserve no longer needs to keep such a tight grip on interest rates to hold down inflation, analysts said. ``What we're seeing is a reversal in an earlier inflationary trend, which may indicate that the time has come for the Fed to ease up on credit by reducing interest rates,'' said Ron Schreibman of the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors. He noted that over the past 12 months, wholesale prices have risen a modest 3.1 percent. ``This report shows that we are neither veering into recession or are we in a situation where inflation is accelerating rapidly,'' Schreibman said. The Labor Department revised the data for the first two months of 1990, saying wholesale prices soared 1.9 percent in January rather than 1.8 percent. February prices fell 0.1 percent rather than holding steady. Wholesale prices also fell slightly in March and April. In May, energy prices dropped 1 percent after having fallen by even larger amounts the previous three months. Gasoline prices were down 2.1 percent and fuel oil fell 6.2 percent. Natural gas increased 0.9 percent. Food overall was up 0.6 percent after having declined by that amount the previous two months. The price of fruits dropped 8.4 percent, vegetables fell 3.9 percent and eggs were down 21.8 percent. But that wasn't enough to offset increases in the costs of other foods, such as the 7.7 percent hike in the cost of pasta, 4.9 percent increase in pork and 8.8 percent rise in the cost of fish. Excluding the volatile food and energy sectors, prices rose a mild 0.2 percent, the identical increase of a month before. Economists often consider this ``core'' number a better indicator of underlying inflationary pressures in the economy. Automobile prices rose 0.3 percent in May after falling the previous two months. Women's and children's clothing costs were up while men's fell slightly. The price of tobacco was up 3 percent while the cost of household flatware, appliances and home electronic equipment fell. The various changes put the index for all finished goods at 117.7 in May. That means a hypothetical selection of goods that cost $100 in 1982 cost $117.70 last month, up from $114.20 a year earlier. Price pressures in earlier stages of the production process were down in May. Intermediate goods and crude goods both fell 0.1 percent. An example of the three processing stages would be bread for finished goods, flour for intermediate and wheat for crude. Consumer prices, up at an annual rate of 6.8 percent for the first four months of 1990, have been rising at a steeper pace than wholesale costs. May consumer numbers are due out Friday. Producer prices reflect only the cost of goods while consumer prices are heavily influenced by the cost of services.

DOC.HEAD: Court Upholds Pollution Fines
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 3rd graf, The impact, to note that plant now closed. This also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court ruled today the government may impose severe fines against air polluters even when federal officials are slow to decide on proposals for cleaning up the atmosphere. By a 9-0 vote, the justices upheld the Enviromental Protection Agency's power to seek fines of up to $25,000 a day against a General Motors plant in Massachusetts. The impact of the ruling for future cases may be limited. The House and Senate have passed separate bills revising the federal Clean Air Act that establish new timetables to address the kind of problem at issue in the General Motors case. Congress is expected to complete action on the legislation this year. Today's case involves pollution from car paint at a GM assembly plant in Framingham, Mass., and focuses on the joint federal-state system for cracking down on dirty air. GM shut down the Framingham plant last year in a cost-cutting move. Under the federal Clean Air Act, the EPA sets national air quality standards. The states are required to adopt plans to meet those standards and submit them to the federal agency. The EPA in 1980 approved a Massachusetts plan for reducing pollution from paint at auto assembly factories. The plan required car makers to comply fully with the federal rules by Dec. 31, 1985. But EPA officials extended the deadline for any plant switching from lacquer paints to enamel, which emits less pollutants. GM initially planned to stay with lacquer at the Framingham factory but in June 1985 announced it would convert to enamel by the summer of 1987. The company asked that it be exempt from the Dec. 31, 1985, standards for 20 months. Massachusetts officials approved GM's proposal and submitted a revised plan to the EPA on Dec. 30, 1985. Without waiting for federal approval, GM began building a $200 million plant in Framingham to use the enamel system while continuing to operate its factory that uses lacquer paint. EPA officials went to federal court in August 1987 seeking fines of up to $25,000 a day against GM for 20 months of air-quality violations at the old Framingham plant. It was not until September 1988 that the EPA rejected the state-approved pollution control system at the new plant. A federal judge barred the EPA from imposing fines against GM for violations of the Dec. 31, 1985, standards. The judge said the federal agency itself violated the Clean Air Act by taking more than four months to rule on the state-approved plan submitted Dec. 30, 1985. But the 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in 1988 said the EPA's failure to meet the four-month deadline does not disqualify it from fining companies that violate previously approved pollution control rules. The appeals court ordered further lower court hearings to decide the size of the fines. The Supreme Court today upheld the appeals court ruling. Justice Harry A. Blackmun, writing for the court, said references to the four-month deadline in the law do not ``create a general requirement that (the EPA) process all proposed revisions (in clean-air plans) within four months.'' ``Passing mention'' of the four-month period cannot be ``inflated into a requirement that (the EPA) process each and every proposed revision within four months,'' he said. The U.S. Chamber of Commerce, siding with GM, said a ruling favoring the government is an incentive to the EPA to delay and treat businesses unfairly. The case is General Motors vs. U.S., 89-369.

DOC.HEAD: Economic Union: Cause for Hope and Worry
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Restores Beck's first name in 32nd graf, `Beck...' This also moved on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY5
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Hubert Rulitschka knows exactly what he's going to do when he swaps his East German money for West German marks next month. ``It's going right into the bank. I can't afford to go crazy with money. After all, I might lose my job after July 2,'' said Rulitschka, who sells baked goods on this border town's tiny market square. East Germany is less than three weeks from its official plunge into capitalist waters, and there's much concern about how high and dangerous the resulting waves will be. West Germany's powerful mark will become East Germany's legal tender and the two nations will merge as a single economic entity. East Germans will be able to exchange up to 4,000 East marks at a 1-to-1 rate and the remainder at 2-to-1 under the economic merger agreement. Exchanging the first 4,000 marks will give an East German the equivalent of nearly $2,400. Economic merger will be a huge step toward German unification and dislocations are inevitable. As many as 2 million people could lose their jobs as inefficient factories and businesses disappear. But no one is certain how high unemployment will really climb. There also is worry that handing marks to East Germans could cause a nationwide buying spree and a rise in inflation on both sides of the border. Residents of this town of 16,000 appear to have faith in Western promises of eventual affluence. Their optimism is not surprising. The East German economy is near collapse as the result of four decades of Communist mismanagement. But East Germans also are worried that the possible aftershocks _ especially the loss of jobs _ could be severe. Heiligenstadt's giant Solidor factory, which makes zippers, buckles and other small items, will likely emerge relatively unscathed from the merger because it already has a good position in the international market. But even at Solidor, workers worry about job security. ``This job is boring, but I don't fancy the idea that I might lose it. I have not been told whether I'll have it after the ecomomic merger,'' said a young woman working on an assembly line. Hartmut Scherf, Solidor's general director, said up to 160 people among the 2,400-strong work force may have to be let go immediately. Hope and trepidation are reflected in East Germans' plans for their newly acquired marks. There are people like Rulitschka, who figure it's best to build up a security net in case the transformation to capitalism gets rocky. But there are others anxious to use their hard currency to improve their lifestyles. Rudolf Kessel, a Heiligenstadt gynecologist, has big plans for the marks he and his wife will receive. His wife is also a physician, and she wants to start a private practice at home. ``We'll buy new equipment to be used at home. It all comes from West Germany, and costs a lot of money,'' said Kessel. A colleague of Kessel's said she is eager to get marks, but also worried because her rent will go up as East German subsidies are scrapped. ``I'm paying 100 marks (about $30) right now,'' she said. ``I figure that will triple.'' In Muehlhausen, an industrial city about 12 miles away, a young woman said she's going to buy a second-hand Mercedes. ``We've been dreaming about the West's wealth for a long time,'' said the woman. ``I'm not going to miss this chance to get exactly what I want.'' Even though the official starting date for economic union is July 2, it has in fact already begun. A man from the West German city of Kassel has set up a used-car lot in East Germany, just across the border. East Germans driving in and out of their homeland can get a good look at his cars. The prices average 5,000 marks, or $2,958, just about the right price for an East German who has just been handed a wad of marks. For weeks, West German traveling salesmen have been roaming East German roads, making deals and scouting out places where they can set up their own outlets after the merger. West German tourist agencies have set up offices in East German communities, offering travel deals to exotic places like Majorca and Paris, sites many East Germans have only read about or seen on television. Much of the produce now sold on East German squares was grown in West Germany. Workers _ from factory employees to chimney sweeps _ are undergoing retraining by West Germans to help prepare them for new kinds of work in a quickly changing nation. Bernd Beck, the Heiligenstadt mayor, says he is worried because his city hall employees aren't trained for the Western-style bureaucracy that will quickly develop in communities across East Germany. Retraining of city employees has already begun, he said. But he's convinced the fruits of economic union will far outweigh the discomforts. ``People are for the most part optimistic, because they know they'll have real money and that they can buy good products with it,'' said Beck. ``Daily life has already become better for us,'' he said. ``We're able to buy video recorders and good television sets at lower prices then before. ``We can only be winners.''

DOC.HEAD: Philips Warns 1990 Profits Will Drop During Overhaul
DOC.TEXT: The Philips NV electronics multinational on Thursday warned that the replacement of its president and a major company overhaul would not prevent this year's profit from falling far behind normal. The unusual warning to investors that 1990 earnings would be ``very low'' marked a major move toward openness by the electronics giant. Philips faces a lawsuit by U.S. stockholders who claim they were misled by the company, which allegedly issued overly optimistic predictions over the first quarter of this year. On May 14, Philips chairman Cor van der Klugt resigned after accusations that he failed to disclose until the very last minute that Philips would barely be breaking even over that period. Philips net profit from normal operations were a mere 6 million guilders, the equivalent of about $3.2 million, in that quarter, down from 223 million guilders, or $117 million, in the first quarter of last year. In a brief statement released Thursday, Philips warned this year's second-quarter profit will be ``appreciably lower'' than last year's second-quarter figure of 197 million guilders, or $104 million. ``Net result for normal business operations for 1990 as a whole will ... be at a very low level,'' said the statement, blaming the setback on a major restructuring program. Philips' income for all of 1989 totaled 792 million guilders, $417 million. Details on the overhaul will be disclosed on July 2, a day after Van der Klugt's successor Jan Timmer takes over, Philips spokesman Ben Geerts said. Dutch newspapers have speculated that Timmer, who is credited with salvaging Philips' Consumer Electronics Division through widespread staff reductions, may sell off its computer division, which has been blamed for the disappointing first-quarter results. Industry analysts attribute Philips' woes to poor managment and tougher competition from Asian electronics companies.

DOC.HEAD: S&L Rescuers Will Be Out of Money By Fall, Administration Says
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 11 grafs with Brady testimony; picks up 9th pvs,`It plans...'; Trims last three grafs to shorten. This also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady told Congress today that the administration's savings and loan bailout could exhaust its borrowing authority as soon as the October-December quarter. The Resolution Trust Corp., the 10-month-old agency responsible for cleaning up the S&L mess, ``could, with an aggressive schedule of case resolutions, run out of funds by the end of this calendar year or early next year,'' Brady told the House Banking Committee. His latest testimony followed by three weeks a dramatic increase in the administration's estimate of the cost of the S&L problem. Brady had roughly doubled the estimate to between $89 billion and $132 billion, after earlier insisting that $50 billion provided by Congress last year could cover most S&L losses. Any estimate of how much more money is needed from taxpayers is ``highly uncertain,'' Brady said, but a ``representative range'' for fiscal year 1991 beginning Oct. 1 would be ``about $30 billion to slightly over $50 billion.'' He did not specify how the administration believed the money should be raised, saying only that the matter should be considered in budget negotiations between the White House and congressional leaders. He strongly suggested that Congress should provide an open-ended authorization for more rescue spending, rather than a specific amount that may prove inadequate. Providing a specific amount ``means having to face the prospect of returning at relatively short intervals as markets change and, with them, the estimates,'' he said. Brady said the bailout program could continue beyond the end of this year without new funds by slowing down the pace of its S&L rescue program and gambling that real estate markets and interest rates will improve. But, he rejected that. ``We believe that there is too much speculation already. Our job is to be steady, do the work, and take no further gambles with the taxpayers' money,'' he said. Brady's assessment of when the money will run out is supported by the Congressional Budget Office, which told the committee's chairman, Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, that the RTC ``will exhaust its $50 billion ... early in fiscal year 1991.'' RTC Chairman L. William Seidman, in remarks to reporters Wednesday, indicated his agency has at least enough borrowing authority left to handle another 95 to 120 failures. The RTC so far has seized 443 failed S&Ls, ``resolving'' 148 by paying off depositors or by selling the institutions to new investors. It plans an additional 45 resolutions by the end of June. And, Seidman said, it expects to handle 50 to 75 in the July-September quarter. But the agency still is having difficulty keeping up with the failure rate. Thrift regulators have indicated at least another 299 institutions still operating independently appear headed for failure. Despite the dramatic increase in the administration's new S&L cost estimate, the Congressional Budget Office is attacking it as too conservative. Brady had based his new cost estimate on assumptions that 925 S&Ls would topple. However, CBO director Robert D. Reischauer said that does not include an additional 792 institutions that are technically solvent but would fail if forced to list their assets at market value. Reischauer said his office expects many marginal institutions to fail, leaving only about 1,200 healthy S&Ls. Even if few marginal thrifts fail, Brady's cost estimate should be $150 billion, Reischauer said in a letter to Gonzalez. The administration is not factoring in the cost of likely delays in closing so many S&Ls, he said. In a separate development, the RTC intensified its effort to sell repossessed S&L real estate, offering to provide potential buyers with personalized computer lists of properties that may interest them. Effective today, 35,908 properties valued originally at $14.9 billion will be open to offers. More than half the properties, 19,067, with a value of $10.2 billion, are in Texas. The rest are scattered through 45 other states, the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico. Mostly the agency is offering residential parcels _ 29,977 properties _ but it is also listing 232 pieces of land and 5,699 commercial properties. ``We have everything available from a $15,000 pool hall in Houston to uranium mines,'' said Lamar C. Kelly Jr., RTC director of asset and real estate management. The new inventory is current through next March 31. In January, the RTC released its first list of 30,123 properties, current through Sept. 30. The agency has sold 13,200 of those, leaving about 17,000 to be carried over to its new list. Kelly said the agency hopes a new marketing strategy _ using computers _ will expose the RTC's real estate to more buyers.

DOC.HEAD: Weather Forecast Pressures Crop Futures
DOC.TEXT: Forecasts for good growing conditions in the Midwest sent grain and soybean futures tumbling this morning on the Chicago Board of Trade. Prices opened lower across the board, as expected after Wednesday's losses. But the declines in the corn and soybean markets were unexpectedly steep. Analysts attributed much of the selling to the National Weather Service's latest 30-day outlook, released late Wednesday, which predicts normal to above-normal temperatures and rainfall in Midwestern growing regions through mid-July. The agency's new six-to-10-day outlook projects similar conditions during the period June 19-23. The forecasts prompted selling by commodity funds at the opening bell ``and no one was there to buy it,'' said Mark Weidner, an analyst with Cargill Investor Services Inc. in Chicago. In early trading, wheat futures were 1 cent to 2{ cents lower with the contract for delivery in July at $3.32} a bushel; corn was 1{ cents to 5 cents lower with July at $2.85} a bushel; oats were 3{ cents to 6{ cents lower with July at $1.37{ a bushel; soybeans were 9 cents to 10{ cents lower with July at $5.96 a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, led by sharp declines in the pork markets due to sluggish demand for pork products and bearish chart signals. Live cattle futures were .20 cent to .55 cent lower with June at 76.70 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent to .37 cent lower with August at 84.60 cents a pound; live hogs were unchanged to 1.40 cents lower with June at 62.90 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.10 cents to the permitted daily limit of 2 cents lower with July at 68.45 cents a pound. Cattle futures settled mostly higher on Wednesday while pork futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Indicted Former Owner of Failed Texas S&L Says He's Innocent
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Dixon's appearance, comments. Picks up 4th graf, `The indictment...'. DELETES outdated 16th graf, `His attorney...'. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The former owner of the collapsed Vernon Savings & Loan today said he is innocent of charges that he spent thousands of dollars in thrift money on pleasure trips, prostitutes and illegal contributions to politicians. Donald R. Dixon, 50, was charged Wednesday with conspiracy, misapplication of funds, making false statements and other offenses. ``Perhaps when my day in court comes, if they'll listen, they'll find out what really happened and the blame can be properly assessed and properly assigned,'' Dixon said. Dixon appeared before U.S. Magistrate John B. Tolle this morning and was freed on a personal recognizance bond. He did not enter a plea at his court appearance, but told reporters afterward that he intended to plead innocent. ``For the moment, the U.S. government is making a scapegoat of me because they're unaccountable for their role in the $500 billion or greater loss the American taxpayer has to pay,'' he said. His attorney, William Ravkind, refused to let Dixon answer a question about his personal finances. The indictment alleges the political contributions were made ``for the purpose of currying favor and influence'' in anticipation of regulatory action by the Texas Savings and Loan Department and the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. Prosecutors said the politicians didn't know the contributions were illegal, and none was charged. Nor were any thrift regulators. If convicted on all charges, Dixon faces 190 years in prison and a $9.5 million fine. Government attorneys said the thrift is a prime example of abuse in the S&L industry. Under Dixon, who moved the thrift to Dallas from the town of Vernon, assets of the thrift grew tenfold until federal regulators shut it down. Five other Vernon officials have pleaded guilty to crimes in the $1.3 billion collapse of the S&L. Former president Patrick G. King and former chairman Woody F. Lemons have been sentenced to prison for their part in the 1987 collapse. ``These complicated, white-collar crime cases take time to develop, but the Justice Department is committed to the investigation, prosecution and incarceration of those who ripped off our financial institutions and have left the taxpayers of the United States holding the bag,'' U.S. Attorney Dick Thornburgh said in a statement. Dixon was accused of encouraging employees to make about $7,000 in political contributions and then reimbursing them with expense money or phony bonuses to skirt restrictions on corporate campaign contributions. Among other things, Dixon was charged with conspiring with other Vernon officials to give money to Texas Democrat Jim Wright, the former House speaker who was pressing federal regulators to stop trying to close insolvent Texas thrifts. The indictment alleged Dixon also billed Vernon $10,500 for prostitutes for himself and others at a 1985 Vernon board of directors' party at Dixon's Solana Beach, Calif., beach house and on a yacht cruise in San Diego harbor. In 1985, Dixon allegedly used Vernon money for hunting trips with senior Vernon officials to Kansas and San Diego. L. Linton Bowman III, then commissioner of the Texas Savings and Loan Department, went along, the indictment said. Lodging, meals, female companionship and other expenses cost $4,866, the indictment said. Dixon also was accused of using his airplane for an illegal activity _ transporting prostitutes from Texas to California. Former Vernon vice president Patrick Malone testified at King's 1989 trial that contributions were solicited from King and other top thrift executives. The money was for the 1986 gubernatorial primary campaign of former Rep. Tom Loeffler, R-Texas, and the re-election bids of Wright, who resigned after a House ethics investigation unrelated to the Vernon case; former Rep. Jack Kemp, R-N.Y., now secretary of Housing and Urban Development; Sen. Jake Garn, R-Utah, and Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif. Dixon threw parties for other S&L operators aboard his yacht on the Potomac River in Washington to raise money for the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, chaired by then-Rep. Tony Coelho, D-Calif., the indictment said. At Coelho's request, Wright intervened with federal regulators to discuss Vernon, according to a report to the House Ethics Committee by Richard J. Phelan, an outside counsel hired to investigate Wright. Phelan reported that Wright telephoned Edwin Gray, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, and asked if Vernon were going to be shut down. Wright told the ethics panel he did not know Dixon. But Phelan's investigation produced a picture of Wright and Dixon aboard the yacht. The photograph bore the inscription, ``My best personal regards, Jim Wright.'' Wright's administrative assistant in Fort Worth did not immediately return phone calls seeking comment today. Dixon was the lead defendant in a $540 million federal fraud lawsuit brought after the Vernon shutdown but had not faced criminal charges until Wednesday. The lawsuit alleged that Dixon and other thrift officers grossly overstated Vernon's profits and net worth in order to pay $22.1 million in illegal dividends to Dondi Financial Corp., a holding company headed by Dixon. The Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp. lawsuit said top officials ``began to loot Vernon for their personal financial benefit and defraud its depositors, creditors and the FSLIC.''
