DOC.HEAD: Inventories Up, Sales Down, Government Says
With AM-Inflation, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Business inventories inched upward 0.1 percent in April while sales fell 1.1 percent, the government said Thursday in the second report this week showing increasing consumer caution. ``It is disconcerting that the consumer sector is so weak,'' said Evelina Tainer, senior domestic economist with the First National Bank of Chicago. ``The consumer sector is supposed to be the underpinning of economic growth and the weakness does not bode well for growth in the second quarter.'' The Commerce Department said business sales totaled a seasonally adjusted $533.04 billion, down from $535.99 billion in March when they rose 0.6 percent. Sales on the retail level were down 0.9 percent in April. In a report Wednesday, the department said retail sales in May fell 0.7 percent. It was the first time they had declined for three consecutive months since the fall of 1981, during the last recession. Analysts have attributed consumer caution to a sluggish job market and weak wage gains. Retail sales represent about half of consumer spending, which has been a driving force for the economy during much of the last eight years. Overall, consumer spending accounts for about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. However, Ms. Tainer said, inventories are keeping in line with sales and their slight increase in April ``does not lead to any recessionary outlook.'' If inventories were to rise excessively, it could mean cutbacks in production and a loss of jobs. Commerce said business inventories in April totaled a seasonally adjusted $794.46 billion, up from $793.67 billion in March, when they were unchanged from the previous month. The April business activity produced a 1.49 ratio of inventories to sales, up slightly from a 1.47 ratio a month earlier but down from the 1.53 ratio last November. The ratio means it would take 1.49 months to exhaust inventories at the April pace. It peaked at 1.70 in October 1982 during the last recession. In addition to the drop in retail sales, manufacturing sales were down 1.2 percent and wholesale sales were off 1.1 percent. Retailers had the biggest increase in inventories, up 0.3 percent, followed by a 0.1 percent gain in the manufacturing sector. Wholesalers' inventories, on the other hand, dropped 0.2 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Southland Announces Revised Restructuring Proposal; Missed Payment
DOC.NOTE: Eds: AMs version planned.
DOC.TEXT: Debt-ridden Southland Corp., owner of some 6,900 7-Eleven convenience stores, Thursday announced a sweetened restructuring proposal for its bondholders and said it would miss an interest payment due Friday on its public debt. The revised restructuring, a key condition of the troubled company's agreement to sell a controlling interest to its Japan-based partners, also would reduce the stake held by Southland's founding Thompson family. Southland has been struggling to continue making payments on the billions of dollars in debt it incurred in 1987 when the Thompson family took the company private in $4.9 billion leveraged buyout. In March, it agreed to sell a controlling interest to its Japanese partners, Ito-Yokado Co. Ltd. and 7-Eleven Japan Co. Ltd., for $400 million and the assumption of debt. Under the revised proposal, bondholders would receive debt securities with an aggregate principal amount of about $550 million, bearing cash interest at rates of 12 percent to 14 percent and maturing in six to seven years. The original restructuring proposal offered bondholders $350 million for their debt. Preferred stockholders would get shares of a new issue of preferred stock or common stock of the same value. Bondholders and preferred shareholders also would end up with a total of 18.5 percent of Southland's common stock. The Thompson family would see its stake in Southland reduced to 6.5 percent. ``We estimate that the terms of the revised exchange offers represent an increase in current value of approximately $200 million over the original offers,'' said Clark Matthews, Southland's chief financial officer. ``Our goal in significantly improving the proposal is to put Southland on solid financial footing as quickly as possible.'' The company said it would not make certain interest payments due Friday on its public debt, but would meet continuing obligations to its trade creditors. 7-Eleven Japan, the largest convenience store operator in Japan, operates 3,940 licensed stores. Ito-Yokado, which Southland described as Japan's most profitable supermarket chain, owns 50.3 percent of 7-Eleven Japan. Southland has had a 17-year affiliation with the Japanese concerns. Heightened competition in the convenience store business, plus disappointing sales and earnings growth, have made it tough for Southland to keep making payments on its huge debt, much of which is in high-interest junk bonds. Matthews said the debt and stock restructuring was necessary to give Southland the leeway to make capital expenditures necessary to remain competitive. Southland reported a first-quarter loss of $69.4 million.

For release Sunday June 17
DOC.HEAD: For Boilermaker, 50 Years of Asbestos Leaves Legacy of Pain
With BC-Asbestos Mess
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: By way of introduction, 75-year-old Thomas F. Fallon Sr. lifts his knit yellowshirt to display a scar that cuts an arc from near the spine around the rib cage to the center of the chest. The mark of surgery in 1981, along with smaller scars from tubes inserted into his body for a month, are among the more visible reminders of the penalty for nearly 50 years of working with cancer-causing asbestos. Fallon's wife, Josephine, says he used to be ``a big Irishman.'' Now he struggles to lift himself from a chair, breathes heavily and tires easily, whether on the short walk to the corner store to buy the Daily News or while painting the kitchen doorframe. Asbestos encased the boilers that Fallon built and repaired throughout his career. It tumbled in chunks from ceiling pipes at the Brooklyn Navy Yard in the 1950s. Workers often cut blankets from rolls of asbestos to protect themselves from heat. ``We used to lay on it. We used to handle it with our bare hands,'' Fallon says, pulling out pictures of ship engine boiler rooms, technical diagrams, faded medical bills and legal correspondence. ``We never thought it was poison in those days,'' he says. ``People were dying. They never knew they had it.'' Fallon has mesothelioma, a tumor in the lining of lungs caused by inhalation of asbestos particles. Doctors cut out part of one lung lining and subjected him to chemotherapy. Though they only gave him three years to live, he's survived 10. Fallon is among tens of thousands of victims of ``meso,'' which along with lung cancer and other lesser ailments are remnants of either scientific ignorance or willful negligence by U.S. asbestos manufacturers and users. He also is one of 571 plaintiffs suing Manville Corp.'s asbestos trust fund and other companies that supplied asbestos to the Brooklyn shipyard, where battleships such as the U.S. Missouri and U.S. Iowa were built during World War II. If a settlement fails, a mass trial is set for the fall. While lawyers haggle over the price for asbestos-related injuries, Fallon says he simply wants fair compensation for the pain he feels on humid days and the travel-filled retirement he was denied. Fallon says he never had fair warning. From 1932, when he learned to be a boilermaker, until retiring in 1980, no one told him asbestos could cause diseases that now kill about 10,000 people annually and disable thousands of others. Like many who handled asbestos in shipyards, on construction sites, in chemical plants and elsewhere, Fallon believes the makers of the insulation and building material _ and the government _ concealed its hazardous effects. ``I hope to get a good settlement because the last 10 years have been wasted,'' Fallon says. ``I can't go no place. I can't do nothing. We planned to travel. We can't go too far _ as far as Staten Island and back.'' ``The way I feel know I want my life back,'' he says. ``I feel lost.'' Fallon and his 78-year-old wife live in Bay Ridge, a working-class neighborhood in the shadows of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge that links Brooklyn and Staten Island, where one of their two daughters lives. Theirs was a mixed marriage _ he's Irish, she Italian; he's from Brooklyn, she's from the Bronx. Fallon says for a while he swept up a bar in the morning, repaired boilers during the day, and did freelance typing with his wife at home at night. ``They grew up truly believing in the American dream,'' says Fallon's daughter, Jo Ellen Falconello. ``They were betrayed, pure and simple.'' Fallon says he never made more than $17,000 a year, but loved his work. The Fallons still rent a one-bedroom apartment in a two-family house, where they have lived 20 years, for $400 a month. Family pictures adorn the end tables; the arm chairs have plastic seat covers. The couple lives on Social Security payments of $1,350 a month, and despite his illness and her hip surgery and rapid heartbeat, medical bills haven't been devastating. The Fallons saved about $20,000 in their half-century together, and use the interest for luxuries like gifts for the grandchildren. Fallon in 1986 rejected settlement offers totaling $2,500 from two companies. Jury awards in some cases have exceeded $1 million, but Fallon just wants enough to compensate for the suffering and maybe help his family. ``I expected him to get older but not the way it happened. It just cut him down,'' his daughter says. ``In a way we're very lucky. We still have my father here. The quality of his life isn't what it should be, but he isn't dead.''
DOC.NOTE: End adv Sunday June 17

DOC.HEAD: Pollution Fines Upheld; Texaco Loses Appeal of Antitrust Award
DOC.TEXT: The government may fine air polluters even when federal officials are slow to decide on proposals for cleaning up the atmosphere, the Supreme Court ruled Thursday. The justices voted 9-0 to uphold a lower court ruling supporting the Enviromental Protection Agency's power to seek fines of up to $25,000 a day against a now-closed General Motors Corp. plant in Massachusetts. In a separate decision Thursday, the court barred manufacturers from giving discounts to wholesalers and not to retailers when the discounts are unrelated to any savings for the supplier or to the wholesaler's costs. The decision came in a case involving a $1.35 million antitrust award Texaco Inc. was ordered to pay. The future impact of the pollution ruling may be limited. The House and Senate have passed bills revising the federal Clean Air Act that set new timetables to address the kind of problem at issue in the GM case. Congress is expected to complete action on the legislation this year. The case involved pollution from car paint at a GM assembly plant in Framingham, Mass. Under the Clean Air Act, the EPA sets national air quality standards. The states are required to adopt plans to meet those standards and submit them to the federal agency. The EPA in 1980 approved a Massachusetts plan for reducing pollution from paint at auto assembly factories. The plan required car makers to comply fully with the federal rules by Dec. 31, 1985, but the EPA extended the deadline for plants switching from lacquer paints to enamel, which emits less pollutants. GM in June 1985 said it would convert to enamel by the summer of 1987 and sought a 20-month exemption from the Dec. 31, 1985, standards. Massachusetts officials approved GM's proposal and submitted a revised plan to the EPA on Dec. 30, 1985. Without waiting for federal approval, GM began building a $200 million plant in Framingham to use the enamel system while continuing to operate its factory that uses lacquer paint. EPA officials went to federal court in August 1987 seeking fines of up to $25,000 a day against GM for 20 months of air-quality violations at the old Framingham plant. In September 1988, the EPA finally rejected the state-approved pollution control system at the new plant. A federal judge barred the EPA from imposing fines against GM for violations of the Dec. 31, 1985, standards. The judge said the EPA violated the Clean Air Act by taking more than four months to rule on the state-approved plan submitted Dec. 30, 1985. But the 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in 1988 said the EPA's failure to meet the four-month deadline did not disqualify it from fining companies that violate previously approved pollution control rules. The appeals court ordered further lower court hearings to decide the size of the fines. The Supreme Court upheld the appeals court ruling. GM closed the Framingham plant last year in a cost-cutting move. In the Texaco case, the court unanimously upheld a $1.35 million antitrust award Texaco Inc. was ordered to pay to 12 service stations in the Spokane, Wash., area. Justice John Paul Stevens, writing for the court, said there was no evidence that Texaco's discounts ``constituted a reasonable reimbursement for the value to Texaco of (the wholesalers') marketing functions.'' Business groups that supported Texaco's appeal had said a defeat for the company could undermine ``the most common distributional arrangement in American business: the dual channel system in which a manufacturer or supplier sells to wholesalers at discounted prices lower than those it charges direct purchasing retailers.'' But the court said Texaco's discounts amounted to illegal price discrimination barred by a federal antitrust law, the Robinson-Patman Act. A federal jury ordered Texaco to pay $449,900, a sum that was tripled by the judge to $1.35 million under the act. The 12 service station dealers that sued said from 1972 to 1981 they were placed at an unfair competitive disadvantage because Texaco supplied gasoline to two Spokane-area wholesalers, John Dompier Oil Co. and Gull Oil Co., at discounts ranging from 2.5 cents to 5.75 cents per gallon less than Texaco charged the retailers. Dompier sold the gasoline to other retailers under the Texaco trademark while Gull marketed it under private brand names. The 12 service stations said they suffered because at least part of the discounts were passed on to consumers by competing retailers who bought from the Dompier and Gull. Texaco argued that the discounts were legitimate because they were available to all wholesalers who purchased from the oil comany giant. Stevens noted there was evidence the services offered by the Dompier and Gull were insubstantial and did not justify the discount.

NEW YORK (AM) _ The stock market edged downward today, reflecting concerns about corporate earnings and new evidence of economic sluggishness. Brokers said technology stocks were partly responsible, suffering slips after reports of lower earnings estimates for Digital Equipment Corp. and United Telecommunications Inc. Digital said external forecasts of the company's fourth-quarter earnings were too optimistic. James Osterhoff, vice president of finance, said the company's U.S. market continues to be sluggish, as are certain markets overseas. Michael Metz, a managing director at Oppenheimer & Co., said the news triggered a round of futures-related computerized program selling which brought down technology stocks. United Telecom also fell after analysts cut their earnings estimates for the second quarter and the year. The market's general direction was off after the first of several economic reports due by week's end. The producer price index of finished goods rose 0.3 percent in May, which brokers found disappointing but not unexpected. The report provided little encouragement that the Fed might move soon to relax interest rates. The market is also approaching Friday's ``triple witching hour,'' an event that happens four times a year on Wall Street, when quarterly contracts to buy or sell futures and options tied to stock indexes expire. It has been known to create sharp, unpredictable price gyrations in stocks and can trigger heavy trading toward the close.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-NYSE Trading, Bjt
Wall Streeters Skeptical About Automated Trading
DOC.TEXT: The prospect of automated off-hours trading at the New York Stock Exchange has some Wall Streeters echoing the sentiments of blue-collar workers displaced by machinery on the assembly line. Stock brokers and trading-floor specialists said Thursday they were confident their clients would be better served by trading shares through the traditional NYSE methods. They were skeptical that the plan would work using computers, rather than people on the trading floor, to execute trades. Some also wondered whether there is enough business in the middle of the night to warrant additional hours for the NYSE. ``If the restaurant is open all night, does that make you any hungrier?'' one broker asked. On the floor of the exchange and during cigarette breaks on a Wall Street sidewalk, some exchange workers said they were confident customers get better service through so-called specialists who bring buyer and seller together. Seeking to emphasize advantages of the current system, the traders said specialists occassionally reach compromises between buyers and sellers that bring the seller a higher price than originally sought. ``Show me a machine that can do that,'' said one broker and former specialist who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``I'm doubtful it would work, but it's a foot in the door'' for computerized trading, said a specialist who also asked that his name not be used. ``I have the feeling it's a Trojan horse,'' he said, adding that an automated system likely would be introduced during daytime hours if it is accepted at night. The plan to expand trading hours was first reported in The New York Times and later confirmed through sources. A NYSE spokesman would not confirm the report, but said the exchange has been talking about moving to off-hours trading for two years. Sources who were familiar with the plan said the off-hours trading would eventually lead to three trading sessions through the night. Each stock would be traded once at each session, with all trades handled at a single price. The Big Board hopes after-hours trading would bring back business lost to the Tokyo and London exchanges.

DOC.HEAD: Southland Announces Restructuring, Missed Bond Payment
DOC.TEXT: Debt-ridden Southland Corp., owner of 7,000 7-Eleven convenience stores, on Thursday sweetened a deal to pay off its bondholders in a proposal that slashes the amount of control the founding Thompson family will have. The company also said Thursday it would not pay $69 million in interest due on two bond issues Friday, a move that an analyst said opens up the possibility of an involuntary bankruptcy petition being filed against Southland. The bondholder proposal, which Southland called the second phase in its attempt to climb out from under $1.8 billion in debt, cuts the amount of control that the Thompson family and other existing shareholders will have, from 15 percent of the shares in an earlier proposal to 6.5 percent. The company is offering bondholders $550 million to exchange $1.76 billion in outstanding securities. In addition, bondholders and preferred shareholders would share 18.5 percent of the company's common stock. The new offer for the bonds is about $200 million higher than an earlier plan. The first phase of the restructuring, announced in March, called for Southland's Japanese partners, Ito-Yokado Co. Ltd. and Seven-Eleven Japan Co. Ltd., to pay $400 million cash for 75 percent of the company. But the Japanese investors agreed to hold off consummating that deal until August 15 pending the new restructuring scheme. ``Assuming an agreement can be reached over the next couple of days, the hope is that a specific proposal would be filed with the SEC (Securities and Exchange Commission) by about the middle of next week,'' said John Gordon, president of Deltec Securities Corp. of New York and head of a bondholders committee that worked out the agreement with Southland management and others. Gordon said he was ``enthusiastic'' about the negotiations and said it provided an opportunity for Southland to ``really get back on its feet.'' Suffering disappointing sales and earnings growth, Southland has been strained by debt associated with its $4.9 billion leveraged buyout in 1987, which gave Dallas' Thompson family control of the chain. The company lost $69.4 million in the first quarter of this year, and sold its Citgo subsidiary in January to raise $661.5 million in cash. ``I thought that their initial offer was totally unacceptable, and in fact I would be hard-pressed to think of an offer that could have been more unacceptable than the one they made,'' Gordon said. But he said he was impressed with the negotiations this week that led to Thursday's offer. At least one other bondholder was not as enthusiastic. ``It's incredible the size of the pill that they're asking bondholders to swallow,'' said Jay H. Lustig, head of the high yield department for Drake Capital Securities Inc. of Santa Monica, Calif. ``They're asking bondholders to forgive $1.2 billion in debt in exchange for 18 percent of the company. They have absolutely zero shot of getting 100 percent acceptance,'' he said. The missed interest payment Friday also raises the possibility that Southland could be forced into involuntary bankruptcy if a payment or agreement is not worked out in 30 days, Lustig said. But Gordon said he was optimistic all parties would work out an agreement that would sidestep such a move.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Off Sharply; Dollar Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Gold prices fell sharply Thursday while the dollar finished mostly higher in domestic dealings after putting in a mixed performance overseas. Gold bullion lost about $5 a troy ounce following heavy selling overseas. Unidentified Middle East investors were believed responsible sending gold to a four-year low of $341 a troy ounce before the metal recovered about half its losses in foreign trading. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $346.80 a troy ounce, down $5.20 from late Wednesday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $345.85 an ounce, off $5.15 an ounce. ``All the action took place overnight,'' said Steven Pepper, a vice president at Republic. Gold held to a very narrow range in domestic trading, he said, but the market remained ``confused and demoralized'' by the metal's recent volatility. Traders had ``thought gold could hold'' at the $350-an-ounce level, Pepper said. Earlier in London, gold fell to a late bid price of $345.25 an troy ounce from $350.15 late Wednesday. In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $345.50 from $350.50, and in Hong Kong, gold dropped $4.36 an ounce to close at $350.80. Currency trading was moderate in Europe, but interest in the dollar was rekindled when activity shifted to the United States. Traders attributed the dollar's advance to optimism ahead of Friday's release of merchandise trade figures for April. Market players are ``expecting a very good number,'' said Bob Morrissey, senior trader at the Bank of Boston's New York office. The market consensus is that the Commerce Department will report a trade deficit of about $7.2 billion, which would represent a significant decline from March's wider-than-expected $8.45 billion deficit. But Morrissey said rumors began circulating in the market that the figure could be as good as $5 billion. In that case, he predicted the dollar would break out of its current trading range. A lower dollar helps the deficit by making U.S. goods more competitive on foreign markets, thereby increasing exports. A low deficit would indicate that ``U.S. goods are competitive, and there is room for the dollar to go higher,'' Morrissey said. Also to be released on Friday are reports on the consumer price index and industrial production and capacity, both for May. Dealers said Thursday's goverment report showing U.S. wholesale prices rose a moderate 0.3 percent in May did not provide any surprises. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 153.53 Japanese yen, down 1.02 yen from Wednesday's finish. Later in London, the dollar was quoted higher at 153.90 yen. In New York, the dollar closed at 154.20 yen, down from 154.75 yen on Wednesday. The British pound was quoted at $1.7080 late in London, up from $1.7070 late Wednesday. In New York, it cost $1.7080 to buy one pound, less expensive than Wednesday's $1.7115. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Wednesday's late rates, included: 1.6948 West German marks, up from 1.6865; 1.4355 Swiss francs, up from 1.4240; 5.7015 French francs, up from 5.6720; 1,244.50 Italian lire, up from 1,238.00; and 1.1713 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1720. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Wednesday's late rates, included: 1.6920 West German marks, down from 1.6925; 1.4330 Swiss francs, down from 1.4335; 5.6940 French francs, up from 5.6880; 1.9045 Dutch guilders, unchanged; 1,242.75 Italian lire, up from 1,241.00; and 1.1700 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1722 Silver prices fell. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.770 a troy ounce, down from $4.915 an ounce Wednesday. Earlier in London the metal settled at a bid of $4.80 a troy ounce, down from $4.95.

DOC.HEAD: Rose $988.6 Million in Latest Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 504 money market mutual funds rose $988.6 million in the latest week to $382.14 billion, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The rise in the seven-day period ended Wednesday followed a $385.1 million decline in fund assets the week earlier. The Washington-based mutual fund trade group originally reported that drop as $804.8 million but later revised it. Fund assets hit a record high $392.14 billion in the week ended March 21, 1990. The institute said that in the latest week, assets of 239 general purpose funds rose $1.01 billion to $131.32 billion, assets of 105 broker-dealer funds increased $432.5 million to $159.23 billion, and assets of 160 institutional funds fell $455.0 million to $91.59 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds fell in the week ended Tuesday to 7.65 percent from 7.67 percent the previous week, said Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield fell to 7.68 percent from 7.69 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 43 days, down from 44 days, Donoghue's said. The newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts fell to 6.19 percent as of Wednesday from 6.20 percent a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, fell to 5.04 percent from 5.06 percent. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.92 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, down from 7.94 percent the previous week. Yields were 8.12 percent on 1-year CDs, down from 8.14 percent; 8.12 percent on 2{-year CDs, down from 8.15 percent; and 8.18 percent on 5-year CDs, down from 8.22 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Inflation at Wholesale Level Rises a Moderate 0.3 Percent in May
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `On Wall ...,' to UPDATE with closing market figures. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A fourth consecutive monthly drop in energy prices helped offset higher food costs in May and hold overall wholesale prices to a moderate 0.3 percent increase, the government said Thursday. Analysts viewed the soft increase in the Labor Department's Producer Price Index for finished goods as encouraging news on the inflation front, especially given last winter's huge price gains caused by a severe cold snap. That freeze sent wholesale prices spiraling 1.9 percent in January to a 15-year record. ``We're back on trend after the wiggles of December and January,'' said Donald Ratajczak, director of economic forecasting at Georgia State University in Atlanta. ``The inflationary fears that picked up in the winter months clearly did not have a good foundation,'' Ratajczak said. The report should help dampen inflation worries for the Federal Reserve, which has been under pressure to ease its inflation-fighting campaign and lower interest rates to boost the economy, analysts said. Still, most analysts expected no immediate shift in the central bank's policy. ``The question is how long does the Fed feel it can keep the economy subdued? They may say, `Let's keep our nose to the grindstone on inflation and really see a payoff,''' said Robert Dederick, chief economist at the Northern Trust Co. of Chicago. On Wall Street, investors took the inflation report as a disappointing sign that the Fed would not move anytime soon to relax interest rates. By midday, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials had dropped 12.62, though by day's end it was down just 1.48 to 2,928.22. Many economists were awaiting the government's data on consumer prices for May, due out Friday, for a better picture of the nation's inflation situation. Consumer prices, up at an annual rate of 6.8 percent for the first four months of 1990, have been rising at a steeper pace than wholesale costs. Producer prices reflect only the cost of goods while consumer prices are heavily influenced by the cost of services. For the first five months of the year, overall inflation at the wholesale level was running at a 4.0 percent annual rate, down from 4.8 percent for all of 1989, the government said. Over the past 12 months, wholesale prices have risen a modest 3.1 percent. ``This report shows that we are neither veering into recession or are we in a situation where inflation is accelerating rapidly,'' said Ron Schreibman of the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors. In May, energy prices dropped 1 percent after having fallen by even larger amounts the previous three months. Gasoline prices were down 2.1 percent and fuel oil fell 6.2 percent. Natural gas increased 0.9 percent. Food costs overall were up 0.6 percent after having declined by that amount the previous two months. The price of fruit dropped 8.4 percent, vegetables fell 3.9 percent and eggs were down 21.8 percent. But that wasn't enough to offset increases in the price of other foods, such as the 7.7 percent hike in the cost of pasta, 4.9 percent increase in pork and 8.8 percent rise in the cost of fish. Excluding the volatile food and energy sectors, prices rose a mild 0.2 percent, the identical increase of a month before. Economists often consider this ``core'' number a better indicator of underlying inflationary pressures on the economy. Automobile prices rose 0.3 percent in May after falling the previous two months. Women's and children's clothing costs were up while the price of men's clothing fell slightly. The price of tobacco was up 3 percent while the cost of household flatware, appliances and home electronic equipment fell. The various changes put the index for all finished goods at 117.7 in May. That means a hypothetical selection of goods that cost $100 in 1982 cost $117.70 last month, up from $114.20 a year earlier. Price pressures in earlier stages of the production process were down in May. Intermediate goods and crude goods both fell 0.1 percent. An example of the three processing stages is bread as finished goods, flour as the intermediate stage and wheat at the crude level. The Labor Department revised the data for the first two months of 1990, saying wholesale prices rose 1.9 percent in January rather than the previously reported 1.8 percent. February prices fell 0.1 percent rather than holding steady. Wholesale prices also fell slightly in March and April.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market was down slightly in quiet trading Thursday, reflecting concern about corporate earnings and reports on the state of the economy. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which slipped 3.72 points Wednesday, lost another 1.48 to close at 2,928.22. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 7 to 5 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 560 up, 917 down and 500 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board totaled 135.77 million shares, down from 158.91 million in the previous session. The market started slowly with release of a government report showing the producer price index rose 0.3 percent in May. Traders said the figure was disappointing but not unexpected, and provided little encouragement that the Federal Reserve might move soon to relax interest rates. Stocks also fell after reports of lower earnings for two technology companies, Digital Equipment Corp. and United Telecommunications Inc. Digital said external forecasts of the company's fourth-quarter earnings were too optimistic because of softness in the company's domestic and international markets. Michael Metz, a managing director at Oppenheimer & Co., said the news triggered a round of futures-related computerized program selling which brought down technology stocks. Digital closed down 1} to 86]. United Telecom, the most heavily traded stock on the NYSE, fell 3\ to 40~ after analysts cut their earnings estimates for the second quarter and the year. But the market remained relatively quiet, as some traders waited for more economic data on Friday, including the May consumer price index and April trade deficit figures. Some brokers were nervous about Friday's ``triple witching hour,'' an event that happens four times a year on Wall Street, when quarterly contracts to buy or sell futures and options tied to stock indexes expire. It has been known to create sharp, unpredictable price gyrations in stocks and can trigger heavy trading toward the close. ``There's a lot of concern for tomorrow with the triple expirations,'' said George H. Boyd III, manager of equity research at Kidder, Peabody & Co. ``It makes today a difficult day to say whatever's happening is part of a trend. It's probably pretty difficult to say this week is significant of a trend.'' The Dow Jones industrial average has seesawed since peaking at 2,935.19 last Monday. It fell 72.81 points in the next four days and then surged a cumulative 71.04 points Monday and Tuesday. Banking and other financial issues were generally down Thursday. Federal National Mortgage fell ~ to 42{; Citicorp dropped { to 23[; Chase Manhattan slipped | to 24|; and BankAmerica slid ~ to 31[. Precious metals stocks also fell, with Newmont Gold down 1{ to 36|. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 161.10 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $16.66 billion, or 0.48 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 1.02 to 197.98. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 1.65 to 424.51, and S&P's 500-stock composite index fell 2.00 at 362.90. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market fell 1.76 to 467.10. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 364.30, down .74. Due to an NYSE closing price error on Wednesday for Chevron, the closing average for the Dow Jones 30 industrials on Wednesday was 2,929.70, rather than 2929.95, as reported earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Boeing Will Lose Money Again This Year On Defense Business, Chairman Says
DOC.TEXT: Boeing Co., whose commercial airplane orders helped it report an 87 percent jump in its first-quarter profit, will lose money this year on its military business, the company's chairman said. On the heels of a 1989 deficit of $559 million for its military business, the outlook is dim. ``I won't speculate on which of our military programs will ultimately be canceled or scaled back, but a number of them are clearly vulnerable,'' Frank Shrontz, Boeing's chairman and chief executive officer, told an investment conference Tuesday. Nonetheless, Boeing remains committed to the defense and space business, Shrontz said. The Seattle-based company hopes to be able to continue to pull in about $5 billion in defense sales annually. On the commercial side, Shrontz projected that Boeing's share of $600 billion worth of world airplane sales over the next 15 years will keep the company's production lines busy. Boeing has a commercial-order backlog approaching $100 billion. Boeing earned $302 million, or $1.31 a share, on sales of $6.4 billion for the first three months of 1990, compared with a profit of $161 million, or 70 cents a share, on sales of $4 billion in the first quarter of 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Forecast: Ad Spending Should Improve Next Year
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf pvs, Robert J. Coen... to CORRECT to $130.4 billion sted million. SUBS 14th graf pvs, While double-digit... to CORRECT to roughly $38 billion sted million.
DOC.TEXT: Domestic advertising spending is expected to rise 7.5 percent to $140 billion in 1991 following this year's disappointing results, which will be hampered by weak local ad budgets, a prominent forecaster said Thursday. Robert J. Coen, who heads the forecasting unit at the advertising agency McCann-Erickson, reduced his earlier projections for this year to a 5.3 percent gain, or a total of $130.4 billion, from the 6.2 percent gain he estimated in December. In a semi-annual report on ad spending, Coen said ``the economic indicators have not been very good since the fall of 1989, and they are the cause of most of the slowdown in ad spending.'' He blamed sluggish retail spending and poor retailer profits for depressing the local advertising market this year. Local ad revenues are expected to increase just 4.7 percent this year _ to $57.54 billion _ instead of the 6.2 percent gain he forecast six months ago. Local advertising is concentrated heavily in newspapers and local television stations, both of which had poor ad sales in the first quarter of the year. In newspapers, total ad revenue was off 1.3 percent in the first quarter. A 2.7 percent gain in retail advertising was unable to offset a 6.4 percent decline in classified ad spending. At local television stations, ad spending by local car dealers slumped 21 percent in the first quarter, while bank and department store ad expenditures fell by 14 percent and 13 percent, respectively. Coen noted in the report, however, that the advertising budgets of many major brands have risen significantly on a national level this year. He predicts a 6.3 percent gain in national ad spending, to $73.85 billion this year, in line the projections he issued in December. Syndicated television ad revenues were up a sharp 31 percent during the first four months of the year, while national ads on cable television stations were up 17 percent in the period. The three major television networks had an average 11 percent gain in national ad spending through April when compared with the year-ago period. During the first quarter, spending on advertising food products on network TV jumped 18 percent, toiletries ads rose 15 percent and drugs and personal care products were up 14 percent. Fewer ads for cigarettes and cars kept magazine advertising revenue up only 1 percent. Revenue from national ads in newspapers was up 5.4 percent in the first quarter. For the remainder of the year, Coen predicted, national marketing budgets will continue outpacing local advertising budgets. But in a sluggish economy, it will be ``a tough ad sales year for many media,'' his report said. If Coen's 7.5 percent growth estimate for 1991 is accurate, it would mark the largest gain since 1988, when domestic ad spending was up 7.7 percent over the previous year. While double-digit gains in ad spending have been reported overseas as recently as 1988, domestic ad spending has not improved by double-digit margins since 1984, when a 15.8 percent increase was reported. Still, Coen's projection marks a roughly $38 billion increase in ad spending since 1986, the first year domestic ad spending rose above the $100 billion mark. The outlook for advertising growth overseas this year is expected to rise 5 percent over 1989 levels to $133.8 billion, when taking into account a stronger dollar. Total worldwide ad expenditures are expected to reach $264.2 billion this year, up 5.1 percent from last year. Though worldwide ad growth averaged just 5 percent last year, off from three years of double-digit growth, Coen predicted worldwide spending will ``begin to pick up steam in 1991, fueled by the expansion in free market economies and growing competition in consumer markets.''

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Selling Presses Gold Below $350; Silver Hits 12-Year Low
DOC.TEXT: A new round of Saudi Arabian selling pressed gold futures prices below $350 an ounce Thursday for the first time in nearly four years and triggered a sympathetic sell-off in the silver market, where prices plunged to 12{-year lows. Steep losses also were posted in futures prices for many other commodities including soybeans, hogs, pork bellies, coffee, sugar and cocoa. Near-term crude oil futures likewise fell but other energy futures as a whole were mixed. In the second straight day of heavy selling pressure on New York's Commodity Exchange, gold futurs settled $5.20 to $6.10 lower with the contract for delivery in June at $346.80 a troy ounce, the lowest daily finish for a Comex gold contract since July 14, 1986. Silver futures ended 14.5 cents to 17.1 cents lower with June at $4.77 a troy ounce, the lowest close since Dec. 27, 1977. For the fourth time in the past three months, the gold market's plunge was precipitated by large sales of gold bullion in London by Saudi interests, analysts said. The $40-an-ounce drop in gold prices that began with the first bout of Saudi selling on March 26 has quashed investor interest in precious metals, said William O'Neill of Merrill Lynch Futures. ``Gold is a market that greatly deals in psychology,'' O'Neill said. ``The market psychology is so negative right now that it would take something of a very significant nature to change the scenario.'' O'Neill said the possibility of further heavy bullion sales by the Saudis or by gold-producing countries such as South Africa and the Soviet Union, which have also been large sellers lately, make a drop to $325 an ounce a not-unlikely prospect. ``There's no reason to assume it's over,'' added analyst Bette Raptopoulos of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. In other commodities, soybean futures fell sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade, mimicking the previous day's action in the corn market amid forecasts for a month of ideal growing conditions in the Midwest. Grain futures also closed lower across the board. Bearish chart signals also figured in the decline, as did Wednesday's steep drop in corn futures prices, said Anne Frick, senior oil seed analyst for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ``I think beans are very cognizant of movement in corn,'' she said. Wheat futures settled 1{ cents to 2 cents lower with July at $3.32} a bushel; corn was 1{ cents to 3\ cents lower with July at $2.87 a bushel; oats were 2} cents to 5 cents lower with July at $1.41 a bushel; soybeans were 13{ cents to 15\ cents lower with July at $5.91\ a bushel. Near-term hog and pork-belly futures plummeted their respective daily limits of 1.5 cents and 2 cents a pound on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, pressured by sluggish demand for pork products and weak technical signals. The selling interest spilled over into the adjacent cattle pits, where prices finished moderately lower. Live cattle futures settled .10 cent to .50 cent lower with June at 76.67 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .25 cent lower with August at 84.72 cents a pound; live hogs were .80 cent to 1.5 cents lower with June at 62.67 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.3 cents to 2 cents lower with July at 68.45 cents a pound. Prices also tumbled on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange, on a combination of technical sell signals, signs of greater-than-expected supplies and selling to raise money for margin calls on other markets, analysts said. Coffee futures plunged 3.35 cents to 4.7 cents with July settling at 87.10 cents a pound; sugar finished .50 cent to .67 cent lower with July at 12.25 cents a pound; cocoa was $27 to $31 lower with July at $1,191 per ton. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled .45 cent lower to .17 cent higher with July at $17.13 a barrel; heating oil was .07 cent to .60 cent lower with July at 48.50 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .45 cent lower to 1.27 cents higher with July at 60.12 cents a gallon.

DOC.HEAD: S&P Lowers Chrysler, Ford Credit Ratings
DOC.TEXT: Standard & Poor's Ratings Group on Thursday downgraded its credit ranking for Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp., signaling sagging faith in the auto industry's finances. Another major Wall Street credit rating company, Moody's Investor Services Inc., said it would decide by the end of the month whether it would change Chrysler's rating. The ratings reflect how Wall Street views the credit worthiness of companies and their subsidiaries. Lower ratings generally mean companies must pay higher interest to borrow in the credit markets. S&P dropped Ford one notch to ``double-A-minus,'' from ``double-A,'' considered a high level of investment grade securities. Chrysler fell to S&P's lowest investment-grade level of ``triple-B-minus'' from ``triple-B.'' S&P Vice President Scott Sprinzen and Moody's credit rating Chairman Harold Goldberg stated separately that Chrysler's main profit-makers, its minivans and Jeeps, were coming under direct attack by competitors. ``The company (Chrysler) will require substantial spending in the next several years to position themselves in a broader array of products and to be a more effective competitor,'' Goldberg said Thursday. S&P also said Ford is boosting new product spending, which will delay debt reduction in connection with its recent acquisitions of The Associates Corp. consumer finance concern and Jaguar PLC, the British luxury automaker. The two acquisitions cost Ford nearly $6 billion. Ford reported first-quarter earnings of $506.2 million, down 70 percent from a year ago. Ford spokesman Tom Foote said the company was disappointed with the S&P decision, saying the company's balance sheet is strong ``and we expect our investments to lead to further strengthening of our financial situation.'' Chrysler spokesman Tom Houston said S&P's action was unwarranted. ``Moreover, Chrysler also notes that just recently the market readily accepted the landmark offering of $1.1 billion, 30-year Auburn Hills Trust certificates, thereby expressing high confidence in the company over a very long term,'' Houston said. In April, Chrysler announced that it would sell its yet-to-be-completed technical center in Auburn Hills, north of Detroit, through 30-year certificates and then lease it back. The deal was expected to raise nearly $800 million. Chrysler shares fell 25 cents to $15.62{, Ford was unchanged at $46.37| and General Motors Corp. was down 37{ cents at $49.62{ in Thursday trading on the New York Stock Exchange. S&P said GM also was coming under competitive pressure. But the giant automaker was better suited than Ford and Chrysler to withstand it and a reassessment of its credit quality was not warranted, Sprinzen said. On Wednesday, Chrysler called Moody's review announcement inappropriate and unwarranted. ``Chrysler believes that its first-quarter profitability was impressive given the massive reduction in dealer inventories and points out that the company's $1.5-billion ongoing cost-cutting program contributed substantially to those results,'' Chrysler stated Wednesday. Chrysler reported $71 million in profit during the first quarter, down 80 percent from a year ago, but better than what many analysts had expected. The earnings came despite huge incentive costs in January, when the company offered a $1,000 rebate on its popular minivans. The Big Three offered larger incentive packages and temporarily shut down factories in January to shrink new-car inventories. The strategy worked and since the first of the year, the companies have been trimming incentives. New minivans and sport-utility vehicles that other automakers are beginning to sell are pointed directly at Chrysler's popular minivans and Jeeps. Chrysler said Wednesday it had sold 752,935 North American-made cars and trucks through June 10 this year, down 13 percent from last year. The company's share of the U.S. car market was 11.4 percent, down from 13.1 percent a year ago, and its portion of the truck market dropped to 21.8 percent this year from 23.2 percent last year. Moody's also is concerned about the recent drain of top executives from Chrysler, Goldberg said. In the past six weeks, Gerald Greenwald quit as vice chairman to head a $4.54-billion union bid to buy United Airlines and Michael Hammes left as vice president for international operations to run Black & Decker Corp.'s huge toolmaking operations. Chrysler Motors Chairman Bennett Bidwell said he will retire by 1991 and Treasurer Frederick Zuckerman has said he will leave this summer.

DOC.HEAD: Contel Offering Early Retirement to 900
DOC.TEXT: Contel Corp. said Thursday it is offering early retirement to about 900 employees as part of a previously announced cost-cutting program. The telecommunications company said it was launching the retirement program to avoid layoffs while reducing the workforce. Under the plan, a retirement ``window'' will be created in July, during which retiring employees will receive three years toward their ages and three years toward their service dates in determining individual benefits. The program will be offered to employees 52 and older who have at least seven years of service with the company as of Dec. 30, and are in job classifications and locations that may be affected by the restructuring of the Telephone Operations Sector. Contel said in April it was starting a two-year restructuring to make the sector more efficient, market-focused and responsive to consumers. The restructuring is expected to reduce the workforce by 4 percent and result in up to $25 million in pre-tax costs.

DOC.HEAD: EFTA Ready For Negotiations With The European Community, Leader Says
DOC.TEXT: Foreign trade ministers of the six West European nations comprising the European Free Trade Association put final touches Wednesday on a joint platform that could provide the base for close cooperation with the European Community. ``We are ready to proceed with formal negotiations (with the EC) without delay,'' said the European Free Trade Association's current chairman, the Swedish Minister of Foreign Trade, Anita Gradin. The ministers of EFTA also signed a declaration of cooperation with government representatives of Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Poland. The declaration aims at improving the conditions for free trade between the three countries and the EFTA nations: Austria, Finland, Iceland, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland. Steps include reducing technical barriers to free trade and promotion of trade via seminars and exhibitions. ``Free trade requires market economies, convertible currencies, political pluralism ... it will take time,'' said Hansjorg Reng, an EFTA official. He said Israel, Turkey, the Gulf states and other Eastern European countries had shown interest in similar cooperation declarations with EFTA. The EFTA delegates are seeking ways to make their nations part of a united Europe without compromising their sovereignty. Gradin told reporters the EFTA nations are ``in no doubt in a position to speak with one voice'' after the talks in Goteborg. She said delegates had trimmed a list of ``fundamental interests'' in which EFTA members want to be exempted from EC regulations to a dozen. They include areas where EFTA standards are higher, such as in health, safety and environmental matters, she said. ``We are not prepared to lower our standards ... but I am sure we can find solutions,'' she said. The formula for the envisioned close cooperation between the EC and EFTA is called the European Economic Space. As envisioned, agreement on the plan would lead to a free flow of goods, labor, services and capital among 350 million people in 18 west European countries. The EC has 12 member states.

DOC.HEAD: Cholesterol-Free Milk to Hit The Market Monday
DOC.TEXT: A Georgia dairy on Thursday introduced a cholesterol-free milk product that uses vegetable fat in place of animal fat. Officials at Mathis Dairy touted the new drink as safe for the millions of people who can't drink milk because of medically restricted diets. The drink, which is not technically milk because it contains no milkfat, is targeted at a limited market and will cost about 30 cents more per half-gallon than regular milk, dairy officials said. It is the latest bid by the dairy industry to make its products more appealing to health-conscious consumers. ``We're excited as to what this could mean to the dairy industry as a whole,'' said Jack Mathis, dairy vice president. The product, to go on sale around Atlanta Monday, will be introduced elsewhere depending on its success. Mathis said he expected other dairies, some of which already have low-cholesterol milks on the market, to develop similar products. Mathis said the new product, called Mathis@Sun-up, is a joint venture with Sun Up Farms Inc., a smaller Atlanta dairy that developed the drink. It has been served to 8,000 people in taste tests over the last six months with overwhelmingly positive results, he said. Joe DiBruno of Sun Up Farms said the technology for making a cholesterol-free milk has existed for years. But he said his is the first one that avoids the watery taste common to skim milks, which contain a tiny amount of fat and cholesterol. Though Mathis@Sun-up is believed to be the first cholesterol-free milk to hit the market, researchers in Peoria, Ill., reported last year they had developed a concentrated milk that is low in fat and free of cholesterol and also uses vegetable oils. DiBruno said the new product is made in a manner similar to standard lowfat milks. Whole milk, which contains 3.5 percent milkfat, is funneled through a clarifier, which removes the fat. But instead of the normal practice of putting back measured amounts of milkfat, a soybean-based vegetable fat is mixed in. The resulting drink, which contains 2 percent vegetable fat, has a texture and taste similar to regular 2 percent lowfat milk. It has 120 calories per serving, same as 2 percent lowfat milk, and has a similar vitamin content, DiBruno said. Americans consume about 6.2 billion gallons of milk a year, although sales of whole milk have declined sharply since 1971, according to the Agriculture Department.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Insists That Japan Honor Trade Commitments
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 9th graf pvs, `However, two ...,' with 3 new grafs to UPDATE with Mosbacher comments; picks up 10th graf pvs, ``It would ...''. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration, worried about a lack of progress in trade talks with Japan, insisted Thursday that the Japanese honor commitments to open markets to American and other foreign goods. U.S. negotiators have grown concerned over what they perceive as Japanese foot-dragging in the talks, aimed at reducing the United States' $49 billion trade deficit with Japan. Critics have said Japan's intransigence is directly linked to a decision by the Bush administration to remove Japan from under a tough section of trade law known as Super 301, which carries the threat of economic sanctions. Recent negotiations in Hawaii produced little progress in writing the text of a final report on negotiations aimed at altering the economies of both countries as a way of attacking the underlying reasons for the huge trade imbalance. Japan and the United States signed an interim agreement on the talks, known as the Structural Impediments Initiative, in April and face a deadline of early July for producing a final report. However, in several key areas, the Japanese are refusing to make commitments sought by U.S. negotiators. ``As we go from the interim report to the final report, we want to keep the pressure on to make sure that all the commitments make it through into that final report,'' White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater told reporters. Fitzwater downplayed reports that administration officials believed the Japanese side was stonewalling now that the threat of economic sanctions under Super 301 was no longer present. But Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher refused to dismiss the possibility that Japan was using a stonewalling technique in the current negotiations. ``I hope for all our sakes they are just testing us to see if we have lost any of our resolve,'' Mosbacher said when asked about the talks during a congressional hearing. ``They did take some very good first steps but they have got a lot farther to go, as we do.'' Two other senior administration officials, briefing reporters on condition that their names not be used, expressed clear disappointment Thursday with the lack of progress. ``It would be highly regrettable that if, at this stage, this process lost momentum and reversed itself,'' one official said. He said he believed there had been a reduced level of involvement by senior Japanese officials in the process. The U.S.-Japan trade talks were stalemated earlier this year before a hastily arranged summit meeting between Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu and President Bush got the negotiations back on track. Secretary of State James A. Baker III is scheduled to meet Japanese Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama in San Francisco on Friday and the administration is hoping those discussions will break the current stalemate. Japanese officials have insisted that they have gone as far as they can go with the commitments made in the April report, while the U.S. is characterizing the April report as only a ``way station,'' with much more concrete language needed to carry out the vague promises. The next round of talks on structural barriers is scheduled for June 25-26 in Tokyo, with the final report due before the economic summit meeting in Houston on July 9. If not cleared up beforehand, a trade fight between the United States and Japan would cast a pall over the annual economic summit of the world's seven richest industrial countries. In the April report, Japan promised to open its retailing system, boost spending on public works projects, strengthen antitrust legislation and loosen restrictions on foreign investment, all in an effort to expand opportunities for foreign companies to do business in Japan. The United States pledged to cut the federal budget deficit and take measures to increase savings and investment, all proposals economists agree are needed to reduce Americans' appetite for foreign goods. The new Japanese negotiating stance has not gone unnoticed in Congress, where lawmakers were upset by the administration's refusal to rename Japan to a Super 301 ``hit list'' as a way of keeping pressure on the Japanese to open their markets. Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., warned the administration this week that Congress ``may have no choice'' but to respond with retaliatory legislation of its own if Japan is not more forthcoming.

DOC.HEAD: UAW-Big Three Talks Open 3rd Week of July
DOC.TEXT: The United Auto Workers and the nation's Big Three automakers will begin contract negotiations in the third week of July for about 500,000 workers, the union said Wednesday. Company spokesmen who declined to be identified said tentative dates for the beginning of talks were July 18 at General Motors Corp., July 19 at Ford Motor Co. and July 20 at Chrysler Corp. A UAW spokesman, who also refused to be identified, confirmed those dates. Contracts between the union and each of the Big Three expire Sept. 14, the first time in 11 years the three contracts have had common expiration dates. In Canada, talks between the three companies and the Canadian Auto Workers union are expected to get under way the following week. Those agreements also expire Sept. 14. The UAW has set job security as its top priority in the negotiations. Other issues include wages, pension improvements, health care and more responsive management. The opening of talks is largely ceremonial, with dozens of people packed into the main negotiating room at each of the U.S. automakers' headquarters. UAW President Owen Bieber and chief negotiators for the companies shake hands across a huge table. Much of the bargaining takes place in subcommittees that focus on specific areas of the contracts. Economic matters usually are among the last negotiated. An hourly worker on an assembly line now makes about $15.75 an hour. Traditionally, as the deadline draws near, the UAW selects a ``target'' company on which to focus efforts and suspends talks at the other two. Terms of an agreement at the target company, called a pattern contract, then are modified slightly and brought to the other two. This year, Chrysler labor Vice President Anthony St. John has hinted that the financially struggling company may break from the pattern.

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Up In Latest Period
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT M2 figures.
DOC.TEXT: The two broadest measures of the nation's money supply rose in the week ended June 4, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 rose to a seasonally adjusted $3,263.9 billion from a revised $3,259.4 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, rose to a seasonally adjusted $4,057.3 billion from a revised $4,050.5 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, rose to a seasonally adjusted $808.2 billion from a revised $803.9 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The annual growth rate in M2 so far this year is 4.1 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The annual growth rate in M3 was 1.5 percent, which is below the Fed's target range of 2.5 percent to 6.5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,268.1 billion, a 3.9 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,062.0 billion, up 1.2 percent, while M1 rose 4.1 percent to an average of $805.8 billion. In other reports: _The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $1.021 billion a day in the week ended Wednesday, up from $442 million the previous week. _The Federal Reserve said net borrowed reserves averaged $384 million in the two weeks ended June 13, compared with free reserves of $390 million in the previous two-week period. _The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $306.4 billion in the two-week period ended June 13, up from $304.9 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Passes Leave Bill in face of Veto ThreatPvocates the same policies
DOC.TEXT: as president as he did on the campaign trail when he sought the presidency in 1988,'' said Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. ``There simply are not the votes available to us to frustrate passage,'' said an opponent, Sen. Thad Cochran, R-Miss. ``We concede the Senate's will is to pass this bill.'' Business groups opposed the bill, and their lobbyists said some senators who opposed it wanted to avoid a recorded vote and were acting in hopes that Bush would veto it and that the House would sustain that veto before the Senate had to vote. If it turns out that way, senators would not have to go on the record on the issue. A vote in either House to sustain a veto kills the bill. The Constitution requires votes on overriding vetoes to be by roll call. The bill requires business and government employers to provide workers with up to 12 weeks of unpaid medical leave or leave for the care of a new child or an ill child, parent or spouse. It exempts businesses with fewer than 50 workers, and workers who are the highest-paid 10 percent within a company. Employers would have to continue health insurance benefits for those on leave and restore returning employees to their previous jobs or equivalent positions. ``Thanks to the leaders, both the majority and minority leaders, a decision was made not to contest the matter and to pass the bill,'' said its sponsor, Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn. ``I've learned long ago you don't argue about a victory when you get one. I'm also also convinced that had it come to a (recorded) vote we would have prevailed.'' Dodd argued in brief debate a day earlier that the job-protected leave was a minimum guarantee any worker should receive. ``The bottom line is this: American parents ought to be able to have jobs and their families as well,'' Dodd said. ``Parents ought to be able to deal with a rare family crisis without losing those jobs.'' Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, opposed the bill, saying he favored leave for workers but opposed a federal requirement that employers offer it. ``I don't want to see anybody fired because they have a baby, or an adoption ... or a serious illness in the family,'' Hatch said. ``I think we could come up with a way to give business incentives to do this, but I don't think we should force them.'' Business association representatives met with White House chief of staff John Sununu May 7 and said he promised them Bush would veto the bill. In the House, opponents argued in long debate that the bill would be costly, a bad precedent and burdensome for businesses, ultimately hurting American competitiveness. Supporters said nearly all industrialized nations already provide such minimum job security to workers, however, and many have provisions for full or partial pay. The bill's sponsors said it would cost virtually nothing for employers, while opponents charged it would carry additional costs for training, temporary employees and overtime. The bill would cover federal employees, with even more generous leave provisions. It would cover House employees but not employees of the Senate.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-NYSE Trading Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are brief details about the New York Stock Exchange's plan for after-hours stock trading and an explanation of the current system. The exchange has been presenting the ideas to Wall Street brokerage firms recently. Exchange Chairman John J. Phelan Jr. on Thursday confirmed plans for a five-step program to phase in after-hours trading, perhaps leading to 24-hour trading by the year 2000.
DOC.HEAD: CURRENT SYSTEM
DOC.TEXT: The NYSE is open from 9:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. Eastern time. Stocks of U.S. and foreign companies comprise the 1,700 listed on the exchange. Trades are entered either manually or electronically on the exchange floor. Specialists on the floor ``make markets'' for individual stocks by matching buyers with sellers and generate action in less heavily traded stocks. Brokers who take orders at banks of yellow telephones on the floor often trade with other brokers at a stock's post; in those cases specialists serve as traffic cops, making sure the trade is properly recorded. If there is no buyer or seller, the specialist records the order and awaits a corresponding transaction. Or, the specialist will step in and complete the trade in order to keep the market active.
DOC.HEAD: AFTER-THE-CLOSE TRADING
DOC.TEXT: In the first stage, the NYSE would hold two 15- to 45-minute sessions after the market closes in an attempt to recapture some trading currently lost to the London Stock Exchange. That activity mainly involves program trading and other techniques typically not used by small investors. One session would allow traders to trade stocks at the day's closing prices and the other would let them disclose their own trades. Both practices could help program traders complete transactions. Such trades now often are completed in London or via independent electronic trading services.
DOC.HEAD: NIGHT TRADING
DOC.TEXT: Sometime in 1991, the NYSE would begin holding auctions of each listed stock at 8 p.m., midnight, and 5 a.m. Eastern time. The stocks would trade once at each auction, with trades combined at one agreed-upon price for each issue traded. Brokers could enter electronic orders for stocks at their offices in the evening in New York, as the trading day begins in Tokyo. They would be able to see what other orders had been placed and alter their own. At 8 p.m., the exchange would pair off as many orders as possible in one huge trade that could involve millions of shares and hundreds of buyers and sellers. The process would be repeated at midnight and 5 a.m., when the London market opens.
DOC.HEAD: LATER STAGES
DOC.TEXT: The plan calls for moving at some stage to a form of conventional trading overnight, leading finally to round-the-clock trading. Exchange officials didn't give details about the later stages, although Phelan said 24-hour trading could be in place by the year 2000.
